fields.headline: Supreme court orders recount
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A divided Florida supreme court on Friday ordered the immediate manual recount of ballots, keeping  Vice-President Al Gore's presidential hopes alive.
fields.body:
A divided Florida supreme court on Friday ordered the immediate manual recount of ballots, keeping Vice-President Al Gore's presidential hopes alive.

The Florida supreme court ordered manual recounts to begin in Florida's contested presidential election on Friday.

"Because time is of the essence, the recount will commence immediately," said the court's spokesman, Craig Waters.

The opinion overturned a ruling by Circuit Judge N Sanders Sauls, who had refused to order a recount.

"Because time is of the essence, the recount shall commence immediately," the supreme court said.

It ordered a far broader recount than Mr Gore had sought, however, saying that so-called undervotes - meaning ballots on which there was no vote for president - must be recounted in all 67 Florida counties.

It was not clear whether Mr Bush would appeal the ruling.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Dan
fields.trailText: As a different way of discovering new places once you have landed, how about taking a local map and writing your name on it in big letters. Then, try to trace that path on foot and see what you come across!
fields.body:
Sam, Just been reading the book 45 by Bill Drummond. There are a few interesting ideas in there. Firstly, try taking a stone from the place that you are in and dropping it off in the next place that you land. Then, pick up another and take it to the next place. What you will end up with is a stone that will have the ancestry of all the others that have travelled around the world with you. (I guess you didn't bring one from England with you, so you might have to sacrifice something else to validate the whole thing). Also, as a different way of discovering new places once you have landed, how about taking a local map and writing your name on it in big letters. Then, try to trace that path on foot and see what you come across!

Take care and have a really great time,

Dan

fields.headline: 255 charities investigated by commissioners
fields.trailText: The Charity Commission carried out 255 investigations into malpractice, fraud and other abuses against charities last year, its annual report reveals.
fields.body:
The Charity Commission carried out 255 investigations into malpractice, fraud and other abuses against charities last year, its annual report reveals.

The charities watchdog says its inquiry work resulted in the protection or repayment of over £25m of charitable money placed at risk of embezzlement, or misuse.

Cases include:
 A commission inquiry found that the ex-master of the Sherbourne House residential home charity had spent charitable funds on cars for personal use and a pension fund for his wife. A court later ordered repayment of over £200,000 to the charity.
 A bogus lawyer was sentenced to 30 months imprisonment after a commission investigation into the Public Law Centre legal advice charity revealed that he had set up a fictitious board of trustees and was appealing for funds to grant naming organisations in the charity's name.
 An army regiment which mistakenly used money from its own charitable welfare funds to purchase a residential training centre was ordered to repay £160,000 to the charity.

The investigations resulted from 1,312 "evaluations" in which the commission assessed allegations of abuse or maladministration against charities.

Charities in England and Wales had combined income of over £24bn in the year to March 2000, the report reveals.

In the 12 months to March 2000, the commission received more than 8,000 applications for registrations from new charities - of which 5,000 were accepted.

Some 10,000 charities were removed from the register, many of them having fallen into disuse.

The Charity Commission is tasked by the government with protecting public confidence in charities. It registers, monitors and supports charities and has powers to investigate wrongdoing.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Christoph
fields.trailText: In Washington, I can tell you that Georgetown is rocking at night, so for anything from dinner to dancing (via drinking), it's the place to be.
fields.body:
Hi Sam! Just read that you're going to DC... so I thought I'd fill you in on some of my (very basic) memories... Washington is great, because you can walk to a lot of the downtown sights if you're not too tired. (Walk the Mall - From Lincoln Memorial to Congress Hill... long but really interesting) If you don't want to see too many museums, just go to the National Air and Space Museum, even if you just have the slightest interest in that kind of stuff. They have all the great rockets - even a couple of Russian ones - old planes (make you wonder how on earth someone dared to fly them) and it's not too big, so it makes a nice visit. Also, make sure to go up the Washington Monument... the view is brilliant on a clear day. I don't know about the White House... I didn't think the tour was that great, kind of boring and not much to see.

And even though I was a kid back in the day (17 in 1995), I can tell you that Georgetown is rocking at night, so for anything from dinner to dancing (via drinking), it's the place to be.

Alright, I hope this is some help, and have fun exploring Washington!
Christoph

webTitle: Longing for the end of the presidential saga

fields.headline: Longing for the end of the presidential saga
fields.standfirst: America's pundits are showing signs of election strain, as Derek Brown discovers
fields.trailText: America's pundits are showing signs of election strain, as Derek Brown discovers.
fields.body:
It is a golden mini-era for commentators and pundits. Every political nook and cranny has been explored, every angle covered. For more than a month, they have churned out their daily quota of opinion larded with the occasional fact.

Now, some of them have clearly had enough. Will Durst of the San Francisco Examiner, for example, has an acid, witty, sidelong look at the process.

Al Gore, he concedes, cannot be blamed for refusing to concede: "This isn't a contest for junior high school hall monitor, this is for president of the United States of America. Leader of the free world.

"We're talking king of the planet here. Power. Domination. Babes. Think Leonardo DiCaprio with a nuclear football. Besides, it doesn't really matter who wins, they won't be able to govern.

"No mandate to speak of. Deadlocked senate. 'I don't have to listen to you. You're not the REAL president. You are not the boss of me'.

"Less effectual than a compass in an electro magnetic power plant."

In the Washington Post, columnist EJ Dionne indignantly examines the double standards of the Republicans:

"As I write, we await decisions from the Florida supreme court and the two absentee ballot cases. If the courts go against Gore, the pressure on him to quit will be enormous.

"As for Bush, he's above the courts, above the vote counts, above inconvenient questions about whether he really won the election.

"If the courts rule against Bush, he'll just keep going until January. Will anyone say a word? Heads Bush wins, tails Gore loses."

Coming at it from the other side of the argument, Linda Chavez chucks a column of vitriol over the vice president in the Chicago Tribune.

"No one will ever convince Al Gore that he lost the election. If he had his way, no doubt he would personally count every one of the 6m votes cast in Florida to satisfy himself that he won after all.

"He has already hinted that he or his allies will file suit under Florida's freedom of information laws to do so.

"Let him believe what he wishes. If he insists on deluding himself that he won, it will only make him an increasingly bitter and unhappy man.

"But the country should be allowed to move forward without the Gore legal team trying to block the way."

The leader writer of the Miami Herald comes up with a vivid analogy.

"Like expectant parents, we must pace the waiting room knowing that nothing more can be added to the debate."

The column goes on to undermine that opening premise, by arguing that, whatever the ruling of the state supreme court, there should be further action against the Republican activists who blatantly meddled with thousands of applications for postal votes.

The Dallas Morning News points out the increasingly serious implications of the court cases for a smooth transition of power next month.

It highlights the complex system of congressional approval for the new presidential cabinet members, and chides the Clinton administration for not doing more to help the rival candidates form their putative administrations.

"It would be foolhardy to predict the rulings in the various courts considering interrelated issues this week, but all sides should be moving with dispatch.

"This litigation must end. Soon. In the meantime, the Clinton administration should do more to help with transition. Now."

The Boston Globe believes that, 30 days after the elections, both candidates should abide by the imminent decision of the Florida supreme court, and drop all other legal moves.

"The courts may never be able to provide a perfect outcome for what is so clearly an imperfect election. But they can confer a sense of fairness and propriety.

"Both candidates and all Americans should find a way to accept their verdict."

At the heart of the legal action in the Florida state capital, the Tallahassee Democrat offers an interesting sidebar on the political junkies following the intricate arguments.

Among them, it discovers a Briton in a bit of a pickle: "Peter Spiegel of the Financial Times of London shivered in his blazer as he stood near the front of the line as he had since 6am. 'My hands don't work any more,' said the reporter, who is based in Washington DC. 'I didn't bring any warm clothes. I flew down originally to West Palm Beach (in early November) and I haven't been home since'."

webTitle: Week 2: Bombay to Pushkar, via Udaipur

fields.headline: Heat, dust, chaos and Octopussy's garden
fields.standfirst: From the mad drivers of Ahmadabad to the calm of Gandhi's ashram and tea and cakes at Lake Palace. Indian contrasts in Sue's second weekly email
fields.trailText: 'Already, I have been on an Indian train, seen an elephant, eaten thali, drunk chai, taken one lot of Imodium, seen a Hindu wedding procession and been splashed by sacred cow wee when I did not jump out of the way quickly enough. (Is this a blessing?)' Sue reports from the north of India
fields.body:
Pushkar, India
Hello everyone
Now I am really here. What a difference a few days make. After a shaky start, I am now in traveller mode and loving every minute. Already, I have been on an Indian train, seen an elephant, eaten thali (delicious), drunk chai, taken one lot of Imodium, seen a Hindu wedding procession and been splashed by sacred cow wee when I did not jump out of the way quickly enough. (Is this a blessing?)

On Sunday I met my group of Imaginative Travellers for the three-week overland trip to Nepal. There are only four of us - me, Carol the tour leader, and Mike and Clare, a couple from New Zealand. We all seem to be getting on fine.

We left Bombay on Monday (I will try the places suggested by Jen and Steve when I return in January) and travelled into the non-tourist state of Gujarat to Ahmadabad. It was much pleasanter than Bombay, in that there were no beggars and the people were friendly and curious. However at the risk of seeming obsessed with Indian traffic, this was worse! Imagine all the foreign and student cyclists in Cambridge, multiply by several tens of thousands, add an equal number of scooters and motorised rickshaws, not forgetting the odd cow, cram them all into a square mile and tell them to go as fast as possible while continually sounding their horns, and you might come close to picturing it.

In contrast, Gandhi's ashram - where his movement began - was a moving place full of peace and calm. We moved on into Rajasthan to the beautiful city of Udaipur. It is a magical place full of temples and fountains surrounded by hills. Watching the sun set over the city from 2,468 feet up at the Monsoon palace was an early highlight. We had English tea and cakes in the Fateh Prak Palace overlooking the Lake Palace (roughing it again). This is where Octopussy was filmed and no visit is complete without eating in one of the restaurants while watching it on video.

Yesterday we arrived in Pushkar. If you have ever wondered where all the dreadlock folk go after Glastonbury, look no further. They are here drinking bhang lassi in little groups. Carol stongly advised us not to try it however much we had enjoyed our banana lassi at breakfast.

We did a two-hour climb up to a temple at the top of a hill. Having got our breath back, it was taken away again by the views of the town and its lake surrounded by desert and hills. Yet another unforgettable sunset.

It is good to do this bit in a small group. Bruce and I do venture out on our own, partly to give the Kiwis time without me tagging along and also to prepare for the next five months. I hope soon to get over the need to keep repacking my bag. Email places are plentiful but often very slow and unreliable, which is frustrating as it does not give me much time to reply to messages. But I love reading them and am jotting down places to eat and stay (Stuart and Lucie, I am going to Jaisalmer next week).

Rainy England seems an age and a world away. India has certainly begun to weave its spell. (Don't worry kids and boss - I will come back.)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Jen
fields.trailText: Directly across from the White House in Washington is the national Christmas tree in Elipse Park. It is gorgeous, and you must stop there and take a walk around. The national tree is surrounded by many smaller trees representing each US state and territory.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,
I heard that you may be making a stop in Washington DC. If this is not correct, please ignore. If you are coming, then read on. I have lived in DC for 5 years now and have some favourite sites that you may want to visit. First, to get a glimpse of the entire city, take a ride up the elevator in the Washington Monument and have a peep at our beautiful capital! The best time to go is late at night or early in the morning depending on whether you want a day view or night view. I believe that the White House is giving Christmas tours right now so maybe you could actually take a stroll inside the President's house. Get in line early, though, because tickets sell fast and only go on sale at the beginning of each day. Directly across from the White House is the national Christmas tree on the Elipse. It is gorgeous and you must stop there and take a walk around. The national tree is surrounded by many smaller trees representing each US state and territory. None of these activities cost anything! Best of luck in your travels, and I hope you enjoy Washington DC as much as I do!!!

webTitle: After the tear gas, down to business on the Riviera

fields.headline: After the tear gas, down to business on the Riviera
fields.standfirst:
Europe editor Ian Black reports on an EU summit which sees 15 leaders haggling over a complex deal

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
Europe editor Ian Black reports on an EU summit which sees 15 leaders haggling over a complex deal.
Special report: European integration
fields.body:
Security barriers manned by watchful gendarmes and heavily- armed CRS riot police are not the most welcoming aspect of the European Union summit in Nice, whose lovely pink and ochre stucco Italianate buildings can hardly be seen for convoys of speeding VIP limousines and press buses.

But such distractions are a routine part of the bi-yearly talkfests that are billed as deciding the future of a continent. That is truer of this summit than many others, since rather than just issue a set of bland conclusions on matters ranging from BSE to maritime safety, Jacques Chirac and his fellow leaders have to sign up to a new EU treaty - designed to make creaking institutions work when new members from eastern Europe start joining the club in the next few years.

On Thursday morning, as the summiteers flew in, it was Seattle on the Riviera for a couple of telegenic hours: tear gas swirled and stones rained down as the anti-globalisation crowd plus a band of ragtag Basque and Corsican separatists vented their wrath on "fascism-capitalism".

But all was quiet along the palm-fringed Promenade des Anglais yesterday as the 15 leaders got down to business inside the giant Acropolis conference centre, haggling over the complex deal that will allow them to leave declaring success, bleary-eyed but happy, in the early hours of Sunday morning.

No one knows, at this stage, exactly what that deal will be, but there was no shortage of rumours swirling around the press centre, as diplomats from the member states and the EU institutions in Brussels chatted to journalists, handing out texts, spinning merrily about the nuances of national positions and generally feeding the insatiable media beast.

Of the big items that need to be sorted, the hottest is still the crucial question of how to "re-weight" votes in the decision-making council of ministers. The unionÍs four big boys, Germany, France, Britain and Italy, currently have 10 each while at the other end of the scale tiny Luxembourg has two.

With up to 13 new members likely to join the EU in the coming years, that must change, not least because the bigs worry increasingly about being outvoted by the smalls. Spain, the Netherlands and Belgium all want to increase their voting power.

But, however you look at it, the problem always comes back to that odd couple, France and Germany, the historical axis around which the European Community was founded back in 1957. Parity worked fine then, but since reunification, 82m Germans have had the same number of votes as 59m French citizens.

So everyone in Nice is agog: will Chirac agree to give Gerhard Schröder even a symbolic edge? According to one view, the issue has become so complex that France no longer considers a small concession on votes a taboo - if that is the only way to get an overall agreement on streamlining the EUÍs workings to prepare for enlargement.

But others argue that it is politically impossible for the Gaullist president to do this. And anyway, Germany might be prepared to stick with parity in return for agreement on a new intergovernmental conference in 2004 to review future constitutional arrangements, vital for Berlin because of pressure from the provincial governments or Länder.

If the outcome turns out to be simpler reweighting, the large states would have 30 votes, with Germany getting a token one to three more to reflect its far larger population. If that happened, the broader spread would leave more room to differentiate between medium and smaller countries.

Germany had originally supported a so-called double majority, in which any decision would need both a majority of country votes and a majority of the EUÍs 350m- plus population to pass.

These issues are so complex that even veteran experts and euro-bores - and there are many here in Nice - have trouble following them. But the end result would be to ensure that France retained as much influence as possible while finally accepting GermanyÍs post-unity status.

But such distractions are a routine part of the bi-yearly talkfests that are billed as deciding the future of a continent. That is truer of this summit than many others, since rather than just issue a set of bland conclusions on matters ranging from BSE to maritime safety, Jacques Chirac and his fellow leaders have to sign up to a new EU treaty - designed to make creaking institutions work when new members from eastern Europe start joining the club in the next few years. webTitle: UK charities find conflict in government's attitude to globalisation

fields.headline: Conflict on globalisation
fields.standfirst: The white paper on globalisation and development should generate some innovative responses to its challenges but, according to a report by UK charities, there is a conflict in the government's thinking
fields.trailText: The white paper on globalisation and development should generate some innovative responses to its challenges but, according to a report by UK charities, there is a conflict in the government's thinking.
fields.body:
On the one hand, the government has seemingly adopted "free trade", "liberalisation", "privatisation", "free markets" and "voluntarism" as central components of its response to globalisation. On the other, it recognises the importance of government intervention to address persistent market failures concerning issues such as equity, redistribution and the internalisation of social and environmental costs.

Commissioned and funded by Action Aid, CAFOD, the RSPB, UK Food Group (UKFG) and World Wildlife Fund, the following extract from the report pinpoints some of the key assumptions and battlegrounds behind the white paper.

Globalisation - a fact of life?

According to one department for international development (DIFD) official, "Globalisation is an unstoppable process involving information technology and the globalisation of markets - globalisation is with us."

While it is true that part of the globalisation process involves technological change (e.g. improved communications and transport technology) it is also clear that other globalisation processes, such as increasing international mergers and acquisitions, increasing fluidity of capital and increasing interdependence of markets are critically influenced by government policy. Whether or not globalisation is unstoppable is a moot point - but to control the way in which it shapes our lives lies within the power of governments.

Should growth come before environmental protection?

According to one DETR official: "There is a respectable argument that states that countries have to reach a certain stage of development before they can seriously devote much in the way of resources to environmental protection."

This statement suggests that growth is the path to environmental improvement. It does not, however, account for the interaction between growth and environmental degradation. Growth - as we currently measure it - has environmental implications as this necessarily entails increased consumption and resource use. The Government has recognised the consumption problem saying that, "Most environmental degradation is underpinned by the consumption patterns of middle and upper income groups and the large, increasingly, globalised production system that meets and shapes their needs." This sits uneasily with advocacy of a growth leads to environmental improvement strategy.

For example, UNEP figures estimate the number of motor vehicles per person in North America is 0.75, 30 times that of Africa (0.025 vehicles per capita). Coincidentally, North American per capita fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions are among the highest in the world. If North American consumption levels were achieved worldwide, the total number of vehicles would reach some 4,500 million - a massive increase from the 676 million vehicles in 1996.

The government needs to recognise that developed countries, despite efficiency improvements, have not reduced their absolute reliance on natural resources (merely their share in GDP), that their absolute consumption rate of such resources continues to increase, and that imported natural resources are crucial to industrialised economies.

Trade liberalisation - to what end?

According to one DFID official, "Clare Short has identified trade liberalisation as beneficial and a fact of life." That said, some government documents, and indeed Clare Short, have indicated that liberalisation can adversely affect some people and that such people should be helped with appropriate safety nets.

However, even the safety nets approach may not be an adequate response. Investment bank Salomon Smith Barney estimates that the concessions to reform China has made in bilateral deals negotiated with the USA, EU, Canada and Japan in order to join the world trade organisation could work out at the loss of some 40 million jobs, or 3% of China's population. This is the same, proportionately, as if the UK implemented economic reforms costing 1.85 million jobs. It is unlikely that a big enough safety net exists for this kind of massive social disruption.

There is insufficient recognition in government thinking that, in some circumstances, the social and/or environmental adjustment costs of liberalisation may be too high. Rarely, if ever, does the government recognise that in some situations, liberalisation is simply the wrong policy or that effective social and environmental measures should be in place before liberalisation is pursued.

On the impacts of trade on the environment, according to a ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food (MAFF) official, "The answer lies not in preventing trade but in ensuring that mechanisms are in place to address externalities - trade is not a part of production therefore environmental degradation is not a part of trade - policy frameworks need to be in place to address externalities while generating trade."

Trade does have one important direct environmental impact - the greenhouse gas emissions from freight transport that contributes to climate change. The social and environmental costs of international freight transport are currently not internalised into prices meaning that the cost of long distance transport is distorted. As the MAFF official mentions, addressing such externalities is important but the crucial issue is when and how.

It is also important to recognise the interaction between trade liberalisation, increasing reliance on international markets, the desire to be competitive and the impact this can have on attempts to improve social and environmental standards.

On trade, agriculture and development, the government largely promotes an approach in which all countries should liberalise to similar degrees. Yet, according to a DFID official, "In some cases food security is best achieved by producing at home. In other cases by generating income so that food can be purchased. The challenge at the moment is dumping of Western produce. There are certain circumstances when national food self-sufficiency will be appropriate." This suggests that there may be cases where protecting domestic agriculture is an important and appropriate policy option. It does not sit well with the one-size-fits-all approach to liberalisation normally advocated.

Growth, equity and redistribution

A certain amount of confusion exists over how to address growth and equity. According to a DFID paper: "Growth will depend on a continuation of market friendly policies which promote investment in the context of low inflation and effective macro-economic management. For many governments this will mean continued commitment to programmes of economic reform and market liberalisation."

Economic growth through expanded trade and investment flows is seen as the best means of alleviating poverty and increasing welfare.

This is tempered to some extent by a recognition that, according to one DFID official, "Intervention is necessary to prevent anti-poor growth and to facilitate pro-poor growth." That said, the official goes on to state that, "This should not be redistributionist since growth would then be inhibited - it should take the form of safety nets, etc. - assisting vulnerable groups to cope with trade policy change is important."

The DFID document, on the other hand, states that "More equal countries are able to convert a given level of growth into greater poverty reduction. There is also evidence that reduced inequality is good for growth." (DFID, International Development Target Strategy Paper on Economic Wellbeing).

So where should the government stand on growth and equity? A range of research has shown that economic growth is just one aspect of poverty reduction and that underlying issues of access to resources, education, health care etc. are just as, if not more, important.

One important policy measure identified in the report is land reform; an issue recognised by one DFID official who states that, "There is beginning to be a realisation of the importance of agriculture in economic growth - this has not been on the agenda for the last ten years and is beginning to come back again. Agriculture is important not only for improving livelihoods of people in rural areas but also as an engine for economic growth. Agrarian reform is coming back on the agenda. It is present in the Economic Wellbeing paper and beginning to come back in World Bank discussions."

The economic wellbeing paper mentioned above does indeed talk of land reform, stating that, "Some direct measures are possible to improve income distribution, notably through land tenure reform and pro-poor public expenditure strategies." The paper goes on to say that, "The thrust of the paper, however, is that, for long-term and sustainable poverty reduction, poor people must contribute more effectively to growth" (DFID, International Development Target Strategy Paper on Economic Wellbeing). Such an emphasis results in a failure to put forward concrete policy proposals on redistributing assets (for example, promoting land reform) as well as redistributing opportunity.

Past experience shows that land reform is unlikely to be successful without supporting policies to help poor, marginal farmers take advantage of it. The government should encourage such complementary measures.

Who are the key influences?

It is difficult to get a completely accurate picture on the range of influences on government thinking concerning globalisation issues. However, the research suggests that, from the UK, the Overseas Development Institute (ODI), Institute for Development Studies (IDS) and International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED) are influential. The World Bank and the World Resources Institute (WRI) are two of the most respected international institutions. According to one DFID official, "The Dollar and Kraay paper [a World Bank document] on economic growth has been particularly influential recently."

Notable by their absence are UN bodies such as the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). Also seemingly absent are organisations and institutions from the developing world.

Conclusions

Government thinking on globalisation is characterised by contradictions. There is tension between a focus on free market and deregulatory policies and a focus on government intervention to promote more equitable and sustainable ways of improving the quality of life.

In the past few years, there has been no shortage of calls for, and opportunities to implement, a new way of managing globalisation. UNDP, World Bank and UNEP reports have all called for a different approach from governments. The key test then, for the globalisation white paper, is where it will place its emphasis.

Useful links


The World Bank's Dollar and Kraay paper on growth
International Institute for Environment and Development
World Resources Institute
Institute for Development Studies
Overseas Development Institute

Notes

The key texts employed as a basis for deriving principal assumptions underlying government thinking were: Eliminating World Poverty: A Challenge for the 21st Century (DFID, 1997); International Development Target Strategy Paper on Economic Well-being (DFID, 1999); Strategies for Achieving the International Development Targets - Environmental Sustainability and Eliminating Poverty (DFID, 2000); Consultation Draft of White Paper on International Development - Globalisation and Development (DFID, 2000); Making the Next Trade Round Work for the World's Poor (DFID, 1999); Future Multilateral Trade Negotiations - a 'Development Round'? (DFID, 1999); Lifting One Billion People Out of Poverty - the Role of Trade and Investment (DFID, 2000); Transcript of Evidence given to the House of Commons International Development Select Committee by D. Batt, J. Roberts and C. Bridge (February, 2000); Evidence given to the House of Commons International Development Select Committee by Clare Short (May, 2000).

Documentary evidence from these texts was complemented by material drawn from a number of face-to-face interviews with key staff from the Department for International Development (DFID), the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF), the Department for Trade and Industry (DTI), and the Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR). These staff were selected because all were involved in the production of, and/or thinking behind, the globalisation white paper.

fields.headline: Chirac widens split on defence
fields.trailText:
Jacques Chirac, the French host of the crucial EU summit in Nice which opened yesterday, was last
           night accused of playing domestic politics with European defence policy after insisting that Nato must
           be kept at arm's length on key military issues.
fields.byline: Ian Black and Michael White in Nice , and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Jacques Chirac, the French host of the crucial EU summit in Nice which opened yesterday, was last night accused of playing domestic politics with European defence policy after insisting that Nato must be kept at arm's length on key military issues.

In remarks that irritated Tony Blair, President Chirac used his first summit appearance to underline his long-standing wish to minimise the alliance's role in the new rapid reaction force.

The French president, whose police had earlier been forced to dispel anti- summit protesters with teargas, insisted that he had no intention of seeking to weaken Nato. But he insisted that although the 60,000-strong force would co-ordinate with Nato command, it had to be "independent" from its Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe.

Given the historic French hostility to the US domination of Nato, President Chirac's comments set alarm bells ringing as EU leaders gathered for a summit designed to smooth the entry of former Soviet bloc states, some of which are already Nato members.

Spokesmen for Mr Blair, already under fire from Eurosceptics at home over the alleged threat to Nato, told reporters that the French leader was fully committed to the project. It is designed to let European peacekeepers act in the EU's own backyard in future crises similar to the Kosovo drama which exposed the EU's military impotence.

"The important thing is that the military planning capability rests with Nato," the prime minister said.

Detailed documents to be approved by all 15 leaders today formally declare the EU's support for the 50-year-old Nato alliance. They state explicitly that the rapid reaction force "does not involve the establishment of a European army" - the emotive phrase whose use by Tory tabloids has enraged Downing Street.

But the timing of the incident is unfortunate for Mr Blair at the start of what promises to be a bruising summit where vital institutional reforms have to be agreed to facilitate decision-making after the EU moves to 15 to an eventual 27 members.

Iain Duncan-Smith, shadow defence secretary, jumped into the row in London. "Tony Blair's cynical attempt to cosy up to the French by betraying Nato is in ruins," he said last night. "The French president has now made clear that the price of the Euro army is the exclusion of the Americans from an alliance which has kept the peace in western Europe for more than 50 years."

With a UK election expected next spring, Mr Blair knows he must defend Britain's red lines -vetoes on tax and social security. Yesterday his Tory predecessor, John Major, warned him to leave "plenty of fat" around his negotiating position to protect those core issues from too much pressure between now and what may prove a deadlocked summit that staggers into Sunday.

The Nato spat comes days after a warning from the outgoing US defence secretary, William Cohen, that the alliance could become a "relic of history" if the EU does not do more to share its burdens - as Mr Blair wishes - and protect the cohesion of Nato's command structure.

In Brussels, Nato officials are expressing concern about France's refusal to commit itself to close cooperation between Nato and the EU on military planning.

"They are refusing to be tied down to an EU-Nato agreement," one official said.

Britain insists that the main role of the EU's proposed military staff, of some 100 personnel, must be to liaise with Nato. Though it could have an advisory role, it must not lead to a separate EU command and control structure, says Britain. This is also the position of the US. France is continuing to block arrangements that would automatically and permanently "lock in" the EU with Nato, say Nato officials.

But diplomats said the French statement was intended largely for domestic political purposes after similar remarks by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, Mr Chirac's likely rival for the presidency in 2002. Both put on a united front last night.

Mr Blair flew to the summit declaring he would defy fellow leaders who want him to surrender Britain's veto in crucial areas as part of the reform of EU decision-making. "The British position on tax is quite clear," he said. "Every country has got its clear no-go areas and on the issue of tax there is no way we are going to yield up the veto."

Hot agenda items at the summit are how to reduce the size of the 20-strong European Commission, to extend qualified majority voting into new areas and to re-weight votes in the European Council to give big countries, including Britain, a bigger voice.

At the start of the summit , French riot police fought pitched battles with protesters a few hundred yards from the main venue, firing volleys of teargas as fireworks and furniture were hurled towards them. A group of several hundred Spanish anarchists, radical trade unionists and Basque and Corsican separatists were thought to be orchestrating the protests.

Spokesmen for Mr Blair, already under fire from Eurosceptics at home over the alleged threat to Nato, told reporters that the French leader was fully committed to the project. It is designed to let European peacekeepers act in the EU's own backyard in future crises similar to the Kosovo drama which exposed the EU's military impotence. "The important thing is that the military planning capability rests with Nato," the prime minister said. Detailed documents to be approved by all 15 leaders today formally declare the EU's support for the 50-year-old Nato alliance. They state explicitly that the rapid reaction force "does not involve the establishment of a European army" - the emotive phrase whose use by Tory tabloids has enraged Downing Street. But the timing of the incident is unfortunate for Mr Blair at the start of what promises to be a bruising summit where vital institutional reforms have to be agreed to facilitate decision-making after the EU moves to 15 to an eventual 27 members. Iain Duncan-Smith, shadow defence secretary, jumped into the row in London. "Tony Blair's cynical attempt to cosy up to the French by betraying Nato is in ruins," he said last night. "The French president has now made clear that the price of the Euro army is the exclusion of the Americans from an alliance which has kept the peace in western Europe for more than 50 years." With a UK election expected next spring, Mr Blair knows he must defend Britain's red lines -vetoes on tax and social security. Yesterday his Tory predecessor, John Major, warned him to leave "plenty of fat" around his negotiating position to protect those core issues from too much pressure between now and what may prove a deadlocked summit that staggers into Sunday. The Nato spat comes days after a warning from the outgoing US defence secretary, William Cohen, that the alliance could become a "relic of history" if the EU does not do more to share its burdens - as Mr Blair wishes - and protect the cohesion of Nato's command structure. In Brussels, Nato officials are expressing concern about France's refusal to commit itself to close cooperation between Nato and the EU on military planning. "They are refusing to be tied down to an EU-Nato agreement," one official said. Britain insists that the main role of the EU's proposed military staff, of some 100 personnel, must be to liaise with Nato. Though it could have an advisory role, it must not lead to a separate EU command and control structure, says Britain. This is also the position of the US. France is continuing to block arrangements that would automatically and permanently "lock in" the EU with Nato, say Nato officials. But diplomats said the French statement was intended largely for domestic political purposes after similar remarks by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, Mr Chirac's likely rival for the presidency in 2002. Both put on a united front last night. Mr Blair flew to the summit declaring he would defy fellow leaders who want him to surrender Britain's veto in crucial areas as part of the reform of EU decision-making. "The British position on tax is quite clear," he said. "Every country has got its clear no-go areas and on the issue of tax there is no way we are going to yield up the veto." Hot agenda items at the summit are how to reduce the size of the 20-strong European Commission, to extend qualified majority voting into new areas and to re-weight votes in the European Council to give big countries, including Britain, a bigger voice. At the start of the summit , French riot police fought pitched battles with protesters a few hundred yards from the main venue, firing volleys of teargas as fireworks and furniture were hurled towards them. A group of several hundred Spanish anarchists, radical trade unionists and Basque and Corsican separatists were thought to be orchestrating the protests.

webTitle: The making of Tomb Raider in Cambodia

fields.headline: Raiders of the lost temple
fields.standfirst: What happens when a big-budget Hollywood film rolls into one of the world's most isolated and strife-torn countries?  James East  reports on Tomb Raider's week-long shoot at Angkor Wat in Cambodia
fields.trailText: What happens when a big-budget Hollywood film rolls into one of the world's most isolated and strife-torn countries? James East reports on Tomb Raider's week-long shoot at Angkor Wat in Cambodia
fields.body:
Any Buddhist monks making a pilgrimage to the Cambodian temple of Angkor Wat two weeks ago would have been greeted by an unexpected sight: a strikingly pretty, superbly toned young woman engaged in unarmed combat with a group of masked marauders, watched by a full-scale Hollywood production crew. For this sacred site is one of the chief locations used in the filming of Tomb Raider, the first big-screen outing for Eidos's phenomenally successful cyberbabe, Lara Croft.

Lara, in the shape of Oscar-winning actress Angelina Jolie, was looking exceptionally lithe in a jet-black catsuit; the result, apparently, of several months spent bungee jumping, motorbike riding and martial-arts training. Closer examination proved impossible, alas: bystanders who strayed too close to the set were scared off by cries of "Oi, you! Keep back!" from a pack of hulking British minders.

A few hours later, a group of daytrippers visiting the Bayon temple asked what all the trucks and cameras were for. The temple guide explained that they were filming a "love story". Had they been allowed closer to the set, the tourists would have witnessed something rather different: a grim-faced Lara expertly power-sliding her Land Rover through a morass of mud and water for the cameras.

For director Simon West, there was never any question about who should play the lead. "Angelina was always my only choice, not even my first choice," he said. "It really was a one-horse race. If she didn't do it, I can't think who else would have been suitable."

Tomb Raider is the first film to be shot in Cambodia since Peter O'Toole played Lord Jim in the shadow of Angkor Wat in 1964 (one reason why West wanted to film there). Since then, however, the country has had other things on its plate: bombed by the US during the Vietnam war, ravaged by Pol Pot and his Khmer Rouge cadres in the 1970s, under occupation by Vietnamese troops in the 1980s and engulfed in civil war in the early 1990s, it has long been a no-go area for hardened backpackers, never mind unwieldy US film crews. Roland Joffe's The Killing Fields (1984), which described the background to the murder of some two million Cambodians by Pol Pot's regime, was filmed in neighbouring Thailand.

So the impact of Tomb Raider could be significant. If the film incarnation of Lara Croft is anything like as successful as her virtual counterpart, Cambodia can expect to enjoy something of a renaissance. Judging by the impact on tourism of the modestly successful Leonardo DiCaprio vehicle The Beach, which triggered a mini-invasion of Thailand's Phi Phi Leh island, Angkor could be swamped with tourists within a couple of years.

For a time, though, it looked as if the Cambodian Tourist Board would have to postpone its recruitment drive, since the scenes to be filmed there nearly did not happen at all. Cambodia's film infrastructure is almost nonexistent, and much of the equipment had to be brought in from Thailand along a road that once ran through a Khmer Rouge stronghold. The road is littered with potholes and mines, and the transport crew - with the assistance of a minesweeper and the Royal Cambodian army - had to drive almost 30 trucks full of equipment along it. Inching its way towards Siem Reap, the gateway to the temples, the convoy often had to stop altogether while soldiers repaired the bridges ahead.

"I can't wait until it is all over and they have gone home," said a frazzled transportation manager, gulping down a beer at the end of a particularly weary day on set. "Then I can get some sleep." He was, he said, being paid just $500 per week.

For most locals, however, used to the daily grind of negotiating washboard roads, the sum represents a king's ransom. Five hundred dollars equates to more than a year's wage for most Cambodians, who usually scrape by on one or two dollars a day.

Susan D'Arcy, publicist with the Paramount film unit, said hundreds of Cambodians had been employed for Tomb Raider as extras or crew. Tens of thousands of much-needed dollars have been pumped into the local economy in hotel bills, mobile-phone rentals and wages.

For translator Riem Sunsoley, who learned his English in a refugee camp on the Thai border, the film has been a huge boon, earning him $25 a day for five weeks. He is putting the money towards building an orphanage for the street kids who live around the temples.

He is thankful to Hollywood, but says political peace is more important. "If politics does not go downhill then everything will develop. I hope more people from other countries will come to Cambodia," he said.

Just as valuable as the influx of cash, says Paramount, is the fact that Cambodians are witnessing first-hand how films are made. In the 1960s, Cambodia had a small but vibrant national film industry, largely thanks to the patronage of the country's movie-mad king, Norodom Sihanouk. Its chief output was formulaic, sickly-sweet love stories that were unashamedly cranked out for the masses. But Pol Pot single-handedly devastated the industry, killing most of the directors and actors who failed to flee the country in time.

Since the ascension of former Khmer Rouge commander Hun Sen, the country's film industry has remained stagnant, stifled by the popularity of Hollywood and Hong Kong kick-and-chop movies. More importantly, Cambodia has no purpose-built cinemas. The old French colonial theatres have been converted into warehouses, shops or karaoke bars, and most movies are watched at home in the form of pirate videos. The fuss surrounding Ms Jolie and company, hopes the local artistic community, will revive interest in both film and film-making.

The film is also good news for the temples. The conservation authority responsible for preserving and protecting the complex is charging Paramount $10,000 per day for seven days. Much of the money will go back into caring for the temples themselves.

Cambodia's conservationists have worked hard to avoid the outcry that followed the filming of a Mortal Kombat sequel in Thailand, where fight scenes were shot among the ruins of the Buddhist temples. Devout Buddhists were upset that violence had been allowed to disrupt what should have been a haven of peace.

Conservationist Ashley Thompson, of Cambodia's Apsara temples authority, said the agency had worked extremely closely with Paramount to ensure that Cambodia's image was not sullied. "The film has made it past the censors here in Cambodia. What they told us is that there is violence, but that there are no guns and that Khmers [Cambodians] are not portrayed as violent people, but foreigners."

An extremely detailed contract was also drawn up to ensure that the temples would not be damaged in any way. However, the authorities decided against insisting on total control of what could be filmed. "Coming out of years of oppressive regimes, it seemed that censorship should not be something that we supported. Cambodia should be open, and violent films should be allowed, even if we don't like them," said Ms Thompson.

Cambodia has found peace under strongman Hun Sen. But halfway through filming came an unwelcome reminder that the peace is all too fragile. On November 24, the capital, Phnom Penh, reverberated with the sound of gunfire when between 70 and 80 armed men laid siege to the city centre. Eight were killed and scores of suspects were rounded up. The alleged leader of what has been called an attempted coup was later arrested in Siem Reap - just a few hundred yards from where the Tomb Raider crew was staying.

If the violence continues, salvaging Cambodia's tarnished image may be a task beyond even Lara Croft.

fields.headline: Sticking to the basics
fields.standfirst: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen adds some new overheads to her weekly staff meetings
fields.trailText: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen adds some new overheads to her weekly staff meetings.
fields.body:
This week I added a couple of new overheads to the set I use for my meetings with staff. One lists all those who have recently been commenting on our services and proffering advice about how to improve them (John Barratt, SSI, Joint Review, Idea); another synthesises their messages to one phrase, "stick to the basics". This has felt like a week where I have largely managed to do this without too much difficulty, so that's good!

Had a good management team meeting which focused mainly on budget issues. You know the kind of thing - reviewing our growth bids, looking for savings, finding suitable words to describe the implications of proposals that won't make the centre accuse us of waving bleeding stumps. But we also managed to complete the whole agenda. I put it down to the Danish pastries I supplied.

I listened, together with a colleague from the corporate management team, to a group of senior managers presenting the results of a three-day management development course they attended. It was very effective and rather uplifting. It began with a Guardian headline in June 2004 declaring Lambeth to be a flagship council and then went through all the characteristics of the organisation that had led to this achievement. Some interesting and highly credible ideas were proposed, such as using radio more effectively as a communication tool. There was an interesting emphasis on leadership, with a clearly articulated desire for some top-down confident action around values and strategy. Of course I liked it because that's what we are trying to do!

Had a very focused and useful performance review meeting with the chief executive. We've established a structure of twice-monthly meetings, and agreed on the performance information we will be looking at - this includes financial monitoring, PIs, improvement plan actions and any other issues of concern that we need to look at. I suspect my pile of papers related to the latter point is greater than those of my colleagues. I (sadly) still get a thrill from seeing graphs and the first hints of trend analysis. A year ago we couldn't even say how many children the council was looking after; now we need to be careful we don't just produce information in unmanageable reams, but actually do something with it that helps managers to manage.

Finish the week meeting with colleagues from health and the other two LAs in our bid to push forward on Information for Health. I chair the local authority collaboration group, which sits alongside a number of others such as the primary care and acute collaboration groups. I have been feeling increasingly that actually it would be more effective to ensure we get effective LA representation on the other collaboration groups rather than talking among ourselves about what Information for Health means for local authorities - so I almost succeeded in dissolving a working group, but didn't quite manage it as I discovered we need to coordinate the production of a three-year plan for our sector. Oh well, I tried.

fields.headline: Frostrup to present Clinton documentary
fields.trailText: 12pm: Mariella Frostrup is being lined up to present a documentary on Bill Clinton's first year away from the White House, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Mariella Frostrup is being lined up to present a major British documentary about Bill Clinton's first year away from the White House.

The TV presenter is said to have been personally requested by Mr Clinton to front the show.

If the deal goes ahead, she will follow the president for a year after he quits to put together a mini-series on life after the presidency.

The BBC is thought to be involved in the negotiations, which have yet to be finalised.

Such a deal would be an extraordinary coup for Ms Frostrup, who has had to fight criticism that she is just a "dumb blonde".

She was plunged into controversy last month when she was chosen by the BBC current affairs series Panorama to present a one-off show on reality TV.

Her appearance on the flagship show caused consternation in some quarters and led to criticism that the flagship show was being dumbed down.

The BBC faced serious embarrassment when Lorraine Heggessey, the new controller of BBC1, dismissed as a joke the idea that Panorama would be presented by Ms Frostrup.

It later emerged that the presenter had already been signed up.

Ms Frostrup already runs her own production company, Brazen Husky, and works as a presenter for Channel 5.

fields.headline: Cambridge women near numerical parity
fields.trailText: Almost half the first-year undergraduates at Cambridge this year are women, the university announced today. The percentage of women freshers rose to 48% - up from 45% in 1999.
fields.body:
Almost half the first-year undergraduates at Cambridge this year are women, the university announced today. The percentage of women freshers rose to 48% - up from 45% in 1999.

Cambridge attributed the boost in female admissions to a recent campaign to encourage more women to study science. The Women in Science, Engineering and Technology Initiative, led by Dr Nancy Lane, aims to increase the representation of women in the sciences at Cambridge at all levels.

Clare and King's are among the colleges with a 50-50 male-female ration among first years. Peterhouse, to which 70 men and 18 women were admitted in 1999, retains a low proportion of female students, but such a deficit is balanced by the all-female colleges of Newnham and New Hall.

At graduate level, Cambridge's male-female ratio is 58:42.

Student union women's officer Laura Timms rejected the suggestion that women's colleges no longer had a role now that women were no longer heavily outnumbered at Cambridge, pointing out that women often lacked female academic role models at mixed colleges.

"There isn't [a balanced intake] within graduate study, and most certainly there isn't at academic level," she said. "The students' union is planning to do an additional study on the quality of life at different colleges, and Newnham and New Hall offer benefits such as multi-disciplinary seminars which many other colleges don't."

"The value of female role models is fundamentally enshrined in women's colleges," she added.

webTitle: Iffyosaurus Dinosaur skeleton exposed as fake

fields.headline: Iffyosaurus Dinosaur skeleton exposed as fake
fields.trailText: For 116 years it graced the halls of the National Museum of Wales at Cardiff - the fossilised skeleton of a 200m-year-old predator that once cruised the Jurassic seas.
fields.body:
For 116 years it graced the halls of the National Museum of Wales at Cardiff - the fossilised skeleton of a 200m-year-old predator that once cruised the Jurassic seas.

It survived the scrutiny of scientists who had known Charles Darwin, and Richard Owen, the Victorian scholar who coined the word dinosaur. It survived revolutions in palaeontology, arguments over evolution and scandals in the world of fossils.

Then curators at Cardiff decided the remains of the ocean-going carnivore ichthyosaurus needed a brush up - and realised that they had been taken in.

"When we stripped off five layers of paint we found it was an elaborate forgery," said Caroline Buttler, a conservator. "It was an amalgam of two types of ichthyosaurus plus a clever attempt at fake parts."

Ichthyosaurs were discovered by fossil collector Mary Anning on the Dorset coast in about 1809. Cardiff's specimen was presented by a local businessman, Samuel Allen, in 1884.

It will now go back on display as an example of a fake. Museum officials have dubbed it "iffyosaurus".

webTitle: Zadie Smith wins Guardian First Book Award

fields.headline: Zadie Smith wins Guardian First Book Award
fields.standfirst:
Hear David Baddiel discuss the shortlist
Hear Zadie Smith's acceptance speech
You will need RealPlayer to listen to these clips. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: Magic realism in multi-ethnic Britain - Guardian Prize goes to Zadie Smith's White Teeth
fields.body:
Eleven months after achieving one of the most talked-of fiction debuts of the decade, Zadie Smith was last night declared winner of the £10,000 Guardian First Book award for her novel White Teeth.

Her sprawling, comic epic about multi-ethnic Britain, which uncovers a wonderland of magic realism in the London subtopias of Cricklewood Broadway and Willesden, beat a strong shortlist of four other books, all by American writers.

Despite her rudely funny writing, she was described by one of the readers' groups, which play a unique part in the judging process, as being "like Jane Austen".

Smith, 25, a Cambridge student until three years ago, said after receiving the award: "It's the prize I really wanted to win. The Guardian is a very lucky prize because it's not restricted by nation or race or gender. It's incredibly wide.

"It's got my favourite books of the year on it. I've heard lots of people say it's a sad year for fiction but I think these people were just looking in the wrong direction."

The seven judges' unofficial runner-up was Naomi Klein's critique of post-modern consumer capitalism and designer label culture, No Logo, a book that has become influential for the world trade talks protest generation and was also a favourite with some readers' groups.

The Guardian prize - inaugurated last year - is Smith's first British award, although she was shortlisted for the Orange women-only prize in June and is a finalist in the fiction section of the Whitbread books award, to be decided next month. In October, she won the $10,000 fiction prize in the newly launched International Ebook awards for works converted from print into electronic form.

The judges praised White Teeth for its "muscular prose style" and "beautifully drawn characters", calling it a "sensationally good novel", which was "feisty, funny, satirical, and tender".

This year's judges were the geneticist Steve Jones, the novelists Julian Barnes, David Baddiel and Toby Litt, the broadcaster Kirsty Young and the Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger. They were headed by the Guardian's literary editor, Claire Armitstead. The prize is to recognise and reward new fiction.

During their final session, Barnes said White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99) gave him "a burn of envy as a fiction writer". Baddiel said it was "on its way to being a great novel". Though Professor Jones acknowledged its astonishing promise, he felt it was very much a young first novel, with too many characters and a simplistic ending. Among Litt's reservations was its "narrative tricks" inherited, he felt, from Salman Rushdie.

No Logo (Flamingo, £14.99) aroused equal enthusiasm but deeper disappointment. Kirsty Young said: "People should be strapped to chairs and made to read it." Litt called it "a most important book". To Baddiel, it was "incredibly refreshing", but stylistically pedestrian. Barnes found its analysis lucid but based on too few first-hand interviews. For Jones, it "fell rather flat" and was parochial.

Also on the shortlist, Dave Eggers' elsewhere highly praised memoir A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99) tells - with what one critic called "great whooping arcs" - the story of bringing up his younger brother alone. Litt said it had some of the best writing on the shortlist. Barnes had "80% praise". To Baddiel, it was solipsistic and showed the limits of a diarist.

Prof Jones said that if the judging was "on oddness grounds" Mark Danielewski's post-modern haunted house mystery House of Leaves (Anchor, £13) would win. It reaped 60% of votes on the Guardian website. Young gave it marks for ambition, Litt found it moving and daring but also apt to undermine itself. Barnes, whom it left unscared, wanted to like it more.

Catfish and Mandala (Flamingo, £10.99) is Andrew Pham's account of returning by bicycle to re-explore the Vietnam he left in the 1970s. Barnes spoke of how cleverly it used "a gentleness and lyricism of tone to describe things of extreme violence". It was painful and well-written. Jones, also strongly in favour, called it "very, very powerful". However, it left Litt and Young cold.

Unanimously, the readers' group from Borders Books music cafe in Charing Cross Road, London, chose No Logo for "an eloquent analysis that deserves to change our cultural outlook". The Cheshire Oaks group singled out Catfish and Mandala as "fantastic" and White Teeth as "very funny". The York group also went for Catfish and Mandala and two titles that were not shortlisted - the science writer Mark Buchanan's Ubiquity (Weidenfeld, £20) and TE Carhart's The Piano Shop on the Left Bank (Chatto and Windus, £15.99). A Borders group in Glasgow also judged the books.

fields.headline: New Hall, old feminism
fields.standfirst: Rachel Halliburton, a graduate of all-female college New Hall, argues that single sex colleges should no longer be the battleground for equality of the sexes at Cambridge
fields.trailText: Rachel Halliburton, a graduate of all-female college New Hall, argues that single sex colleges should no longer be the battleground for equality of the sexes at Cambridge
fields.body:
It seems that women have won a great victory in the war that began almost 130 years ago. Battle commenced when Girton was stationed as a female stronghold on Cambridge's outskirts. Girls who dared to lay claim to brain-cells needed to begin their fight for intellectual equality by capturing territory, since Cambridge academics had protected themselves against petticoat power with a statute forbidding mixed colleges. If a woman wanted to plant bombshells blasting them out of the complacency of male intellectual superiority, the obvious strategy was to found a college of one's own.

But now the number of female undergraduates entering the university has reached 48%, and dusty male dons shuddering at what oestrogen overload might do to academia have - on the whole - been consigned to museums. Combine this with the fact that as long ago as 1988, Magdalene became the last all-male college to surrender its garrisons to female students, and the question arises - what use is there now for the all-women college?

As a graduate of New Hall, which was founded in 1954, I would like to venture the opinion that the woman's college has had its day. True, my college represented a vital landmark in providing a modern relaxed setting for ushering more female undergraduates into the university. True, its success is reflected in gutsy, interesting, and high-achieving graduates like actress Tilda Swinton and pioneering classical pianist, Joanna McGregor. But now it has little to give women that cannot be provided by mixed colleges. Those who watched the disastrous University Challenge of 1997 might say it offers less.

This is not to say feminism should be consigned to the past in Cambridge. Far from it. The urgent questions to be addressed now are not how many women are at the university, but why last year only 16% achieved firsts compared to 24% of men, and why - far more shockingly - only 6.2% of the university's professors are female. While I was there, the positions of New Hall and Newnham in the academic league tables certainly did not justify the argument that women might do better academically in isolation. New Hall, in addition, has a mixed teaching staff, and so has given up the battle in the area where it most needs to be fought.

The focus, then, should be on how women's achievements are measured, and how more subtle forms of prejudice might be undermining them than they faced in the 1870s. The battle for base-camp has been won: now the battle of wits should begin in earnest.

New Hall
Newnham

webTitle: Self-confident midfielder,  Unfashionable manager, and  Over-rated left-footer

fields.headline: Self-confident midfielder,  Unfashionable manager, and  Over-rated left-footer
fields.trailText: HOULLIER TAKES THE BISCAN
fields.body:
HOULLIER TAKES THE BISCAN

Jean-Michel Ferri. Bernard Diomede. Erik Meijer. Nobody can say that Gerard Houllier doesn't know what he's doing in the transfer market. That's why Liverpool fans won't in any way be concerned to hear that their manager is currently suffering from a minor nervous breakdown after spunking £5.5m of his wad on Croatian midfielder Igor Biscan.

"The price isn't low," Houllier moaned as accountants from Dynamo Zagreb set about fingering his purse. "We are living in an era of football where you have to buy the potential because the finished article is too expensive," the nail-chomping Frenchman continued, perhaps suggesting his expensive new charge will be lucky to see first team action for a while.

But 22-year-old Biscan doesn't expect to waste any time hanging around on the bench with second-string losers like Djimi Traore or Michael Owen. "I think even though I am still young I can bring some power and skill and I believe I will find my place," he bragged with the arrogance of youth. "I've waited for a long time to come here and now I want to prove I can play here." Considering Juventus and Barcelona were also in for the 6ft 5in Croat, we're sure he can. Although the Fiver remembers Milan showing an interest in Vegard Heggem before his transfer to Anfield... and he's hardly Thomas Helveg, is he?

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 8: Click here

HEAVEN KNOWS SMITH'S MISERABLE NOW

Jim Smith is no glamour puss - he manages Derby for starters - and the straight-talking veteran fears that he is falling even further out of fashion. Ahead of his side's trip to play slick outfitters Chelsea's of Chelsea, Smith has let fly at the Premiership's "showbiz culture".

You see, while Smith turned to the equally down-to-earth Colin Todd to help Derby out of their considerable hole, Chelsea's turned to Claudio Ranieri. So it's no surprise that Smith has outrageously claimed that they could at least have chosen someone who did not require an interpreter. "If a guy comes in and can't speak any English then he must have a major problem," Smith declared to a group of almost-fluent hacks. "How can he get his message across? But this is a showbiz world and a world of plcs. It is big business. Clubs are looking for a name as opposed to ability."

Predictably, Smith is no more enamoured with the equally well-tailored Sven-Goran Eriksson, England's knight in shining armour. So whenever the Swede chooses to ride over the horizon, he shouldn't expect to find straight-laced Jim in the welcoming party. "You look at the situation with Eriksson. It is a gimmicky kind of thing to do," Smith claimed, using his finest Queen's English.

Damsels (or at least football teams) in distress would be better off going for English acumen over foreign sophistication, cried Smith. "There are a lot of very good young managers out there. But as many of them don't fit the image, they don't get a chance. That's the way the game is," he concluded, before dropping his trousers to reveal a fetching pair of union jack boxer shorts.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I know for a fact he would love to come here and play for me to try and get match fit" - Newcastle boss Bobby Robson on Ronaldo. Hmm, somebody's going to get hurt, aren't they?

THEY'RE BETTER THAN BEST

If you think that Alan Green and the Imperial Lord Ferg hate each other, then you haven't basked in the sub-Saharan temperatures that are generated whenever Diego Maradona and Pele are in the same continent. In short, Maradona reckons Pele is, to use the football parlance, a raving left-footer - and over-rated to boot. Meanwhile Pele, when he's not cementing his role as the planet's worst tipster - England to win Euro 2000 anyone? - has let it be known that he doesn't like the stumpy Argentinian either.

It's a messy business, that's for sure. And in the absence of sorting things out the old fashioned way - give them a pair of 12 ouncers and throw them in a barn is what we say - the Fiver hoped that next week's Fifa vote to find the Footballer of the Century would settle matters. How wrong we were. Because according to Spanish newspaper Ole, Maradona is set to win the award - based on the recommendations of a Fifa panel as well as internet voting - just two weeks after Fifa had refused to put him on their short list. And he's already rubbing Pele's nose in it!

"Let's be serious - don't compare me with him any more," a joyous Maradona claimed. "They say Pele has played in World Cups, but nobody explains that he did not play in 1962 and in England when he played a game and a half." And just in case anyone was in any doubt how happy Diego was, he then added: "This is the most important prize I could have, alongside a cap that Fidel Castro gave me!"

Meanwhile in Brazil, frantic lobbying is taking place to try to alter the vote, although Maradona being Maradona he has pledged to accept the outcome of the result. "I've heard that the Brazilians are lobbying and that Fifa are seeing what they can do so that the prize is split with Pele," he thundered. "I've told my agent to tell them that if they do this, I'm not going. Yesterday, I was packing my suitcase and today I'm emptying it again. If the people voted for me, then the prize is for me. They can't start inventing ways of taking it away from me." You almost feel sorry for him, don't you? That's just us, then.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea have confirmed that Barcelona have enquired about Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, reports Teamtalk, with the possibility of a cash plus player deal. Football 365 claim that one of those players will be Emmanuel Petit, who the Sun says will be on his way back to Arsenal for £1m.

West Ham manager Harry Redknapp wants to buy Gareth Southgate from Aston Villa, but only if John Gregory lowers his valuation of the central defender, according to Soccernet. "I could be interested in him at around £5-6m but Villa are asking £10m which is way too high," said Redknapp. "However, we do need more defenders."

Manchester City face competition from Everton in their bid to sign Bordeaux striker Lilian Laslandes, claims Teamtalk. The French club could be interested in a player-plus-cash deal involving Everton's Ghanaian midfielder Alex Nyarko.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ken Bates appears to have survived a crisis in his leadership of the 'new' Wembley project. Bates emerged from a meeting at FA headquarters in Soho Square this afternoon and declared: "We have spent a long time discussing all aspects and I have received a unanimous vote of confidence."

Neil Lennon says he is "absolutely thrilled" that his £5.7m move from Leicester to Celtic has finally been completed. "I was desperate to come here. I always wanted to come here. I'm absolutely thrilled to be here," he admitted.

Huddersfield have signed Peter Ndlovu from Birmingham on a month's loan.

Aberdeen's SPL game against Dundee United tomorrow has been postponed because of a waterlogged pitch.

Harold Phipps, who was a member of Charlton's FA Cup-winning side in 1947, has died at the age of 84. The defender played in three Wembley finals for the Addicks, including the war cup final against Arsenal in 1943.

Paolo di Canio was robbed of at least seven penalties last season according to Harry Redknapp and Premier League referees' boss Philip Don. "We showed a video to Philip Don with seven penalty claims from matches last season and he agreed that every one was a penalty," said Redknapp. "They were absolute certain penalties but every one of them got turned down."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Premier League Preview (12midnight, 4am)
So bad even Sky don't bother showing it before the witching hour.

Sky Sports 2: Live FA Cup Football (7pm)
Walsall play Barnet for the right to draw and subsequently humiliate Manchester United in the third round.

Hold The Back Page (10pm)
Why not click here and tell Brian Woolnough just how much you rate his luxurious bouffant?

Sky Sports 3: Australian Soccer League (5pm)
"I can't see the goal for all these empty tinnies piled up on the penalty spot, Bruce." "No worries, Bruce, just let me get me ute and we'll load 'em on the back."

Because according to Spanish newspaper Ole, Maradona is set to win the award - based on the recommendations of a Fifa panel as well as internet voting - just two weeks after Fifa had refused to put him on their short list. And he's already rubbing Pele's nose in it! "Let's be serious - don't compare me with him any more," a joyous Maradona claimed. "They say Pele has played in World Cups, but nobody explains that he did not play in 1962 and in England when he played a game and a half." And just in case anyone was in any doubt how happy Diego was, he then added: "This is the most important prize I could have, alongside a cap that Fidel Castro gave me!" Meanwhile in Brazil, frantic lobbying is taking place to try to alter the vote, although Maradona being Maradona he has pledged to accept the outcome of the result. "I've heard that the Brazilians are lobbying and that Fifa are seeing what they can do so that the prize is split with Pele," he thundered. "I've told my agent to tell them that if they do this, I'm not going. Yesterday, I was packing my suitcase and today I'm emptying it again. If the people voted for me, then the prize is for me. They can't start inventing ways of taking it away from me." You almost feel sorry for him, don't you? That's just us, then. THE RUMOUR MILL Chelsea have confirmed that Barcelona have enquired about Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, reports Teamtalk, with the possibility of a cash plus player deal. Football 365 claim that one of those players will be Emmanuel Petit, who the Sun says will be on his way back to Arsenal for £1m. West Ham manager Harry Redknapp wants to buy Gareth Southgate from Aston Villa, but only if John Gregory lowers his valuation of the central defender, according to Soccernet. "I could be interested in him at around £5-6m but Villa are asking £10m which is way too high," said Redknapp. "However, we do need more defenders." Manchester City face competition from Everton in their bid to sign Bordeaux striker Lilian Laslandes, claims Teamtalk. The French club could be interested in a player-plus-cash deal involving Everton's Ghanaian midfielder Alex Nyarko. NEWS IN BRIEF Ken Bates appears to have survived a crisis in his leadership of the 'new' Wembley project. Bates emerged from a meeting at FA headquarters in Soho Square this afternoon and declared: "We have spent a long time discussing all aspects and I have received a unanimous vote of confidence." Neil Lennon says he is "absolutely thrilled" that his £5.7m move from Leicester to Celtic has finally been completed. "I was desperate to come here. I always wanted to come here. I'm absolutely thrilled to be here," he admitted. Huddersfield have signed Peter Ndlovu from Birmingham on a month's loan. Aberdeen's SPL game against Dundee United tomorrow has been postponed because of a waterlogged pitch. Harold Phipps, who was a member of Charlton's FA Cup-winning side in 1947, has died at the age of 84. The defender played in three Wembley finals for the Addicks, including the war cup final against Arsenal in 1943. Paolo di Canio was robbed of at least seven penalties last season according to Harry Redknapp and Premier League referees' boss Philip Don. "We showed a video to Philip Don with seven penalty claims from matches last season and he agreed that every one was a penalty," said Redknapp. "They were absolute certain penalties but every one of them got turned down."
