Sky Sports 2: Live FA Cup Football (7pm) Walsall play Barnet for the right to draw and subsequently humiliate Manchester United in the third round. Hold The Back Page (10pm) Why not click here and tell Brian Woolnough just how much you rate his luxurious bouffant? Sky Sports 3: Australian Soccer League (5pm) "I can't see the goal for all these empty tinnies piled up on the penalty spot, Bruce." "No worries, Bruce, just let me get me ute and we'll load 'em on the back."

fields.headline: Stabbing that exposed Scots racism
fields.standfirst:
Murderous street attack left Asian man dead, and subsequent proceedings put the attitudes of British officialdom in the dock

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Murderous street attack left Asian man dead, and subsequent proceedings put the attitudes of British officialdom in the dock
fields.body:
On a dark winter's night Surjit Singh Chhokar got out of his car and slammed the door. It had been a long shift at the restaurant and in one hand he carried a takeaway curry and in the other a bottle of Irn Bru. He was a Scots Asian.

From the window of her council flat above, Mr Chhokar's girlfriend watched him drive into the street, before turning away from the familiar scene. A few minutes later Elizabeth Bryce looked helplessly on while her boyfriend bled to death.

As Ms Bryce made her way to the door of her home in Wishaw, Lanarkshire, Mr Chhokar, 32, was met in the street by three white men: Ronnie Coulter, 32; his nephew, Andrew Coulter, 19; and David Montgomery, 23. It was around 11.20pm on November 4 1998, and the three were waiting for Mr Chhokar to resolve a dispute over a stolen giro cheque. Andrew Coulter was armed with a heavy bat. Someone was carrying a knife.

Almost as soon as Mr Chhokar met the three men, a scuffle broke out. He tried to back away, but Ronnie Coulter followed and punched him repeatedly. Seconds later, Mr Chhokar was attacked with the bat. Vainly, he swung round the Irn Bru bottle in an attempt to defend himself. Upstairs, his girlfriend heard him scream.

Ms Bryce ran to the window; from there she could see the attack. She ran out on to the street and picked up a spade, making for the three men. Mr Chhokar crossed the road towards her and cried out: "They stabbed me."And he had been stabbed - through the heart.

Andrew Coulter and Montgomery drove off in their car. Within hours, Ronnie Coulter had scrubbed his and his nephew's clothes clean. The next day, his ex-girlfriend says, he handed her a bag stuffed with the clothes and a set of knives with one blade missing. A few days after the attack, Montgomery had his car valeted before it was sold.

"That night I was sleeping and I heard my daughter-in-law and my grandchildren at the door. They were all crying," said Darsham Chhokar, Surjit's father. "They kept saying, 'Surjit is no more'. I didn't understand."

Set of knives

Within days, Ronnie and Andrew Coulter and Montgomery had been arrested. There were no other suspects; all three admitted being at the scene of the crime. Ronnie and Andrew Coulter shared a first floor flat in a high rise on the rundown Gowkthrapple housing scheme. A few floors above lived Mr Chhokar; he knew both men. But on the morning of December 4, Andrew Coulter broke into Mr Chhokar's flat and stole his giro. Mr Chhokar, even his family admit, was far from an angel, but when he found out Andrew Coulter had stolen his benefit cheque he was furious. Mr Chhokar informed the DSS and told Ms Bryce he planned to bring in the police.

Four months after Mr Chhokar's murder, Ronnie Coulter stood trial. No one informed the Chhokar family of the court date, though relatives spotted it in a newspaper. When the family arrived at court, they expected to see all three men in the dock. The crown office has consistently refused to say why Ronnie Coulter stood trial alone.

Before he stood trial, Ronnie Coulter lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming Andrew Coulter and Montgomery for the murder. The Chhokar family, who speak little English, did not understand what was going on in the court. They were not alone. After six days the trial ended abruptly. Ronnie Coulter was convicted on a charge of assault. The crown did not move for sentencing and he walked free from court. The Chhokars were devastated; the trial judge, Lord McCluskey, was furious.

He told the jury: "A young man was murdered in a public street by one or more persons whose identities have been freely discussed in this case. For reasons I cannot begin to understand, one, and only one, of those persons was placed in the dock and charged with the crime."

The lord advocate was initially dismissive of the unprecedented attack on the crown office, but its timing was crucial. Lord McCluskey made his comments in March of last year, two weeks after the publication of the Macpherson report. As scrutiny of race relations in Britain moved to the top of the political agenda, Neville Lawrence, father of the murdered black teenager Stephen, travelled to Glasgow to lend his support.

Pressure applied

Race campaigners, MSPs and MPs began to pile pressure on the crown office. The family began to be offered meetings. At the start of last month, Andrew Coulter and Montgomery stood trial for Mr Chhokar's murder. This time, though, things were different.

In an unprecedented step, the family was given courtroom translators. When Andrew Coulter and Montgomery blamed Ronnie Coulter for the murder, the Chhokars understood what was going on. As the trial proceeded, however, it became obvious there was little chance of obtaining successful convictions. Margaret Chisholm, mother to Andrew and sister to Ronnie, told the court Ronnie had confessed to the murder. She said he boasted: "I've stabbed the black bastard."

As portents of a crisis echoed louder, a group of Scotland's most senior judges held a secret emergency meeting. Even before the jury had returned, the new lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, had announced he would be holding a press conference. At that conference, two inquiries were announced. Raj Jandoo would head one into the treatment of the family. A second inquiry, headed by Sir Anthony Campbell QC, would examine the decision not to prosecute all three men together. This was not enough to appease the family, who are calling for a full public inquiry.

"Raj Jandoo is a high court prosecutor and junior counsel who relies on the lord advocate for cases. How can we guarantee that he will be independent? The lord advocate appointed Sir Anthony Campbell and the crown office will decide which of his findings it makes public. That is not an independent inquiry by anyone's understanding," said Aamer Anwar, spokesman for the family.

The fallout from the obvious failures in the Chhokar case is being felt in Scotland. After the jury delivered its not guilty verdicts in the second trial, it could finally be revealed that Andrew Coulter was in prison for stabbing another man to death. He killed Patrick Kelly, 26, while on bail for Mr Chhokar's murder.

At the weekend, the Scottish justice minister, Jim Wallace, admitted there had been institutional racism in the crown office and Strathclyde police. Both bodies refused to comment on the accusation.

The case has also prompted a wider examination of the treatment of black people by the criminal justice system. Of 1,274 people employed by the crown office and procurator fiscal, only seven are from ethnic minority backgrounds.

But accusations of racism are being fought hard in many quarters of the system - and legal officials have voiced concern that the opportunity to expose widespread incompetence in the crown office might be eclipsed by campaigners too keen to bring in the race angle.

Within hours of the attack on Mr Chhokar, the police had informed a local councillor that it was not a racial murder. However, in the new year, Imran Khan, solicitor to the Lawrence family, and Michael Mansfield QC, will help the Chhokar family launch a full campaign for a public inquiry. They already have cross-party support from MSPs.

Bigger picture

In the meantime, a Sikh family in Lanarkshire is left trying to understand how they lost their son - and how British justice let them down so badly.

"My family had it in their blood that British justice was the best in the world. What I had been told was that British justice was blindfolded and everyone was treated equally," said Darsham Chhokar. "I have come to see that my family were not treated in that way, because they were black. It has destroyed my faith in the word justice, especially British justice."

webTitle: Three cheers for the three stars

fields.headline: Three cheers for the three stars
fields.standfirst: Bulbous truffles and succulent thrush breasts mark 100 years of the Michelin guides
fields.trailText: Bulbous truffles and succulent thrush breasts mark 100 years of the Michelin guides
fields.body:
There are certain words which, injected into the most casual of conversations, should give the Paris correspondent pause. These include, in no particular order: centenary, Michelin guide, three stars, Ducasse, celebration, and lunch.

"I am inviting you," the nice Frenchman on the phone said for the third time, "to a lunch devised and created by Alain Ducasse of the Plaza Athenée hotel, at which all 38 three-star chefs of Europe will together celebrate 100 years of the Michelin Red Guide. Would you by any chance be interested in coming?"

It was, of course, a necessary sacrifice, a chore reluctantly performed in the name of an ever deeper and more perfect understanding of France and its culture, an onerous hour or four passed itching to get back to the keyboard.

The half-dozen doormen springing to attention as the taxi pulled up were, frankly, a pain; the welcoming committee of bobbing frock-coated attendants a bore; the glass of Gosset Grand Rosé champagne proffered at the entrance to the many-chandeliered splendour of the dining room a yawn.

But as a legion of immaculately dressed black-tie waiters swooped in with the starter (noix de Saint-Jacques, bouillon lié de laitue, tartufi di Alba), the maitre d'hotel got down to business.

Each table was shown a carved wooden casket containing the precious white truffles; the assembled chefs took turns sniffing appreciatively at several thousand pounds worth of bulbous deli cacy. "Do not inhale too deeply," advised Michel Roux, Britain's only three-star, chef from the Waterside Inn at Bray, near Maidenhead.

"You will ruin your organ for the duration."

The scallops, accompanied by another vintage champagne, had died for the greater glory of France: firm yet succulent, exploding (as the tri-stellar Italian on my left remarked) on the palate, but, how you say, tenderly. "Perhaps a tad overdone," Mr Roux remarked. "But the guy is cooking the same menu for 50 people. Can't be easy."

Then followed the truffe noire, pomme de terre en marmelade et fleur de sel, accompanied by a humble 1995 Chateau Pape Clement Grand Cru classé, widely judged an inventive, dense yet flavoursome dish typical of the mastery that has made Mr Ducasse the only man in the world with six Michelin stars.

Langoustine de Bretagne au sauce épicé was apparently a slight disappointment, rather too complex in the nose and altogether a bonfire on the tongue, as a culinary legend who wished to remain nameless put it. But the poitrines de grive en cocotte sauce salmis (thrush breasts in salmi sauce, for the uninitiated) were genuinely remarkable.

Relieved, Mr Roux stuck his nose in his plate and inhaled hugely.

"That," he pronounced, "is pure Ducasse. His cuisine is so perfectly developed. I would have been satisfied with a big dish of this. Forget the rest."

The 1988 Chateau Pape Clément Grand Cru etc etc with which he washed it down was not half bad either.

A hush descended. The tables were artfully swept of every last crumb; the linen napkins changed for the fourth time. There appeared to be at least five waiters for each of the 10 tables.

The Italian maestro smiled. "Dessert, I suppose," he said. "I heard Ducasse has nine master patissiers in the kitchen. Is this true?"

The coupe café-chocolat, tasse de chocolat fort et brioche roti, was a quasi- religious experience.

Then a couple of hundred sous-chefs trooped out from Ducasse's kitchen and Bernard Naegellen, the amiable outgoing director of the 1,800-page French foodies' bible, the man who has made royalty of these 38 men - or rather 36 men and two women, both of the latter, intriguingly, Italian - got up to say a few words.

To be honest, I'm not quite sure what they were. Something about continued excellence, objectivity, incorruptibility, all that matters is on the plate. Cook for the customers, not the critics.

Next year, a Briton, Derek Brown, takes over as head of the guide. If they decide to give him a welcome nosh, I suppose I might be free.

webTitle: Government to rush through hunting bill

fields.headline: Government to rush through hunting bill
fields.trailText: The government is to rush through a ban on fox hunting by holding the bill's second reading on Monday December 18, the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, said yesterday. By Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
The government is to rush through a ban on fox hunting by holding the bill's second reading on Monday December 18, the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, said yesterday.

The haste suggests some ministers think there is a serious chance of forcing the bill on to the statute book before a May general election.

Alternatively, the government has calculated it is not averse to a fight with the Conservative rural lobby in the run-up to the election.

MPs will be given a free vote on three options. The key vote will be in a separate debate in the new year when MPs will take the bill as a committee of the whole house.

Once one of the options has been chosen the bill will be debated in detail by a smaller group of MPs in committee.

The procedure is the same as that used by the government to pilot deregulation of Sunday trading in the Shops Act. The three options, to be revealed in detail today when the bill is published, will be voluntary regulation, an outright ban, and licencing under a form of statutory regulation.

Downing Street indicated that the prime minister will vote for an outright ban.

Ms Beckett denied the decision to place the hunting bill so early in the timetable threatened to clog up the rest of its legislative programme, including its anti-crime measures.

Ms Beckett said: "All the Lords have to do is agree with what the Commons agrees then there is no need to clog anything up."

fields.headline: On the menu
fields.standfirst: Vongole
fields.trailText: Vongole
fields.body:
Vongole I know what they are. OK, smarty pants, what are they?

Clams as in spaghetti alla vongole. How true, oh wise one, but which clams?

What do you mean, which clams? Are they carpet-shell, venus, verni or palourde?

Any more? Cherrystone, quahog, pism, razor, hamaguri . . .

Stop, stop. I give in. Which are the ones for vongole? Actually they're palourdes, or verace in Italy, Noted for their delicacy and sweetness. And if you want to be really smart, ask if they come from the Golfo di Goro.

How can I tell them from all the others? They're no more than 5cm long, quite rounded, like a small cockle, and smooth.

Special report: EU integration
fields.trailText:
Europe editor Ian Black reports on an EU summit which sees 15 leaders haggling over a complex deal.
Special report: EU integration
fields.body:
Security barriers manned by watchful gendarmes and heavily- armed CRS riot police are not the most welcoming aspect of the European Union summit in Nice, whose lovely pink and ochre stucco Italianate buildings can hardly be seen for convoys of speeding VIP limousines and press buses.

But such distractions are a routine part of the bi-yearly talkfests that are billed as deciding the future of a continent. That is truer of this summit than many others, since rather than just issue a set of bland conclusions on matters ranging from BSE to maritime safety, Jacques Chirac and his fellow leaders have to sign up to a new EU treaty - designed to make creaking institutions work when new members from eastern Europe start joining the club in the next few years.

On Thursday morning, as the summiteers flew in, it was Seattle on the Riviera for a couple of telegenic hours: tear gas swirled and stones rained down as the anti-globalisation crowd plus a band of ragtag Basque and Corsican separatists vented their wrath on "fascism-capitalism".

But all was quiet along the palm-fringed Promenade des Anglais yesterday as the 15 leaders got down to business inside the giant Acropolis conference centre, haggling over the complex deal that will allow them to leave declaring success, bleary-eyed but happy, in the early hours of Sunday morning.

No one knows, at this stage, exactly what that deal will be, but there was no shortage of rumours swirling around the press centre, as diplomats from the member states and the EU institutions in Brussels chatted to journalists, handing out texts, spinning merrily about the nuances of national positions and generally feeding the insatiable media beast.

Of the big items that need to be sorted, the hottest is still the crucial question of how to "re-weight" votes in the decision-making council of ministers. The unionÕs four big boys, Germany, France, Britain and Italy, currently have 10 each while at the other end of the scale tiny Luxembourg has two.

With up to 13 new members likely to join the EU in the coming years, that must change, not least because the bigs worry increasingly about being outvoted by the smalls. Spain, the Netherlands and Belgium all want to increase their voting power.

But, however you look at it, the problem always comes back to that odd couple, France and Germany, the historical axis around which the European Community was founded back in 1957. Parity worked fine then, but since reunification, 82m Germans have had the same number of votes as 59m French citizens.

So everyone in Nice is agog: will Chirac agree to give Gerhard Schröder even a symbolic edge? According to one view, the issue has become so complex that France no longer considers a small concession on votes a taboo - if that is the only way to get an overall agreement on streamlining the EUÕs workings to prepare for enlargement.

But others argue that it is politically impossible for the Gaullist president to do this. And anyway, Germany might be prepared to stick with parity in return for agreement on a new intergovernmental conference in 2004 to review future constitutional arrangements, vital for Berlin because of pressure from the provincial governments or Länder.

If the outcome turns out to be simpler reweighting, the large states would have 30 votes, with Germany getting a token one to three more to reflect its far larger population. If that happened, the broader spread would leave more room to differentiate between medium and smaller countries.

Germany had originally supported a so-called double majority, in which any decision would need both a majority of country votes and a majority of the EUÕs 350m- plus population to pass.

These issues are so complex that even veteran experts and euro-bores - and there are many here in Nice - have trouble following them. But the end result would be to ensure that France retained as much influence as possible while finally accepting GermanyÕs post-unity status.

While pushing for a more faithful reflection of its added stature, Schröder has insisted the vote question is a "political issue, not a mathematical one". Intriguing stuff, though no one yet knows how it will all end.

The only certainty is that by the small hours of Sunday morning, some solution will miraculously emerge. "When you get to 11 or 12 oÕclock at night on the last night, then suddenly everything that is not resolved becomes tradeable," said one veteran negotiator.

And if all else fails, sleep deprivation and lack of other basic needs may do the trick: veterans of the 1997 Amsterdam summit remember one expedient that worked wonders in the last crucial stretch. The caterers ran out of food and a deal swiftly followed.

webTitle: A dress is for life, not just for Christmas

fields.headline: A dress is for life, not just for Christmas
fields.standfirst: You saw it hanging there and it stole your heart. Hadley Freeman on finding the perfect frock
fields.trailText: You saw it hanging there and it stole your heart. Hadley Freeman on finding the perfect frock
fields.body:
It is so draughty! They must be catching colds all the time!" shivers Daphne (Jack Lemmon) in Some Like it Hot, the first time (s)he wears a dress. But even Daphne appreciates the power of the dress after receiving jewellery and a proposal from a besotted millionaire. The right dress, it seems, brings out the feminine allure in all of us.

Certain fashion moments are deserving of hyperbole, so indulge me. Finding The Dress is like falling in love: you suddenly see yourself as desirable and idealised, timeless and elegant. It is a glorious ego trip. I found My Dress five years ago, unexpectedly, in a pokey shop in Cambridge. It is long, black and clinging, with a little trim on top, and it has got me through half a decade of parties, without ever becoming tedious. After a lifetime of sartorial one-night stands, the power of the truly stylish frock has been a revelation.

Elizabeth "That Dress" Hurley would seem to appreciate - indeed, owes her career to - the power of the frock, but hers are temporal affairs. Hurley-esque show stoppers are all very well, but they look gimmicky on the second outing, tired on the third. Equally, bypassing trends means you won't look like a fashion sheep, nor will your "perfect party dress" be unwearably passé within a month.

The high street is pretty good for dresses this season, Warehouse and Top Shop most notably. When it comes to designer labels, Colette Dinnigan and Elspeth Gibson are queens of the flattering but sexy gown. Diffusion labels (Versus, DKNY) can be better bets than the splashier offerings from the main line as they are less recognisable and less prone to timely fads, yet still very desirable.

This, of course, does not mean boring basics over fun frocks. But the point of a party dress is to draw attention to your own fabulous self, not the garment. That is what will provide you with the desired whiplash and gasps when you make your entrance. Cinderella-like, you feel magically transformed, as Daphne discovered. True fashion love is a very sweet thing indeed.

webTitle: Environment scheme fights waste on the beaches

fields.headline: Environment scheme fights waste on the beaches
fields.standfirst: Simon Parker talks to Durham county council project manager Ray Leonard about Turning the Tide, a major environmental regeneration project for the county's coastline aimed at dealing with waste from more than a century of coal mining and spoil tipping
fields.trailText: Simon Parker talks to Durham county council project manager Ray Leonard about Turning the Tide, a major environmental regeneration project for the county's coastline aimed at dealing with waste from more than a century of coal mining and spoil tipping.
fields.body:
Why did you decide to start the project? What problem was it created to solve?
The origins of the project can be traced to the political lobbying of central government in the 1950s by the two local authorities, Durham county council and Easington district council, over the National Coal Board's practice of disposing of colliery waste by tipping directly onto the beaches.

How did you go about putting it together? How and by whom was it funded, and what partners did you have to get involved?
The project has a long history. Over the last 50 years, even in the face of an active coal industry, policy documents were produced examining the potential of non-industrial areas of the coast, together with options for different methods of disposal by the coal industry.

While these documents demonstrated a commitment to the coastal environment, none of them brought in powers to enforce change, so they were destined to become shelf-bound and dusty. The local authorities were never going to be associated with forcing the mines to close, as the local population had few alternative employment options.

The collapse of the industry presented opportunities to address the coastal environment. The last colliery closed in 1993, however the National Trust began buying land on the coast prior to this.

This produced a natural partnership of the two authorities and the trust as the major landowners along the coast. Together with the Countryside Commission (now agency), they initiated a series of studies, which informed what became a successful bid to the Millennium Commission.

The commission was inviting bids for bold projects and had the capacity to fund very large schemes. The timescale for bids was particularly tight but, using the studies as a starting point, the partners sent in the project bid for Turning the Tide.

The commission announced an award of £4.5m in principle in December 1995, although negotiations were not completed until June 1997.

What did it cost?
The project is still active but we forecast a project cost of approximately £10.4m. The Millennium Commission supplied £4.5m, Durham county council £450,000, English Partnerships £2.2m, British Coal £510,000, the Countryside Agency £770,000, and European structural funds provided £1.2m. Smaller amounts of money came from a range of other sources.

How long did it take?
Although the programme was originally going to last five years, negotiation issues with the commission delayed the start. We began in earnest around spring 1997, and so will have been active for around four years when we formally wrap in March 2001.

Is it working?
Yes. The project is very broad in nature and it's difficult to summarise. The obvious physical changes have been very successful, and have been complemented with "softer" projects such as art projects, community consultation and involvement. A point worth making is the role of the Millennium Commission funding. While it is tied into the overall project objectives, we have been allowed to use it flexibly. Therefore, during the course of the programme as new opportunities have arisen or issues have forced change, we have been able to respond appropriately, rather than lose ground.

What difficulties did you encounter?
Negotiations with the Millennium Commission became lengthy and a little protracted. As a programme of 100 smaller projects, Turning the Tide did not fit easily into the standard funding contract, which had been developed around the single major project model.

Land purchase - the habitat reversion project relied on our ability to purchase specific agricultural land in the coastal zone. Although we had the finance, we had no immediate recourse to compulsory purchase orders. Initially, the landowners did not want to sell. Ultimately, we have purchased all the land targeted, but this has taken some time to assemble.

Community liaison - the project had been brought together so quickly it had little community endorsement. The challenge has been to inform, consult and involve the community in a programme of 100 projects being delivered in a tight timescale.

Project team - the team was recruited specifically for the project. As we are on fixed term contracts, the team is now fragmenting - a common experience. This is causing difficulty in maintaining the project delivery.

Would you recommend it to other authorities? Why?
The project reflects very specific issues facing the Durham coast. In terms of good practice, we feel there is a great deal to be learned from our experiences - and no doubt to be improved upon. It is worth noting that our principles of partnership were established before the funding opportunity arose - many partnerships are not too strong and do not survive post project. The Turning the Tide partners are already considering what to do next.

Would you do it again?
Yes. Whatever the issues, the principles and processes adopted in Turning the Tide should be compatible.

fields.headline: How social services are funded
fields.standfirst: Councils spend more on social services than any other sector apart from education. Steve Brown looks at where the money comes from
fields.trailText: Councils spend more on social services than any other sector apart from education. Steve Brown looks at where the money comes from.
fields.body:
How much do we spend on social services?
The Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy says this year's budget for England will hit £10.2bn.

Does government funding cover that cost?
No. According to the government, £9.4bn should be available for personal social services in England this year. Just over £700m of this is funded through specific and special grants, but the vast majority (£8.7bn), comes through local government's mind-bogglingly complicated standard spending assessment (SSA) system.

Try me.
SSAs signal the amount of council spending to which the government is prepared to contribute grant support. They apply to services such as education, social services, police, fire, highways and the environment and are used to allocate the revenue support grant, business rates and council tax.

Sounds very equitable...
Except that the SSA assesses the relative costs of providing comparable services between different authorities, not the absolute need of each. The key issue is how much ministers are prepared to feed into the machine. There is no doubt that the overall pot for social services is too small - with councils spending around 10% more than the sector's SSA.

Where does that extra money come from?
Although each major council-run service has its own SSA, councils are given a grant allocation which they can spend on services that take priority. "Overspending" on social services can translate into higher council taxes. However, since ministers still have some control over council tax levels, spending over the SSA on social services often means "underspending" on other council services such as libraries, rubbish collection, street cleaning or roads.

Are councils simply inefficient at running social services?
With the demand for services increasing, people living longer and higher expectations for quality of life, many social service costs are out of councils' control. The SSA simply hasn't kept pace with these pressures.

Is the situation sustainable?
Already councils are being forced to charge for services to meet growing demand. According to the audit commission, 94% of councils now charge for home care services, compared with 72% in 1992-93.

Is there any sign of change?
The government's priorities lie elsewhere. Although education spending is also above its SSA, local authorities are being forced to defer each year's increase in funding to schools. If councils increased social services funding in line with the SSA increase, council taxes in some authorities would be unacceptably high. So some councils have been forced to increase social services budgets by less than the level indicated by the SSA increase.

Is the SSA system the same throughout the UK?
In Wales councils receive a single SSA for all their services and the Welsh assembly has attempted to move SSAs into line with real spending. The £613m social services budget, not including specific grants, is a 7.6% increase on last year. While social services face the same pressures on funding as elsewhere, the assembly has made services for children a high priority following the Waterhouse report on child abuse.

Scottish "social work" funding operates along similar lines to that of England, although the terminology is different. For SSA, read grant aided expenditure (GAE). Like England, Scotland spends more on social work than its GAE, with the budget for 2000/2001 at £1.23bn - 7% higher than its GAE. Scotland's first minister, Henry McLeish, has indicated that he will reconsider the Sutherland commission findings on long term care, setting Scotland apart from England and Wales by giving elderly people free personal and nursing care.

In December, councils expect to receive three year grant allocations for the first time. Angus Skinner, Scotland's chief social work inspector, says this is a major step forward for social work departments. "The health service plans on a five year cycle and that is what we have to go for," he said. "Up to now it has been far too annualised."

And in Northern Ireland, social service funding is on a completely different footing. While the rest of the UK is desperate to foster better cooperation between the NHS and social services, Northern Ireland is already joined up. Its four health and social services boards deal with health and social care. But this too has its problems as the boards do not have access to local taxes to boost social care spending. If anything, symptoms of underfunding, such as bed blocking, are even more pronounced.

webTitle: Poor healthcare blamed for homeless deaths in Scotland

fields.headline: Poor healthcare blamed for homeless deaths in Scotland
fields.standfirst: The NHS is accused of providing the homeless with a second-rate service and placing lives in peril
fields.trailText: The NHS is accused of providing the homeless with a second-rate service and placing lives in peril. Barbara Millar reports
fields.body:
The reluctance of many homeless people to seek healthcare because they feel their health problems will remain undiagnosed or untreated is putting lives at risk, claims Tricia Hughes, director of The Big Issue magazine in Scotland.

Ms Hughes cites the recent case of 35-year-old Big Issue vendor Sammy Irvine who was taken by magazine staff to the accident and emergency department of a Glasgow hospital with abscesses on his legs. After a brief examination he was sent back to the hostel where he was living. Just 48 hours later he was rushed back into hospital, where he died.

"Homeless people are being given a second-rate health service and are dying as a result," says Ms Hughes. "The health problems faced by homeless people are horrific and the NHS is not geared up to dealing with them."

The Scottish executive's recent announcement that it is to appoint a health and homeless co-ordinator to champion the health needs of Scotland's homeless is welcomed by Ms Hughes.

"But, at the end of the day, it is just one post," she adds. "We will need an exceptional individual to take up this job if it is ever going to make a difference to homeless people dying on the streets."

The health and homeless policy co-ordinator's post is intended to help primary care trusts and health boards to develop strategies to meet the specific health needs of homeless people. The postholder will also be responsible for spreading good practice and creating training programmes.

An existing Scotland-wide homelessness/health network already brings together health workers who deal with the homeless - primarily from primary care trusts - and has been sharing good practice on an informal basis. The new co-ordinator role is seen as providing more structure to this approach, as well as giving more direct access to the Scottish executive.

Shelter Scotland, which has welcomed the new co-ordinator initiative, estimates that on any given night there are between 500 and 1,000 rough sleepers in Scotland, compared with a figure of around 1,200 rough sleepers per night across England.

Dr Laurence Gruer, a consultant in public health medicine with the Greater Glasgow health board, believes the number of rough sleepers in Scotland could be greatly reduced.

A 1998 health board survey in Glasgow found just 55 people sleeping rough in the city. Dr Gruer says the biggest cause of homelessness in Glasgow stems from the 6,000-plus people a year who are forced to stay in a hostel because they have no home of their own.

Recent figures reveal that 70% of Scotland's homeless who live in hostels are in Glasgow, adds Dr Gruer. Homeless hostel dwellers tend to be men (85%), some 60% of whom have severe alcohol dependency problems. A further 25% (75% of whom are aged 25-44) have drug dependency problems, mainly heroin addiction.

A high percentage of homeless suffer from depression, anxiety and panic attacks. The lack of a good diet often leads to gastric problems and many experience difficulty accessing the services of a dentist, chiropodist or optician.

Although many homeless are technically registered with a GP, this is usually in the area in which they used to live. In any case, they often find it difficult to make an appointment with a GP because of the chaotic nature of their lives, says Dr Gruer. Others find it difficult even to register with a GP, using a hospital accident and emergency department when necessary, which is often inappropriate for ongoing health needs.

In an attempt to improve access of services to the homeless, a new £1.2m city-centre facility in Edinburgh called Access Point provides housing advice, social services, benefits information and healthcare. A GP and practice nurse are available 8.30am-5.30pm Monday-Friday on an open referral basis. Funding for the centre was provided by Edinburgh city council, Lothian primary care trust and the Rough Sleepers Initiative.

In Glasgow, a healthcare team with the remit to deliver services exclusively to the city's homeless is being provided by the Greater Glasgow primary care trust. The team offers chiropody, dentistry, dietary services, physiotherapy, well woman services and psychiatric services. Funding has recently been identified to create a team of doctors, nurses and social workers to work in the city's hostels, specifically helping homeless people with drug and alcohol problems.

"Unless you deal with the drug and alcohol problems effectively you cannot help people extricate themselves from their homeless situation," says Dr Gruer. He adds that the health and homeless co-ordinator should be able to ensure resources are efficiently targeted rather than being frittered away by fragmentation and duplication.

fields.headline: Rapid reaction force 'not Euro army'
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: EU leaders meeting in Nice have reached an agreement on the proposed rapid reaction force, and declared that it is not a European army.
fields.body:
EU leaders meeting in Nice have reached an agreement on the proposed rapid reaction force, and declared that it is not a European army.

The force will retain links with Nato despite claims from the French president Jacques Chirac yesterday that it would be independent.

His remarks led many to speculate that the rapid reaction force would split Nato but, said Tony Blair's official spokesman, such claims were "hysterical nonsense".

Europe minister Keith Vaz said that the 60,000-strong force would only be used when Nato was not involved.

And Mr Chirac sought to reassure the plan's critics: "No one in Europe is in any way questioning the importance or the status of the Atlantic alliance," he said.

"There is no reason to be concerned. Europe is going to make its own contribution to its own security."

The EU wants the rapid reaction force to give it an autonomous capacity to make military decisions and, where NATO as a whole is not engaged, conduct EU-led military operations.

That force will require permanent political and military bodies to run it. It is expected to be complete in 2003.

webTitle: MPs given chance to ban fox hunting

fields.headline: MPs given chance to ban fox hunting
fields.standfirst: Special report: Hunting debate
fields.trailText: MPs will be given the chance to ban fox hunting in a controversial government bill that was unveiled today.
fields.body:
MPs will be given the chance to ban fox hunting in a controversial government bill that was unveiled today.

Home office minister Mike O'Brien said that they would receive a free vote on three options - self regulation through an independent supervisory body, a licensing regime to regulate hunting, and a ban on all hunting with dogs, except in a few limited circumstances.

If MPs vote to outlaw the sport, as is expected, peers will still have the opportunity to debate all the options when the Hunting Bill reaches the Lords.

Mr O'Brien said that the government remained neutral on the issue.

He said: "This is an important and controversial issue as has been evidenced by the space given to it in the newspapers and by the amount of correspondence we get here on it.

"Lots of attempts have been made to deal with hunting by way of private members' bills but all have failed. Our hope is that, by bringing forward a government bill, we can deal with the contentious issue in a clear and straightforward way."

The second reading debate takes place on Monday December 18, followed by a committee stage on the floor of the Commons.

The minister added: "The government is neutral on the issue and individual MPs will be able to vote as they feel appropriate."

The bill proposes a maximum £5,000 penalty for breaking a hunting ban.

Prince Charles enjoys foxhunting, but Mr O'Brien confirmed there have been no discussions with the royal family about the bill.

However, a clash between the Commons and the Lords is almost certain.

When asked if the view of the elected chamber will prevail in the event that MPs vote for a ban and peers support one of the other options, Mr O'Brien replied: "Procedures of parliament will be followed.

"Both the Commons and the Lords have their appropriate role, and the Commons is obviously the elected chamber."

Urged to disclose whether ministers would use the Parliament Act to steamroller the bill into law if the Lords refuses to accept a total ban, Mr O'Brien said: "Obviously, the Parliament Act is available, but we've made no decision on whether to use it.

"That will be a matter for the Commons rather than the government."

The Countryside Alliance warns that thousands of rural jobs will disappear if a ban comes in, but Mr O'Brien confirmed that there are no plans for compensation.

He added that the alliance had a "democratic right to protest", provided it was done peacefully and did not disrupt the lives of others.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said: "I believe that this bill should allow the issue of hunting properly to be resolved.

"It is plainly an issue which arouses strong views on all sides of the argument."

The Home Office has received 100,000 letters from the public about hunting since 1997, showing opinion fairly evenly divided on the issue. Public opinion polls however, are in favour of a ban.

Richard Burge, chief executive of the Countryside Alliance, said that the Bill "curtails a rural minority's civil liberty, with no benefits for the rural majority or for animal welfare".

Douglas Batchelor, chairman of pressure group Deadline 2000 and chief executive of the League Against Cruel Sports, said: "Parliament has debated hunting many times before but never with a government bill and a guarantee of parliamentary time.

"This is an historic opportunity to finally end this cruel and barbaric practice which has no place in a modern society."

The shadow home affairs minister, David Lidington said: "This bill is a classic example of Labour's warped sense of priorities. They have no time for a bill on adoption, no time for legislation on seizing criminals' assets or on corruption, no time to update the mental health laws, yet there is time for a fox-hunting bill."

He said that it was wrong to "criminalise the many thousands of decent, law-abiding citizens who take part" in hunting.

fields.headline: Fear of backlash muzzles the media
fields.standfirst:
Royalty: hypocrisy unites writers and readers

Special report: the future of the monarchy
Join the debate online
fields.trailText: Royalty: hypocrisy unites writers and readers
fields.body:
"God bless you, ma'am", shout the atheist republican news editors. "Long live the Queen," cry the muck raking royal correspondents. "May the Windsors reign for ever," chorus newspaper proprietors, editors and circulation directors. For here is just the first of a series of paradoxes which must be unravelled before we can grasp the hypocritical attitude towards royalty by the people who own, edit, write for and read the modern press.

Most owners and their journalists, whether from right or left, are wedded to the concept of a classless society. Free market meritocrats who seek the cliched level playing field are as withering about the nature of inherited privilege as the egalitarians of the left. But these basically anti-monarchist proselytisers for freedom of thought and freedom of the press dare not tell their readers what they really think.

Tabloids, the papers with mass circulations, have been particularly shy, though in recent years some columnists - notably Richard Littlejohn in the Sun - have been allowed to advance their "controversial" views. Campaigning day after day against the euro is fine. Editors have never contemplated - or dared - doing the same to monarchy.

Why? Because they believe there is such widespread and deep public support for the royal family that they might face a backlash from readers. The monarchy does have one rabid press champion, as yesterday's Daily Telegraph illustrated. It ran six separate articles prompted by the Guardian's call for a referendum on the monarchy. A leader writer huffed while the court and social writer puffed. But columnist Daniel Johnson stooped to make the lowest bow. The Guardian campaign is both ludicrous and sinister, he wrote, though that description more aptly fitted his own assertion of some of the monarch's greatest virtues: her cosmopolitan appeal to ethnic minorities; her stabilising political role; and the sense of continuity represented by inherited privilege.

Now we come to the second paradox. Editors, based on a century of experience since the dawn of popular papers, believe royalty is a seller. Good, upbeat, stage managed stories sell. But exposures of private behaviour sell best of all. Yet editors also know that the revelation of royal family secrets tends to bring the monarchy into disrepute. By training the spotlight on them, they undermine the notion of the family's supposedly special place at the apex of society.

That's a risk they are prepared to take since they are working for commercial entities which must maximise sales and profits. The initial peeling away of the royal magic during the 1950s was tentative, but its anti-deferential spirit still managed to upset the Queen and her advisers. Hugh Cudlipp, editorial director of the Daily Mirror, led the charge. One of his most famous front pages shocked the palace by implying that the young Queen and her husband, who was in Gibraltar while she was in England, were having marital difficulties. "Fly Home, Philip!" said the headline, to kill "ridiculous and baseless" rumours.

In another sally from the same period, the Mirror made an unsubtle attempt to pierce the wall of silence about Princess Margaret's romance with Peter Townsend with a front page demand: "Come on Margaret, Please Make Up Your Mind". This kind of timid criticism was rare, although the Daily Sketch, then edited by Bert Gunn, a sort of 1950s Kelvin MacKenzie, got into trouble when one of its reporters attempted to smuggle herself into the Duke of Kent's wedding reception in the back of a car. Gunn thumbed his nose at the resulting censure by the Press Council but also obsequiously apologised to the palace. And so it has been ever since, through Margaret's rocky love life, Prince Charles's upbringing and his romances, culminating in the press orgy over the most saleable non-royal royal of all, Princess Diana. The papers have intruded and retreated, feigning abject sorrow for any hurt caused to her majesty, then waiting for the next opportunity to intrude all over again.

Despite their pledges of good behaviour they just can't help themselves. The Windsors star in Britain's real-life soap opera. And here is the third paradox: the family needs the press as much as the press needs the family. They cannot afford to retreat entirely from the public gaze because that risks alienating people.

So they have courted publicity only to find that it is impossible to draw a line. That takes us to the fourth paradox. The public consumes and condemns with equal enthusiasm. Readers lap up the stories and pictures, then they decry the methods used to obtain them. It is this deep vein of hypocrisy which lies at the heart of the whole enigma. The monarch is a golden goose which the public, through the press, is bound to kill.

Since Diana's death, some of the palace's newer and wiser advisers have realised this fact. Hence the subtle marketing of Prince Charles, culminating recently in his being pictured with an Aids baby in his arms, and the trenchant protection of Prince William. For the moment the press appears to be dancing to the palace's tune. It cannot last. This is a celebrity driven age in which the public cannibalises its idols and the royal family are the ultimate celebrities. The next intrusion, in the public interest of course, is just around the corner.

fields.headline: The fading intifada
fields.standfirst:
Arafat's command over Palestine's militant factions, shaky at best, now looks increasingly under threat, writes Derek Brown.
Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Arafat's command over Palestine's militant factions, shaky at best, now looks increasingly under threat, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
After ten weeks of bloodshed, the Palestinian uprising is beginning to lose its grisly momentum.

It's not over - an Israeli woman teacher was killed his morning in an ambush in the occupied West Bank - but there are signs of war-weariness among the teeming and impoverished Palestians.

More dangerously, there are also signs of growing disillusion with the Palestinian leadership. There cannot be an confidence that the plethora of militant factions will pay any heed to Palestinian National Authority president Yasser Arafat's latest order to cease firing on Israeli troops.

Some groups, notable in the West Bank town of Nablus, have already abandoned their guns, in protest against PNA corruption and incompetence. Others, like the gunmen who killed Jewish settler Rina Didovski this morning, are simply ignoring the president.

Arafat's authority has never been more shaky. He has always been used to absolute power within the Fatah and PLO movements, and the unqualified sycophancy of all around him. But for the past five years he has been responsible not for a movement, but for a fledgling state.

The tiresome details of administration, and the rising swell of opposition, often seem to baffle and even paralyse him. He has been in indifferent health for years, and there is rising speculation about a successor - never easy in a system which stifles dissent.

For two and a half months, Arafat has exorted his people to ever greater sacrifice. They have responded not nobly but well. Of the 300 deaths and 10,000 woundings, an overwhelming majority of the victims have been Palestinian.

Not a single life in the seedy, flyblown Palestinian territories has been untouched by the turmoil, and even more by the Israeli security blockade. Some 120,000 workers have been denied their livelihoods in Israel. Food and medical supplies are running perilously low. Ever since Arafat returned to Palestine in the mid-1990s in the wake of the Oslo peace accord, the people there have had an ambivalent attitude to him. They gave him a delirious welcome as the father of the revolution and the putative head of the dreamed-for sovereign state.

Much less welcome were the legions of cronies who followed Arafat home from exile in Tunis and elsewhere. They were given all the plum jobs in the new administration and they remain an elite, in a society which had endured more than a generation of Israeli occupation.

Disillusion with the PNA was put aside when the intifada erupted. Now it is resurfacing in the bitter realisation that once again the people have suffered, while the leadership is unscathed.

fields.bodyText: After ten weeks of bloodshed, the Palestinian uprising is beginning to lose its grisly momentum. It's not over - an Israeli woman teacher was killed his morning in an ambush in the occupied West Bank - but there are signs of war-weariness among the teeming and impoverished Palestians. More dangerously, there are also signs of growing disillusion with the Palestinian leadership. There cannot be an confidence that the plethora of militant factions will pay any heed to Palestinian National Authority president Yasser Arafat's latest order to cease firing on Israeli troops. Some groups, notable in the West Bank town of Nablus, have already abandoned their guns, in protest against PNA corruption and incompetence. Others, like the gunmen who killed Jewish settler Rina Didovski this morning, are simply ignoring the president. Arafat's authority has never been more shaky. He has always been used to absolute power within the Fatah and PLO movements, and the unqualified sycophancy of all around him. webTitle: Bell prepares to stand against evangelical Conservatives

fields.headline: Bell prepares to stand against evangelical Conservatives
fields.trailText: Former BBC war correspondent Martin Bell today announced his "provisional" intention to stand as an independent at the next general election, despite making a promise when first elected that he would be a one-term MP.
fields.body:
Former BBC war correspondent Martin Bell today announced his "provisional" intention to stand as an independent at the next general election, despite making a promise when first elected that he would be a one-term MP.

Mr Bell, dressed in his trademark white suit, announced his plan to contest a Tory-held seat in Essex. He told a press conference in the Brentwood and Ongar constituency today that being an MP was "the best thing" that had ever happened to him, and he regretted his tactical decision to stand only once.

It was important to maintain an independent presence in the House of Commons, he said.

He had been invited to stand for the seat by concerned locals amid claims that the local Conservative constituency association has been infiltrated by evangelical Christians from a local church.

The seat was held for the Conservatives at the last general election by Eric Pickles with a majority of 9,690, making it the sixth safest Tory seat in the country.

Since then, however, some 200 members of the charismatic Peniel Pentecostal Church have enrolled in the local party and voted their members into key posts, including the deputy chairman of the constituency association.

A number of ousted party members, who formed an independent conservative group, subsequently contacted Mr Bell expressing concern about the influence wielded by the church in the party.

However, Mr Bell faces a tough fight to hold on to his place in parliament. In 1997, Conservative and Liberal Democrat candidates stood down to allow him a clear run.

This time, neither party looks likely to be so helpful. Brentwood and Ongar Liberal Democrat prospective parliamentary candidate David Kendall said that the party would fight Mr Bell for the seat.

"We knew the Independent Conservatives were going to stand at this election, the only question was over who their candidate would be. Now it seems likely it will be Martin Bell," he said.

"Although Martin will be standing as an independent, locally, a lot of people know he has the backing of the Independent Conservatives," Mr Kendall told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

fields.headline: Unpicking church and state raises tangled questions
fields.standfirst:
Disestablishment: some clerics fear change would mean legislative marathon

Special report: the future of the monarchy
Join the debate online
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Disestablishment: some clerics fear change would mean legislative marathon
fields.body:
Constitutionalists, bishops and politicians took a huge intake of breath yesterday at the prospect of the mountainous legislative processes that would be required for the disestablishment of the Church of England and the parliamentary time it would take up.
Many see disestablishment - the disentangling of the Church of England from the constitutional fabric of the state - as an inevitable consequence of the repeal of the 1701 Act of Settlement. But while some view the process as having limited value for the amount of legislative time taken up, there are plenty in Parliament and the Church of England who believe it would free both sides to fulfil their proper roles in society.

A two line Commons early day motion calling on the government to disestablish the church began to draw signatures yesterday but disestablishment would not be a simple process.

At least a dozen acts of parliament would be required for it to be repealed, together with an unravelling of current constitutional relations with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland and the 15 Commonwealth countries of which the Queen is also head of state. Even the domestic church settlement would require untangling: who would appoint bishops and deans and would they continue to sit in the House of Lords? Who would assume responsibility for the upkeep of the 40% of the country's listed buildings which are churches?


Who would bear the future cost of the clergy? Who would meet the full future cost of church schools? Who would own the Royal Peculiars such as Westminster Abbey? Many church buildings predate the Reformation and were gifted to the Church of England by Queen Anne - would they revert to the monarch and then have to be gifted anew? Would the Roman Catholic Church have a claim on its old properties?
What would be the employment status of chaplains in the armed services? Should ordained clergy be allowed to stand for Parliament for the first time since 1801? What would happen to canon law and would it be testable in secular courts? Some of the answers may be obvious but all would require legislation, giving plenty of scope for supporters of the status quo to mobilise parliamentary opposition and needing plenty of government stamina and determination. Disestablishment of the church in Wales took place in 1920 but only after previous bills had been defeated in 1886, 1892, 1894, 1909 and 1912.
The Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt, bishop of Winchester and the church's spokesman on constitutional affairs said: "If I may mix a metaphor, it's like a ball of string with many ends and it is extraordinary how quickly if you pull one of them you will find yourself ending up in deep water.î It is easy to find bishops, like Mark Santer, bishop of Birmingham, who pronounce themselves relaxed about the prospect of disestablishment. ÜI don't think it would be the end of the world,î he said. Senior clergy such as Canon Paul Oestreicher or the Venerable George Austin, former archdeacon of York, from different political perspectives, say the move would enable the church to stand on its own feet and concentrate on its religious mission.
But others are less sure. The Rev Keith Sinclair, rector of the parish church standing next to Aston Villa's stadium in Birmingham, says other faiths often look to the local vicar for a lead in the community precisely because of the church's perceived status. To start the process of diesestablishment, the general synod of the Church of England would almost certainly have to make the first move. It is doubtful if there is an appetite for this.
A senior official at Church House, centre of the C of E's bureaucracy, said: "Parliament would have to create a new church body to inherit the assets of the current church, so politicians would still have a role in settling the structure. It would be an absurdity. Just as a rail company is not owned by the people who happen to be on the train at the time, the Church does not belong just to the people who attend it. Everyone has a view on what the Church of England does, even if they never go to services. You would have to de-spiritualise the expectations of the nation.

webTitle: CHI head Homa to talk online

fields.headline: CHI head Homa to talk online
fields.standfirst: Peter Homa, head of the commission for health improvement, will be online Wednesday, December 13, to answer your questions about NHS inspections
fields.trailText: Peter Homa, head of the commission for health improvement, will be online Wednesday, December 13, to answer your questions about NHS inspections
fields.body:
He may not like being dubbed "the Chris Woodhead of the NHS", but that slighly perjorative soubriquet reflects the fears among many in the NHS over the role of Peter Homa, and the organisation he heads, the commission for health improvement (CHI).

Mr Woodhead, the former head of the infamous education regulator Ofsted, became well known for his "naming and shaming" of poor-performing schools and teachers and his uncompromising critiques of the education system.

Mr Homa has insisted that he does not want CHI to inherit Ofsted's "hit squad" reputation. He said he wants a more constructive, collaborative relationship with the NHS bodies he inspects, with the aim of improving standards of patient care.

But are NHS staff right to worry that they will be "named and shamed" Ofsted-style? Is CHI necessary, or is it just another expensive and time-consuming level of bureacracy? Will it improve standards, or cramp the style of medical professionals?

CHI publishes its first clinical governance reviews next Wednesday, December 13, and you can post questions to Mr Homa who will be conducting a live online interview the same day in Talk.

Peter Homa: a brief cv
Peter Homa is director for the Commission of Health Improvement. After completing the NHS National Management Training Scheme in London in 1981, he gained extensive healthcare management experience working in various hospitals in England and Canada.

In 1989, Peter joined The Leicester Royal Infirmary and became unit general manager and subsequently chief executive. In 1998, Peter was selected to create and lead the NHS executive's national patients' access team to help reduce the number of patients waiting for NHS treatment.

In August 1999, Peter was appointed inaugural director for the Commission for Health Improvement and received a CBE for services to health care in the 2000 Queen's birthday honours list.

 Post your question now in Talk

fields.headline: BBC2 unveils winter schedule
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: BBC2's winter schedule includes an epic drama, three new gardening programmes and a Weird Weekend with Paul Daniels, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
TalkBack Productions' epic drama, In a Land of Plenty, will form the centrepiece of BBC2's winter programming line-up.

The 10 x 60-minute series, adapted from Tim Pears' novel, follows one middle-class family over 40 years.

BBC2 will also be launching three new gardening programmes. The Garden with Dan Pearson sees one of Britain's most influential and innovative garden designers offering horticultural tips.

Also hitting the screens are The Curious Gardeners, featuring Gordon Taylor and Guy Cooper, and The Flying Gardener presented by Chris Beardshaw.

BBC2 festive highlights over Christmas include Gary Lineker fronting a new family-friendly science series called Are You Superhuman? about the power of the human body.

Trouble at the Top will try to unravel the last 12 tumultuous months at the beleaguered Millennium Dome.

Master of horror Christopher Lee will add a chilling edge to the Christmas schedule with readings of ghost stories by MR James.

Other winter highlights on BBC2 include new comedy with The Royle Family's Ralf Little joining Coronation Street's Beverley Callard in a new show called Two Pints of Lager (and a Packet of (Crisps).

Interviewer Louis Theroux returns to BBC2 spending a Weird Weekend with comedian Paul Daniels and his wife, Debbie McGee.

BBC2 will also be marking the 100th anniversary of the death of Queen Victoria with a week of dedicated programmes. A series of documentaries will sketch a social history of her reign examining issues ranging from the Victorian psyche to the architecture of the time.

webTitle: Community strategies key to future of local government

fields.headline: Community strategies key to future of local government
fields.standfirst: The Local Government Act 2000 received royal assent in July, but only now are some of its key provisions making their presence felt, writes Dermott Calpin
fields.trailText: The Local Government Act 2000 received royal assent in July, but only now are some of its key provisions making their presence felt, writes Dermott Calpin
fields.body:
The Local Government Act 2000, which received royal assent in July, has ushered in a whole new era for local government, paving the way for directly elected mayors in towns and cities and, where there is no strong public support for this option, allowing councils to set up new-style cabinet systems.

These developments represent the most radical overhaul of the traditional committee system in more than 100 years, and form a central part of Prime Minister Tony Blair's determination to establish modern forms of local governance as part of a larger project to modernise government as a whole.

Just as important as these new forms of political management, the Act also includes new wide-ranging powers for councils to work in partnership with other organisations to improve the quality of life in their communities.

This new power to "promote the economic, social and environmental wellbeing" of their areas is a pivotal feature of the legislation. In the long run, it could prove to be far more radical and far-reaching than the introduction of elected mayors.

A white paper published in July 1998 set out an ambitious framework for the future of modern local government. It repeatedly emphasised the importance of partnerships, public involvement and consultation.

This theme is central to the idea of community planning, and to the development of community strategies as a key link between the drive for political management reforms and the emphasis that best value places on improving service quality and efficiency.

For Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, the arrival of community strategies signals a cultural shift in the way councils work and relate to their communities. "They will give local people a chance to develop a long-term vision for their area and help set out how their aspirations will be delivered," she says.

Draft guidance on preparing community strategies was published in June 2000. Local authority leaders now expect the final regulations to be published in early December, when Ms Armstrong is due to speak at a Local Government Association conference on community leadership.

Though many local authorities feel under pressure to deliver direct services, the new legislation clearly stresses their community leadership role. The white paper said: "Councils are the organisations best placed to take a comprehensive overview of the needs and priorities of their local areas and communities."

This role is underpinned by the new legislation. But the new duty to promote the "wellbeing of communities" is not something which councils can exercise in isolation. They are expected to work closely in partnership with, and to consult widely with, other local organisations - businesses, voluntary associations and residents groups - in drawing up their community plans.

Community plans allow councils to develop more ambitious overarching or "joined-up" strategies for improving quality of life in their areas. They can do this by bringing services together to address broader issues, such as health or regeneration needs.

Community plans are likely to incorporate the broad emphasis on sustainable development put forward by earlier Local Agenda 21 sustainable development initiatives. But they should also inform the fine detail of best value performance plans that will set out concrete proposals for improving quality of life for people in their areas.

webTitle: Haines set to take over at the IPA

fields.headline: Haines set to take over at the IPA
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Leagas Delaney chairman Bruce Haines is set to become the next president of the Institute of Practioners in Advertising, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Bruce Haines, the Leagas Delaney chairman, is set to become the next president of the Institute of Practioners in Advertising.

He has been adopted as the IPA's presidential candidate. If formally elected, Mr Haines will succeed Rupert Howell, the HHCL & Partners chairman, whose two-year term of office ends next April.

Mr Haines is one of advertising's most successful businessmen. His agency has recently been acquired by Canadian group Envoy Communications for £59m.

Two years ago, Mr Haines was instrumental in staging the agency's buyout from Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO for just £4m.

Since the buyout, the agency has seen huge growth in its home market, the establishment of successful offices in San Francisco, Paris, Rome and Hamburg plus a standalone new media company, The Digital Partners, in London.

Leagas Delaney is responsible for high-profile campaigns for Adidas and Barclays.

Mr Haines will complete a new senior front-line at the IPA, which is seeking a replacement for Nick Phillips, its director-general, who retires next summer.

Mr Howell, one of the UK's most high-profile agency chiefs, will be seen as a tough act to follow at the IPA where he has been an enthusiastic public defender of the industry.

fields.headline: Night of storms kills two
fields.standfirst: Special report: weather watch
fields.trailText: A couple were today found dead in a flooded Devon river after a night of torrential storms and gales across southern Britain.
fields.body:
A couple were today found dead in a flooded Devon river after a night of torrential storms and gales across southern Britain.

The woman's body was found in a car floating upside down in the river close to the village of Cheriton Fitzpaine, near Crediton in Devon.

Her companion in the vehicle was swept away by strong currents and his body was later recovered by police.

The car appears to have smashed through wooden railings on a bridge and then plummeted into the flood-swollen river.

Linda Mawson, whose home overlooks the accident spot, discovered the car while checking her home for storm damage and called the police.

"Just a few yards down the stream I saw the car. The water was a raging torrent, it was very scary. I couldn't have done anything," she said.

The first officer on the scene tried desperately to get the woman out of the car but, said a spokesman for Devon and Cornwall police, was too traumatised to talk about the rescue bid.

Five severe flood warnings have been issued by the Environment Agency in Wales, the Midlands and southern England and a further 152 flood warnings are in force across England and Wales. Rain fell overnight in some parts of the country that are still recovering from the recent floods.

The highest rainfall was recorded in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire, where 1.6in fell in 12 hours. During the same period, England and Wales were deluged with around a half to a third of an inch of rain.

At the height of the storm west Wales was practically cut off from the rest of the country when two major roads into the region were closed by flooding.

Coastguards and police, all in wetsuits, rescued a man who was stuck up to his waist in mud at a flooded caravan park in Dawlish Warren, Devon.

The rescuers called a helicopter from RAF Chivenor to join efforts to evacuate more than 90 people - including a number of pensioners - from the site after it was cut off by rising waters. The residents were taken to safety at a leisure centre in the nearby coastal town of Dawlish.

Several people had to be rescued from their cars after getting stuck in rising waters.

Train operator First Great Western says that rail services in south west England will be disrupted for up to a week because of a flooded bridge north of Taunton.

"There is still widespread road flooding across the region, as well as a lot of debris and branches," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Going to war against climate change

fields.headline: Going to war against climate change
fields.standfirst: The post-Hague hiatus may provide an opportunity to address the problems of climate change, says Andrew Simms
fields.trailText: The post-Hague hiatus may provide an opportunity to address the problems of climate change, says Andrew Simms.
fields.body:
After the Hague summit, a meeting in Bonn, in May 2001 will provide the next opportunity for politicians from industrialised countries to agree how to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The current target for developed countries is a 5.2% overall emissions reduction. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) says that 60 - 80% is needed, while the head of the UN Environment Programme puts the figure at 90%. Fogged by diplomatic incidents the way forward becomes harder.

The potential loopholes in the Kyoto Protocol meant that a bad agreement in the Hague could have been worse than none. The original negotiating position of the United States allowed for a deal that might have led not to a cut in greenhouse gas emissions, but a 14 per cent increase over the period 1990 - 2010. Some said that the manipulation of so-called carbon sinks was a form of carbon laundering.

Indeed, the current hiatus could turn out to be an opportunity. Firstly, because people are increasingly aware that the consequences of declining fossil fuel resources and climate change cannot be avoided. And secondly, because more coherent solutions than the Kyoto Protocol are being promoted and gathering support.

In 1965 discoveries of new oil sources peaked. Thirty-five years later the growth in oil production has also peaked and begun its long decline. In 1998, adding together total world energy demand over the next few decades with known or anticipated available fuel sources, the International Energy Agency noticed there was a gap between supply and potential demand.

To fill the gap it used something called "unidentified unconventional" fuel sources. But this fuel didn't actually exist, it was an exercise in creative accounting to stop policy makers from worrying. Looking ahead for the next few decades, uncertain comfort is now available from new projections that fill the supply-demand gap with fossil fuels that have only a 5% chance of discovery.

Statistically, neither sinks nor better efficiency can make the necessary cuts in emissions, or deal with declining oil supplies. Over a 200 year period efficiency would need to improve nearly 200 thousand per cent. It seems we must brace ourselves for the equivalent of an environmental war economy in order to reduce consumption.

Past experience shows that the shift to a low-energy economy needn't be all bad. The alternative of business-as-usual also looks far worse. Projections based on data collected by the reinsurance giant Munich Re show that by about the year 2065 the economic costs of climate change could surpass the value of total world economic output. Already by 2025, half of all people living in developing countries will be vulnerable to extreme weather events, floods and storms according to the UN.

Conventional economic growth is hard-wired to rising greenhouse gas emissions and concentrations - the so-called lock-step. The question is how to break that lock-step and manage our withdrawal from fossil-fuels in as painless a way as possible, within an orderly framework?

Transport, trade and agriculture are the parts of our economy that are especially fuel-addicted. But given the right approach and the necessary policy tools there is no reason why we cannot turn things around and benefit from the process. During the Second World War we adapted to measures for radical resource conservation. Even in the United States fuel was strictly rationed to eliminate unnecessary travel.

At the moment the internal dynamics of globalisation are making us more, not less, fuel dependent. Air freight, the most polluting transport mode, has gone from virtually zero fifty years ago, to the equivalent of flying one ton of goods over 100 billion kilometres a year. New generations of planes are being built, thirsty for fossil fuel, which will need to fly for decades still to pay-off construction costs.

There is a model called contraction and convergence rapidly gaining support. Already backed by many developing countries, its principles were endorsed in The Hague by Belgium, France and Sweden and it accords with the US desire for a truly global solution. Pioneered by the London-based Global Commons Institute it was also recently endorsed by the Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution. It works by setting a global cap on greenhouse gas concentrations, with an emissions budget that is reduced over time. Tradable emissions rights are then pre-distributed on a per-capita basis, converging globally to equal shares per person by an agreed date, for example 2030.

While the city of Bonn may no longer house the German government, next May it will be at the centre of the most important international negotiation there is.


• Andrew Simms is head of the global economy programme at the New Economics Foundation and co-author of: Collision Course - Free trade's free ride on the global climate

fields.headline: Tonight twins special draws 6m
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald special on conjoined twins Jodie and Mary drew a good audience last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald special, which featured the first interview with the parents of conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, drew a good audience last night despite being dropped into the schedule at the last minute.

The Tonight special, which had been heavily trailed in national newspapers following Wednesday's partial lifting of a high court reporting ban, averaged 5.9m - a third of available viewers - between 10-11pm last night.

The BBC's Ten O'Clock News got 5m viewers - a 25% share.

On BBC1 earlier in the evening, an average of 6.2m tuned in to watch Liverpool progressing to the next stage of the Uefa Cup on Match of the Day Live from 8-10pm.
