fields.headline: Waterstone's war gets dirty
fields.trailText: Small publishers hit back, clicks and mortar booksellers take the lead, and Bloomsbury takes branding to heart
fields.body:
As the book trade gears up for what many believe to be the most important Christmas bookselling season since... well, since last year's, there is little indication of the spirit of goodwill infiltrating the trade at the end of what has been a divisive year.

It is over a week since about 600 small and medium publishers wrote to the Office of Fair Trading claiming that the nation's largest dedicated bookseller, Waterstone's, was abusing its market position by demanding new supply terms of 50% (see previous column). It may be the festive season but there are no signs that David Kneale, Waterstone's increasingly embattled managing director, is about to have a Scrooge-like reawakening and send Turkey-flavoured balms to his suppliers in the shape of softer terms demands.

Mr Kneale has recently gone public to say that he will not go public, telling the trade press last week: "I won't debate our commercial terms in public." Unfortunately for Mr Kneale, everyone else will. But, as has been pointed out in the letters pages of some newspapers, publishers are not without a card trick or two. Those who have sent unordered books to Waterstone's befuddled warehouse in the hope that the books will inveigle their way on to the shop floor are being particularly unhelpful.

Clicks and mortar take the lead

There was one piece of good news for Waterstone's this week, along with other clicks and mortar booksellers (ie those with both high street shops and an online offering). Internet consultant Forrester produced an e-tailer power chart showing that Amazon.com has been knocked off the number one spot by Borders.com, the US internet bookseller that is also America's second largest high street bookstore. Forrester suggests that, with the profile of internet users becoming less 'techie', this could be the start of a trend.

Clicks and mortar booksellers could pick up greater numbers of customers by dint of their online store's natural affinity with their high street stores. According to Forrester, unless Amazon can build a strong link with an offline retailer and offer such things as local store delivery or return/exchange of books, it will be at a disadvantage when competing with clicks and mortar booksellers.

Branding at Bloomsbury

Other web activity this week involved the relaunch of Bloomsbury's website. It has a new name, Bloomsburymagazine.com, and a mission to be an "exciting blend of literary magazine, reference library, publisher and bookshop".

Still flushed with success and cash thanks to Harry Potter and Margaret Atwood's Booker-winning novel The Blind Assassin, the site is not without its merits (the decision to sell a full range of books and not just its own, for instance, is laudable).

However, the problem with publishers running their own literary magazines (or bookshops) is the temptation to overload them with their own books - they would not be publishing them if they did not think they were worthy of such attention, after all - and so undermining their credibility.

Bloomsburymagazine.com has lolloped into this trap without a second's thought, blithely promoting The Blind Assassin as its book of the month and running two features on Hunter S Thompson (Bloomsbury publishes a new book of his letters later this month) in the same section.

But should we be surprised? Sadly, not. According to Bloomsbury's head of reference marketing and brand development Gordon Kerr, the site is "about enhancing the Bloomsbury brand". Somebody at Bloomsburymagazine.com must have twigged what was afoot, however, and helpfully commissioned an article on Naomi Klein's No Logo, which Mr Kerr would be well advised to read. As it points out: "Rather than serving as a guarantee of value on a product, the brand itself has increasingly become the product." The pity is that Bloomsbury has invested real money into its new website (something many UK publishers have been reluctant to do) but is clearly unwilling to let it be more than an extension of its brand.

webTitle: Four shortlisted for Microsoft games account

fields.headline: Four shortlisted for Microsoft games account
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Four ad agencies have been shortlisted to compete for the global launch of Microsoft's Xbox games console, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Four advertising agencies are celebrating this week after making it onto the pitch list of the year.

Bartle Bogle Hegarty, Lowe Lintas, 180 and Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO have all been shortlisted to compete for the global launch of Microsoft's Xbox games console.

The winner will launch the console across Europe with the backing of a reported £350m media spend.

Earlier this week BBH resigned its £60m Sega account simply to gain access to the pitch - a testament to how fiercely the battle will be fought.

All four agencies were chosen on the basis of their creative prowess, their ability to target a youth audience and their operations across Europe.

The initial presentations were made this week and an appointment is due before the end of the year.

The successful agency will position the Xbox as a direct competitor to Sony's PlayStation 2, Nintendo's forthcoming Dolphin console and Sega's Dreamcast.

Microsoft has claimed that Xbox will be two to three times more powerful than Sony's PlayStation 2.

It predicts that in three years' time it will draw 85% of the revenue to its home and retail division from the games sector.

webTitle: Hollywood Reporter: The Academy Awards - and they're off...

fields.headline: And they're off...
fields.standfirst: The films that should win the Oscars (but probably won't)
fields.trailText: The films that should win the Oscars (but probably won't)
fields.body:
There is a consensus among film writers that this has been a duff year at the movies. And casting one's eye about as Christmas approaches, it is hard not to think they have a point. Where is this year's Magnolia? Its American Beauty? Its Being John Malkovich? Where are the out-of-nowhere surprises such as The Sixth Sense or The Blair Witch Project? They're nowhere.

I have to confess that if I had my way, every year would be 1955: Cinemascope and three-strip Technicolor would be at their high tide, the studios would still be intact and Alfred Hitchcock, Douglas Sirk, Nicholas Ray and Vincente Minnelli would all still be riding a foam-crested wave. European cinema would be preparing to enter its most magnificent quarter-century, with New Waves about to break over Italy, France, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Britain to a lesser extent and West Germany to a much greater extent. There was so much left to learn, so many surprises still in store for us. I can dream. But if I had all this I suppose I'd also have to put up with segregation and vice-president Nixon.

And so we return to the present-imperfect tense: this year, discovering good movies was a process like sifting through dogshit for diamond rings - nasty, dirty work. There was the by now overfamiliar parade of remakes, retreads and rereleases that, if they were like The Exorcist, shamed the contemporary company they kept in the US's multiplexes. I'm paid to go to the movies but there were plenty of weekends when I wouldn't have gone to the movies if you'd, well, paid me.

Here at the end of the year, however, there is a sudden flurry of promising new releases, most primed for Oscar consideration, that may prove me wrong. As everyone is now aware, the harrowing four-month ordeal we call the Oscar process is now under way, competing on LA news pages with Byzantine dirty-cop scandals and the post-electoral farce.

A slew of this year's critical and commercial hits have been catapulted into a limited rerelease. Thus one can briefly see Gladiator and Wonder Boys, Erin Brockovich and Chicken Run on the big screen again. And, more importantly, you can also see them in full-page ads in the LA Times, where films can reinstall themselves in the collective consciousness of the Academy's voting base.

Smaller ads make claims for the virtues of smaller movies such as Almost Famous, Requiem for a Dream, Pay It Forward and Quills. Then there will be a set of one-week limited releases - prereleases, really - to enable movies that will receive a wide release in the new year to qualify for Oscar nominations.

This will include Robert Zemeckis's Cast Away, which may go some way towards restoring Zemeckis's soiled reputation, and which stars the always Oscar-hungry Tom Hanks. Also opening is Ang Lee's magnificent Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which fulfils one of my recent dreams: returning the great Chow Yun-Fat to his original Asian context. It is also that rare and blessed thing - a martial arthouse movie. I want it to win everything.

I am glad to see that some of Hollywood's earliest Oscar contenders have fallen at the first hurdle (a pox on the first movie of the year to feature the words "Oscar-worthy!" on its poster). One of these was Pay It Forward, a sudsy melodrama in the Magnificent Obsession mould (in its dreams). Its casting looked like a masterclass in Oscar-seeking: Helen Hunt (playing working class, titter), Kevin Spacey (playing ugly) and that brat from The Sixth Sense. Its ambitions were swiftly hobbled by audiences.

It was joined in oblivion by Men of Honor, a movie beset by one of those tell-it-all trailers and by Robert De Niro's improbable southern accent. I'm also hoping that the nauseating The Legend of Bagger Vance will lose its momentum before anyone is sick enough to reward its sugary lies about the nature of the old south.

Meanwhile we can expect heavy campaigning by the makers of other films: Proof of Life (starring the wonderfully thuggish Russell Crowe); Thirteen Days, Kevin Costner's Cuban missile crisis thriller; M Night Shamalyan's Unbreakable; Remember the Titans; and The Contender.

But for me the best news of all is that there are so many British films deemed worthy of consideration. Chicken Run is doing the rounds again, and the crowd-pleasing Billy Elliot is on the verge of a wide release in hopes of Full Monty-size takings. Michael Winterbottom's The Claim is staking (forgive me) its claim.

Sadly Croupier (pictured), my nomination for best movie, seems to have been excluded from the competition because it played for five minutes in Singapore a few years ago. Nonetheless, Croupier's stateside success - the result of a two-year marketing slog in the teeth of the fiercest, stupidest resistance imaginable - has not only garnered the film numerous critical plaudits, it has shamed distributors into rereleasing it in its own country, where it was barely given a chance to succeed on its original unveiling.

The great Mike Hodges, vindicated at last. And Terence Davies's luminous adaptation of Edith Wharton's The House of Mirth, which still burns in my head several days after seeing it, is proof that Britain is not short on world-class film-makers. Best Picture, if there's any justice at all.

Its ambitions were swiftly hobbled by audiences. It was joined in oblivion by Men of Honor, a movie beset by one of those tell-it-all trailers and by Robert De Niro's improbable southern accent. I'm also hoping that the nauseating The Legend of Bagger Vance will lose its momentum before anyone is sick enough to reward its sugary lies about the nature of the old south. Meanwhile we can expect heavy campaigning by the makers of other films: Proof of Life (starring the wonderfully thuggish Russell Crowe); Thirteen Days, Kevin Costner's Cuban missile crisis thriller; M Night Shamalyan's Unbreakable; Remember the Titans; and The Contender. But for me the best news of all is that there are so many British films deemed worthy of consideration. Chicken Run is doing the rounds again, and the crowd-pleasing Billy Elliot is on the verge of a wide release in hopes of Full Monty-size takings. Michael Winterbottom's The Claim is staking (forgive me) its claim. Sadly Croupier (pictured), my nomination for best movie, seems to have been excluded from the competition because it played for five minutes in Singapore a few years ago. Nonetheless, Croupier's stateside success - the result of a two-year marketing slog in the teeth of the fiercest, stupidest resistance imaginable - has not only garnered the film numerous critical plaudits, it has shamed distributors into rereleasing it in its own country, where it was barely given a chance to succeed on its original unveiling. The great Mike Hodges, vindicated at last. And Terence Davies's luminous adaptation of Edith Wharton's The House of Mirth, which still burns in my head several days after seeing it, is proof that Britain is not short on world-class film-makers. Best Picture, if there's any justice at all.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Chicken Run | Gangster No 1 | Stir of Echoes
fields.trailText: Chicken Run | Gangster No 1 | Stir of Echoes
fields.body:
Chicken Run
Retail (£16.99) and DVD (£19.99) Fox Pathé Cert U
****

Aardman survives the transfer to a big-screen international co-production (with DreamWorks) with aplomb. There's very little Americanisation and the aura of a home-made British cottage industry survives together with the company's traditional subtlety, narrative coherence and Heath Robinson approach to machinery. To British viewers, the film's stars are much the same as the Creature Comforts animals that first delighted us on TV, and Julia Sawalha (stroppy) and Jane Horrocks (bubble-headed) retain their usual characteristics in a crowded henhouse. But it was all fresh to the Yanks, who lapped up this Great Escape update - with a hint of Animal Farm mixed in - accents and all. At heart, it's rather a feminist fable, with the men (such as Mel Gibson's flippant flyboy) all pompous, stupid or untrustworthy. But this never gets in the way of the comedy, which is heartwarming and surprisingly poignant by turn, aided by some inspired plotting (look out for the torn poster if you have yet to see it). The DVD includes directors' commentary, a "making of" documentary and an Aardman archive.

Gangster No 1
Rental and DVD (£19.99) VCI/FilmFour Cert 18
****

A visually stylish study in psychopathology and a British gangster film that reminds you of Performance or Get Carter rather than Lock, Stock - a great relief, frankly. At its heart is a startling performance by Paul Bettany as a heartless, cold-eyed gangster on the rise. Bettany is the lout taken under the wing of David Thewlis's fastidious villain and gets "arse'oled on the smell of success". Bettany, largely restricted to TV up to now, is scarily believable, resembling the young Michael Caine, and every bit as unflinching as Jack Carter. There's no wallowing in gore but when Bettany sets out for a bit of the old u-v ("machete, axe, gun, chisel"), it's hard not to flinch. Director Paul McGuigan skilfully builds momentum with the aid of Czech cinematographer Peter Sova (who made Diner and Donnie Brasco so visually memorable). Malcolm McDowell lets rip as the older gangster looking back in anger and the chameleonic Thewlis provides another refined portrayal, but this is very much Bettany's triumph. The DVD includes interviews and deleted scenes.

Stir of Echoes
Rental (£19.99) Fox Cert 18
***

Kevin Bacon gets hypnotised by Illeanna Douglas, thus opening a door that makes him telepathic in this spooky and unsettling film that can't quite escape the "it's a bit like" trap. It starts with an eerily self-possessed child with three names talking to the camera (but it's Zachary David Cope not The Sixth Sense's Haley Joel Osment), and this small, white child discovers a telepathic bond with a very tall black man (but it's not The Shining's Scatman Crothers). This is a shame because Stir of Echoes is a ghost story that gives you a real jolt from time to time and its main couple are the estimable Kevin Bacon - better than the film he's in, as usual - and Kathryn Erbe, who has witchy potential but is cast here in the straight worried wife role.

webTitle: In brief: Julia Roberts denies dalliance with Bruce Willis

fields.headline: Julia Roberts denies dalliance with Bruce Willis
fields.standfirst: Plus: Adam Sandler to star in James Stewart remake; Michael Caine may put his voice to Chicken Run follow-up; Ethan Hawke writes his second novel; big-budget film about the original Siamese twins
fields.trailText: Plus: Adam Sandler to star in James Stewart remake; Michael Caine may put his voice to Chicken Run follow-up; Ethan Hawke writes his second novel; big-budget film about the original Siamese twins
fields.body:
 A spokeswoman for Julia Roberts (pictured) is furiously denying reports that the actress is having a relationship with Bruce Willis after rumours started circulating around Hollywood that the two stars have become an item. American gossip columnist Jeannette Walls quotes a source close to Roberts as saying, "Bruce calls Julia all the time. She keeps insisting they're just friends, but I don't believe her."A spokeswoman for the Erin Brockovich star denies there is any hint of romance between the two, insisting Julia is still seeing Benjamin Bratt and that she and Bruce are "just friends"

 Comedian Adam Sander and director Steve Brill are to work together on a new project, despite failing to set the box office alight with their last film, Little Nicky. Variety reports that Brill is in final negotiations to write and direct Sandler's forthcoming picture, Deeds, an homage to Mr Deeds Comes to Town, Frank Capra's Oscar winner from 1936, which starred Gary Cooper and Jean Arthur.

 Paul Whitehouse and Sir Michael Caine are rumoured to be lending their voices to a new animated movie from Chicken Run producers, Aardman Animations, according to Ananova news. The plasticine version of The Tortoise and the Hare, from Aesop's fables, is due to go into production next March. An Aardman spokesman would neither confirm nor deny the stories before the official announcement of casting early in February.

 Ethan Hawke has landed a six-figure advance for his second novel, Ash Wednesday. Uma Thurman's cerebral husband has written a tale of romantic obsession to follow the success he enjoyed five years ago with The Hottest State, but the canny star of the forthcoming update of Hamlet has retained the film rights for both books.

 Walt Disney are to retell the story of real-life Siamese twins Chang and Eng Bunker in a $45m (£31.1m) movie epic, based on the controversial Darin Strauss novel. Titus director, Julie Taymor, is in negotiations to direct the project. An insider says, "This is possibly one of the toughest and most complex movies ever taken on by a film company. It's walking into a medical and emotional minefield because of the subject matter. It deals with one of the most fascinating stories to go into print, but unless it is handled properly in terms of taste and style, the end product could be embarrassing or offensive."

webTitle: Madonna to wed Ritchie in Highlands

fields.headline: Highland fling
fields.standfirst: Banns in remote Scots town make singing star's wedding official
fields.trailText: Banns in remote Scots town make singing star's wedding official
fields.body:
A small notice posted in the register office of the remote Sutherland town of Dornoch yesterday confirmed the world's worst kept secret. Madonna and her film director boyfriend are to marry three days before Christmas.

The announcement for Madonna Louise Ciccone and Guy Stuart Ritchie on December 22 was one of four banns to be displayed, as required by law, by the local registrar, Lesley Connor. "This is the most famous person we have put up on the list," she said. "The interest is nice for Dornoch and good for local businesses."

Within hours every hotel room in the quiet seaside town, population 2,500, was booked. It is thought that the pair will marry at the 776-year-old Dornoch cathedral, with a reception at the nearby celebrity retreat of Skibo castle.

There have also been rumours they may marry at the castle and have their son, Rocco, christened at the cathedral on December 21. Earlier this week Madonna was spotted visiting the cathedral and checking the acoustics with a burst of Ave Maria. Skibo castle was the choice of actor Ewan McGregor and Full Monty star Robert Carlyle for their marriages, and has welcomed celebrities such as Sean Connery, and Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones. The castle's one time owner, the steel magnate Andrew Carnegie, described the Gothic structure as "heaven on earth."

The tabloids predict that the singer's star-studded reception will have a Braveheart theme, with straw scattered on the castle floors for a mediaeval banquet and waiters dressed as Scottish warriors.

Yesterday, as journalists trampled up and down Dornoch's main street trying to uncover details of the event, shopkeepers and residents appeared unperturbed. "It certainly makes the place busy," said William MacDonald, the ironmonger-cum-florist. "Personally, I don't see it as any big deal. Dornoch was here before Madonna was born and it will be here long after she's left." And, said one man: "I'm still waiting for someone to tell me who Madonna is. I thought it was a painting by Leonardo da Vinci."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: Arsenal are to be offered the opportunity to re-sign Emmanuel Petit from Barcelona for £1m, a fifth of the price the Spanish side paid for him in the summer. The French midfielder is becoming increasingly frustrated at his lack of first-team opportunities, reports the Sun.
fields.body:
Arsenal are to be offered the opportunity to re-sign Emmanuel Petit from Barcelona for £1m, a fifth of the price the Spanish side paid for him in the summer. The French midfielder is becoming increasingly frustrated at his lack of first-team opportunities, reports the Sun.

Leicester's manager Peter Taylor is to tempt Ipswich with a £5m offer for their in-form striker Marcus Stewart, according to the Daily Star. Taylor will also try and sign Chelsea's Jody Morris as a replacement for Neil Lennon. "Morris is a player I really like. He has got great ability and is certainly a player that would be in my thoughts without a doubt," Taylor said.

Liverpool are prepared to sell Robbie Fowler to accommodate Internazionale's Robbie Keane, according to the Yorkshire Post. A spokesman for Gerard Houllier's team denied the report. Meanwhile, Teamtalk claims that Keane will move to Leeds for £18m next summer if they grant Inter first refusal on Harry Kewell.

Tottenham fans finally have something to celebrate after Ramon Vega suggested in the Daily Star that he will leave the club in the summer. "I have six months to go and from January I can talk to other clubs so it's a good position to be in," the hapless defender said. "If the club wants to talk to me I will listen but I can always wait and see if other offers come in."

Paolo di Canio's spat with David James continues with the West Ham forward saying that Aston Villa's goalkeeper has "a brain the size of a pea". The pair have been at each other's throats all week after James finally responded to Di Canio calling him a "cretin" and a "moron" a year ago. More of the same can be expected after the match between the two sides tomorrow.

fields.headline: Canal Plus approves Vivendi/Seagram merger
fields.trailText: 12.15pm:French pay-TV group Canal Plus has approved the blockbuster merger of Vivendi and Seagram, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shareholders in French pay-TV group Canal Plus have given the final seal of approval to the blockbuster merger of Vivendi and Seagram.

The extraordinary general meeting backed the £51bn deal by 98%, creating a multi-media conglomerate called Vivendi Universal.

Canal Plus is 49%-owned by French media company Vivendi, which will now merge with Seagram's Universal Film and Universal Music operations.

Vivendi will use its internet and telecoms interests, which include the Vizzavi mobile internet service, to take advantage of Universal's substantial content catalogue.

The deal catapults the company into third position in global media rankings, behind CBS-Viacom of the US and AOL-Time Warner, which will be the world's number one company if it wins regulatory approval.

However, rumours continue to circle of a board-level dispute between Canal Plus and Vivendi, amid reports that Canal Plus boss Pierre Lescure has fallen out with his Vivendi counterpart, Jean-Marie Messier.

The two are believed to have clashed over the future independence of the channel.

"It's not a merger, it's a seizure," said one Canal Plus manager at a staff meeting recently.

Managers at the pay-TV channel have complained that its parent company will take control of the whole operation, although Vivendi has promised to give Canal Plus independence in the areas of marketing and editorial direction.

Meanwhile, French film industry associations have launched legal challenges to the merger, claiming Canal Plus will be swamped by its partners, endangering the French TV and film industry.

Vivendi co-financed 80% of all French feature films produced last year.

webTitle: Star feature writer quits the Express

fields.headline: Star feature writer quits the Express
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Feature writer Ros Wynne-Jones has resigned from the Express in protest at the new owner's style, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Ros Wynne-Jones, the Daily Express's star feature writer, has become the latest high-profile journalist to resign from the newspaper after the arrival of new owner Richard Desmond.

Ms Wynne-Jones, who is also associate editor of the paper and best known for her celebrity profiles and campaigning journalism, resigned this morning to take up a feature writer's job on the Mirror.

She made it clear that she objected to new owner Richard Desmond's approach to running the paper.

"I came here with Rosie [Boycott] from the Independent to do a very specific job on the paper. It is clear that will not now be possible," she said.

"I've been offered a great job somewhere else and I will be doing the sort of campaigning journalism I like. But I would much rather have been doing that here."

Ms Wynne-Jones' departure follows the resignation of home affairs editor David Taylor yesterday. Express columnist Peter Hitchens left earlier this week.

Columnists Stephen Pollard and Mary Kenny and political editor Anthony Bevins have also quit the paper, saying they do not want to work for Mr Desmond.

webTitle: Quills wins top prize from National Board of Review

fields.headline: Quills wins top prize from National Board of Review
fields.trailText: The Oscar chances of Quills were given a boost when it received the best picture prize, as the awards are often seen as a good indicator of the winners at the Academy Awards
fields.body:
With Oscar night only a few months away, every award ceremony is now seen as an Academy Award indicator. The announcement of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures 2000 Award Winners is no exception.

Quills (pictured), the biopic of the Marquis de Sade, which stars Geoffrey Rush and Kate Winslet, was named best picture of the year by the Board which is made up of teachers, writers, actors and film professionals.

Julia Roberts, hotly tipped for an Oscar nomination, won best actress for the title role in Erin Brockovich and the film's director, Steven Soderbergh, was honoured for his work on Brockovich and the Michael Douglas drama, Traffic.

The board named Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon best foreign film and Spanish actor Javier Bardem won the best actor award for his role as Cuban-born poet and novelist Reinaldo Arenas in Before Night Falls.

The awards aren't always an accurate Oscar predictor. In 1998, the board chose Gods and Monsters as the top film over Shakespeare in Love, which went on to win on Oscar night. Last year, however, the Board gave top honours to American Beauty, which scooped five Academy Awards, including best picture.

The Board's top 10 films of 2000 were Quills, Traffic, Croupier, You Can Count on Me, Billy Elliot, Before Night Falls, Gladiator, Wonder Boys, Sunshine and Dancer in the Dark.

The awards will be presented January 16 in New York.

fields.headline: NSPCC defends publicity spend
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The NSPCC has defended its decision to spend up to a quarter of its funds on publicity campaigns, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The NSPCC has come under fire after it was revealed that it spends around a quarter of the money it raises on publicity campaigns.

The charity has admitted it spends at least 50% of its income on publicity, campaigning and administration.

The NSPCC has so far spent £18m on its high-profile Full Stop campaign, featuring the Spice Girls, footballer Alan Shearer and other stars. The campaign, which was launched in March 1999, is aimed at combating child abuse.

But the NSPCC today insisted it had a responsibility to raise awareness of cruelty to children as well as to raise money.

It said that many of the children helped by the charity would never have come forward without the campaign.

The NSPCC's spending was highlighted by Community Care magazine following the release of the charity's annual report.

An NSPCC spokesman said that increasing public awareness and campaigns for changes in the law were "essential" work.

"We are not going to end cruelty to children through local services alone," he said.

"The vast majority of those who have been abused may never come forward without our campaigns, so we cannot help them. We help hundreds of thousands more children by influencing legislation and policy than we could directly through local services."

fields.headline: Childcare strategy fails minority families
fields.trailText: A leading charity says the government's national childcare strategy is failing to deliver benefits to minority children, writes Nicola Hill
fields.body:
A leading charity says the government's national childcare strategy is failing to deliver benefits to minority children.

In response, childcare charity the Daycare Trust has launched a report, Ensuring Equality, setting out 20 recommendations to tackle racism and address the needs of minority ethnic families.

The charity gives examples of nurseries in racially diverse areas being staffed and used predominantly by white people. It also cited the fact that of the 150 early years development and childcare partnerships, only 4% have a subgroup to examine minority issues. The partnerships are responsible for driving forward the government's childcare strategy.

It calls on the government and service providers to monitor the composition of ethnicity of staff and users in childcare services; to train staff to understand the Race Relations Act and to empower children and workers from minority communities.

Stephen Burke, Daycare Trust director, said: "The government must ensure that its massive investment in childcare reaches all children and families who need services. Childcare can help promote equality and tackle disadvantage, but still too many children and families from black and minority ethnic communities are missing out."

webTitle: Bin Laden: aiming at the symptom, not the disease

fields.headline: Bin Laden: aiming at the symptom, not the disease
fields.standfirst: As the US tries a new tack in its fight against terrorism, Brian Whitaker questions the wisdom of concentrating so much effort on the hunt for Osama Bin Laden
fields.trailText: As the US tries a new tack in its fight against terrorism, Brian Whitaker questions the wisdom of concentrating so much effort on the hunt for Osama Bin Laden.
fields.body:
Picture the scene. "So, Mr Bond, we meet at last!"

Special Agent 007 has finally made it to Afghanistan and is face to face with a fabulously wealthy but evil genius who is out to destroy the world: Osama bin Laden.

Bin Laden presses a button and the top lifts off a mountain to reveal his infernal death machine.

But Bond and his shapely companion sabotage the computers and escape with only seconds to spare before the mountain self-destructs, taking Bin Laden with it.

Bond and his girl retire triumphantly to a luxury pad in Kabul - only to be arrested by the Taliban and shot for immodest behaviour.

This would certainly put a neat end to Bin Laden and, perhaps just as usefully, to the James Bond films - but real life isn't like that.

Since the end of the Afghan war, Osama Bin Laden has become synonymous with Islamic terrorism.

If intelligence services are to be believed, he and his associates have been involved in terrorist plots in such far-flung countries as Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Egypt, Indonesia, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Malaysia, Morocco, the Netherlands, Pakistan, the Philippines, Romania, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Syria, Tanzania, Turkey, Uganda, the United Arab Emirates, the United States and Yemen.

This week, American and Yemeni investigators said that they had uncovered evidence linking him to the bombing of the USS Cole in Aden on October 12, which killed 17 sailors.

In the United States, he is on the FBI's "Ten most wanted men" list, but missile attacks on his Afghan hideout have failed to dislodge him, and the offer of a $5m reward has not, so far, led to his capture.

The latest plan is to try to prise him out of Afghanistan through a UN security council resolution - sponsored by the US and Russia - which would tighten a ban on air travel to the country and freeze the Taliban's assets abroad.

But the question that has to be asked is what this would achieve.

Putting him on trial would immeasurably enhance his prestige among Islamic militants, and executing him would create a martyr: one more reason for the extremists to attack Americans.

The other big question is whether, with Bin Laden out of the way, anti-American terrorism would stop or even be substantially reduced.

Focusing on Bin Laden as the "mastermind" or instigator behind virtually all serious attacks on US overseas interests is not only pointless but also rather foolish.

It encourages the idea (comforting for many Americans) that such attacks have no real motive: Bin Laden is mad or has some kind of grudge and pays people to do these things.

It's only his charisma, money and technical know-how that keeps them going.

This avoids having to confront more disturbing questions about perceptions of the way America throws its weight around and the resentment that this arouses among many ordinary Muslims, not just terrorists.

Bin Laden, who is now aged 43 or perhaps a little older, started out as a respected and wealthy Saudi businessman, having studied management and economics at King Abd al-Aziz University in Jeddah.

His family came originally from southern Yemen, but prospered in the kingdom through their construction business.

Today, they are considered the wealthiest non-royal family in Saudi Arabia.

During the Afghan war of the 1980s, Usama bin Laden - in common with many other Saudi businessmen - saw a religious duty to support the Islamic rebels financially against Moscow's puppet regime.

He could afford to be more generous than most, and he also became more deeply involved than most.

Not only did he pay for weapons and what, by his own account, were thousands of Muslim volunteers from the Middle East and North Africa to join the Mujahideen, he went there himself and took part in the fighting.

Using the resources of his construction business, he blasted new guerrilla trails across the mountains and tunnelled into the rock to create underground hospitals and arms dumps.

The United States at the time also supported the Mujahideen, since it regarded the Soviet Union as a greater threat, and must therefore carry some responsibility for what happened next.

The Soviet withdrawal left many of these volunteer fighters at a loose end but still filled with the spirit of jihad. In some ways, they were like the American veterans after Vietnam - deprived of adrenalin and unable to adjust to a quiet life.

But, unlike the Vietnam veterans, their efforts had not been futile. They had defeated a superpower and were flushed with success.

Many - including Bin Laden - told of narrow escapes from death, which led them to believe that God had preserved them for a purpose.

Unwelcome in their home countries, they dispersed throughout the Muslim world and often became involved in local Islamist movements, where they were known as "Afghans".

The effect of the Afghan war was to create an international network - largely informal - of people who had a shared experience and a sense of common purpose (albeit a violent one), and to create a pool of expertise which could be called upon to help in terrorist attacks around the world.

There is little doubt that Bin Laden plays an important role in sustaining this network - through funding, training, contacts, and other things - but we should be careful to regard him as a symptom of the disease, not its cause.

webTitle: Doctors despair over pressure on NHS

fields.headline: Doctors despair over pressure on NHS
fields.trailText: Doctors' leaders warned yesterday that the medical profession was falling into a state of "clinical depression" as it struggled to provide proper care for patients in an overstretched NHS. John Carvel reports
fields.body:
Doctors' leaders warned yesterday that the medical profession was falling into a state of "clinical depression" as it struggled to provide proper care for patients in an overstretched NHS.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said it was no longer accurate to talk about a winter crisis in the health service, because problems of under-capacity and overwork continued all year round.

Reporting on the association's council meeting on Wednesday, he said: "The mood was one of despair and powerlessness to influence what is going on, because of not having the workforce or capacity." The condition of GP representatives could best be described as "clinically depressed".

Dr Bogle supported the government's NHS reform plan in July and was present in Downing Street on Monday when Tony Blair launched a winter planning strategy for the service. But his members have become increasingly disillusioned by the speed at which extra resources earmarked for the NHS can be translated into a better service for patients.

The BMA published results of a Mori opinion poll showing the proportion of the general public satisfied with the NHS fell from 72% in January 1998 to 58% last month.

When asked who or what was most responsible for the current state of affairs, 44% of the unprompted replies referred unspecifically to "the government", 20% to "the Conservative government", 11% to "the Labour government", 16% to NHS managers, and 2% to doctors.

Dr Bogle said: "The message from the public is clear. Despite increased spending on the NHS, politicians in this government and the last have failed to fulfil the public's expectations. People see doctors as the solution, not the problem."

Ten years ago GPs could almost have guaranteed finding a bed for their patients, but now most hospitals were permanently full. In some regions hospitals were forced to cram too many beds in smaller wards, leading to increased risks of infection.

Dr Bogle said it was commonplace for GPs to avoid sending patients to hospital when it would have been advisable to do so if a bed had been available.

GPs preferred the risk of possible censure by the General Medical Council for unsatisfactory treatment to the certainty that a trolley wait could do even more harm.

The BMA council heard of patients in Leeds being transferred to Nottingham to find intensive care beds. A patient needing orthopaedic treatment had been told the first available appointment was in September 2002.

Dr Bogle said hospitals were buying "trolley beds", a cross between a trolley and a bed, for patients waiting admission. It sounded "like a scene from Monty Python", with hospital managers claiming they had reduced trolley waits by putting people on equipment that looked like a trolley, but counted as a bed.

The Department of Health said the BMA had misinterpreted the opinion poll. It showed 58% satisfied with the NHS, compared with 28% dissatisfied. The satisfaction rating was higher than when the government came to power in 1997.

"The government and the BMA agree that the main problem in the NHS is capacity - not enough doctors and nurses. We are making progress, with over 4,000 more doctors since 1997 and many more nurses," a spokesman said.

The NHS Confederation, representing health service managers, said the decline in satisfaction reflected what people heard from the media and politicians, not the experience of recent patients.

"Doctors should be bringing forward proposals for improving practice rather than wringing their hands about shortages of staff that we all know exist, but can do nothing to rectify in the short term," said Nigel Edwards, its policy director.

 The Mori poll was based on 2,000 interviews throughout Britain in the last week of November.

webTitle: Robert Downey Jr fired from film after drugs arrest

fields.headline: Robert Downey Jr fired from film after drugs arrest
fields.trailText: Amid rumours that the latest of a long line of arrests has made him uninsurable, Robert Downey Jr has lost a high-profile role because of fears that he will be jailed
fields.body:
Robert Downey Jr, who is facing renewed drug charges that could land him back in prison, has been dropped from his comeback film, America's Sweethearts.

The co-producer of the film, Tom Sherak, has confirmed that it is: "definite that we're out looking for somebody" to fill Downey Jr's shoes when production begins in January.

As reported yesterday, Downey Jr checked himself into Cedars Sinai Medical Centre suffering from depression after he was arrested over the Thanksgiving weekend for the possession of drugs. He is due to appear in court on December 27 but it seems that the producers of America's Sweethearts, which also stars Julia Roberts and Catherine Zeta-Jones, fear the troubled star will return to prison. Sherak told USA Today: "We need to move forward with this, and we're not sure what's going to happen on December 27."

Other reports suggest that the reason Downey Jr has been dropped from the cast is that he is now uninsurable. If he is found guilty, the Chaplin actor could return to prison for six years.

The story comes out amid reports in People magazine today that Downey Jr fell off the wagon well before his arrest over the Thanksgiving Weekend. The Magazine quotes an unnamed friend of Downey Jr's ex wife who said the actor: "has been getting loaded on and off" since he got out of prison in August. The report also claims that two weeks before his arrest, the 35-year-old actor left his seven-year-old son with an assistant in the middle of the night so he could score drugs. Downey Jr's publicist, Alan Nierob, denies the allegations.

The actor, out on bail after his arrest, is currently finishing off work on his 10-week stint on the TV Show Ally McBeal.

fields.headline: The one that ran and ran. And ran . . .
fields.standfirst: It's not so much a play as a national institution. As The Mousetrap approaches its 20,000th performance next week  Andy Beckett  asks, what keeps it going?
fields.trailText: It's not so much a play as a national institution. As The Mousetrap approaches its 20,000th performance next week Andy Beckett asks, what keeps it going?
fields.body:
Backstage at the St Martin's Theatre in London, there is a canvas- covered drum. It stands waist-high, mounted in a wooden frame, immediately behind the set of the Mousetrap. The canvas is a little frayed, and the top of the frame has a curious worn-down smoothness, a slight oiliness to the touch.

For at least half an hour every night except Sundays, and on every Tuesday and Saturday afternoon since 1952, a lightly sweating hand has gripped this wood while another has vigorously spun the drum against the canvas. A crude but persistent whistling, the sound of a blizzard as imagined in cartoons and melodramas, has quavered across the stage and around the auditorium. The Mousetrap's wind machine has provided suitable accompaniment, claustrophobic yet cosy, to the murders and drawing room revelations of the longest-running play in the world.

There is, however, a small cost. At the start of each show, the wind machine operators are fresh and fast. By the end of act one they are slowing, slumped over the drum frame. Imagine the shoulder twinges afterwards. Nobody at the theatre talks about installing a machine.

A week tomorrow, the pared-down, patched-together theatrical treadmill that is The Mousetrap is to give its 20,000th performance. Next year, assuming it continues its run, will be the play's 50th year of continuous production. A long time ago, it ceased being an adaptation of one of Agatha Christie's slighter works and became something else: a record-breaker, a curiosity, a fixture for tourists, an ambiguous example of infinite success. To a certain sort of theatre-goer or stage professional, the Mousetrap is heaven - a fragment from a lost dramatic age of polite dialogue and sets with floral sofas. To lots of other people - fans of new drama, most critics - the play is a glimpse of hell. Every year, every ageing line is spoken without alteration. Every year, a coveted venue in England's theatrical heartland is unavailable for anything else.

Yet complaining seems worse than pointless; all publicity, like each additional show, makes The Mousetrap more of an institution, provides more reasons to see it beyond two hours of Detective Sergeant Trotter's investigations at "snowbound Monkswell Manor". Disrespectful critics seem condemned, with each passing anniversary, to revisit The Mousetrap and try to close it. At least one has been trying since the early 70s.

The pinky-red neon of The Mousetrap sign glows day and night from a dark side street, perfectly positioned for tourists, between Leicester Square and Covent Garden. The sign is so vast and bright, with "49th Year" in slightly larger figures than "Agatha Christie", that you barely take in the small cream theatre behind it. Next door to the most secure theatrical employer in the country are the offices of the actors' union, Equity.

Inside the St Martin's, the foyer is shallow and draughty. There is a worn crimson carpet, slightly chipped panelling, and carefully polished brass. A wooden scoreboard with moveable painted numbers to announce the number of shows so far, like something from an old cricket ground, occupies most of one wall. A dusty Mousetrap sweatshirt (£15) is pinned up next to the Mousetrap postcards (collages of old tickets, anniversary badges and cast members), and Mousetrap mousemats, already commemorating "November 2002: 50th Anniversary".

Ticket sales recently have been a bit slow, though. In the box office, which is occupied by two women with patient smiles, they blame the trains. On non-matinee afternoons, the phones only require attention sporadically. The odd wrapped-up tourist bustles in from the street. A Dutch couple want to know how long the play is. An American man wants "the best seat you have". Otherwise, near-silence: small coughs from the box office, snatches of mobile phone calls from the pavement outside, a homeless man staring in as he drags his sleeping bag past.

Staff conversations at St Martin's have a slightly ritual quality.

"Are we busier?" asks an usher, coming in to work.

"No. No," says one of the women in the box office.

"It'll pick up," says the usher.

"Yes, yes," says the woman. Then they start discussing the size of the new advertising boards outside.

These days, the theatre's non-acting employees, contrary to Mousetrap tradition, tend to be temporary and young. Lopez and Lovatto are two of the names on the staff rota. Among the framed Mousetrap cartoons from long-gone English newspapers in the circle bar, there is staff gossip in Spanish. One of the ushers reads scripts up there. A measure of cynicism seems to prevail: "The sole objective of most people working in the building," says one, "Is to get out of the building as soon as possible."

David Turner, the director, comes in around 11am. "I'm not often here of an evening," he says quite casually, solid and jolly in green tweeds. He lives on the Sussex coast. "People say to me, 'Do you watch it every week?'" His eyes light with stage-incredulity: "I'd go potty!"

But, as among his subordinates, irreverence can conceal a certain dependence. Turner first directed The Mousetrap in 1987; he has continued for much longer than any of his 19 predecessors. "When I first came here," he says, slightly out of breath on the twisting climb up to his attic office, "the stairs weren't a problem." Before the St Martin's, he was director of the Connaught Theatre in sleepy Worthing, trying to freshen up The King and I and The Sound of Music. When the call to the St Martin's came, "I was over the moon."

Turner's tiny office window opens directly above the neon Mousetrap logo. "I love the play," he says with feeling. "It's not Chekhov and it's not Shakespeare. But it's very subtle . . . I wander round the audience, and I love to hear them talking about it. I follow Americans up the stairs afterwards." He looks as happy as Billy Bunter: "Agatha Christie liked everyone to go on their way rejoicing."

On top of his immaculate filing cabinets, next to all his correspondence as Mousetrap curator with ladies in Norfolk and North America, is a pile of sheets logging every performance. "Last night was one hour fifty-nine and a half minutes," he says without looking. There is a column for curtain calls (seven on the first night in London in November 1952, fewer thereafter) and on-stage accidents ("lampshade on wall bracket above radio dislodged by Mr Ralston's door slam in Act II"). But Turner's most precious archival item is a tattered blue paperback, which he eases out of a plastic bag like a hoarded bar of gold. It is the very first version of the script, complete with an opening scene later removed and never performed:

"A London street on a foggy day. Two workmen are sitting by a charcoal brazier.

Bill: Wireless says it's going to snow.

Alf: It's cold enough for it.

Bill: Perishing cold.

Alf: Expect there'll be a lot of accidents in this fog . . ."

The Mousetrap's origins seem as dusty as its language now. It was written in 1947 as a half-hour BBC radio play titled Three Blind Mice, an 80th birthday present for Queen Mary. Agatha Christie, who called herself "a perfect sausage machine", then stuffed it with jokes and additional characters into a stage play four times that length, which opened in Nottingham in October 1952 and briefly toured the midlands and the north of England. Christie thought the play might last six months.

The involvement of Richard Attenborough as Sergeant Trotter made The Mousetrap a success in London for two years, but when he left in 1955, the takings plummeted. The theatre gave the production notice to quit, and a new lease was only negotiated on condition that a new play would take The Mousetrap's place.

It was then, though, that what you might call the Mousetrap Effect first occurred: the moment news of its imminent closure got out, people crowded in to catch a performance while they still could. "If we put a notice up now saying 'closing month'," says Turner , "we'd probably be busy for two decades."

In 1958, The Mousetrap became the longest-running British play ever. By the mid-70s, it was the longest-running in the world. In 1977, the beleaguered prime minister, Jim Callaghan, was persuaded to attend the 25th anniversary celebrations. "Alas, I have little time to go to the theatre," he wrote on a card, still framed in the foyer. "I would like to come and see your play sometime during the next 25 years."

It remains a singular experience. First, there is the wait in the foyer: a small heat from the radiators, the toilets locked until half an hour before, the rest of the theatre roped off like a stately home. The ushers are transformed, erect at their stations, hands behind their backs, in waistcoats or new Mousetrap sweatshirts, pony tails scraped back. The audience, for the sparsely attended shows early in the week, appear to be deliberately seated in clusters. But once inside the dark-wood auditorium, the empty rows seem not to matter. The lighting is dim and warm. Introductory piano music tinkles. Couples gulp down gin and tonics in the snug bars and giggle conspiratorially.

The play creaks comfortably along. Lines are bellowed. Clues are given with emphasis. Poses are struck and held for whole minutes. A revolver is produced at the climax, and then, once all has been resolved, there is a reconciliation scene involving a hat box from Harrods. The oohs from the stalls are the loudest of the evening. Afterwards, it feels like the satisfactory completion of another episode of a long-running game show. The men in the audience say, "I told you so."

It is probably unwise to condemn or romanticise it all. Before Tuesday's matinee, in the dressing room always given to the actor playing Trotter, a keen young man called Alan Freestone says: "This means I can buy a flat." He has not had a West End job before. He says his agent was in the play 25 years ago.

There is a letter from the theatre's management on his dressing table. Like the rest of the cast, which is completely changed annually, he is informed that the celebrations attending the 20,000th performance have "very specific public relations objectives". The actors will have only limited access.
fields.bodyText: Backstage at the St Martin's Theatre in London, there is a canvas- covered drum. It stands waist-high, mounted in a wooden frame, immediately behind the set of the Mousetrap. The canvas is a little frayed, and the top of the frame has a curious worn-down smoothness, a slight oiliness to the touch. For at least half an hour every night except Sundays, and on every Tuesday and Saturday afternoon since 1952, a lightly sweating hand has gripped this wood while another has vigorously spun the drum against the canvas. A crude but persistent whistling, the sound of a blizzard as imagined in cartoons and melodramas, has quavered across the stage and around the auditorium. The Mousetrap's wind machine has provided suitable accompaniment, claustrophobic yet cosy, to the murders and drawing room revelations of the longest-running play in the world. There is, however, a small cost. At the start of each show, the wind machine operators are fresh and fast. By the end of act one they are slowing, slumped over the drum frame. Imagine the shoulder twinges afterwards. Nobody at the theatre talks about installing a machine. A week tomorrow, the pared-down, patched-together theatrical treadmill that is The Mousetrap is to give its 20,000th performance. Next year, assuming it continues its run, will be the play's 50th year of continuous production. A long time ago, it ceased being an adaptation of one of Agatha Christie's slighter works and became something else: a record-breaker, a curiosity, a fixture for tourists, an ambiguous example of infinite success. To a certain sort of theatre-goer or stage professional, the Mousetrap is heaven - a fragment from a lost dramatic age of polite dialogue and sets with floral sofas. To lots of other people - fans of new drama, most critics - the play is a glimpse of hell. Every year, every ageing line is spoken without alteration. Every year, a coveted venue in England's theatrical heartland is unavailable for anything else. Yet complaining seems worse than pointless; all publicity, like each additional show, makes The Mousetrap more of an institution, provides more reasons to see it beyond two hours of Detective Sergeant Trotter's investigations at "snowbound Monkswell Manor". Disrespectful critics seem condemned, with each passing anniversary, to revisit The Mousetrap and try to close it. At least one has been trying since the early 70s. The pinky-red neon of The Mousetrap sign glows day and night from a dark side street, perfectly positioned for tourists, between Leicester Square and Covent Garden. The sign is so vast and bright, with "49th Year" in slightly larger figures than "Agatha Christie", that you barely take in the small cream theatre behind it. Next door to the most secure theatrical employer in the country are the offices of the actors' union, Equity. Inside the St Martin's, the foyer is shallow and draughty. There is a worn crimson carpet, slightly chipped panelling, and carefully polished brass. A wooden scoreboard with moveable painted numbers to announce the number of shows so far, like something from an old cricket ground, occupies most of one wall. A dusty Mousetrap sweatshirt (£15) is pinned up next to the Mousetrap postcards (collages of old tickets, anniversary badges and cast members), and Mousetrap mousemats, already commemorating "November 2002: 50th Anniversary". Ticket sales recently have been a bit slow, though. In the box office, which is occupied by two women with patient smiles, they blame the trains. On non-matinee afternoons, the phones only require attention sporadically. The odd wrapped-up tourist bustles in from the street. A Dutch couple want to know how long the play is. An American man wants "the best seat you have". Otherwise, near-silence: small coughs from the box office, snatches of mobile phone calls from the pavement outside, a homeless man staring in as he drags his sleeping bag past. Staff conversations at St Martin's have a slightly ritual quality. "Are we busier?" asks an usher, coming in to work. "No. No," says one of the women in the box office. "It'll pick up," says the usher. "Yes, yes," says the woman. Then they start discussing the size of the new advertising boards outside. These days, the theatre's non-acting employees, contrary to Mousetrap tradition, tend to be temporary and young. Lopez and Lovatto are two of the names on the staff rota. Among the framed Mousetrap cartoons from long-gone English newspapers in the circle bar, there is staff gossip in Spanish. One of the ushers reads scripts up there. A measure of cynicism seems to prevail: "The sole objective of most people working in the building," says one, "Is to get out of the building as soon as possible." David Turner, the director, comes in around 11am. "I'm not often here of an evening," he says quite casually, solid and jolly in green tweeds. He lives on the Sussex coast. "People say to me, 'Do you watch it every week?'" His eyes light with stage-incredulity: "I'd go potty!" But, as among his subordinates, irreverence can conceal a certain dependence. Turner first directed The Mousetrap in 1987; he has continued for much longer than any of his 19 predecessors. "When I first came here," he says, slightly out of breath on the twisting climb up to his attic office, "the stairs weren't a problem." Before the St Martin's, he was director of the Connaught Theatre in sleepy Worthing, trying to freshen up The King and I and The Sound of Music. When the call to the St Martin's came, "I was over the moon." Turner's tiny office window opens directly above the neon Mousetrap logo. "I love the play," he says with feeling. "It's not Chekhov and it's not Shakespeare. But it's very subtle . . . I wander round the audience, and I love to hear them talking about it. I follow Americans up the stairs afterwards." He looks as happy as Billy Bunter: "Agatha Christie liked everyone to go on their way rejoicing." On top of his immaculate filing cabinets, next to all his correspondence as Mousetrap curator with ladies in Norfolk and North America, is a pile of sheets logging every performance. "Last night was one hour fifty-nine and a half minutes," he says without looking. There is a column for curtain calls (seven on the first night in London in November 1952, fewer thereafter) and on-stage accidents ("lampshade on wall bracket above radio dislodged by Mr Ralston's door slam in Act II"). But Turner's most precious archival item is a tattered blue paperback, which he eases out of a plastic bag like a hoarded bar of gold. It is the very first version of the script, complete with an opening scene later removed and never performed: "A London street on a foggy day. Two workmen are sitting by a charcoal brazier. Bill: Wireless says it's going to snow. Alf: It's cold enough for it. Bill: Perishing cold. Alf: Expect there'll be a lot of accidents in this fog . . ." The Mousetrap's origins seem as dusty as its language now. It was written in 1947 as a half-hour BBC radio play titled Three Blind Mice, an 80th birthday present for Queen Mary. Agatha Christie, who called herself "a perfect sausage machine", then stuffed it with jokes and additional characters into a stage play four times that length, which opened in Nottingham in October 1952 and briefly toured the midlands and the north of England. Christie thought the play might last six months. The involvement of Richard Attenborough as Sergeant Trotter made The Mousetrap a success in London for two years, but when he left in 1955, the takings plummeted. The theatre gave the production notice to quit, and a new lease was only negotiated on condition that a new play would take The Mousetrap's place. It was then, though, that what you might call the Mousetrap Effect first occurred: the moment news of its imminent closure got out, people crowded in to catch a performance while they still could. "If we put a notice up now saying 'closing month'," says Turner , "we'd probably be busy for two decades." In 1958, The Mousetrap became the longest-running British play ever. By the mid-70s, it was the longest-running in the world. In 1977, the beleaguered prime minister, Jim Callaghan, was persuaded to attend the 25th anniversary celebrations. "Alas, I have little time to go to the theatre," he wrote on a card, still framed in the foyer. "I would like to come and see your play sometime during the next 25 years." It remains a singular experience. First, there is the wait in the foyer: a small heat from the radiators, the toilets locked until half an hour before, the rest of the theatre roped off like a stately home. webTitle: FA could keep Wembley and ditch new stadium

fields.headline: FA could keep Wembley and ditch new stadium
fields.trailText: The twin towers of Wembley could remain intact after all under a scheme to refurbish, rather than demolish, the existing stadium being considered by senior Football Association officials.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary, John Cassy  and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
The twin towers of Wembley could remain intact after all under a scheme to refurbish, rather than demolish, the existing stadium being considered by senior Football Association officials.

All 12 members of the FA board, plus chief executive Adam Crozier and chairman Geoff Thompson, are to discuss at least three proposals for the future of the national stadium today at an emergency board meeting called to address concerns that the £660m project is too costly and has become blighted by negative publicity.

Officials will also discuss the future of fellow FA board member, Chelsea chairman Ken Bates, who is also chair of Wembley National Stadium Limited (WNSL), the FA subsidiary company set up to oversee the project, following widespread criticism of his leadership.

The most radical option, refurbishment of the old stadium, would save the FA millions of pounds. It would also please traditionalists within football.

The most favoured option, however, is for a streamlined version of the new stadium, which would jettison a hotel and vast amounts of office space originally proposed by Mr Bates.

The Chelsea chairman has already conceded that he is willing to cut the cost of the new Wembley by £70m following mounting criticism.

The third and least favoured option is for the FA to press ahead with the existing £660m project which would include a hotel, office space and banqueting facilities.

Mr Bates is expected to undergo a severe grilling at to day's meeting and could even face a vote of confidence. Many want to see him removed or playing a marginal role.

Mr Crozier and other senior officials have already said that they plan to take over the Wembley project and sideline Mr Bates.

A senior FA source said: "This is the biggest single issue facing the FA. Forget appointing an England manager - he can always be fired. Get Wembley wrong and financially we could never recover."

Chase Manhattan, the US investment bank hired to raise £410m in the City, has scrapped its original timetable to find backers for the project. The bank, which will not attend today's meeting, refused to comment yesterday.

The 30 or so banks it has approached, none of which has yet stumped up any cash, are concerned about the revenue projections for the Wembley stadium, especially the amount of money which will be generated from a higher number of corporate hospitality seats.

Chase is understood to still be in talks with 20 or so banks and is working hard to try to allay their concerns about the revenue projections.

An FA spokesman also said the stadium was looking for a new pitch because the conditions of its £120m lottery grant stipulate that it must be able to reopen within six weeks if the financing of a new stadium falls through.

One possible candidate to succeed Mr Bates as chairman of WNSL is Clive Sherling, a respected City businessman and a partner of venture capital group of Apax Partners, who is a director of the project.

fields.headline: NSPCC defends spending record
fields.trailText: The NSPCC has defended its spending record after figures revealed that half of the money it receives does not go directly on services for children.
fields.body:
The NSPCC has defended its spending record after figures revealed that half of the money it receives does not go directly on services for children.

The children's charity admitted that 50% of the total income raised is spent on publicity, campaigning and administration, but a spokesman said those activities were vital for protecting children as well.

The charity said nearly £53m, which is 86% of the money it received last year, went "directly" towards helping children.

Of that figure 59% went on its local services for children while the rest went mainly on publicity and campaigning. Only the remaining 14% of all the donations the NSPCC received went on administration and support.

A spokesman for the charity said: "Our local services to children are the core of the NSPCC's work. But we are a campaigning organisation and we have a twin-track approach to our work."

The NSPCC launched its Full Stop campaign, featuring the Spice Girls, footballer Alan Shearer and other stars, in March 1999.
It spent £18m on advertising the campaign and as a result has raised £80m with further pledges of £100m. "With £80m coming in we have a return on our investment of more than four to one, which is very efficient," the spokesman added.

The NSPCC spokesman said increasing public awareness and campaigns for changes in the law were "essential" work. "We are not going to end cruelty to children through local services alone," he said.
"Among many other reasons, the vast majority of those who have been abused may never come forward without our campaigns, so we cannot help them."

Gerald Howarth, Conservative MP for Aldershot, said he would be writing to the NSPCC revoking his support for the Full Stop initiative which he signed up to in the House of Commons.

Neil Hunt, NSPCC director of child protection, defended the spending on Radio 4's Today programme. He said: "We took a conscious decision that having been around for 115 years and helping millions of children, that the millennium was an opportunity for us to raise debate about child protection in this country.
Raising awareness of this issue does not come cheap. We're making no apologies about this."

fields.headline: Clow names TBWA 'successor'
fields.trailText: 10.45amAd guru Lee Clow heightened rumours of his retirement this week by announcing his 'successor', writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Lee Clow, the man behind some of the world's most famous ad campaigns, heightened rumours of his retirement this week with the announcement of a successor.

Mr Clow, creator of the "Think different" ads for Apple, "Air Jordan" for Nike and the Energizer bunny advertising, has named Chuck McBride as the new creative director of the entire TBWA Chiat Day network.

The legendary Mr Clow remains chairman and chief creative officer at TBWA Worldwide but will pass some of his responsibilities to Mr McBride, the former creative director of TBWA Chiat Day's San Francisco office.

Mr McBride has a tough act to follow. Mr Clow is a member of the One Club hall of fame, the art directors' hall of fame and the Museum of Modern Art's advertising hall of fame.

Three years ago, USA Today named him creative executive of the year.

Now well into his 50s, Mr Clow remains the archetypal creative - clad in a T-shirt, shorts and his trademark sandals.

Mr McBride will oversee the creative output of TBWA Chiat Day's four north American offices, in Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York and Toronto.

He will remain in San Franciso to manage the creative department and the Levi account.

While Mr Clow has stopped short of using the word successor himself, he has referred to Mr McBride as "the kind of talent that can take this agency to the next level and be responsible for the future".

Mr McBride joined TBWA in San Francisco two years ago after being courted by Mr Clow for years.

webTitle: Former Border TV chief joins Brainspark

fields.headline: Former Border TV chief joins Brainspark
fields.trailText: 10.45: Internet firm Brainspark has hired former Border TV chief Paul Corley as a non-executive director, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet firm Brainspark has boosted its management team by recruiting long-time TV executive Paul Corley as a non-executive director.

The appointment follows the recent launch of a the company's broadband-focused consultancy and development business, EC1 Media.

Mr Corley was formerly chief executive officer at Border Television and chairman of Border Radio Holdings.

His career in television spanned almost 25 years, having also been producer on Channel 4's The Tube, controller of factual and regional programmes at Carlton and controller of factual programmes at ITV.

Mr Corley said: "The team at Brainspark includes some of the most experienced and respected practitioners in the field working in a very fast-evolving environment.

"I am looking forward to helping them continue to build on their successes to date."

webTitle: Boro will relish survival training with Terry

fields.headline: Boro will relish survival training with Terry
fields.trailText: Anyone who doubts Terry Venables's commitment to his new job should have spent a couple of days with him in Austria this week. At the ITV hotel we were staying in for Manchester United's Champions League game he even had a video in his room to watch Middlesbrough tapes.
fields.body:
Anyone who doubts Terry Venables's commitment to his new job should have spent a couple of days with him in Austria this week. At the ITV hotel we were staying in for Manchester United's Champions League game he even had a video in his room to watch Middlesbrough tapes.

I know he's really got the tingle and the urge for it. He's been asking people about the best areas to get accommodation and changed to a flight from Vienna via Amsterdam yesterday to get to Teesside earlier. Mind you, he called his wife to make sure he'd got enough gear up there because he didn't want to go in on his first day with creased shirts.

Whatever he turns up in, I'd be delighted to have him if I were a Middlesbrough fan. I don't think there's any question they will survive. Terry genuinely wants to help Bryan Robson and fancies the challenge. He knows certain people are looking for him to fail and it gives him a great chance to stick two fingers up at his critics.

The knockers talk about his time at Crystal Palace and Portsmouth but this is an entirely different scenario. He's going to do what he does best, which is working with players, and I get the impression he's willing to work day and night to knock them into shape.

One of the things that impressed Terry at Boro were the training facilities, and that's a plus because it gives you something to look forward to when you go there in the morning. I phrase it like that because I never saw the job as work and I'm sure Terry doesn't either.

In fact I sense a renewed vigour in him. I felt the same when I came back into management after a break, and what Boro will get is a man with the enthusiasm of a 37-year-old and the experience of a 57-year-old. You can take a job and wonder, "What have I done?" but Terry seems to have no doubts.

Getting back into the swing will certainly be easy for him because he is so in touch with the game. People such as he and I are talking about players as much as if we were in the job. Of course Terry will lean heavily on Robbo's know-how until he gets his own feel of the thing but he'll be training this morning. I expect he'll do a bit of defensive work and a few set plays but he won't try to cram a million things into the players' heads. It will be more about motivation and getting people to play to their maximum.

Terry's such an impact man that the players will find something extra in their locker at Sunderland tomorrow. In time, once he's settled on the shape he wants, he'll spend a lot of time coaching and organising. He'll put new ideas in people's minds and do a lot of work on set plays, particularly attacking wise, because he's always done that. It was one of his great strengths with England.

When everything has settled I think it would do Robbo good to take three weeks in the sun. He looks battle-worn. He's gone out front and taken most of it on the chin and in many ways a lot of the players have hidden behind him.

But I don't go along with the idea that Terry's arrival has undermined Bryan. To me it shows how open-minded and brave Robbo is, and how much he's got Middlesbrough at heart, that he'll step aside for someone who in his view is the best. People say, "What about when he has to step up again?" but six months down the line doesn't matter. What matters is the staying up.

If that happens I believe Boro will keep Terry in some capacity which doesn't affect his other commitments, but I don't go along with the idea that Robbo's lost the players. The club are in one of those ruts that can hit anybody and Robbo and the chairman Steve Gibson have taken a very positive step.

Terry's arrival will be a breath of fresh air and he knows he's got the time and squad to survive. When you're at that end, normally you're looking for front players but he's got four good ones in Brian Deane, Hamilton Ricard, Alen Boksic and Noel Whelan, who can be top-class when he gets his finger out. I worked with Noel at Coventry and I'd be very surprised if he doesn't respond to Terry's promptings.

Unfortunately Terry's much too sharp to let me in on what he's being paid but whatever it is looks money well spent. Let's face it, if Middlesbrough thought they could sign a player for around £1m who would keep in the Premiership they'd be doing cartwheels.
