It will be more about motivation and getting people to play to their maximum. Terry's such an impact man that the players will find something extra in their locker at Sunderland tomorrow. In time, once he's settled on the shape he wants, he'll spend a lot of time coaching and organising. He'll put new ideas in people's minds and do a lot of work on set plays, particularly attacking wise, because he's always done that. It was one of his great strengths with England. When everything has settled I think it would do Robbo good to take three weeks in the sun. He looks battle-worn. He's gone out front and taken most of it on the chin and in many ways a lot of the players have hidden behind him. But I don't go along with the idea that Terry's arrival has undermined Bryan. To me it shows how open-minded and brave Robbo is, and how much he's got Middlesbrough at heart, that he'll step aside for someone who in his view is the best. People say, "What about when he has to step up again?" but six months down the line doesn't matter. What matters is the staying up. If that happens I believe Boro will keep Terry in some capacity which doesn't affect his other commitments, but I don't go along with the idea that Robbo's lost the players. The club are in one of those ruts that can hit anybody and Robbo and the chairman Steve Gibson have taken a very positive step. Terry's arrival will be a breath of fresh air and he knows he's got the time and squad to survive. When you're at that end, normally you're looking for front players but he's got four good ones in Brian Deane, Hamilton Ricard, Alen Boksic and Noel Whelan, who can be top-class when he gets his finger out. I worked with Noel at Coventry and I'd be very surprised if he doesn't respond to Terry's promptings. Unfortunately Terry's much too sharp to let me in on what he's being paid but whatever it is looks money well spent. Let's face it, if Middlesbrough thought they could sign a player for around £1m who would keep in the Premiership they'd be doing cartwheels.

webTitle: Barmby strikes as Reds throw caution to wind

fields.headline: Barmby strikes as Reds throw caution to wind
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool 2 (Heskey 28 Barmby 60) Olympiakos 0
Liverpool win 4-2 on aggregate
fields.trailText: Liverpool's belief that they are well-nigh unbeatable on home soil carried them through the wind and the rain here last night and into the last 16 of this season's Uefa Cup.
fields.body:
Liverpool's belief that they are well-nigh unbeatable on home soil carried them through the wind and the rain here last night and into the last 16 of this season's Uefa Cup.

But, in a tournament now awash with Champions League drop-outs far greater, far more demanding, tasks do lie ahead for Britains sole survivors.

Gérard Houllier had been somewhat apprehensive in the days leading up to this game, an understandable reaction bearing in mind the squandered opportunities and criminal wastage of the tie's first leg in Athens a fortnight earlier.

On paper at least, a 2-2 draw against a group of players who have come to regard victories on home soil as the inevitable by-product of pulling on their boots was highly commendable but Houllier made little or no attempt to conceal a sense of disappointment which, in truth, verged on outrage.

Liverpool's superiority in that first game was so pro nounced, the class divide between the sides so glaringly apparent, that Olympiakos' knee-jerk response was to dispense with their coach Yiannis Matzoyrakis.

As Matzoyrakis had been at the helm for just seven months and had led his team to the Greek title last season, he had every reason to feel somewhat aggrieved.

Even so, Houllier did not feel inclined to gamble. Indeed, his team selection hinted - rather broadly - at over-caution for, with both Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler left on the substitute's bench, there was a palpable sense that the Merseysiders were quite prepared to hold what they had.

Not that they held back in any way. No, the Greeks did well to emerge unscathed from a furious and sustained initial onslaught, one which would have yielded a Liverpool goal had the goalkeeper Dimitri Eleftheropoulos not responded with sublime athleticism to touch over, just, a Steven Gerrard volley from distance.

Olympiakos actually took to the inclement conditions rather well, moving the ball across a slippery, rain-sodden surface to good effect even if in their haste to fashion an early breakthrough they often lost their shape and surrendered their discipline.

This unexpected willingness to attack - quite often with a callous disregard for their own well-being at the back - was almost their undoing on countless occasions for Houllier had picked a team capable of mounting spring-heeled counter-attacks.

To this end, Danny Murphy - surprisingly selected ahead of Christian Ziege - was crucial for he, perhaps more than anyone in the Anfield firmament provides tangible evidence that hard work can still carry you a long way in a sport now dominated by prima donnas.

Murphy worked tirelessly and yet, as is so often the case, was a mere spectator when Liverpool's mounting pressure was finally met with its reward on 28 minutes.

It was a nice move, too, Emile Heskey collecting Nick Barmby's astute pass before galloping clear to score with a low drive, his 12th goal in his last dozen games.

Heskey's proficiency left Olympiakos chasing two goals and seemingly uncertain as to whether they should toss all caution to the prevailing wind or rein in their ambition in the hope that their opponents would tire in the evening's final quarter. Olympiakos entertained high hopes until the hour mark when they succumbed for a second time.

This time Barmby was to pull the trigger rather than provide the ammunition, firing in a shot from an acute angle which managed to strike both posts before dropping behind the line.

Liverpool (4-4-1-1): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Barmby, Gerrard (McAllister, 90min), Hamann, Murphy (Ziege, 78); Smicer; Heskey.

Olympiakos ( 4-4-2) Eleftheropoulos; Mavrogenidis (De Souza, 53), Amanatidis, Anatolakis, Georgatos; Poursanidis, Patsatzoglou, Zetterberg (Niniadis, 63), Djordjevic; Giovanni, Alexandris (Oforiquaye 63).

Referee: M Pereira (Portugal).

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week seventeen

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week seventeen
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. What are these wasters up to now?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £199.83, Sean Ingle = £95.15, Football Unlimited punters collective = £59.99, Paul MacInnes = £46.20
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £199.83, Sean Ingle = £95.15, Football Unlimited punters collective = £59.99, Paul MacInnes = £46.20

Scott Murray: Manchester City v Everton: Everton to win at half-time £10 @ 12/5

City's behaviour at Maine Road of late has been nothing short of shocking. Out of the ten games they've played at home so far this season, they've made a show of themselves by haplessly conceding the first goal no fewer than eight times. Eight times. They even let Gillingham open the scoring, for Liam and Noel's sake.

Now, Everton are no great shakes themselves, so I wouldn't necessarily back them to win the match. They could even lose it. But you can still see them taking an early lead and holding onto it for a while. Can't you?

Sean Ingle: Two £4 singles and a £2 double: Bari v Bologna: Bologna to win at 7/5; Lyon v Bastia: Bastia to win at 3/1.

In his seminal work Politics and Purges in China, Frederick C Teiwes revealed for the first time what life was like in the court of Mao Zedong from 1950 to 1965. Until then, the prevailing wisdom was that Mao allowed debate, discussion and perhaps even the odd moment of dissent among the communist hierarchy. But in fact the reverse was true: when the supreme Chinese leader wasn't robbing hand-picked teenage girls of their virginity, he was ruling with an iron fist.

And anyone who dared disagree with him quickly lived to regret it.

Reading Blue Square's Patrick Murray's column this week, I couldn't help be reminded of Mao. Sure, Mr Murray isn't yet ruler of the world's next superpower. And as far as I know, he's no sex-crazed dictator either. But his manichean view of betting - singles wonderful, anything else evil - is strangely reminiscent of Maoist dogma. Well, at least to me.

In an attempt to avoid the gambling equivalent of being sent to the Chinese countryside in disgrace, I've decided to pay some attention to Mr Murray's words. Well, sort of, because of I've gone for a two singles/one double combination.

Bologna are riding high in Serie A, and although their away record isn't fantastic (two wins, two losses), they've beaten the dross (Perugia and Napoli) whenever they've come across them. Which means they are surely excellent value at 7/5 to see off struggling Bari, who are second from bottom.

My other bet is Bastia to win away at Lyon. Bastia have an excellent recent record - in their last three games they've thrashed Marseille 3-0, drawn 0-0 away at Bordeaux and disposed of Auxerre 3-1. So why they are 3-1 against to beat Lyon - who draw most of their matches and recently lost at home to Lille - is beyond me, especially in a league as unpredictable as Le Championnat.

Lee Calvert of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Newcastle to win at Arsenal £5 @ 6/1

The odds on the Newcastle win seem silly to me. Sixes on any two-horse race seems frivolous, but when you consider the factors working against Arsenal then it seems even more so.

To explain: Arsenal had a terrible match in midweek in which they capitulated after racking up a two-goal lead; add to that the fact that traditionally teams fair very badly in any game directly following a European match and you've got my reasoning in a nutshell.

The only thing working against Newcastle is that Shearer is injured, but he's hardly been on fire this term and in any case Newcastle can get goals from all over.

Paul MacInnes: A Sean Ingle trademark treble: Rangers to beat Motherwell @ 2/9, Chelsea to beat Derby @ 1/2, Dundee United to beat Aberdeen @ 7/2 - £5.10

Right then. I can't be bothered with a long-winded essay this week about how my luck ought to come in and how, if it doesn't it ought to have done because my wager was so well reasoned.

This week I am simply going to write that I think the recently-improved Dundee United are good value to beat troubled New Firm rivals Aberdeen at 7/2, but because of rules I couldn't bet on them alone so I plumped for what I thought were two of the more certifiable home wins on offer to make a treble.

Simple. At least, simple enough to do me out of another fiver (plus the extra 10p I tacked on to make me look like an individual).

fields.headline: Late chips knock BATM for £600m
fields.standfirst: Market favourite tumbles on profits warning.
fields.trailText: Market favourite tumbles on profits warning
fields.body:
More than £600m was wiped off the value of BATM Advanced Communications yesterday after the stock market darling warned turnover was expected to fall short of expectations.

The Israeli designer and builder of routers and switches for the internet saw its share price more than halve to a year low of 157.5p.

Before September it had been one of the London market's highly rated stocks..

In a statement the company said it "expects revenues in the second half of at least $55m compared to approximately $37m in the first, making a total of at least $92m for the full year". The house broker had been expecting full-year turnover of $115m.

BATM said $55m was a worst case and Dr Zvi Marom, the chief executive, told re porters that he expects pretax profits for the full year to meet expectations of about $15m, even on lower turnover.

One analyst said: "I think a company that has high expectations attached to it should not disappoint its investors, but it should not be relevant to the future of the company." If people believed in the company yesterday they should still believe in it today.

BATM blamed the profit warning on the inability of Infineon, the German chipmaker, to deliver on time. It had commissioned Infineon to manufacture optical transceivers but, although delivery dates had been confirmed, they had not arrived.

Dr Marom said: "We've commissioned another manufacturer... we should get the parts in the first quarter and we'll ship then. If we can get them earlier, we'll ship earlier."

Infineon confirmed the delivery problems. Anke Pickhardt, a spokeswoman, said: "Demand for our products is so high that we have had to concentrate on our strategic customers."

Deferred orders from telecoms customers and the company's caution in accepting orders "from certain customers with aggressive expansion plans," also contributed to the lower turnover figures, BATM said.

Product development and research were on track and turnover was expected to grow significantly in 2001, in line with previous forecasts by analysts.

fields.headline: Rangers exit with a whimper
fields.standfirst:
Kaiserslautern 3 (Klose 8, Buck 65, Lokvenc 79) Rangers 0
Kaiserslautern win 3-1 on aggregate
fields.trailText: Rangers were tossed out of Europe in humiliating fashion yesterday, capitulating before Kaiserslautern and their raucous supporters who filled this stadium to its rafters.
fields.byline: Graham Spiers at the Fritz-Walter stadium
fields.body:
Rangers were tossed out of Europe in humiliating fashion yesterday, capitulating before Kaiserslautern and their raucous supporters who filled this stadium to its rafters.

Both the game and his tactical plan imploded before the eyes of Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager, as Kaiserslautern sliced at will through a flat-footed defence.

With Rangers trailing at the break, Advocaat sent out a re-cast unit in the second half with the intention of aggressively taking this game to the home side and building on Rangers' 1-0 win in Glasgow. The script, though, began to smoulder the moment Youri Djorkaeff cleverly released Andreas Buck on goal and he calmly advanced on Stefan Klos before prodding the ball home.

Vratislav Lokvenc, Kaiserslautern's towering Czech, added a third in the 78th minute as Rangers disintegrated; Klos, indeed, saved them at least twice in the dying minutes as German attackers marauded towards him.

How different it could have been had Rangers converted just one of the three good chances that fell to them in the opening 45 minutes. There was scarcely a period when this match was comfortably in their grasp, yet the arithmetic of home and away in Europe meant one goal scored by the Scottish champions would have put enormous pressure on the Germans. Neither Jörg Albertz nor poor Kenny Miller, twice, could pull off the deed.

"We have no excuses - Kaiserslautern were the better team and deserved to go through," said Advocaat afterwards. "I think we had maybe five or six chances overall in this game, on top of the many we created at Ibrox in the first game, and we failed to take them. At this level of European football, if you do that, you lose."

Most glaring of Rangers' worries was their dependence on the raw Miller, who, at 20, may be an exciting prospect but is still dreadfully unprepared for these nervous forays into Europe.

Miller whacked two good chances high over Georg Koch's bar before hobbling around for the rest of the first half and then being replaced by Michael Mols.

It was probably Advocaat's insistence on Rangers needing 11 fit men "for a physical battle" that made him leave two of his Dutch infantry - Mols and Ronald de Boer - on the bench. Mols confessed this week that he might spend the rest of his career playing parts of matches, and De Boer, in true Rangers fashion, arrived from Barcelona with an injury.

Yet Mols, from the moment he arrived, defied the prognosis on his knee and gave Rangers immediate presence. He twisted, turned and opened angles through which Rangers might attack; they did with scant reward.

In the combustible atmosphere, Rangers toiled to recover from a goal conceded criminally early. Kaiserslautern's clever passing was already making Rangers giddy before Miroslav Klose, their prized young striker, burst into the box with Scott Wilson wobbling in front of him. With the defender falling over, Klose prodded a shot which became airborne and flew past the startled Klos.

Buck's strike in the 63rd minute was a beautiful creation by Djorkaeff, confounding Rangers' offside trap. The third from Lokvenc 12 minutes from time was a downward header past a hacked-off Klos.

Kaiserslautern (3-4-1-2): G Koch; H Koch, Yakin, Ramzy; Buck, Hristov (Basler, 87min), Komljenovic (Strasser, 3), Grammozis; Djorkaeff; Klose (Marschall, 69), Lokvenc.

Rangers (3-5-2): Klos; Wilson, Konterman, Amoruso; Ricksen (McCann, h-t), Reyna, Tugay (Dodds, 76), Albertz, Numan; Wallace, Miller (Mols, h-t).

Referee: K E Fisker (Denmark).

webTitle: Infogrames buys ailing Hasbro games outfit

fields.headline: Infogrames buys ailing Hasbro games outfit
fields.trailText: Infogrames, Europe's largest computer games company which failed to buy Eidos earlier this year, is paying $100m for the loss-making interactive divisions of American toy group Hasbro.
fields.body:
Infogrames, Europe's largest computer games company which failed to buy Eidos earlier this year, is paying $100m for the loss-making interactive divisions of American toy group Hasbro.

The deal to buy Hasbro Interactive and Games.com adds around 200 video games to Infogrames' range. Even before its official launch next year, games.com has registered 1m users and 4m visitors.

Infogrames, which is paying Hasbro $5m in cash and $95m in 4.5m new shares, also gains a 15-year licence to develop and publish digital interactive games based on Hasbro properties.

These include the interactive versions of children's games and toys such as Action Man (above), Mr Potato Head and Tonka Trucks. Board games including Monopoly, Scrab ble, Risk and Boggle are also part of yesterday's agreement.

Infogrames' shares fell €2.5 to €21.5 as analysts worried that integrating Hasbro Interactive's losses could push Infogrames into the red. The stock has lost 60% since hitting a high of €58 in February.

But Bruno Bonnell, Infogrames chairman and chief executive officer, said the takeover of Hasbro Interactive would not dent Infogrames earnings and the company would return to profitability this financial year.

Infogrames' courting of Eidos did not go through because the companies could not agree on a price. An Infogrames spokesperson said: "Infogrames has always had a very acquisition-focused strategy."

The deal to buy Hasbro Interactive and Games.com adds around 200 video games to Infogrames' range. Even before its official launch next year, games.com has registered 1m users and 4m visitors. Infogrames, which is paying Hasbro $5m in cash and $95m in 4.5m new shares, also gains a 15-year licence to develop and publish digital interactive games based on Hasbro properties. These include the interactive versions of children's games and toys such as Action Man (above), Mr Potato Head and Tonka Trucks. Board games including Monopoly, Scrab ble, Risk and Boggle are also part of yesterday's agreement. Infogrames' shares fell €2.5 to €21.5 as analysts worried that integrating Hasbro Interactive's losses could push Infogrames into the red. The stock has lost 60% since hitting a high of €58 in February. fields.headline: Leeds battle European army
fields.standfirst: O'Leary's cup fighters march on with the red forces, says  David Lacey
fields.trailText: The Champions League is delicately poised and for English interests intriguingly so. The tournament enters its two-month winter break with Manchester United's prospects looking stronger than they did, those of Leeds United reborn yet again and only Arsenal giving real cause for concern.
fields.body:
The Champions League is delicately poised and for English interests intriguingly so. The tournament enters its two-month winter break with Manchester United's prospects looking stronger than they did, those of Leeds United reborn yet again and only Arsenal giving real cause for concern.

With two rounds run on a league basis before the competition reaches its quarter- finals, the Champions League may have abandoned much of the spirit of the original European Cup, which, though it was not a straight knockout, did at least retain some of the feeling of cup football most of the time.

Yet the pattern of a number of matches this season suggests that teams are still approaching games in cup-fighting mood. Take Leeds United's 1-0 win over Lazio in Rome on Tuesday night. That was surely a classic piece of cup football: a triumph of sound defending and disciplined midfield play followed by an exquisitely burgled late goal and, ultimately, inspired goalkeeping.

Manchester United may be the team most likely to bring the European Cup to England for the second time in three seasons but for the moment the continued refusal of Leeds to accept the ill luck of their group draws is holding the attention.

With each setback the determination of David O'Leary's players to do better in their next European match is redoubled. Leeds went to Rome having been outplayed at home by Real Madrid a fortnight earlier but, as Lazio quickly discovered, emerged a team transformed.

At this level simply battling for survival is not enough. The quality of Leeds's winner on Tuesday, the backheel by Mark Viduka which coincided to perfection with Alan Smith's run through the Lazio defence, was an outstanding example of the standards of passing, movement and finishing to which potential European champions need to aspire.

Leeds's chances of making the last eight as runners-up to Real in Group D will rest largely on the outcome of their two games against Anderlecht in February. The Belgian champions, who lost their opening match in the first round 5-1 to Manchester United but still won the group, are another example of the need to keep faith with ability.

As much applies to Arsène Wenger's Arsenal, who having won their first-round group in impressive style are now bottom of Group C in the second phase with one point from two matches. Unlike Leeds, the response by Arsenal to a bad initial result in the second round, their 4-1 defeat by Spartak in Moscow, was to throw away a 2-0 lead against Bayern Munich on Tuesday.

Whereas Leeds have been handicapped more than most by injuries, Arsenal's recent indifferent form is more about a decline in confidence. This problem appeared solved during the first hour against Bay ern when, despite the absence of Dennis Bergkamp, the Arsenal attack combined pace and imagination with a rediscovery of their finishing touch.

Yet after Thierry Henry and Nwankwo Kanu had scored two excellent goals, a lapse in concentration by, of all people, Tony Adams and Martin Keown allowed Bayern back into the match, and once Mehmet Scholl's wickedly flighted free- kick had brought the scores level the freshly healed cracks in Arsenal's confidence quickly reopened.

Wenger must hope that by the time his side face Lyon in February they will have regained the form that produced a 15-match unbeaten run after the defeat at Sunderland on the opening day of the season. Playing Silvinho, unfit on Tuesday, on the left of midfield instead of Robert Pires and keeping the impressive Ashley Cole at left-back might be worth considering.

For the next two months Arsenal will concentrate on gathering the Premiership points they need to ensure a place in next season's Champions League. They still look the most likely runners-up to Manchester United but need to beware of Liverpool and, perhaps, Leicester or Ipswich.

By the time Sir Alex Ferguson's team, having seen off Panathinaikos and Sturm Graz, meet last season's beaten finalists Valencia their lead domestically should be well into double figures. For Leeds, third place in the Premiership looks the most viable option and O'Leary's side will spend Christmas and the new year period striving to close the seven-point gap that currently lies between Elland Road and more Champions League drama next season.

Failing that they could still get there by winning the European Cup this time. Improbable maybe, but not impossible.

webTitle: Republican right challenges Dubya's unifying promise

fields.headline: Republican right challenges Dubya's unifying promise
fields.standfirst: The governor of Texas is insisting he'll be a unifying president. But, as Martin Kettle explains, other powerful Republicans are thinking very differently
fields.trailText: The governor of Texas is insisting he'll be a unifying president. But, as Martin Kettle explains, other powerful Republicans are thinking very differently.
fields.body:
George W Bush's transition team has adopted "bringing America together" as its slogan, and not a day now passes without Mr Bush or one of his surrogates talking about the need to "reach out" to Al Gore's supporters.

Having campaigned before election day as "a uniter not a divider", Mr Bush is making it clear that he intends to present himself to the American people as a conciliatory leader.

He will be a man who is ready to work with the Democrats in a new and bipartisan spirit in the evenly divided political environment that has been created by the 2000 election.

That, at least, is what Mr Bush would have you believe. But this, in turn, is precisely why Texas congressman Tom DeLay's press interviews this week have been so intriguing.

Because either Mr DeLay or Mr Bush is heading for a fall.

Mr DeLay, the Republican majority whip in the House of Representatives, is probably the most powerful politician on Capitol Hill today.

But you would not know that from the negligible amount of publicity that the congressman from Houston attracted during the election campaign.

Mr DeLay, who, with Newt Gingrich, was the principal architect of the Clinton impeachment drive, has been kept strictly out of sight from August to November, content to raise funds and consolidate alliances, skills of which he is a master.

This week, however, he came out into the open, with a series of remarks that amount to a declaration of war - not just on the Democrats, but on almost everything that Mr Bush has been saying.

"You're going to think I'm crazy," Mr DeLay said this week, "but I didn't see this as a tie election. This is something I've been working for for 22 years.

"I mean, we got it. The Republicans are the majority party in this country."

From where Mr DeLay sits, the results on November 7 were not a triple stand-off but a hat-trick of Republican wins.

You will hear no talk from Mr DeLay about politicians of good will getting together. What you will hear is the triumphalism of a man who believes that the operative word in the phrase "narrow majority" is majority, not narrow.

"We have the House, we have the Senate, we have the White House, which means we have the agenda," Mr DeLay announced on Wednesday.

He could hardly have put it more clearly than that. But, just in case there might be someone who detected a note of bipartisan backsliding, Mr DeLay then underscored his point.

"We'll act exactly the same way as we have been. We'll write conservative bills and ask the Democrats to participate," he said.

"The things we've been dreaming about we can now do."

Two of Mr DeLay's closest allies struck the same note. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas announced on Tuesday that Republicans now had the opportunity they have been seeking for half a century.

Congressman John Doolittle of California described the party's position as "awesome", and announced that the moment had arrived to implement "the rest of the Contract with America" - in other words, the Newt Gingrich deregulatory agenda of 1994.

If there are still people out there who think that it is going to make no difference whether Mr Bush or Al Gore ends up as Bill Clinton's successor, then they should look at the legislative priorities that Mr DeLay has set out for a Bush administration.

Mr DeLay's priorities are to cut personal and corporate taxes, remove consumers' right to sue large corporations and reduce the size of the federal government while expanding the armed forces budget.

He also wants to ban so-called "partial birth" abortions, and rally the party against any measures to reform campaign finance laws or introduce tighter gun controls.

Some of this is bravado, of course, but don't ever think that Mr DeLay is not serious. Not only that. No one in US politics, with the exception of Mr Bush, is in a stronger position to set the agenda right now than Mr DeLay.

The question of the moment is this: which Texas Republican is going to be the winner and which the loser?

Because they can't both be telling the truth.

webTitle: Scottish Media Group buys SRH stake

fields.headline: Scottish Media Group jumps gun by buying SRH stake
fields.trailText: 10.45am:Scottish Media Group has taken a stake in Scottish Radio Holdings ahead of the communications white paper, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Scottish TV company SMG has pre-empted next week's communications white paper by making a move for rival broadcaster Scottish Radio Holdings.

Scottish Media Group has taken a 14.9% stake in SRH, owner of the Radio Clyde and Radio Forth stations, in anticipation of a relaxation of radio ownership rules.

SMG said: "The UK media sector continues to evolve through developments such as the promised communications white paper.

"SMG intends to be a leading player in any consolidation of UK media and believes that this investment positions it well until the implications of the new legislation are clear."

Culture secretary Chris Smith is next week expected to announce a change in the current "points system" of radio ownership.

The key players in the UK commercial radio industry are keen to reduce the number of independent companies from 12 to three, allowing the likes of SMG, Capital Radio, GWR and Emap to launch acquisition sprees.

SMG owns Virgin Radio and is keen to build up its Scottish portfolio if the white paper allows operators to increase their share of the radio audience.

SRH has had a bumper year, reporting record profits of £20m on turnover of over £70m.

Rumours have circulated the City for some time that SMG would make a move on SRH, but the company denied any intent to significantly increase its holding.

SMG said it has "no current intention of making an offer for the whole of SRH".

As the holder of the Scottish Television and Grampian ITV franchises, SMG is the sixth largest TV programme maker in Britain. It also owns the Herald and Evening News newspapers.

SMG's shares shot up 7.9%, or 22p, to 261p on the news, with some analysts predicting a possible merger between the two companies.

The publication of next week's white paper is likely to spur merger and acquisition activity in the media sector, as ownership rules are likely to be relaxed across the board.

Radio companies have been vocal in their demands for a change to the present system.

webTitle: SRH advises shareholders to hold fire

fields.headline: SRH advises shareholders to hold fire
fields.standfirst: Dec 8: SMG buys SRH stake
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Scottish Radio Holdings has told its shareholders to take no action after SMG sparked a likely auction for the company, writes Dan Milmo.
Dec 8: SMG buys SRH stake
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings (SRH) has told its shareholders not to accept any further offers for its shares from Scottish Media Group.

SMG, the media company that owns Scottish Television and Virgin Radio, today snapped up a 14.9% stake in SRH, a move that is likely to spark an auction for the company.

The publication of next week's communications white paper is likely to relax radio ownership rules, making SRH a prime target for its bigger rivals

However, SRH is unlikely to hand over control without inviting other bidders into the ring, as a consolidation spree looms for the whole sector.

SRH said in a statement: "The board of SRH anticipates that there will be significant changes to media ownership rules and this may open the way to a period of consolidation in radio.

"In view of this, the board strongly advises SRH shareholders to take no action."

An SRH spokesperson added that the company had a "duty" to raise the maximum amount of money for shareholders and this may alter the landscape around SMG's takeover manoeuvres.

All the major commercial radio players have expressed their desire to reduce the sector to three key companies, with Emap, GWR, Capital Radio and SMG likely to lead the way.

SRH has licences in Ireland and central Scotland, making it an attractive target for any company seeking to establish a UK-wide radio network.

fields.headline: White paper to announce 'ombudsman' system for BBC complaints
fields.trailText: The BBC is to be stripped of its powers to act as judge and jury on viewers' complaints, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The BBC is set to be stripped of its powers to act as judge and jury when it comes to viewers' complaints.

A new high-street bank style system of dealing with aggrieved licence payers will instead be put in place, giving an outside body regulatory power over the BBC board of governors for the first time.

Culture secretary Chris Smith will announce a new "ombudsman" system as part of the much-anticipated communications white paper next Tuesday.

Under the proposals, licence payers will still go to the BBC with their complaints in the first instance.

But if they are not satisfied they can go to the outside regulator.

The new body will have the final say when it comes to complaints and will judge whether the BBC's own internal complaints system - which has often been criticised for being opaque - has been fair.

At present viewers only have recourse to an internal appeals system that operates under the auspices of the board of governors.

A government source said: "At the moment viewers feel they have nowhere to go if the BBC ignores their complaint. They can go to the BSC but they don't feel the BBC is being held to account.

"It will be similar to the complaints system that operates in banks and building societies. There will be a series of options open for licence payers with an ombudsman holding the final say."

It is understood, however, that not all issues will be covered by the ombudsman - the BBC will still adjudicate over matters concerning impartiality.

The BBC fought hard to maintain control in this area, amid fears that its editorial independence could be compromised in the face of complaints from politicians and lobby groups.

fields.headline: Goldman trims Microsoft forecast
fields.trailText: An influential Wall Street analyst downgraded Microsoft yesterday, citing renewed evidence that consumers were buying fewer personal computers.
fields.body:
An influential Wall Street analyst downgraded Microsoft yesterday, citing renewed evidence that consumers were buying fewer personal computers.

Shares in the world's most highly valued software company fell by $3.81 -about 8% - to $52.88 after Rick Sherlund of Goldman Sachs, which handled Microsoft's initial public offering in 1986, trimmed his earnings and sales estimates for the next six months.

Mr Sherlund described the revision as "relatively moderate" and based on the "preponderance of evidence of sluggish retail PC demand". Apple Computer underlined the slowdown in consumer spending this week when it issued a profits warning.

Goldman Sachs trimmed both earnings and sales estimates for Microsoft, cutting $125m from the revenue forecast to $6.7bn-$6.8bn. The Apple warning also helped prompt a Microsoft downgrade at rival Merrill Lynch, where analyst Chris Shilakes predicted weakening demand for software upgrades.

In a note to investors, Goldman tried to lessen the impact of its downgrade by saying retail PC purchases account for only 10% of Microsoft revenues.

Mr Sherlund also suggested that much of the downgrade had already been digested by the market. Shares in Microsoft have more than halved since the beginning of a year in which it has fallen foul of the courts for abusing its monopoly position.

fields.headline: At this price?  Coats Viyella
fields.trailText: Since it became clear in May that Coats Viyella was not going to be taken private through a buyout engineered by Lord Rothschild, the share price has unwound like one of its own balls of thread.
fields.body:
Since it became clear in May that Coats Viyella was not going to be taken private through a buyout engineered by Lord Rothschild, the share price has unwound like one of its own balls of thread.

The latest move by Lord Rothschild, a call for an extraordinary general meeting to discuss proposals for new blood to be brought on to the board, might have been expected to trigger a recovery.

But the shares were up a mere 0.25p at 45.5p yesterday, compared to more than 60p earlier in the year. The reaction was muted in part because the shares had been given a little forward momentum last week by speculation about a boardroom shake-up.

There are also many who believe that further upheaval is not good news for a company already in the middle of restructuring.

A letter to the Coats Viyella chairman, Sir Harry Djanogly, from Blake Nixon, executive director of Lord Rothschild's fellow shareholder activists at Guinness Peat Group, is scathing about current performance and calls for a review of the company's disposal programme.

The dissidents hold 35% of Coats Viyella equity so they will get an EGM. The fact they had to call for a special meeting indicates the board has not been receptive to requests for a change in direction.

Understandably, directors do not relish another review of business strategy. Only after much soul searching and use of consultancy time did management agree to offload large parts of the business to concentrate on the core, £1bn turnover operation: threads. Last night this strategy was in doubt and the short-term prospects for Coats Viyella's share price look poor.

The longer term view has to be better if the company can benefit from the financial and intellectual muscle of Lord Rothschild's RIT Capital plus Guiness Peat and South Africa's Chapman Consortium.

Terry Macalister

webTitle: Into the Silicon valley of hope they gallop

fields.headline: Into the valley of hope they gallop
fields.standfirst:
America's hi-tech haven welcomes determinedly optimistic immigrants - but some old timers say the pioneer spirit is fading along with the share prices

Net news
fields.trailText: America's hi-tech haven welcomes determinedly optimistic immigrants - but some old timers say the pioneer spirit is fading along with the share prices.
fields.body:
Jeremy Burton is excited. The 33-year-old from Stockton-on-Tees is sitting in his office at Oracle's gleaming Silicon Valley headquarters, demonstrating his latest toy, Blackberry, a tiny device that allows users to access their company email wherever and whenever they want.

It is the latest must-have accessory for every executive who wants to stay connected and Mr Burton could not be happier. "I only set it up last night but already I'm addicted. I sent my secretary an email from the car on the way into work this morning and she couldn't work out how it was getting to her. It's brilliant."

Mr Burton started out answering the phones at Oracle's customer help centre in Guildford, Surrey, in 1993. Five years ago, after a promotion to the marketing department, he travelled to Oracle's global headquarters at Redwood Shores, about 15 miles south of San Francisco, to help with a product demonstration. He has been there ever since.

Today he is a senior vice president, responsible for the global marketing of Oracle's software products, manages a team of 160 people and drives a Porsche.

As a Brit Mr Burton used to be a rarity here but California's internet revolution, like the gold rush before it, is attracting thousands of immigrants every year. An increasing number are Brits chasing dreams and fortunes, determined to play a part in an era many say will go down in history as the second industrial revolution.

Mr Burton could retire tomorrow if he cashed in his share options. Yet he typically spends 12 hours a day in his office six days a week and puts in another two or three hours when he gets home. Last year he racked up 200,000 business miles.

"I love it. Working here is totally unlike working in England. My grandfather was a coal miner, my dad ran the local unemployment office in Stockton, I speak with a northern accent and went to the local comprehensive but no one cares. All they want to know here is whether I can get the job done.

"You work long hours but it's an incredible buzz. When I give presentations there can be 4,000 people in the audience. That's more than Hartlepool United get for a home game."

Pilgrims expecting glamour and beauty to go with the latest technology and the sunshine will be disappointed, however. Silicon Valley has no heart, neither physi cally nor metaphorically. It stretches from San Francisco down Highway 101 past Redwood City, Menlo Park and Palo Alto to San Jose about 40 miles to the south.

Some say its spiritual centre is Palo Alto where Bill Hewlett and David Packard founded the computer firm Hewlett-Packard in a garage in 1939. Others say it is the University of Stanford, whose labs have supplied start-ups that now account for 60% of the revenues in the valley.

Until the late 1960s the area was known as the Valley of the Heart's Delight. Apricot and plum orchards were the region's main revenue generators. Today those groves have been replaced by mile upon mile of soulless business parks that are home to the likes of Oracle, Cisco, Netscape, Yahoo! HP and Sun Microsystems. Glance in a copy of the San Jose local weekly paper and you will find a news section dominated by stories about San Francisco, a thin arts section and page upon page of advertisements for cosmetic improvement, four-wheel drives and three-bedroom bungalows with prices starting at $500,000.

Woodside, where thoroughbred horses graze in the paddocks of ranch-like homes, is where Oracle's Larry Ellison and Cisco's John Chambers live.

Sandhill Road, where the big venture capital firms congregate, oozes wealth and power. In the third quarter alone an area a little over two square miles handed out a record $6.6bn, more than a third of all venture funds invested in the US.

Residents throughout the region have to cope with some of the highest house prices and worst traffic problems in the US. Rush hour on the 101 seems to last all day, commutes are getting longer and public transport is almost non-existent.

Yet still they flock here, armed with a business plan and a dream..Many find the valley culture totally alien when they arrive. "Spend £1m on property in Stockton and you'd get a whole street but here you'll only get a reasonable place - you won't get a mansion," Mr Burton says.

"Yes, you miss the silly things. Match of the Day, sipping oxtail soup while watching Middlesbrough get beat 2-0 on Boxing day, the pub culture, the cynicism, the sense of humour."

Corporate pride is a big thing. In the canteen at Commtouch, an email outsourcing specialist, staff munch on free lunches and play table football below garish posters plugging the employee referral scheme: Earn cash rewards or a weekend in Mexico each time you persuade a friend to come and work at Commtouch.

There is a dry cleaning service, regular company barbecues for all the family and a golf course behind the car park. And, of course, everyone is given stock options.

"Companies treat their staff well here because they know that if they don't someone else will," says Isabel Maxwell, president of Commtouch. A Brit and one of the valley's highest-profile entrepreneurs, she has reason to be thankful for the lack of interest in people's backgrounds: she is the daughter of disgraced publishing magnate Robert Maxwell.

For all the talk of meritocracy and equality, female executives of Ms Maxwell's seniority are still a rarity and an MBA or M Eng from Stanford or Harvard is still far more likely to get you in the door.

Silicon Valley fosters innovation and entrepreneurs unlike anywhere else in the world. Those that have been here a while say the high tolerance of risk, vast quantities of venture capital, a large skilled workforce and a desire to execute on business plans at unmatched speeds make it a compelling location to start a business.

Nick Denton, 34, co-founded Moreover.com, a service that aggregates news from across the net, in London in 1998. He says Moreover had to open an office on the west coast if its global ambitions were to be taken seriously. "San Francisco is the capital of the internet world and you have to have an embassy here."

Moreover is one of the lucky ones. Of every 100 hopefuls like it, 99 are dispatched empty handed. Of those that gain funding, only 10% survive.

Mr Denton heads the US operation and a 20 strong staff of Brits, Latvians, Hungarians, Canadians and Americans. Moreover's office, in an area previously populated by seedy night clubs and warehouses, is a model dot.com start-up: an open-plan fifth-floor loft space packed with flashy laptops and the requisite table football.

"All high-technology companies, regardless of location, will be required one way or another to maintain a presence here," agrees Wilf Corrigan, a Liver pudlian who founded semiconductor firm LSI Logic in the early 80s and is now a billionaire. "Silicon Valley will continue to be the place which other states and other countries will try to emulate."

Entrepreneurs come to the valley to "breathe the internet", says Mr Denton. "You can learn more from going to a party here than you can from spending a week at a conference in Europe. Venture capital firms in the valley offer a totally different quality of money than in Europe."

San Francisco's obsession with the internet is as offputting for some as it is inspiring and addictive for others. In the run-up to the US presidential election, Gore, Bush and Washington politics rarely rated a mention on the social circuit.

Some of the Brits stick together. Mr Denton shares a house with Adam Gold, vice president of finance at UK-founded start-up Obongo. They were two of the original team behind First Tuesday and have replicated the cocktail party-cum- networking idea in San Francisco with a monthly event for expats called Eurotrash.

Another favourite hangout is a pub called The Mad Dog in the Fog, largely because it shows British football live on a big screen. "You can go in there at 4am on a Saturday and find groups of lads drinking pints, eating fry-ups and watching Man U v Leeds live from Old Trafford," says Dominic Johnson, marketing director of intelligent software firm Autonomy, which has headquarters in San Francisco and Cambridge.

Much about San Francisco is upside-down. Floor space in the district where Moreover is based is now more expensive than the financial district where big players such as Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch have offices.

Veterans of the valley say it is losing some of pioneer-days purity. Twenty-something graduates with no working experience can demand "ridiculous" salary and share option packages, Ms Maxwell says.

Share prices are monitored feverishly. Mike Mortiz, a Cardiff-born partner at Sequoia, the venture capital firm that gave Yahoo! and Cisco their first funding, says the market sell-off has been beneficial. "There is a sense that the tourist season in Silicon Valley is ending. The bankers and consultants are scuttling back to where they came from."

Exhausted programmers pulling all-nighters at the big firms remain resolutely upbeat, deaming not of a place in history but of early retirement.

"When that stock hits $120 I'm gone," one engineer at Cisco admitted. "Some want four or five million [dollars] before they retire. Me, I'm happy to take less. All me and my wife want is a place in the hills and money to travel comfortably."

He may have some time to wait, however. Cisco shares were trading yesterday in New York at just over $50.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Once upon a time in the land of Widdy Web...

fields.headline: Once upon a time in the land of Widdy Web...
fields.trailText: Whenever I feel jaded and disillusioned with politics, I have a certain, surefire tonic. I fire up the internet and log on to www.political.co.uk/ annwiddecombe, or the Widdy Web as it is known to its creator and thousands of admirers.
fields.body:
Whenever I feel jaded and disillusioned with politics, I have a certain, surefire tonic. I fire up the internet and log on to www.political.co.uk/ annwiddecombe, or the Widdy Web as it is known to its creator and thousands of admirers.

This is not politics as most of us experience it. Here there are no insults shrieked across the chamber, no skulduggery in the division lobbies, no plotting, no scheming, no backstabbing or twisted, thwarted ambition. The Widdy Web is a magical island of calm, as re-assuring and gentle as Five Acre wood, or the riverbank in the Wind in the Willows where Ratty and Mole are enjoying an endless summer picnic.

In particular, when you reach the Widdy Web home page, you should click on "Junior", admire the picture of Ann hugging a giant Pooh bear even bigger than she is, and then select "My cottage". Up comes a picture of our heroine looking, it must be said, somewhat morose as she stands in front of a newly glazed front door.

Perhaps she knows that under Jack Straw's stewardship almost everyone who goes outdoors is mugged within 10 minutes, because she looks a lot happier in the snap taken inside the humble cot.

She explains to the kiddies that she needed to spend time in Maidstone, "so I bought a little cottage ... soon I will be adding more pictures of my cottage to this site. It is very pretty in summer, with lupins all up the front garden and clematis all around the walls. I do hope you like my cottage."

Like it? I love it. In summer, when the floods recede and some trains start running again, I'll be there in shorts and a t-shirt, a bag of sausage rolls and wine gums in one hand, and a stone bottle of ginger pop in the other! Then we'll spread one of Ms Widdecombe's tartan jackets on the grass and have a lovely, lovely time together!

But the section I like best of all is entitled "My Cats". This is genuinely affecting because it's clear that she truly loves her pets. They have been central to her life. She can remember all of them - from Jimmy, who she used to chase as a little girl, through Tibby, Monty, Blacky, Sooty, Sweep and now Pugwash, a handsome black cat who was "sadly dumped by his owners, who bought him as a Christmas present but then didn't love him properly".

There is, perhaps, slightly more information here than the most enthusiastic young felixophile could require. "Our next cat was Mitten-the-Kitten. He was a black cat with a white shirt and white paws and we bought him from Herman-the-German for 50p.

"Mitten had a good life, and used to like fresh liver, though he didn't like it if any splashes arrived on his white shirt when he would move very disdainfully away from the dish and solemnly wash it off before returning to finish his meal. Mitten lived to the grand old age of 14, when sadly he died of kidney failure."

And they say that people are no longer bothering to surf the internet!

Yet, and yet, I found myself rather moved. Miss Widdecombe pretending to be horrified by something Jack Straw has said is much sillier than her thoughts about her cats, which at least are sincere and passionately felt.

I popped into the chamber to see John Bercow (or "Bercow-the-Berk" as Ms Widdecombe's family would no doubt have called him) raging against the Nice summit, just as it was getting under way. He was banging on about "our right freely to chart our destiny as a nation ... the inalienable rights of free-born Englishmen are not to be sold for a mess of pottage..."

Give me Ann Widdecombe's cats any day. And they would have loved a mess of pottage, which was simply a sloppy meat stew.

webTitle: Drug not available on NHS does slow Alzheimer's, study finds

fields.headline: Drug not available on NHS does slow Alzheimer's, study finds
fields.trailText: A drug has been shown to slow deterioration in the way patients with Alzheimer's disease function in their daily lives, according to research published today which will strengthen the case for such drugs to be prescribed on the NHS.
fields.body:
A drug has been shown to slow deterioration in the way patients with Alzheimer's disease function in their daily lives, according to research published today which will strengthen the case for such drugs to be prescribed on the NHS.

There has been much controversy about the three drugs now in use for Alzheimer's, of which galantamine (Reminyl), the subject of the latest research, is one. All three - the others are donepezil (Aricept) and rivastigmine (Exelon) - are cholinesterase inhibitors and work in the same way.

While the families of Alzheimer's sufferers want the drugs to be prescribed on the NHS and claim they improve their relatives' quality of life, some specialists have argued that the studies so far only show benefits that are measurable in terms of scores on tests.

But the latest study, according to the Alzheimer's Disease Society, has a different design. It was funded by the manufacturers and published in this week's British Medical Journal.

It claims to find "significant benefits" for patients' daily living. There was an improvement in a small number of cases, but in a large number the deterioration usually seen with Alzheimer's was slowed.

Gordon Wilcock, professor of care of the elderly at Frenchay hospital, University of Bristol, and colleagues, investigated 653 patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease attending 86 outpatient clinics in Europe and Canada.

The results showed that the condition of 50% of patients who received a placebo declined. This compared with 38% of those on a lower dose of galantamine and 35% of those on a higher dose.

In 33% of those on a placebo there was no change, compared with 44% and 41% of those on low and high dose galantamine respectively.

The research has gone to the national institute for clinical excellence, which is considering whether to recommend that this class of drugs be made available on the NHS.

webTitle: Conkers get the boot as schools fear lawsuits

fields.headline: Conkers get the boot as schools fear lawsuits
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Traditional playground games like British bulldog, conker fights and even football and skipping are being banned from schools because head-teachers fear they will be sued if children get injured, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Traditional playground games like British bulldog, conker fights and even football and skipping are being banned from schools because head-teachers fear they will be sued if children get injured, according to research published today.

The study, by Sarah Thomson of Keele University, claims that the school lunchbreak is in danger of becoming a sterile, joyless time as teachers over-react to an increasingly litigious society.

Yet far from wanting to play computer games indoors, many children wanted bois terous physical activities and a proper break from their classroom work.

The findings, set out in today's Times Educational Supplement, were based on analysis of the playground activities of 1,000 children in Staffordshire, Shropshire and Lancashire. Even football was banned at three out of six primary schools she surveyed for being too anti-social. British bulldog was outlawed at all six. Some schools banned conkers as "offensive weapons".

The need to show a tightly-controlled play environment to Ofsted inspectors was also a factor in schools trying to cut down on boisterous physical activity, the research showed.

webTitle: Graduates are bullish on career and salary prospects

fields.headline: Graduates are bullish on career and salary prospects
fields.trailText: Graduates are an increasingly powerful and demanding group, brimming with confidence and forcing employers to fulfil their expectations or risk losing the war for talent, a new survey revealed last night.
fields.body:
Graduates are an increasingly powerful and demanding group, brimming with confidence and forcing employers to fulfil their expectations or risk losing the war for talent, a new survey revealed last night.

Seven per cent of graduates now expect a "golden hello" payment and one in five who had received a job offer felt sufficiently confident to turn it down, according to the Guardian's Grad Facts 2000 survey in association with the Association of Graduate Recruiters.

Work and quality of life balance rates highly, with 36% rating over 30 days' holiday as a more attractive benefit than a car or pension scheme.

But while employers are being forced to meet graduates' high expectations in order to attract recruits, they can expect little company loyalty. One third of graduates do not anticipate staying with their first employer for more than a year or two.

The survey of 2,000 final year university students shows that getting a good job and friends is rated more highly than sex or money in terms of graduates' personal interests.

However, job satisfaction is still the main priority, with men more anxious than women about getting an excellent salary - 61% to 52% - while 36% of men are con cerned about a good social life, compared to 29% of women.

Women (31%) were keener than men (19%) to have an inspirational boss or mentor.

The survey also reveals that 51% of graduates said they would baulk at the prospect of having to perform a test when applying for certain jobs.

Seventy per cent expected a starting salary of between £10,000 and £18,000, with over half hoping for at least £14,000 but 8% expected to get over £20,000. In terms of career appeal, one in five females would like to work in the media, while a similar proportion of men wanted computing and information technology careers.

But some 47% of all graduates, men and women alike, thought working for the police, armed forces or prison service would be the most unappealing career, while 33% thought teaching would not be the right choice for them.

Confidence was high and graduates were optimistic about their job prospects despite starting job hunting late. More than half (52%) expected to be job hunting as late as September. One in five graduates who had been offered a job felt sufficiently confident to turn it down.

The survey was carried out by Mori and replies were received from 2,009 questionnaires given to graduates across the UK.

fields.headline: Tobacco firm's new university link-up
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The world's second largest tobacco company, which has been accused of exploiting smuggling in Britain and abroad, is to sponsor a new masters degree in strategic communications at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco is to spend thousands of pounds in a second British university as the government prepares to outlaw commercial advertising and sponsorship.

The world's second largest tobacco company, which has been accused of exploiting smuggling in Britain and abroad, is to sponsor a new masters degree in strategic communications at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology.

Disclosure of the £50,000 investment by BAT follows the row triggered earlier this week over a £3.8m gift to open a school of business ethics at Nottingham University.

Anti-smoking campaigners accused the firm, which is under investigation by the Department of Trade and Industry, of attempting to "buy respectability" and bypass impending legal constraints on promoting tobacco.

Karl Brookes, a spokesman for Action on Smoking and Health, said last night: "When the industry is spending £100m a year and facing a ban, this kind of expenditure can buy respectability on the cheap. They are preparing in advance for the advertising and sponsorship ban."

BAT is to spend £10,000 a year over the next five years financing the Umist course, which will produce the first MSc of its kind and will have a seat on the course's advisory board.

The first part time students will enrol next April, and other sponsors include Tesco, Burson-Marsteller, Allied Zurich, Reuters and the BG Group.

PR Week magazine yesterday reported that two bodies in the public relations sector had endorsed the link but the head of a third had warned the course was "tainted" by BAT's involvement. Roger Haywood, chairman of the PR standards council, was quoted as calling for sponsors to boycott it.

"Potential candidates should also consider postponing their participation until BAT has either pulled out or announced a timetable to change its business ethics," he said.

BAT denies allegations that is has exploited smuggling but its involvement in an industry that kills 120,000 Britons every year has made the acceptance of its money by universities controversial.

The Labour MP Kevin Barron, chairman of the Commons group on smoking and health, said last night: "Universities should reconsider their links with tobacco companies. The industry and BAT are looking at how to get around the advertising ban."

BAT denied it was trying to buy influence or get round the looming advertising ban, a spokesman insisting it was interested in supporting higher education.

Michael Prideaux, BAT's director of corporate affairs, said: "We have a contribution to make to the teachings of corporate communications in order to make a professional discipline. It is better to involve BAT rather than ostracise us."

The Tory health spokesman, Liam Fox, yesterday questioned in the Commons whether the government's tobacco advertising and promotion bill would cut smoking deaths.

"I have an instinctive and uncomfortable feeling about banning advertising of anything which is a legal substance.

"But I am willing to put that to one side if scientific evidence is put forward that any particular mechanism is able to get a reduction in smoking prevalence," said Dr Fox.

webTitle: Inland Revenue investigates Dyke's property company

fields.headline: Inland Revenue investigates Dyke's property company
fields.trailText: 9am: A property company in which BBC director general Greg Dyke is a board member is being investigated by the Inland Revenue, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A property company in which Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, is involved is being investigated by the Inland Revenue.

The inquiry means that Mr Dyke has been unable to fulfill the undertaking he gave earlier this year to dissolve the firm, Coursetopic.

He joined the company's board in October 1999, four months after taking the director general's job.

The wind-up procedure for the company has been halted after a formal objection from the Inland Revenue, which is investigating the trading performance of Coursetopic, according to a report in the Times.

The revelation that Mr Dyke is on the board of a company being investigated by the Inland Revenue is a huge embarrassment for the BBC.

A BBC spokesman said: "Mr Dyke's involvement in this company was the subject of some press coverage in January. The firm wasn't trading then and still isn't. His business managers are in the process of winding it up."

webTitle: Blair must listen to parents more than to employers

fields.headline: Blair must listen to parents more than to employers
fields.standfirst: The green paper is so flexible that those who shout loudest will win
fields.trailText: Half-full or half-empty? The government's green paper on working parents was greeted with some confusion by campaigners.It is one of the most flexible green papers ever written - full of possibility, but no certainty.
fields.body:
Half-full or half-empty? The government's green paper on working parents was greeted with some confusion by campaigners. It is one of the most flexible green papers ever written - full of possibility, but no certainty. Everything, says the Department of Trade and Industry, is out for consultation, so this rubber document can be bounced either way. Who shouts loudest wins - parents or the CBI?

Next Thursday outside the DTI there will be a "baby blockade" with small children and big plastic toys and tractors to mimic the fuel protesters under the banner "Does the government only listen to those with trucks?" The demo is demanding better maternity pay, paid parental leave and the right to work flexible or part-time hours.

Yesterday's green paper launch was a skilled operation. Briefers were out in force, telling one story to employers and another to the parental-rights campaigners. Stephen Byers started out dismally at the DTI: remember his "wealth creation matters more than wealth redistribution" and his attempt to sabotage part-time workers rights. He has come a long way since then but he is still trying to appease both sides.

Last April he was briefing that there would definitely be a right to paid parental leave, (13 weeks spread over five years). Since then the CBI's Digby Jones has bullied and browbeaten with such success that no paid parental leave appears in this green paper. "We were strongly against it," says the CBI.

On the other hand the women in government fought hard too - and there are options in this green paper that could profoundly improve life for parents. Before the manifesto is written, Byers will have to declare which side he is on. Women MPs and ministers were busy sending out the message yesterday - "Push him hard!" Since the CBI is now the government's political enemy anyway, (having played strong cards with considerable stupidity), Byers might as well find favour with the women instead.

One campaigning backbencher emerged from a DTI briefing saying "Brilliant!" Others were more circumspect. Britain's maternity and paternity rights are the worst in the EU and Byers agrees: "The status quo is not an option." Mothers trying to return to work after having a baby have been treated cruelly until now - no childcare and low maternity pay for only 18 weeks. The wonder is that so many do manage to get back to work.

Research by Harriet Harman for the clothing union KFAT, found women working in factories forced to return to work within weeks, describing an almost unbearable wrench. Nationally 25% of mothers go back to work well before their 18 weeks is over because they can't afford not to. Under the family-friendly Tories, maternity pay fell from 40% of average earnings to 20%, forcing poorer mothers back to work ever sooner. Now Labour will probably promise that the £62 a week maternity pay will rise to £100 and possibly more, for the full 26 weeks. Mothers who can afford it can take a full year off, while fathers get two weeks paid paternity leave - a good gesture, long overdue.

But one remarkable proposal could profoundly change the working habits of the entire nation. All mothers and fathers could get the right to reduced working hours for as long as they wish. It would be the first genuine attempt to reform Britain's long-hours culture. After the shameful way the government weaselled out of the EU directive imposing a 48-hour maximum week, here is a chance to turn Labour's "family-friendly" talk into action.

But it may not happen. The CBI yesterday expressed shock at finding the right to part-time working proposed at all. "It would be most damaging. It is a sticking point for us," they said, indignant that for once they were not forewarned. They will fight it all the way, demanding "reasoned encouragement" to employers instead of a legal obligation.

However DTI research found flexible hours was what parents wanted most. This could start a revolution. If campaigners push to see that paid parental leave is reinstated too, with a right to spread it out across one day a week, suddenly the four-day week looks possible - and eventually universal. Why not? With 30% more wealth in the next decade why not work less?

Will Byers stand firm? He has also proposed a loophole that would effectively nullify the right to flexible work. Small businesses may be exempt. That means exempting a third of the workforce, including those who most need the right: many bigger employers already offer flexibility. Labour has gone to extraordinary lengths to mollify small employers as if they were a national treasure, when the opposite is often the case. Small businesses are already exempt from many workers rights.

When the minimum wage was first mooted, it was small employers who claimed thousands of jobs would be lost. Meanwhile large employers briefed - sotto voce - that if some small businesses went to the wall because they couldn't afford to pay a living wage, it would be no bad thing. Those running small nursing homes, or marginal catering and cleaning outfits often offer bad services, undercutting better professional companies that give employees decent conditions.

Some economists suggest Britain's low productivity, about which Gordon Brown fulminates frequently, may be partly connected with the UK having too many small companies: a quarter of all EU firms employing under 20 people are in the UK. As larger companies point out sardonically, few small companies choose to be small. Yet there is a strange Treasury sentimentality about them, offering special tax breaks and assistance. Why should they get a dispensation to mistreat their workforce with exemptions from reasonable employment laws? (Should small chimney-sweeping companies still be allowed to send boys up chimneys?)

Labour's manifesto could trounce the Tories by offering a revolution for young families. It would expose Tory "family" talk for the cant it is. One popular move would be Harman's idea of a special tax credit for under-threes, allowing mothers to stay at home or use it for childcare if they go back to work. What about a pledge for state-of-the-art nurseries in every neighbourhood for all?

Could the Tories refuse to endorse these? Yet every time they match Labour spending, as on health and education, their tax cuts become more incredible. The Tories will mistakenly take the employer's side on these parental rights, while Labour now has the chance to write a dazzlingly popular manifesto for families.

 Parents at Work demo, at the DTI, 1 Victoria St, SW1. December 14, 10.30 am. Bring small children and big toys.

Last April he was briefing that there would definitely be a right to paid parental leave, (13 weeks spread over five years). Since then the CBI's Digby Jones has bullied and browbeaten with such success that no paid parental leave appears in this green paper. "We were strongly against it," says the CBI. On the other hand the women in government fought hard too - and there are options in this green paper that could profoundly improve life for parents. Before the manifesto is written, Byers will have to declare which side he is on. Women MPs and ministers were busy sending out the message yesterday - "Push him hard!" Since the CBI is now the government's political enemy anyway, (having played strong cards with considerable stupidity), Byers might as well find favour with the women instead. One campaigning backbencher emerged from a DTI briefing saying "Brilliant!" Others were more circumspect. Britain's maternity and paternity rights are the worst in the EU and Byers agrees: "The status quo is not an option." Mothers trying to return to work after having a baby have been treated cruelly until now - no childcare and low maternity pay for only 18 weeks. The wonder is that so many do manage to get back to work. Research by Harriet Harman for the clothing union KFAT, found women working in factories forced to return to work within weeks, describing an almost unbearable wrench. Nationally 25% of mothers go back to work well before their 18 weeks is over because they can't afford not to. Under the family-friendly Tories, maternity pay fell from 40% of average earnings to 20%, forcing poorer mothers back to work ever sooner. Now Labour will probably promise that the £62 a week maternity pay will rise to £100 and possibly more, for the full 26 weeks. Mothers who can afford it can take a full year off, while fathers get two weeks paid paternity leave - a good gesture, long overdue. But one remarkable proposal could profoundly change the working habits of the entire nation. All mothers and fathers could get the right to reduced working hours for as long as they wish. It would be the first genuine attempt to reform Britain's long-hours culture. After the shameful way the government weaselled out of the EU directive imposing a 48-hour maximum week, here is a chance to turn Labour's "family-friendly" talk into action. But it may not happen. The CBI yesterday expressed shock at finding the right to part-time working proposed at all. "It would be most damaging. It is a sticking point for us," they said, indignant that for once they were not forewarned. They will fight it all the way, demanding "reasoned encouragement" to employers instead of a legal obligation. However DTI research found flexible hours was what parents wanted most. This could start a revolution. If campaigners push to see that paid parental leave is reinstated too, with a right to spread it out across one day a week, suddenly the four-day week looks possible - and eventually universal. Why not? With 30% more wealth in the next decade why not work less? Will Byers stand firm? He has also proposed a loophole that would effectively nullify the right to flexible work. Small businesses may be exempt. That means exempting a third of the workforce, including those who most need the right: many bigger employers already offer flexibility. Labour has gone to extraordinary lengths to mollify small employers as if they were a national treasure, when the opposite is often the case. Small businesses are already exempt from many workers rights. When the minimum wage was first mooted, it was small employers who claimed thousands of jobs would be lost. Meanwhile large employers briefed - sotto voce - that if some small businesses went to the wall because they couldn't afford to pay a living wage, it would be no bad thing. Those running small nursing homes, or marginal catering and cleaning outfits often offer bad services, undercutting better professional companies that give employees decent conditions. Some economists suggest Britain's low productivity, about which Gordon Brown fulminates frequently, may be partly connected with the UK having too many small companies: a quarter of all EU firms employing under 20 people are in the UK. As larger companies point out sardonically, few small companies choose to be small. Yet there is a strange Treasury sentimentality about them, offering special tax breaks and assistance. Why should they get a dispensation to mistreat their workforce with exemptions from reasonable employment laws? (Should small chimney-sweeping companies still be allowed to send boys up chimneys?) Labour's manifesto could trounce the Tories by offering a revolution for young families. It would expose Tory "family" talk for the cant it is. One popular move would be Harman's idea of a special tax credit for under-threes, allowing mothers to stay at home or use it for childcare if they go back to work. What about a pledge for state-of-the-art nurseries in every neighbourhood for all? Could the Tories refuse to endorse these? Yet every time they match Labour spending, as on health and education, their tax cuts become more incredible. The Tories will mistakenly take the employer's side on these parental rights, while Labour now has the chance to write a dazzlingly popular manifesto for families.  Parents at Work demo, at the DTI, 1 Victoria St, SW1. December 14, 10.30 am. Bring small children and big toys.

fields.headline: News International tightens belt
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's News International has placed a freeze on staff hiring and plans to crack down on expenses amid fears of a global downturn in advertising revenues.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News International has placed a freeze on staff hiring and plans to crack down on expenses amid fears of a global downturn in advertising revenues.

The group, which owns the Sun, News of the World and Sunday Times, is also fearful of rising paper costs.

The cutbacks coincide with the closure of eVentures, an internet investment venture set up by Mr Murdoch and Japan ese venture capital group Softbank.

Dow Jones, owner of US financial newspaper the Wall Street Journal, yesterday issued a profits warning due to declining advertising sales at the publication. That unsettled shares in Financial Times owner Pearson, despite later assurances from the company that the FT's circulation and advertising were well up on last year.

News International advertising revenues have been strong in recent weeks as consumer-focused companies rush to advertise in the run-up to Christmas. However, executives believe demand might diminish after the January sales.

Several newspaper and television groups are already feeling a chill wind from declining advertising spend this winter.

Sales boomed last year, thanks largely to lavish dot.com advertising campaigns but turbulent stock markets and cash-flow problems at several internet busi nesses mean that spend will not be repeated.

eVentures was set up to bring successful US internet businesses to Europe. ePartners, a News Corp-backed unit headed by former BSkyB chief executive Mark Booth, was a 50% shareholder.

Mr Murdoch has struggled to replicate in the online arena his commercial successes in other media. News International's web strategy has seen several shifts and several sites have been shut or face closure.
