fields.headline: 3G mobile debt alarms FSA
fields.trailText: Britain's banks were given a sharp warning yesterday about lending to telecoms firms which are hungry for funds to finance new-generation mobile phone services.
fields.body:
Britain's banks were given a sharp warning yesterday about lending to telecoms firms which are hungry for funds to finance new-generation mobile phone services.

The financial services authority, the City's top watchdog, told 34 banks they should be "particularly alert to any worsening of conditions".

The comments followed a series of reviews the FSA conducted with the major lenders to telecoms companies, although it emphasised most firms were behaving prudently.

There is mounting concern about the financial demands imposed by buying third-generation mobile phone licences in the UK and Germany, as well as rolling out of the networks needed to deliver the services. According to industry estimates, the combined cost of acquiring licences and building networks in Europe will be $300bn (£209bn).

Shares in the German group Mobilcom fell by one-fifth yesterday amid concerns - swiftly denied - that it might be strapped for the cash to finance its 3G programme.

Mark Davis, an analyst at WestLB in London, said investors were worried about the cost of the licences and networks and the fact that it would be some time before the operators began generating revenue.

In terms of revenue per subscriber per month over the length of the licence, the amounts needed to cover companies' investment appeared much more manageable, however. "If you took 100% penetration it would be about €2 a month per subscriber."

The FSA warning came amid suggestions that the cost of rolling out the networks, which will be able to deliver services such as email, web browsing and video conferencing, might be higher than expected.

Quotient Communications, a consultancy firm which has advised the government on telecoms issues, said companies would need more base stations than were required for second-generation networks.

"I don't know if operators have factored that into their calculations," said Quotient managing director Rodney Stewart.

Michael Foot, managing director of the FSA, said that the regulator did not have any immediate cause for concern. "However, firms need to have high-calibre risk management systems in place and need to be acutely aware of the risk of building up concentrations of exposure to the industry, which they might not be able to trade down as quickly as they once hoped."

Among its recommendations the FSA said banks should perform their own credit checks instead of relying on external rating agencies. They should have a clear strategy about the amount of money they wanted to lend to the sector.

The FSA had reviewed the exposure of 34 banks which have lent money to telecoms firms and concluded that the average exposure to telecoms firms was up to 5% of big banks' assets but around 40% of group capital. Most of the exposure was high-grade credit risk.

webTitle: Labour plans £100 a week maternity pay

fields.headline: Labour plans £100 a week maternity pay
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for a near-doubling of statutory maternity pay, in the most radical changes to parental rights since the second world war. Mothers will be offered £100 a week to stay at home with their new-born babies - a huge increase on the current £60.20 a week. By Sarah Hall
fields.body:
Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for a near-doubling of statutory maternity pay, in the most radical changes to parental rights since the second world war. Mothers will be offered £100 a week to stay at home with their new-born babies - a huge increase on the current £60.20 a week.

The move, which would cost the state an estimated £12m extra a week, is designed to slash the number of new mothers who return to work early because they are unable to survive on the current figure. More than half of new mothers return before the 18 weeks of paid leave to which they are entitled - with 80% citing money as the reason.

The plan, widely welcomed by family groups, is among proposals in the government's green paper on work and parents, published yesterday. It seeks to bring Britain's provision for working parents into line with Scandinavian and other EU states.

The consultation document suggests that working mothers should have the right to stay at home for a year after their child's birth - with paid maternity leave extended from 18 to 26 weeks. Unpaid breaks could last up to 12 months - instead of the present 22 weeks - and fathers could be given two weeks' paternity leave, paid at the same rate as mothers. Both parents could have the option of sharing unpaid maternity leave.

In a surprise move calculated to woo women voters, mothers could also have the right to work reduced hours for up to a year after their child's birth. The flexible working could continue when maternity leave ends, although small businesses could be exempt. Large businesses could also be let off if they can prove that their business would be "unduly disrupted".

The reduced hours plan, which the women's ministers, Tessa Jowell and Baroness Jay, and the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, had pressed hard for during a ministerial review process, had been widely expected to be dropped in the face of opposition from big business. But ministers believe it is the key to retaining the third of women who do not return to work after giving birth - at a cost to employers of £3,500 a worker, or £300m a year to the economy

"I think this is the most important issue," Ms Hodge said. "We need to find a way of reconciling the business interests with the interests of a lot of mothers, and what a lot of women want is more flexible working hours." Nearly half of all working women have children under five, with the figure likely to be 70% by 2010.

Launching the paper, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the review group had been surprised to learn that adoptive parents had no maternity rights. They would be able to take paid leave in line with birth parents, he said.

He described the work-life balance as "one of the key issues facing us in a modern society", and insisted that the system had to change. "The labour market has changed dramatically over the last 25 years and the status quo is not an option. We need to give support and assistance to parents, but in a way that business will recognise as important."

He said the employment services would be encouraged to train more temporary replacements for small businesses, while cash advances would be offered to cover employers' maternity pay. "There's an opportunity where we can marry both being a good parent and a good employee."

The proposals, out for consultation until March, were widely welcomed. The Maternity Alliance praised the government's determination to "move things forward"; the Equal Opportunity Commission said it showed a commitment to supporting families.

The Confederation of British Industry said flexible employment practice should be "encouraged, not regulated", and said extending maternity leave and offering paternity leave would hit small businesses.

webTitle: Celebrity mags shun Madonna's big day

fields.headline: Celebrity mags shun Madonna's big day
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Madonna and Guy Ritchie will not be doing a deal with celebrity titles OK! or Hello! for their wedding story, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Madonna and Guy Ritchie will not be doing a deal with a celebrity magazine for their wedding.

Sources say the showbiz couple were asking between £2m and £3m for photographs of the big day, forcing rivals Hello! and OK! to retreat from any serious talks.

Both magazines have had discussions about getting exclusive pictures to the wedding after it was announced that the pair would wed in a Scottish highland village on December 22.

But it was thought that to run the story in Christmas week - with few shops open and most people off work - would fail to generate enough sales to justify the investment.

Hello! publishing director Sally Cartwright said: "The timing of this wedding is unusually unfortunate for magazines and newspapers. It would be difficult to get an adequate return on a significant fee.

"With a big wedding and a commercial deal, the possibility of snatched pictures is very real and the longer the lead time, the greater the risk."

OK! editor Martin Townsend said the title had had "conversations" with representatives for Madonna and Guy Ritchie "on a fairly casual basis".

The war for celebrity exclusives has become more and more heated in recent months.

Last month OK! tried to obtain an injunction on Hello! after it took unofficial wedding pictures of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones after OK! secured exclusive rights to the pictures.

fields.headline: DSS rebuked over benefits fiasco
fields.trailText: Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, is to investigate how Whitehall tried to avoid a "bad press" by covering up an attempt to get 112,000 poor people and pensioners to pay back £10.5m of benefits they had received twice by mistake. David Hencke reports
fields.body:
Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, is to investigate how Whitehall tried to avoid a "bad press" by covering up an attempt to get 112,000 poor people and pensioners to pay back £10.5m of benefits they had received twice by mistake.

An internal Department of Social Security audit report, leaked to the magazine Computer Weekly, revealed that Alastair Darling, social security secretary, was kept in the dark by civil servants on the quickest way to get the cash back. Instead they opted for a complicated process that has still left the ministry owed £3m and has cost £465,000.

The money had been paid twice by the benefits agency into the bank accounts of 111,954 people, 43% of them pensioners, using new automatic bank credits - which will become the standard way of paying benefits from 2003.

Civil servants were advised that the quickest ways to retrieve the extra money would be to withhold payments for one week or debit the recipients' accounts.

A more complicated way involved writing to ask them to return the money, with the threat of legal action if they failed to pay it back. This was the operation carried out, and the problem was compounded by a series of mistakes.

All the letters were sent on the same day, resulting in 2,000 people jamming the benefit agency's switchboard. Nearly 1,000 letters involved sums of less than the 19p stamp it cost to send the demand. Letters were also sent to dead people and to social services departments. Claimants who owed more than £1,000 were sent demands omitting the first digit, and corrected demands had to be sent out.

The report revealed that the ministry had to handle 20,200 telephone calls, 65,000 letters in reply and 168 bounced cheques - costing £17,479. And 77 people refused to pay.

It said Mr Darling chaired a "crisis meeting" after the double payments error was discovered. The reason he was not told about the easy way to claim back the cash was that "this may have caused further bad press or external pressure from lobby groups".

The DSS's auditors expressed concern about the risks of duplicate payments as the government prepares to pay tens of billions of pounds in welfare benefits by automated credit transfer into recipients' bank accounts. "As we move towards delivery in 2003 it is imperative that we limit our exposure," said the report.

Frank Field, a former DSS minister who has asked a series of questions about the overpayments, said: "It would appear that ministers have been kept in the dark. Effective government can only be ensured if officials are open and honest with ministers."

The national audit office is expected to comment on the debacle when it produces its annual report on the DSS accounts next year. It is at present investigating the ministry's competence in handling income support benefits for a report due next summer.

fields.headline: Prebble backs BBC's channel plans
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ONdigital boss Stuart Prebble has backed the BBC's controversial plan to develop a range of niche free-to-air channels, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Stuart Prebble, chief executive of digital terrestrial pay-TV operator ONdigital, has backed the BBC's controversial plan to develop a range of niche free-to-air channels.

Mr Prebble is supporting the move because it will help drive the take-up of digital TV.

He said: "The idea that if you're only receiving BBC1 and 2 you've only got half the set is exactly the one I want to convey.

"Very few brands are strong enough to just extend themselves numerically - and you have to be as powerful and ubiquitous as the BBC to believe that viewers will come to understand the differences between BBC 1, 2, 3 and 4 just as they currently understand the differences between Radio 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. Good luck."

In his MacTaggart speech at the Edinburgh TV festival in August, BBC director general Greg Dyke set out his plan for BBC1 to become more focused on mainstream entertainment, BBC2 to be aimed at older viewers, BBC Choice to become BBC3 and target the youth audience, and for BBC Knowledge to become BBC4 - a Radio 4 on TV.

The announcement met with howls of protest from critics who argued that the proposals would lead to less popular programming, such as documentaries, current affairs and coverage of the arts, being banished to little-watched digital channels.

Mr Prebble, speaking last night at the monthly Royal Television Society dinner in central London, also praised Channel 4 for launching FilmFour and E4.

He added that ITV was now, "thanks to consolidation and common cause among its shareholders, in a position to bring about a seismic shift in the landscape of pay television in the UK", with a "small number of strong and well-resourced ITV multi-channels".

Mr Prebble also dismissed forecasts that the growth of multi-channel TV would mean existing advertising revenue being spread ever more thinly.

He reckoned online and interactive services would open up new revenue streams.

"When TV can do for advertisers lots of things for which they previously had to rely on other media, more advertising money will move into television, producing better content."

Mr Prebble also announced that ONdigital was to sponsor the first ever RTS award for innovation in interactive TV content. The prize will be open to producers, format originators and scriptwriters.

fields.headline: Freeserve marketing chief quits
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Freeserve's marketing director, Neil Sansom, has quit amid fears of a staff exodus following the sale of the company, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve is to lose its marketing director, Neil Sansom, next week amid fears of a staff exodus following the sale of the company.

The news will come as something of a blow to French buyer Wanadoo, which was hoping to retain Freeserve's senior management team after the deal goes through.

Mr Sansom, who has been with Freeserve for nearly two years, is leaving the internet start-up world for a more traditional and established company, Shell.

Mr Sansom, who had his leaving party last week, has managed to keep news of his departure quiet so as not to prompt speculation of a staff exodus or give Wanadoo any cause for concern.

According to a source close to Freeserve, Wanadoo had not been told of Mr Sansom's pending departure at the time of signing the deal.

The only departure announced on Wednesday at the Freeserve/Wanadoo press conference was that of chief financial officer Nick Backhouse.

Mr Sansom is credited as having been instrumental in defining Freeserve's core brand values and launching the company's £8m marketing campaign, "Be Freeserve".

He joined soon after launch in September 1998 from Dixons rival Comet where he was new retail development controller.

webTitle: IPC 'loses its nerve' with Nova redesign

fields.headline: IPC 'loses its nerve' with Nova redesign
fields.trailText: 8.15am: IPC is to redesign women's title Nova following rumours that the publisher lost its nerve after criticism from advertisers. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC is retrenching from the cutting edge design of Nova, which it relaunched last year, following rumours that the publisher lost its nerve after criticism from advertisers.

Jeremy Langmead, editor of the women's magazine, is to rethink the title's original "daring" design to bring it closer to mainstream fashion magazines Elle and Vogue.

Mr Langmead, who joined in September following the sudden departure of Deborah Bee, told MediaGuardian.co.uk that the magazine was "too masculine" and "hard to find your way around".

The original style bible of the 1960s and 70s, Nova was synonymous with the values of swinging London.

Many in the industry hailed IPC's decision to relaunch the magazine last year as a return to a more daring style of magazine design.

But after only a few issues, Ms Bee left the magazine.

Mr Langmead, formerly editor of the Sunday Times's Style magazine, has brought in former Independent on Saturday magazine art director Gary Cochran this week to redesign the title for the March issue.

Meanwhile, Emap Elan's Red also plans a revamp, and is reported to be preparing to launch Red Home, a spin-off home interest title.

Red, under new editor Trish Halpin, is believed to be squaring up to face competition from the new H Bauer women's glossy, codename Project Helena.

fields.headline: Britain hails charter triumph
fields.standfirst:
Human rights articles aim to give EU 'moral dimension'
Special report:European integration
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: European Union leaders yesterday put their names to a new charter of fundamental rights that Britain had successfully fought tooth and nail to keep out of the Treaty of Nice. But Tony Blair has almost certainly not heard the last of it.
fields.body:
European Union leaders yesterday put their names to a new charter of fundamental rights that Britain had successfully fought tooth and nail to keep out of the Treaty of Nice. But Tony Blair has almost certainly not heard the last of it.

The 15 heads of government "solemnly proclaimed" the 53 articles of the charter, which is designed to make existing rights "more visible" to ordinary EU citizens and to give a moral dimension to a body which has never before given prominence to human rights.

Mr Blair rejected Tory charges that the document is the constitution of an embryonic super state. "It's plainly not," the prime minister said. "It's not even legally binding".

And shortly before the ceremony, the prime minister refused to sign a new declaration accompanying the charter's formal launch. "Blair put his foot down and made clear that there was absolutely no question of him signing any further document," one diplomat said.

Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, hailed the charter as a triumph for Britain, and taunted the Conservatives and eurosceptic media for having opposed it. "Everyone who said that this was the end of the world, that this would be a new constitution, they were wrong," he said.

Despite being outside the planned treaty of Nice, some experts believe the charter could start to affect the jurisprudence of the European Court of Justice, which interprets and enforces EU law.

But Mr Vaz insisted: "This charter is not going to be justifiable. You cannot sue under this charter".

British opposition watered down or removed references to the right to strike and protection against unjustified dismissal. The document itself says : "This charter does not establish any new power or task for the community or the union, or modify powers and tasks defined by the treaties".

Although a more sceptical line has prevailed for now, enthusiasts such as France, Germany and Italy are demanding that it be written into a future treaty. Those countries are expected to call for its inclusion in a future inter-governmental conference reviewing the workings of the EU, an idea which Britain will resist.

fields.headline: Under the weather
fields.standfirst:
Forecasters warn of new floods.

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Britain was back on weather alert last night as torrential rain and severe gales battered the south-west and forecasters predicted a repeat of the storms which wreaked havoc in October.
fields.body:
Britain was back on weather alert last night as torrential rain and severe gales battered the south-west and forecasters predicted a repeat of the storms which wreaked havoc in October.

High winds and heavy rain caused flooding and treacherous road conditions in the west country where eight flood warnings were in place. Police reported much of west Wales was cut off by floods, with a severe flood warning on the river Wye in Herefordshire.

The Met Office warned the storms would spread today, and issued a severe weather warning for the weekend of winds of up to 80mph and structural damage. "This weekend's storms will be on a similar scale to the last one on Oc tober 30. Some parts of western Britain will get around two and a half inches of rain which will cause problems for any rivers already on alert," a spokesman said.

The "vigorous depression" which formed in the Atlantic off Portugal and moved towards south western England - shown in the satellite picture above - is set to travel over the Irish sea and Northern Ire land today before hitting western Scotland early tomorrow. Flood warnings are in place on 24 rivers, including the river Ouse in York, where the clean up has barely begun in the wake of flooding which hit thousands of properties six weeks ago.

The A38, A39 and A30 roads in Devon and Cornwall were last night badly hit by flooding, leading to many pile-ups. Devon and Cornwall police spokesman Stuart Elford said there were "dozens and dozens" of road accidents. A landslide at Dawlish closed the main Plymouth to Exeter railway line in Devon.

As the village of Harbertonford in Devon found itself under water again last night, Clive Lawrence, landlord of the Malsters Arms, said: "This is absolutely ridiculous. This is the fifth time this year."

webTitle: Comment:Time for a referendum on the monarchy

fields.headline: Time for a referendum on the monarchy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: "What, you a republican?!," exploded a Tory peer recently when the subject of the Economist's anti-monarchical views came up; "but you are intelligent, you think things through."
fields.body:
"What, you a republican?!," exploded a Tory peer recently when the subject of the Economist's anti-monarchical views came up; "but you are intelligent, you think things through."

I could simply have returned the compliment, but the grilling swiftly moved on, as it often does on this topic, to a claim that I could not possibly have thought of a better constitutional arrangement with which to replace the crown.

It cut little ice when I protested that countless other democracies seem to rub along perfectly well with either an American- or a German-style president. Although my friend and accuser is a very internationalist, even pro-European Tory, he remains gripped by the idea that Britain's constitution has somehow been shown, by the test of time, to be ineffably superior.

I disagree. Britain has simply been lucky - or unlucky, depending on your point of view - that neither war nor internal turmoil has yet challenged its peculiar constitutional arrangements, so it has stuck with the legacy of history. Fair enough, up to a point: as Australia's referendum on the monarchy showed, it is hard to muster support for a change when there is no crisis. So why did we, in October 1994, declare on our cover that the monarchy was "An idea whose time has passed"?

Simply put, it was because I had become editor only in 1993 and the autumn of 1994 brought the first pretext for me to hold forth about this subject. It was the height of the warfare between Charles and Diana, and in response to questioning about Jonathan Dimbleby's biography of Prince Charles, Prince Philip had said, quite sensibly, that a republic was a perfectly good alternative, and that if the British people were to want one then that would be fine by the royal family.

Well, since you asked, we said, we would indeed prefer a republic. Why? Because the Economist's philosophy has always been liberal, not conservative. As such, monarchy of any sort is, I wrote, "the antithesis of much of what we stand for: democracy, liberty, reward for achievement rather than inheritance. Surrounded as it is by privilege and patronage, the crown even has a certain, though not inevitable, bias against capitalism. It may be a symbol of unity but it is also a symbol of aristocracy, of feudal honours, of baseless deference."

But didn't we support Margaret Thatcher? Yes, because she acted to disperse the power of the state and of anti-democratic concentrations of muscle such as the trade unions, and republicanism is a logical extension of that pro-market, pro-individual view - even though the lady herself did not follow her own logic. But wasn't Walter Bagehot your editor, in the 1860s? Yes, and he defined the role of the monarchy in The English Constitution as a "dignified" channel for popular support, behind which the "efficient" parliament and administration could run the country. This depended on the idea that an uneducated populace could not then be relied upon to use power constructively. Now, with an educated populace, such an elitist position would be, to me, indefensible.

That is the argument in principle: a paper that believes in individual freedom and meritocracy ought not to favour a monarchy. In practice, also, the crown has had bad constitutional consequences: through the fiction that it can act as a check on the government, it bears guilt by association with the steady centralisation of power in the hands of the prime minister and his cabinet, especially a prime minister with a large majority in the Commons. The Lords has been neutered as a check since 1911, though it has revived a little since the (absolutely justified) abolition of the hereditary peers. With no constitutional court and a meek judiciary, the only checks are general elections and the media. That is nice for the media, and adds fuel to our natural pomposity and self-importance, but it is not a good way to run a democracy.

And what of the arguments against? To my mind, there are two bad ones and two that should be taken more seriously. One bad notion is that the monarch really does provide a constitutional safeguard, that its role is not a fiction. Although it is not impossible to imagine a monarch playing such a role, just as Juan Carlos did in Spain, my feeling is that in practice, just like the old House of Lords, monarchs will always be constrained by their lack of democratic legitimacy in confronting an over-mighty but elected government. The second is tourism. Gimme a break, is my response: the crowds still flock to Versailles two centuries since the tumbrils rolled.

The two better ones begin with sentiment. Perhaps the monarchy is just something that people like, an institution that may be crusty and not very modern, a bit like an old building, but one which people would rather keep than lose. that would not be my taste, but no democrat can consistently argue that people should have to get rid of the monarchy even if a clear majority still like it.

And then there is perhaps the strongest argument of all: that, abolishing the monarchy would simply not be worth the bother. We at the Economist agree with that, at present: other efforts to introduce checks and balances into Britain's constitution matter more, so let's get on with the second stage of reform of the Lords (including the abolition of all those ridiculous titles), with introducing a more proportionate electoral system, a proper freedom of information law, a more independent judiciary, and so on.

But that does not alter the principle of the matter. And, together with the argument of popular sentiment, it leaves me strongly in favour of a referendum on the monarchy at the next appropriate and logical moment: the succession.

 Bill Emmott is editor of the Economist

webTitle: Police injured as street riot greets leaders

fields.headline: Police injured as street riot greets leaders
fields.standfirst:
Resort's shops and banks attacked

Specialreport:European Integration
fields.trailText: The staid resort town of Nice became a shifting battlefield for riot police and protesters as the EU summit got underway yesterday to the smell of teargas and the sound of police sirens and helicopters clattering overhead.
fields.body:
The staid resort town of Nice became a shifting battlefield for riot police and protesters as the EU summit got underway yesterday to the smell of teargas and the sound of police sirens and helicopters clattering overhead.

Some 4,000 rioters, many masked or hooded, clashed repeatedly with police wearing body armour in the streets around the vast Acropolis congress centre where European Union leaders are meeting until Sunday to discuss crucial institutional reforms.

Flag-waving anti-globalisation demonstrators joined Spanish anarchists, French revolutionary communists, radical trade unionists and Basque and Corsican separatists in pitched battles with police throughout the morning, setting fire to a bank and overturning dozens of cars.

At one stage demonstrators fought their way to within 100 metres of the congress centre, triggering a volley of stun grenades and teargas shells.

"We solemnly condemn these acts," the French president, Jacques Chirac, told a press conference later. "They are in radical contradiction with the democratic traditions of all our countries. They do democracy no service."

Dispersed by fierce charges from CRS riot police, demonstrators replied with a hail of stones, bottles and molotov cocktails. Authorities said at least 16 officers were injured, one seriously, and a dozen protesters arrested.

The demonstrators were "extremely determined, armed with baseball bats, iron bars and carrying jerry cans filled with petrol," said a spokesman from the local government office. "There were certainly unpredictable and uncontrolled elements among them."

Around a dozen people were also injured at Vintimiglia on the Italian-French border in clashes between police and some 1,000 protesters trying to reach the Nice summit.

In the worst of the French violence, rioters set fire to a Banque Nationale de Paris office a few hundred metres from the Acropolis and then attacked the firemen who tried to put it out with sticks and paving stones.

Slogans reading Long Live ETA, Direct Action, Death to Money and Fascism=Capitalism were daubed on the building's facade in Basque, French and Italian. Other banks, offices and car dealerships were splashed with similar slogans. Demanding social justice in Europe, the protesters chanted "No Pasaran", "Europe is not for sale" and "No to a federal Europe".

Across the street, an estate agency's windows were smashed and its desks and computers overturned. "I feel discouraged and disgusted," said its owner, Luc Mercier. "They attacked the windows with sledgehammers. I'm just happy that no one was hurt."

Another angry crowd at tacked the car of a motorist who had knocked over several protesters.

The worst of the violence appeared to be over by midday, with a sizeable group of protesters heading for nearby Monaco to protest against international tax evasion. Some 150 were later detained at the border of the principality, which has long been accused of being a centre for money laundering.

Many protesters condemned the violence. "We are peaceful protesters, we don't want any violence," said Javier Pla, 20, a student from Valencia in Spain, clutching a gas mask. "These people are terrorists."

Anti-globalisation and anti-capitalism protests have become routine at inter-governmental meetings since protesters succeeded in severely disrupting the World Trade Organisation summit in Seattle last year.

Protesters have also created mayhem at an International Monetary Fund meeting in Prague, an informal EU summit in Biarritz and an Asian-European summit in Seoul.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday Inquiry faces collapse over secrets veto

fields.headline: Inquiry faces collapse over secrets veto
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: The Bloody Sunday inquiry could collapse due to a refusal by ministers to disclose documents relating to MI5 informers and to the army, the counsel to the tribunal, Christopher Clarke QC, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The Bloody Sunday inquiry could collapse due to a refusal by ministers to disclose documents relating to MI5 informers and to the army, the counsel to the tribunal, Christopher Clarke QC, warned yesterday.

The inquiry was abruptly adjourned to allow Lord Saville, the tribunal's chairman, to inspect documents covered by public interest immunity certificates blocking disclosure, signed by Jack Straw, and the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon.

The Home Office documents refer to claims made by serving and former MI5 officers, and to two informers known as Infliction and Observer B. The inquiry has heard that they both claim the IRA opened fire before paratroopers did in Londonderry on January 30 1972 in an operation that left 13 unarmed civil rights marchers dead.

The informer known as Infliction is also alleged to have claimed that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness fired the first shot and had the Bloody Sunday episode "on his conscience".

Selected parts of MI5 and army documents have been aired at the inquiry's public hearings. However, large sections have been deleted and a tape of Infliction's debriefing has not been disclosed.

Infliction is understood to have made the allegation about Mr McGuinness in 1984, more than 12 years after the event.

The public interest immunity certificates are being challenged by lawyers acting for the relatives of those killed as well as those acting for the paratroopers.

The families say they should be able to scrutinise the documents to challenge their content; the soldiers to support claims they opened fire only after coming under attack.

In another twist, both the relatives of the victims and the two government departments concerned are citing article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights - the right to life - to back their case.

He told the inquiry: "Information that is not revealed might be something that you would, were it not secret, want to raise with one or more of the witnesses in order to resolve important issues in the case. If you cannot do so, the issue may simply be unresolvable."

webTitle: Concorde failures 'not relevant' to Paris disaster

fields.headline: Concorde failures 'not relevant' to Paris disaster
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: British Airways last night said that official investigations into two Concorde incidents involving parts of the plane falling off, revealed for the first time yesterday, had no bearing on the Air France crash in July which killed 113 people.
fields.body:
British Airways last night said that official investigations into two Concorde incidents involving parts of the plane falling off, revealed for the first time yesterday, had no bearing on the Air France crash in July which killed 113 people.

In the first incident Concorde was forced to make an emergency landing at Heathrow after part of its wing fell off. In the second, five months later, the crew on the same Concorde felt a "vibration plus a thump" as the plane lost part of its rudder.

Both incidents were examined by the air accidents investigations branch, which has made five safety recommendations. BA said they had all been carried out.

The company insisted: "These incidents have no relevance to the Air France crash. We remain confident that our Concordes, currently grounded because of the French investigation, will fly again soon."

BA said that after the incidents in 1998 Concorde's flight crews had handled events with customary professionalism. "The aircraft continued to fly normally and made normal, uneventful landings."

BA said Concorde demonstrated the effectiveness of its design, which limited the extent of any failures to a small section of one control surface. The air accidents investigation branch noted that BA's inspection programme was "well in excess of mandatory requirements".

The report said in the first incident crew members felt the plane shake for two or three seconds as it flew over the Bristol channel with 53 people on board. An engineer saw part of the wing was missing and Concorde slowed down to below the speed of sound and landed safely at Heathrow.

The report said part of one of the elevons - a moving part of the wing used to control pitch and roll - had separated from the wing. It had not been possible to pinpoint why the elevon had failed but its effects on control were "negligible".

In the second incident the crew felt a vibration near the Newfoundland coast, but the pilot decided to continue to New York, where the plane landed safely.

Engineers found that up to 70% of the lower section of the rudder was missing. The effect on the control of the aircraft had again been minimal.

The report recommended that BA and Air France, who own the 11 remaining Concordes, should consider changes to their safety checks on Concorde wings and replace elevons considered at risk.

BA, Air France, Concorde's manufacturer and safety bodies are all working on design modifications which could result in the plane flying again by next spring.

webTitle: Pinochet lawyers appeal against house arrest order

fields.headline: Pinochet lawyers appeal against house arrest order
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Lawyers for General Augusto Pinochet were trying to persuade appeal judges yesterday to overturn a lower court order for the former Chilean dictator's house arrest, arguing that it was based on procedural irregularities and threatened Chile's stability.
fields.body:
Lawyers for General Augusto Pinochet were trying to persuade appeal judges yesterday to overturn a lower court order for the former Chilean dictator's house arrest, arguing that it was based on procedural irregularities and threatened Chile's stability.

Armed forces chiefs were preparing to meet President Ricardo Lagos in the growing constitutional confrontation.

The appeal court case is the latest stage in the prolonged legal battle to force the general to be judged for crimes allegedly committed when he ruled Chile from 1973 to 1990.

The detention order was suspended on Tuesday pending the appeal. Gen Pinochet's lawyers said yesterday that the order had been made before the general had been questioned and before tests of his psychological state.

Human rights lawyers said that Judge Juan Guzman, who ordered the arrest, had acted correctly. "We have all confidence that, given the judge ordering the arrest followed the rule of law all along, there can be no doubt that the appeal will be thrown out," Juan Bustos said.

Judge Guzman is investigating more than 180 cases against the retired general and has repeatedly said that he has strictly adhered to the law.

The arrest order relates to Gen Pinochet's alleged involvement in more than 70 abductions and murders carried out in 1973 by a military squad known as the "Caravan of Death".

Both sides say they will appeal to the supreme court if the verdict goes against them, so the final decision may not be known until late next week.

President Lagos said that after he had met the the four commanders-in-chief to discuss the arrest order he would call a meeting of the National Security Council - which only meets to discuss events provoking institutional crises- once the courts had ruled on the appeal.

Mr Lagos maintains that Gen Pinochet's fate is a matter for the courts and says he will await their ruling to avoid giving the impression that any pressure is being put on the judicial system.

Gen Pinochet, 85, who recently recovered from pneumonia and is resting at his retreat in Bucalemu, 80 miles south-west of the capital Santiago, had been regarded as untouchable in Chile.

The detention order caused concern among rightwingers and the armed forces, which still wield enormous power.

More than 3,000 people died or disappeared, presumed dead, under Gen Pinochet's authoritarian rule from 1973 to 1989 while tens of thousands of Chileans fled the country.

Gen Pinochet returned from Britain in March after spending 503 days under house arrest near London.

He was held in Britain in October 1998 after a Spanish judge sought his extradition to face trial for the torture of Spanish citizens in Chile. But the House of Lords ruled that he was too old and sick to be tried. Doctors said he suffered two strokes while in Britain.

webTitle: Firm in train crash row likely to lose contract

fields.headline: Firm in train crash row likely to lose contract
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The company at the centre of the Hatfield rail crash is likely to lose a £250m Railtrack contract to maintain the east coast main line between King's Cross in London and the Scottish borders, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The company at the centre of the Hatfield rail crash is likely to lose a £250m Railtrack contract to maintain the east coast main line between King's Cross in London and the Scottish borders, it emerged last night.

Balfour Beatty, which warned Railtrack that it had discovered evidence of gauge corner cracking at the site of the crash at least 10 months before the accident, is competing for the contract with another company.

But Railtrack said yesterday it was carrying out a wide ranging review of all its contractors following Hatfield and could decide in future to carry out its own maintenance work.

Balfour Beatty said that it had been the preferred bidder for the contract until August, several months before Hatfield occurred. "But we agreed with Railtrack that it was not possible to complete the commercial and financial arrangements."

Another maintenance company, Jarvis, was then included in the bidding process.

The multi-million five year contract is due to start from next April, but Railtrack said yesterday that Hatfield had "changed the landscape" on the way contracts should be handled. It said that it was looking at tougher methods of monitoring contract work, as well as creating its own department.

This review will be completed early next year in time for a decision to be made about the award of new contracts. Sources indicated that Balfour Beatty was no longer the favourite for the east coast main line deal.

But the company still remains the preferred bidder for new contracts to the value of £350m for the Kent and East Anglia railway network.

Railtrack's planned changes were revealed as Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, chaired another industry meeting to discuss how to tackle the present crisis in rail. He also reacted angrily to a report in the New Statesman that he was adopting a complacent attitude.

Lord Macdonald told the magazine: "It's a crisis of confidence and it's been a crisis of investment, and it's been a political crisis in that privatisation took place in the wrong way."

The New Statesman seized on these words as a denial there was a real crisis, splashing "There is no rail crisis" on its front cover.

His remarks led to a critical reaction from the opposition parties and from commuters.

Archie Norman, shadow transport secretary, said: "What planet is Lord Macdonald living on? How anyone can say that the railways are not in crisis is unbelieveable. People sitting in delays today will find his words frankly astonishing."

Anthony Smith, national director of the rail passengers' council, said that Lord Maconald was misleading the public to deny the crisis.

"It is true that the state of the rail network was slowly improving. But until we have a date for when Railtrack's rerailing programme will end, there is no end in sight of the crisis."

Jonathan Bray, of the campaign group Transport 2000, said: "It is totally out of touch of him to talk like that. The biggest problems this government has faced, fuel and rail, are both transport issues."

Lord Macdonald said there should have been no doubt what he meant, and denied using a "relaxed" tone during the interview.

webTitle: Leader: The UK should drop its asylum veto

fields.headline: Fortress Europe
fields.standfirst:
The UK should drop its asylum veto

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The UK should drop its asylum veto.
fields.body:
A new crackdown on illegal immigrants by P&O Stena line in Calais has caught 43 stowaways in the first 24 hours. Faced with a steep increase in potential fines, the ferry company has hired 40 security guards to check every lorry bound for Dover. The Sun was unimpressed yesterday. It devoted two pages to how the French released the "bogus refugees", allowing them to try again to "sneak into Britain". All of which points to a possible solution, which the Sun might like to contemplate.

One reason why France is turning a blind eye to legal and illegal refugees heading to the UK is the lack of an EU common immigration and asylum policy. The EU member states in the Shengen group, do have a common approach following the 1997 Amsterdam treaty, but UK, Ireland and Denmark opted out. The result is that a pass-the-parcel approach to asylum seekers continues to apply in Europe. The countries under most pressure are those guarding the gates in the east (Germany and Austria) and south (Italy, Spain, Portugal) from the large number of asylum seekers from eastern states and north Africa. But last year's figures show that after Germany, the UK received the largest number of appli cants in Europe. If the UK dropped its veto - as it will be asked to do in Nice - and joined in the common approach, other European states would have to pay more attention to suspicious lorries heading towards UK - and the UK would have access to the Shengen data-base, the largest in Europe, on who has been refused entry by other states.

There are reasons why more liberal organs than the Sun, might also agree to a common approach too. Currently, the UK cherrypicks the EU immigration directives it is ready to back. In Nice, it is supporting two directives tightening regulations (one against traffickers in illegal immigrants and another creating a common expulsion and deportation procedure) but opposing a more liberal move to allow citizens to bring in foreign spouses and relatives. Although all European states vigilantly guard their borders, German and French ministers have joined the British in acknowledging Europe's need to import more skilled workers to fill its labour gaps. This is a new shift. Unlike the US and Australia, immigration has always had a negative connotation in the UK. This new positive approach, is another reason why it would make sense for the UK to drop its veto.

fields.headline: Monarchy reform move in Lords
fields.standfirst: Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Ministers in the Lords have been preparing to accept in principle that the 299-year-old Act of Settlement is anomalous in excluding Roman Catholics, Muslims and other non-Protestants from succeeding to the throne.
fields.body:
Ministers in the Lords have been preparing to accept in principle that the 299-year-old Act of Settlement is anomalous in excluding Roman Catholics, Muslims and other non-Protestants from succeeding to the throne.

Ministers were to make the admission in response to a move to repeal the act by Lord Forsyth, the former Conservative Scottish secretary.

Ministers known to support repeal include the Scottish secretary, John Reid, the first Roman Catholic to hold this post. He has described the act as "inherently discriminatory".

The revelations came as a leading Labour backbencher, Tony Wright - chairman of the public administration select committee - backed the Guardian's campaign for abolition of the act.

He described the act as prejudicial and called for its re form. Scottish Nationalist MPs have tabled an early day motion calling for repeal. Labour MPs are expected to add their names next week.

Ministers will also be forced further into the open on the constitutional controversy when they respond to a challenging report commissioned by the Home Office.

Submitted six weeks ago, it details pervasive religious discrimination and is expected to argue that laws meant to deal with this are anachronistic.

The Home Office constitution unit has written to the Guardian saying the government is still considering whether to give females equal rights to succeed to the throne.

Full text of the Act of Settlement

webTitle: East grows tired of waiting game

fields.headline: East grows tired of waiting game
fields.standfirst:
Pressure builds on EU to move quickly towards a united continent
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Pressure builds on EU to move quickly towards a united continent
fields.body:
Eastern European leaders called yesterday on their EU colleagues at the Nice summit to put aside their divisions and agree on sweeping internal reforms to open the way for a historic reunification of the continent.

Speaking during a ceremony to mark the mission of enlargement, candidate countries repeatedly warned the existing 15 members that failure to agree an overhaul could scupper hopes of finally ending cold war divisions.

"The Europe of today has to take the opportunity offered by the courageous changes in eastern Europe to unite the continent," urged Jacek Saryusz-Wolski, Poland's minister for European affairs. "We're making real advances and we should not be kept out in the cold anymore."

Leaders of the 13 applicant countries joined their EU counterparts for the opening day of the three-day summit, billed as the toughest since Maastricht in 1991. Nice must resolve a series of difficult and interlocking institutional problems if the union is to be able to almost double its size over the coming years.

Without changes to the voting weights of governments, the size of the European commission and the extent of majority voting, decision-making machinery designed for the six founder members back in 1957 will seize up.

Tony Blair, championing the process, said last night that it was "impossible to overemphasise the importance" of the countries of Europe coming together half a century after the end of the second world war. This echoed the theme of his Warsaw speech last month about the future of the EU which was intended to link the institutional reform agenda to the need to enlarge as quickly as possible.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "The EU needs to show courage and imagination with the reforms that are needed to make ready for enlargement."

The EU foreign affairs commissioner and former Tory party chairman, Chris Patten, said the desire of eastern European countries to join the union showed that Eurosceptic fears of a federal Europe were unfounded. "There are at the moment 10 former central and eastern European countries that want to become members of the European Union. They are countries that escaped from the Soviet yoke in the mid and late 1980s.

"Do you actually suppose that a country like Poland, a proud, independent country which fought for its own sovereignty, wants to join the European Union in order to lose that sovereignty? It is barking."

Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Cyprus began negotiating their terms of entry two years ago. Earlier this year they were joined by Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Malta, Lithuania and Latvia.

Turkey, the 13th hopeful, has not begun negotiations because of complications over human rights and disputes over Cyprus and the Aegean.

Enlargement is seen as the biggest single challenge for the EU following the launch of the single currency, though there are varying degrees of enthusiasm for the process. France is widely blamed for refusing to give a date for entry beyond the general commitment to be ready in 2003.

"It is possible that in the poisonous atmosphere after a disappointing summit the accession of the first candidate countries will have to be put off," said Liberal Democrat MEP Andrew Duff. "There are plenty of people in France and Germany who would like a pretext to put it off."

Candidates' fears

Michel Barnier, the French European commissioner, said: "There could be a crisis here. I don't think it will happen, but I can't say it won't."

Estonia's foreign minister, Toomas Ilves, said: "It is important that at Nice the member states come to an agreement that will allow enlargement to succeed. Without that agreement, the process will be slowed down."

Janos Martonyi, his Hungarian colleague, warned that a failure at Nice would set back the enlargement process significantly. "But don't think we will give up. We will be members of the EU."

The summiteers are expected to give final approval to a strategy of intensified negotiations that could see the leading candidates joining by January 1, 2004.

But many of the wannabes are now worrying about the launch of a new and time-consuming constitutional debate which could provoke resistance in the current member states and delay their own entry to the club.

Germany, pushed by its own provincial governments or Länder, is leading calls at Nice for a new review conference in 2004 to define which powers should rest with the union and which with national governments.

On Wednesday the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, told worried Polish leaders in Warsaw that they would have a voice in discussions and that the next inter-governmental conference, leading to yet another EU treaty, would not become a condition for enlargement.

Concerns are also growing over the possibility that current EU leaders will opt for a "big bang" of up to 10 countries joining at once, while leading candidates like Poland, Hungary and Estonia, want to be in first. "Slowing down enlargement, waiting around for a big bang in some distant future will harm those governments which have taken the political risks to move ahead," Mr Ilves said.

Romania's president, Emil Constantinescu, highlighted the view in the new democracies that membership of the EU would be a passport to western-style stability and prosperity. "The member states are thinking already of the new union in the decades to come as a vast and generous force of partnership and unity for Europe in the spirit of the high values of liberty, equality and fraternity," he said.

But Romania is already lingering far behind the first group of EU hopefuls and next Sunday's presidential election, which pits a former communist against an ultranationalist, is unlikely to improve its chances.

Ahead of the talks, the Swedish prime minister, Goran Persson, said failure at Nice would delay, rather than derail, enlargement. "If we fail we will have a setback in the timetable for enlargement, but not in the process. This will go on."

Mr Persson will inherit any lingering problems when he takes over the rotating presidency on January 1.

fields.bodyText: Eastern European leaders called yesterday on their EU colleagues at the Nice summit to put aside their divisions and agree on sweeping internal reforms to open the way for a historic reunification of the continent. Speaking during a ceremony to mark the mission of enlargement, candidate countries repeatedly warned the existing 15 members that failure to agree an overhaul could scupper hopes of finally ending cold war divisions. "The Europe of today has to take the opportunity offered by the courageous changes in eastern Europe to unite the continent," urged Jacek Saryusz-Wolski, Poland's minister for European affairs. "We're making real advances and we should not be kept out in the cold anymore." Leaders of the 13 applicant countries joined their EU counterparts for the opening day of the three-day summit, billed as the toughest since Maastricht in 1991. Nice must resolve a series of difficult and interlocking institutional problems if the union is to be able to almost double its size over the coming years. Without changes to the voting weights of governments, the size of the European commission and the extent of majority voting, decision-making machinery designed for the six founder members back in 1957 will seize up. Tony Blair, championing the process, said last night that it was "impossible to overemphasise the importance" of the countries of Europe coming together half a century after the end of the second world war. This echoed the theme of his Warsaw speech last month about the future of the EU which was intended to link the institutional reform agenda to the need to enlarge as quickly as possible. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "The EU needs to show courage and imagination with the reforms that are needed to make ready for enlargement." The EU foreign affairs commissioner and former Tory party chairman, Chris Patten, said the desire of eastern European countries to join the union showed that Eurosceptic fears of a federal Europe were unfounded. "There are at the moment 10 former central and eastern European countries that want to become members of the European Union. They are countries that escaped from the Soviet yoke in the mid and late 1980s. "Do you actually suppose that a country like Poland, a proud, independent country which fought for its own sovereignty, wants to join the European Union in order to lose that sovereignty? It is barking." Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Cyprus began negotiating their terms of entry two years ago. Earlier this year they were joined by Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Malta, Lithuania and Latvia. Turkey, the 13th hopeful, has not begun negotiations because of complications over human rights and disputes over Cyprus and the Aegean. Enlargement is seen as the biggest single challenge for the EU following the launch of the single currency, though there are varying degrees of enthusiasm for the process. France is widely blamed for refusing to give a date for entry beyond the general commitment to be ready in 2003. "It is possible that in the poisonous atmosphere after a disappointing summit the accession of the first candidate countries will have to be put off," said Liberal Democrat MEP Andrew Duff. "There are plenty of people in France and Germany who would like a pretext to put it off." Candidates' fears Michel Barnier, the French European commissioner, said: "There could be a crisis here. I don't think it will happen, but I can't say it won't." Estonia's foreign minister, Toomas Ilves, said: "It is important that at Nice the member states come to an agreement that will allow enlargement to succeed. Without that agreement, the process will be slowed down." Janos Martonyi, his Hungarian colleague, warned that a failure at Nice would set back the enlargement process significantly. "But don't think we will give up. We will be members of the EU." The summiteers are expected to give final approval to a strategy of intensified negotiations that could see the leading candidates joining by January 1, 2004. But many of the wannabes are now worrying about the launch of a new and time-consuming constitutional debate which could provoke resistance in the current member states and delay their own entry to the club. Germany, pushed by its own provincial governments or Länder, is leading calls at Nice for a new review conference in 2004 to define which powers should rest with the union and which with national governments. On Wednesday the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, told worried Polish leaders in Warsaw that they would have a voice in discussions and that the next inter-governmental conference, leading to yet another EU treaty, would not become a condition for enlargement. Concerns are also growing over the possibility that current EU leaders will opt for a "big bang" of up to 10 countries joining at once, while leading candidates like Poland, Hungary and Estonia, want to be in first. "Slowing down enlargement, waiting around for a big bang in some distant future will harm those governments which have taken the political risks to move ahead," Mr Ilves said. Romania's president, Emil Constantinescu, highlighted the view in the new democracies that membership of the EU would be a passport to western-style stability and prosperity. "The member states are thinking already of the new union in the decades to come as a vast and generous force of partnership and unity for Europe in the spirit of the high values of liberty, equality and fraternity," he said. But Romania is already lingering far behind the first group of EU hopefuls and next Sunday's presidential election, which pits a former communist against an ultranationalist, is unlikely to improve its chances. Ahead of the talks, the Swedish prime minister, Goran Persson, said failure at Nice would delay, rather than derail, enlargement. "If we fail we will have a setback in the timetable for enlargement, but not in the process. This will go on." Mr Persson will inherit any lingering problems when he takes over the rotating presidency on January 1. fields.headline: Warm welcome
fields.standfirst: But no sex, please, we're Californian
fields.trailText: Scarborough-born Keith Teare moved to California in the spring of 1997 to found RealNames.
fields.body:
Scarborough-born Keith Teare moved to California in the spring of 1997 to found RealNames.

The company enables you to type the name of a company into the web browser bar and be directed straight to that firm's home page without needing to know its web address.

Mr Teare, 45, was a relative internet veteran when he arrived having co-founded the Easynet service provider and Cyberia chain of internet cafes.

Despite his track record it took him a year to raise his first financing. "It's not as easy raising money as people think," he says. "I was an outsider, no one knew me and it was only after we'd built a great team of people whose names where known in the valley that we got our money."

RealNames raised $46m in new funds this week to add to $87m already invested by backers including Microsoft, Morgan Stanley and Michael S Dell Capital. Markets permitting, it is likely to file for an IPO in the first quarter of next year.

Mr Teare says he has embraced the Californian culture and found the people amazingly welcoming but still finds some aspects of the valley alien. "Avoid irony at all cost because at least some of the things you say will be believed," he warns. "Humour with any sexual content should be avoided or it will fall foul of political correctness rules. Your employer will tell you it puts the company at risk by opening it up to all kinds of liabilities."

fields.headline: Chirac widens split on defence
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Jacques Chirac, the French host of the crucial EU summit in Nice which opened yesterday, was last night accused of playing domestic politics with European defence policy after insisting that Nato must be kept at arm's length on key military issues.
fields.byline: Ian Black and Michael White  in Nice, and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Jacques Chirac, the French host of the crucial EU summit in Nice which opened yesterday, was last night accused of playing domestic politics with European defence policy after insisting that Nato must be kept at arm's length on key military issues.

In remarks that irritated Tony Blair, President Chirac used his first summit appearance to underline his long-standing wish to minimise the alliance's role in the new rapid reaction force.

The French president, whose police had earlier been forced to dispel anti-summit protesters with teargas, insisted that he had no intention of seeking to weaken Nato. But he insisted that although the 60,000-strong force would co-ordinate with Nato command, it had to be "independent" from its Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe.

Given the historic French hostility to the US domination of Nato, President Chirac's comments set alarm bells ringing as EU leaders gathered for a summit designed to smooth the entry of former Soviet bloc states, some of which are already Nato members.

Spokesmen for Mr Blair, already under fire from Eurosceptics at home over the alleged threat to Nato, told reporters that the French leader was fully committed to the project. It is designed to let European peacekeepers act in the EU's own backyard in future crises similar to the Kosovo drama which exposed the EU's military impotence.

"The important thing is that the military planning capability rests with Nato," the prime minister said.

Detailed documents to be approved by all 15 leaders today formally declare the EU's support for the 50-year-old Nato alliance. They state explicitly that the rapid reaction force "does not involve the establishment of a European army" - the emotive phrase whose use by Tory tabloids has enraged Downing St.

But the timing of the incident is unfortunate for Mr Blair at the start of what promises to be a bruising summit where vital institutional reforms have to be agreed to facilitate decision-making after the EU moves to 15 to an eventual 27 members.

Iain Duncan-Smith, shadow defence secretary, jumped into the row in London. "Tony Blair's cynical attempt to cosy up to the French by betraying Nato is in ruins," he said last night. "The French president has now made clear that the price of the Euro army is the exclusion of the Americans from an alliance which has kept the peace in western Europe for more than 50 years."

With a UK election expected next spring, Mr Blair knows he must defend Britain's red lines -vetoes on tax and social security. Yesterday his Tory predecessor, John Ma jor, warned him to leave "plenty of fat" around his negotiating position to protect those core issues from too much pressure between now and what may prove a deadlocked summit that staggers into Sunday.

The Nato spat comes days after a warning from the outgoing US defence secretary, William Cohen, that the alliance could become a "relic of history" if the EU does not do more to share its burdens - as Mr Blair wishes - and protect the cohesion of Nato's command structure.

In Brussels, Nato officials are expressing concern about France's refusal to commit itself to close cooperation between Nato and the EU on military planning.

"They are refusing to be tied down to an EU-Nato agreement," one official said.

Britain insists that the main role of the EU's proposed military staff, of some 100 personnel, must be to liaise with Nato. Though it could have an advisory role, it must not lead to a separate EU command and control structure, says Britain. This is also the position of the US. France is continuing to block arrangements that would automatically and permanently "lock in" the EU with Nato, say Nato officials.

But diplomats said the French statement was intended largely for domestic political purposes after similar remarks by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, Mr Chirac's likely rival for the presidency in 2002. Both put on a united front last night.

Mr Blair flew to the summit declaring he would defy fellow leaders who want him to surrender Britain's veto in crucial areas as part of the reform of EU decision-making. "The British position on tax is quite clear," he said. "Every country has got its clear no-go areas and on the issue of tax there is no way we are going to yield up the veto."

Hot agenda items at the summit are how to reduce the size of the 20-strong European Commission, to extend qualified majority voting into new areas and to re-weight votes in the European Council to give big countries, including Britain, a bigger voice.

At the start of the summit, French riot police fought pitched battles with protesters a few hundred yards from the main venue, firing volleys of teargas as fireworks and furniture were hurled towards them. A group of several hundred Spanish anarchists, radical trade unionists and Basque and Corsican separatists were thought to be orchestrating the protests.

fields.headline: Virgin creates 1,700 airline jobs
fields.standfirst: Missile upgrade safeguards 1,000 more posts in defence industry
fields.trailText: Nearly 2,000 new jobs were announced yesterday - the bulk created by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic airline - and ministers secured a further 1,000 as part of a £260m facelift to a Royal Navy missile system.
fields.body:
Nearly 2,000 new jobs were announced yesterday - the bulk created by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic airline - and ministers secured a further 1,000 as part of a £260m facelift to a Royal Navy missile system.

Sir Richard said that Virgin planned to recruit 1,700 more staff throughout the next year in what he described as the group's largest recruitment drive. The announcement comes a day after rival BA said it would cut 1,000 jobs at Gatwick.

A further 1,000 jobs in Bristol, Chelmsford and Portsmouth would be secure, after Baroness Symons, the defence procurement minister, awarded the contract to upgrade the ageing Seawolf missile system to Alenia Marconi Systems. The contract will give a new lease of life to the short range missile used in the Falklands and Gulf War. The baroness said that the Seawolf system was fitted to the Royal Navy's type 22 and 23 frigates. About 130 jobs will be created with several sub-contractors for supporting equipment.

Sir Richard said that expansion was the key to Virgin Atlantic's growth. "New routes, such as Toronto, increased frequencies to Delhi and Capetown, and new aircraft, all mean new staff. There will be opportunities for pilots, cabin crew and airport staff based at both Gatwick andHeathrow airports as well as office-based staff."

Virgin Atlantic employs 8,500 people. Some 2,700 work at Gatwick, Sussex, while the rest are based at or fly from Heathrow and Gatwick airports but live across the UK.

Sir Richard said he was committed to the continued expansion of Virgin Atlantic, in which Singapore Airlines has a 49% share. Turnover had grown by more than 15% per annum in recent years.

He pointed out that next year the airline would increase flight frequencies to Las Vegas and reintroduce additional services to San Francisco over the peak summer season. Next year, passengers would also be able to check in at Gatwick the night before their departure.

Virgin now flies to 20 destinations worldwide, and has a fleet of 32 aircraft. When the company buys the world's largest jumbo in five years' time, it will have to recruit at least 1,000 extra cabin crew as well as 250 flight deck staff. Six new Boeing 747's are due to be delivered during next year and six Airbus 340's will be handed over to the company in 2002.

At least 150 jobs will be safeguarded at the Govan shipyard on the Clyde after BAE Systems confirmed that it is building a second vessel for use as an anchor handler and supply vessel, servicing the North Sea oil and gas industries.

webTitle: Behind the screen Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: It being December, the thoughts of all those working in TV naturally turn to Barbados. Why? Because that's where they're most likely to head off to for their winter breaks. And the thing about telly people is that it's not just their holiday locations that are glamorous. The neighbours invariably are too.
fields.body:
It being December, the thoughts of all those working in TV naturally turn to Barbados. Why? Because that's where they're most likely to head off to for their winter breaks. And the thing about telly people is that it's not just their holiday locations that are glamorous. The neighbours invariably are too.

Even so, you can imagine one exec's surprise when he found his Barbados beach villa displayed across several pages of TV listings magazine Heat shortly after his return to Blighty. But he didn't have to wonder overlong, as he knew exactly who'd been staying next door during the sun-kissed week. One Robbie Williams (pictured), allegedly dispatched to the Caribbean by his record company after his latest verbal showdown with Liam Gallagher.

Robbie seemed a bit miserable, stuck on the beach with only a few minders for company. So he joined the neighbouring holidaymakers for the odd sun-downer or two (he was on water only, apparently). They rubbed along fairly well and even shared a diving trip (Robbie's first, apparently, and he loved it).

The only puzzle for the assembled throng was why the omnipresent paparazzi stayed several hundred yards offshore on a boat to take their long-lens pictures. The resulting shots were well out of focus. But don't think our TV friend would be brought into the sordid business of photographing Robbie on holiday. You just can't bribe righteous TV types into selling their holiday snaps to grass on a famous pop star. Not these days, anyway.

Closer to home, evidence has emerged of the importance of the TV Big Cheese's office. The erstwhile den of former Channel 5 chief executive David Elstein has been appropriated by the creatives. The production team for the channel's early-morning kids strand Milkshake! have moved in, after being forced upstairs by the new chief executive Dawn Airey, who's taking more Lebensraum on the programming floor (she's also the channel's director of programmes). A case of executive shakeout, we think. &3149; Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast

webTitle: Prosecutors forbidden to make secret plea bargains

fields.headline: Prosecutors forbidden to make secret plea bargains
fields.trailText: Prosecution lawyers must not make secret "plea bargaining" deals in which defendants plead guilty to some charges in return for a lighter sentence, the attorney general warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Prosecution lawyers must not make secret "plea bargaining" deals in which defendants plead guilty to some charges in return for a lighter sentence, the attorney general warned yesterday.

Lord Williams of Mostyn issued guidance in the wake of the notorious case of Robin Peverett, a former prep school head who walked free as a result of a plea bargain after pleading guilty to nine charges of indecent assault on pupils.

The guidance says prosecutors can accept a plea of guilty to only some of the charges, or to a lesser charge. But they cannot take part in any discussion on sentencing.

For the first time, prosecutors will have to consult victims and their families in deciding whether to accept a plea, and will have to be prepared to give their reasons in open court.

Peverett's victims had no knowledge of the plea bargain in his case, and were astonished when the judge passed an 18-month suspended sentence after cooperating in a deal between prosecution and defence lawyers. The attorney general referred Peverett's sentence to the court of appeal, arguing that it was unduly lenient; it ruled that the prosecution counsel's involvement in the "lamentable" plea bargain barred the crown from in effect going back on the deal.

The guidance says the prosecution must make it clear the attorney general reserves the right to refer a sentence to the court of appeal if he thinks it lenient.

fields.headline: Just out
fields.trailText: Confit de vin - Cepage do Cabernet Sauvignon
fields.body:
Confit de vin - Cepage do Cabernet Sauvignon

Form: Wine jelly.

Flavour: Very delicate; more blackberry than cabernet; the sugar softens to taste of the grape but it's not too sweet; distinct whiff of alcohol although it's only 3.5% by volume.

Verdict: Ingenious method of using up wine you can't sell. Sugar is replaced by highly concentrated grape juice, which is nice. Rather seductive; the texture of the jelly trembles on the brink of turning back to wine. Beautiful dark colour. Would make a fine addition to the Christmas stocking or table and might even help to rescue the Christmas turkey, although probably better with game or lamb.

Price: £2.99 per 125g pot at Sainsbury's.

webTitle: My wife is openly having an affair. I love her, so should I put up with it?

fields.headline: My wife is openly having an affair. I love her, so should I put up with it?
fields.trailText: About 18 months ago my partner denied that she was having an affair with an old friend of hers. She said they simply wanted to see more of each other, including going away for weekends and developing a physical relationship. This has now happened. I love my partner and we have three children. I don't want to split up. Together we went through the 70s, feminism and being critical of the nuclear family. Dealing with jealousy and emotional insecurity has been very painful for me. I find being in this open-ended marriage very difficult. I don't want to tell my partner to leave because I love her and because I have a difficult relationship with our eldest daughter.
