I don't want to split up. Together we went through the 70s, feminism and being critical of the nuclear family. Dealing with jealousy and emotional insecurity has been very painful for me. I find being in this open-ended marriage very difficult. I don't want to tell my partner to leave because I love her and because I have a difficult relationship with our eldest daughter.

Fight your corner

The only way to fight it is to tell her how you feel. If she won't listen, then try talking to a counsellor who will help you to work out what you want.

Hilary Jenkins, Kent

Set ground rules

My husband and I live in a similar way to how your wife seems to want you to live. The big difference is that we agreed it before we got married and before we had children. While I would support what your wife wants, I think the problem is that you have not been given a proper opportunity to agree to it.

When my husband and I married we agreed that we could both have other sexual and romantic relationships but that certain conditions must apply. The most important of these is that our marriage, the relationship between us two and between us as parents of our child, is the primary relationship. Other relationships must be secondary. We also have the right of veto over each other's secondary relationships if either of us is not happy about the other one seeing a particular person.

It sounds as if you and your wife have a very close, loving and honest marriage. If she wants to have a secondary relationship I think you must sit down together, discuss it and make some ground rules by which you will both abide.

Annie, Leicestershire

Three is a crowd

Having had a similar experience, I would like to say that to feel jealous and emotionally insecure is only human when your partner is so intimate with someone other than yourself. This arrangement appears not to be the bargain you originally struck with your partner so many years ago.

Your partner has therefore subverted the relationship between you. Your relationship is not "open" but a triangle. You love this woman, but have you questioned whether she is still in love with you?

Her behaviour suggests not. Your partner has set sail on a course that will destroy you emotionally and ruin your relationship. She must have a peculiar power over you if you cannot take any action in such circumstances.

I do not think that love in any proper sense could encompass such behaviour.

If your partner does not understand that three is a crowd I would suggest that your parting, no matter how painful, should be sooner rather than later. Finally, it doesn't sound as though you are yet angry. You will be. Make sure this is vented appropriately. A professional counsellor would help.

Name and address withheld

Issue an ultimatum

It's time to put your cards on the table. Look her steadily in the eye and state: "You are my wife. If you want to stay married to me, I will not tolerate your adultery. Choose now, please, or we divorce."

Mutual respect and tenderness is the key; if you can't share this, don't waste any more of your precious life with her.

Mrs H Miles, Swansea

Be honest and patient

Try sitting down and working out with her what has caused her to need this relationship and be honest with her about how it it is making you feel.

Take things gently - if she is still in the early stages of the relationship it may be an infatuation that will burn itself out. If it does end, don't expect everything to return to the way it was before: you will have to work together to make things better.

Name and address withheld

I have lived with my husband for 10 years - we married 18 months ago. Six years ago, his brother moved in with us and a year later, his sister also moved in. Three years ago the brother moved out but the sister's boyfriend moved in. They work night shifts, so I rarely see them during the week. My husband is an insomniac and so also tends to work through the night and into the late morning. He gets severe headaches. I work normal hours.

My problem is our sex life. At first, it was fantastic but now the only time we have sex is when he asks for it when he has been drinking. I am not happy with this. I feel we have lost our way over the years and he complains that I never instigate sex. However, I think that his headaches and our differing hours and also living with his family have made it difficult for me to be spontaneous. I love my husband and would rather die than lose him. We get on brilliantly otherwise.

fields.headline: Blind date
fields.standfirst: It sounds like a recipe for disaster: a restaurant staffed with waiters who can't see, where diners eat in total darkness. But the Blind Cow in Zurich is so popular there's a four-month waiting list to get in.  Stephen Moss  on a curious culinary success
fields.trailText: I had dinner in Zurich this week with three Swiss people and an expatriate Brit. We sat together and chatted for a couple of hours, but don't ask me what they looked like. I couldn't see them. Father Christmas dropped by halfway through the meal. I tugged him by the beard, so I knew who it was, but I never saw him either. Or the waitress, Elizabeth; or the barman; or indeed the bar; or the 60 or so other customers; or the piano I was sitting next to; or the food I ate. The room was pitch-black; the serving staff were blind; and the diners were, in effect, simulating total blindness.
fields.body:
I had dinner in Zurich this week with three Swiss people and an expatriate Brit. We sat together and chatted for a couple of hours, but don't ask me what they looked like. I couldn't see them. Father Christmas dropped by halfway through the meal. I tugged him by the beard, so I knew who it was, but I never saw him either. Or the waitress, Elizabeth; or the barman; or indeed the bar; or the 60 or so other customers; or the piano I was sitting next to; or the food I ate. The room was pitch-black; the serving staff were blind; and the diners were, in effect, simulating total blindness.

The restaurant, Blindekuh (Blind Cow, which is the Swiss equivalent of blind man's buff) has taken Switzerland by storm. My fellow diners, who had driven up from Lucerne, had booked four months ago. That wait is not unusual: weekends are full until April. The restaurant's reputation is now spreading beyond the Swiss border: American restaurateurs have been in to assess the possibility of blind dining in the US; there is talk of franchising the Blind Cow concept across Europe; and last week the receptionist took a call from a restaurant owner in Ireland who wanted a precise description of the restaurant so that he could build one in Dublin.

The premises would, unfortunately for potential imitators, be hard to replicate. The restaurant is housed in a former Lutheran church, which perfectly fits this odd mix of philanthropy and commercialism (it is owned by the Blindlicht Foundation, set up by a blind clergyman called Jorge Spielmann to provide opportunities for blind people). Not all the staff are blind: the manager, Adrian Schaffner, is sighted, as is the receptionist, and all the kitchen staff except one. But the dozen or so waiters (most of whom work part time) are blind, as are some of the support staff.

Blindekuh opened in September last year. Spielmann's foundation, which raised £200,000 to launch it, had a dual purpose: to provide work for blind people, and to give those who can see an insight into their world. "We hope to make people more sensitive to the problems of the blind," says Schaffner. "It's a new experience for diners: you take one sense away, so you have to use all the others much more."

When you arrive, your bag and coat are put into a locker - it would be hazardous to leave anything on the floor of the dining room - and you step into a dimly lit ante-room which is supposed to acclimatise you to darkness (occasionally, guests find the blackness of the dining room too claustrophobic and have to leave). When your waiter arrives to greet you, you place your hands on her shoulders and are taken through the blackout curtain and into the dining room. The blind leading the blind.

The room is not merely dark; it is entirely devoid of light. The distinction is important: usually in darkness you can make out shadowy shapes; here you can see nothing. Your eyes work furiously to attempt to see something, but in vain, and the effort is so tiring that you have to close them. In dim light, they would be straining even harder.

The great challenge in eating blind is conversation. A conversation between sighted people relies on body language, facial expressions, eye contact: the words are just part of the interaction. Blind people depend to a much greater extent on their voice. "Usually, in a restaurant, everything is done with your eyes," says Schaffner, "but here you put that away and suddenly everybody is the same. The quality of what you say counts: not your designer tie, not your shoes, not your fashion haircut, not whether you are beautiful or ugly, just your voice. If you don't talk, you don't exist."

The restaurant has become a popular venue for blind dates: couples can meet and see how they get along without the distractions of what they look like and how they eat. In the restaurant, couples can stick to essentials; afterwards, in the lobby, they can check out the aesthetics.

The menu is small: three starters, a meat dish, a fish dish, a vegetarian option, a couple of desserts. The waiters either memorise what has been ordered or, for large parties, use a dictaphone. Eating and drinking is a challenge. Elizabeth encourages me to pour my own beer, which has to be done carefully, using the index finger of the left hand to check how full the glass is. You quickly realise that you have to keep your elbows off the table, a perception underlined by the sound of a bottle falling to the floor elsewhere in the restaurant.

I have no idea how large the room is, or how close the tables are together. It can seat no more than 60, and I was at a table for six, so there are perhaps a dozen tables. Noise levels are normal (ignore those who suggest that darkness makes people talk more loudly), and there is an awkward moment of silence when one of the revellers on my table makes a lewd remark (perhaps in the dark everyone is listening more intently).

Many large groups come to Blindekuh: families, office parties, but so far no wedding receptions (Schaffner thinks the bride would take offence). Clearly, part of the appeal is bonding: a strange, shared experience. It is arguable whether this brief, immobile immersion in darkness gives any real insight into blindness, but clearly it will make you look (or not look) at your friends, family, fellow diners in a different way.

Eating is messy. I courageously had borscht to start, which was surprisingly straightforward once I had located the spoon. But the beef, dumplings and assorted vegetables were trickier. Most of the dumplings went on the table, some of the vegetables ended up on the floor, and cutting meat is almost impossible. The solution is to abandon social niceties (irrelevant in the dark) and eat with your hands.

There may be something mildly transgressive in this whole enterprise. In Vladimir Nabokov's Laughter in the Dark, an unfaithful, gold-digging wife exploits her wealthy husband's blindness by secretly installing her lover in their home. The husband's presence heightens the illicit lovers' passion. Who knows, perhaps my fellow diners were naked; perhaps Elizabeth was naked; perhaps Santa, behind that flowing white (I am making assumptions here) beard was naked. In the kingdom of the blind, the cock-eyed imagination is king. I curb my wilder fantasies. My sole transgression is to lick the dish after I've eaten my ice-cream.

Does the idea work? I would be intrigued to go with someone I knew, to see how the dynamic changed once we were deprived of all the usual props to conversation. It was difficult to gauge talking to four total strangers. The restaurant claims that eating blind makes you think about the food more: you eat more slowly, sniff the food, touch it, savour it. But that is questionable: I wasn't aware of the meal being slower, just messier. You do lose track of time, though: luminous watches have to be removed, mobile phones are not permitted, welcome to the void.

The challenge will be to retain the purity of the idea, especially if Blind Cows spring up elsewhere. The Zurich restaurant works because of the idealism of the founders (tempered by the management nous of Schaffner, who used to work for the Best Western hotel chain), the combination of eating and education (the restaurant also runs intensive afternoon sessions demonstrating what it is like to be blind), and the enthusiasm of the staff, especially the blind waiters who recognise that they have been given a unique opportunity (imagine, in any other context, the employment potential of a blind waiter). Trying to repeat the formula elsewhere will be a leap in the dark.

webTitle: The Act of Settlement must go

fields.headline: The Act of Settlement must go
fields.standfirst:
Extracted from a speech made to the Scottish parliament on December 16 1999, by the Conservative member for Lothian

Join the debate online
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Extracted from a speech made to the Scottish parliament on December 16 1999, by the Conservative member for Lothian
fields.body:
The important issue is whether there should be legislation that blatantly discriminates against a Christian religion. The subject is particularly relevant as we live in a multifaith community. The heir to the throne can accede if he marries a Muslim, a Buddhist, a scientologist, a Moonie, an atheist or a sun-worshipper, but not if he marries a Roman Catholic. Leaving such a stigma in place when no other religion or faith is singled out is grossly unfair.

I wrote to the prime minister, whose response offered no defence or justification for the present legislation. He had "no plans" to do anything about the situation and said that reforming the law would be complex. That is absolutely right. Similarly, it was complex to reform the House of Lords, but that did not prove an insurmountable problem. The complexity can be exaggerated.

It occurred to me that it would be helpful to have a consultation exercise that involved all the faiths and churches in Scotland. The responses indicate widespread consensus against this kind of religious discrimination. Out of nine responses, eight were clearly opposed to discrimination and the ninth was conscious of the complexity of the matter. Cardinal Winning made the valid point that "royal commissions are normally established to tackle some thorny issue on which there is no wide consensus. The campaign to end the Act of Settlement commands broad public and political support. Indeed, I can think of no major public figure prepared to defend the language of intolerance contained in the offensive clauses. What is now needed is a clear signal that this issue will be tackled, and tackled soon."

I cannot but feel the force of that argument. My own church, the Church of Scotland, stated in a letter: "It is the view of the legal questions committee that the discriminatory provisions of the Act of Settlement have no place in our contemporary society. The act was a product of its times and those times are not our times. Thankfully, we live in a climate of ecumenical friendship and cooperation unknown at the beginning of the 18th century."

In his letter, the cardinal put the case even more strongly. "It has been said that the Act of Settlement does not impinge on the daily lives of Catholics, and that is true." The cardinal continued: "Nevertheless its continued presence on the statute books is an offensive reminder to the whole Catholic community of a mentality which has no place in modern Britain." His message to the parliament can be summed up in one sentence: "I wish all of you success in rooting out an offensive, embarrassing and anachronistic blot on our escutcheon."

I must report that The Church of Scotland and the Roman Catholic Church have the support of the Hindu and Muslim faiths in that view. A letter from the Hindu Mandir states: "We as Hindus do not discriminate against anyone."

Mr Bashir Mann of the Muslim community wrote: "The Muslim religion is against all kinds of discrimination on account of race, colour or creed. We would therefore support and amendment to the act, that would remove this flagrant statutory discrimination against the Roman Catholic faith."

As it happens, Mr Bashir Mann is a Labour councillor. I mention that because this should not be a party political matter. When the subject came up in the House of Lords recently, Lord St John of Fawsley said: "Such a major matter is best set in train - and should be set in train - by the government and opposition parties officially acting together." I hope that that will happen.

This debate is a continuation of the debate in 1829 on the subject of Roman Catholic emancipation - enabling Roman Catholics to become members of parliament. The prime minister at the time was the Duke of Wellington. He was on the side of emancipation.

Lord Winchilsea implied that Wellington was being disloyal to his country. The prime minister immediately challenged Winchilsea to a duel - the only time, as far as I can recall, that a prime minister has had to defend his honour in that way. On March 21 1829, not long after first light, the prime minister and Winchilsea met on Battersea fields. When the moment to shoot arrived, the prime minister took careful aim and fired wide. Winchilsea, not wishing to kill his prime minister, fired in the air. He then wrote a grovelling apology.

A few days later, in the face of the stiffest opposition in the House of Lords, Wellington spoke for Roman Catholic emancipation and made the best speech of his life. He obtained a majority of 105 - almost two-thirds in favour.

I hope [to] persuade the prime minister to put reform of the Act of Settlement firmly on the agenda. If the Duke of Wellington - who was, if I may say, even more rightwing than Mr Tony Blair, which is saying quite a lot - was prepared to take a stand on principle and bring in progressive reform, surely it is not too much to hope that our prime minister can show the same kind of moral courage.

The basic truth that was applicable in 1829 and remains so today is that a substantial proportion of our countrymen and countrywomen are of Roman Catholic origin. There are some 800,000 Scots of Roman Catholic origin, and they deserve better than to have outdated legislation, some 300 years old, in force discriminating against them. The Act of Settlement is, as the first minister has described it, a "legacy from the past".

It constitutes what Michael Forsyth called the British constitution's "grubby little secret". The equal opportunities committee of this parliament calls it an "anachronistic anomaly", and the cardinal has described it as an "insult to all Catholics". It is neither in keeping with the spirit of the times nor consistent with the social inclusion that we wish to celebrate in the year of the millennium.

Blatant and hurtful legislation discriminating against a Christian religion is not acceptable, just as discrimination against a race or ethnic community is not acceptable. We have the opportunity to give an example to Britain, by recommending that such discrimination is an offensive anachronism that should be swept away.

The author was Scottish Office minister for home affairs in the Major government 1995-7

When the subject came up in the House of Lords recently, Lord St John of Fawsley said: "Such a major matter is best set in train - and should be set in train - by the government and opposition parties officially acting together." I hope that that will happen. This debate is a continuation of the debate in 1829 on the subject of Roman Catholic emancipation - enabling Roman Catholics to become members of parliament. The prime minister at the time was the Duke of Wellington. He was on the side of emancipation. Lord Winchilsea implied that Wellington was being disloyal to his country. The prime minister immediately challenged Winchilsea to a duel - the only time, as far as I can recall, that a prime minister has had to defend his honour in that way. On March 21 1829, not long after first light, the prime minister and Winchilsea met on Battersea fields. When the moment to shoot arrived, the prime minister took careful aim and fired wide. Winchilsea, not wishing to kill his prime minister, fired in the air. He then wrote a grovelling apology. A few days later, in the face of the stiffest opposition in the House of Lords, Wellington spoke for Roman Catholic emancipation and made the best speech of his life. He obtained a majority of 105 - almost two-thirds in favour. I hope [to] persuade the prime minister to put reform of the Act of Settlement firmly on the agenda. If the Duke of Wellington - who was, if I may say, even more rightwing than Mr Tony Blair, which is saying quite a lot - was prepared to take a stand on principle and bring in progressive reform, surely it is not too much to hope that our prime minister can show the same kind of moral courage. The basic truth that was applicable in 1829 and remains so today is that a substantial proportion of our countrymen and countrywomen are of Roman Catholic origin. There are some 800,000 Scots of Roman Catholic origin, and they deserve better than to have outdated legislation, some 300 years old, in force discriminating against them. The Act of Settlement is, as the first minister has described it, a "legacy from the past". It constitutes what Michael Forsyth called the British constitution's "grubby little secret". The equal opportunities committee of this parliament calls it an "anachronistic anomaly", and the cardinal has described it as an "insult to all Catholics". It is neither in keeping with the spirit of the times nor consistent with the social inclusion that we wish to celebrate in the year of the millennium. Blatant and hurtful legislation discriminating against a Christian religion is not acceptable, just as discrimination against a race or ethnic community is not acceptable. We have the opportunity to give an example to Britain, by recommending that such discrimination is an offensive anachronism that should be swept away. A turkey is not just for Christmas. Yes, it's for all those days, weeks, months which follow, dragging sorry turkey dinner after sorry turkey dinner with them. fields.headline: No: 1778 Cif
fields.trailText: Cif? Sounds like Jif. Looks like Jif. What the hell is it? Jif, I'm afraid, is no more, God rest its soul.
fields.body:
Cif? Sounds like Jif. Looks like Jif. What the hell is it? Jif, I'm afraid, is no more, God rest its soul.

Oh, how I shall miss that distinctive aroma of alpine woodlands, mingled with ah, a hint of fresh bleach! Fret not, my dear, for it is the same product. Jif is merely being relaunched as Cif.

Any particular reason? It's already known as Cif in 39 countries and Lever Brothers has decided that it wants Cif to be the global brand.

Which 39 countries? Presumably the ones where they Snicker and Olay.

Munchies becomes Brekkies, Opal Fruits are transformed into Starburst, Emmerdale Farm morphs into Emmerdale. And now this. Is there no stopping the decay of the English language? Cif cream cleaner removes decay faster than any bathroom product, just for the record.

Thanks. No problem.

And is there nothing we can do? Well, we could always start a Coco Pops versus Choco Krispies-style protest.

And Lever Brothers thinks it can get away with this, does it? Chopping and changing household names like nobody's business, the fickle little beggars. "We aren't changing the product, packaging or logo," a spokesperson says, rather wearily. "We're simply changing one letter in the name. It makes sense to have the brand under one umbrella."

And how much is this consonantal drift going to cost them? Two million squid.

Quid. I think you'll find that the rest of the continent knows it as "squid".

Ah, right. Two million squid. That's a lot of Tip-ex. You mean Cip-ex. Actually the the company is launching an entire repackaging and advertising campaign.

So it won't just be some bloke with a felt tip scribbling away in the household items aisle at my local Safeway? Surprisingly, no.

Any minute now: Caffa Cakes, Celly Tots, C cloths.

fields.headline: Bass plays £4bn waiting game
fields.trailText: Bass, the hospitality group, yesterday revealed it has a £4bn war chest to spend on buying hotels but insisted it would not be rushed into making snap decisions.
fields.body:
Bass, the hospitality group, yesterday revealed it has a £4bn war chest to spend on buying hotels but insisted it would not be rushed into making snap decisions.

The company, already the world's second biggest hotel operator, wants to expand its Inter-Continental, Crowne Plaza and Holiday Inn chains into the world's major cities.

But it refused to comment on how long this may take or 'on speculation that it is interested in a joint £3bn bid for the Granada Compass hotel estate with rival Millennium & Copthorne.

"We are not going to impose an artificial timeline as we want to get it right," said finance director Richard North. "The most important thing is to get value for shareholders."

Bass, which has to change its name next year as a result of selling its brewery interests to Interbrew for £2.3bn, has also earmarked £940m for a group-wide modernisation and will seek approval to buy back around 15% of the issued share capital.

Chairman Sir Ian Prosser said the hotels division, which boasts 3,000 sites, enjoyed a bumper year but its pubs had suffered from the effects of a wet summer and the fuel crisis.

"Market conditions, particularly in the second half of the year have made it a difficult year for Bass Leisure Retail," he conceded.

These conditions resulted in like-for-like sales slipping 2.8%, when the 550 Allied pubs bought in October 1999 are stripped out.

But the figures worsened to 3.7% over the second six months. Prospects do not look any brighter with comparable sales for October and November off 4.2%.

New chief executive Tim Clarke said the board did not have a strong view on whether the hotels and pubs should be demerged, adding that any decision would be based on potential to create shareholder value.

Bass, which operates popular chains such as All Bar One and O'Neills, is also "considering the options" for its smaller inns division of 1,029 unbranded pubs.

Observers believe this "strategic review" is likely to recommend a sale that could fetch up to £700m for the already cash-rich group.

The group announced pre-tax profits, before exceptionals, of £756m for the year to September 30 - an increase of 19% and at the very top end of analysts' expectations.

Turnover stood at £3.78bn for the period, an increase of 22.8%, with the adjusted earnings per share up 8.9% at 62.2p. The dividend also rose 3.1% to 33.3p.

Britvic, its soft drinks division, saw turnover up marginally at 0.9% to lift profits 9.5% to £46m. The results went down well in the City with shares ending the day up 25.5p at 694p - an increase of 3.8%.

This is still some way off the 856p year high, but comfortably ahead of the 575p low.

Analysts expect the results to increase calls for the company to exit pubs, which are vulnerable to the changing whims of fickle consumers, and watch how much they put into acquisitions.

"I view the pub sector very negatively," said one. "There are plenty of other international hotel companies for investors where they don't get exposure to the UK pub market."

webTitle: Anger as BSkyB chief sells £6m shares

fields.headline: Anger as BSkyB chief sells £6m shares
fields.standfirst: Leading investor questions 'motivation' of disposal
fields.trailText: Shareholders in BSkyB yesterday voiced concern over the decision by Tony Ball, chief executive of the satellite broadcaster, to cash in almost all his available share options just weeks after he became entitled to them.
fields.body:
Shareholders in BSkyB yesterday voiced concern over the decision by Tony Ball, chief executive of the satellite broadcaster, to cash in almost all his available share options just weeks after he became entitled to them.

Mr Ball banked nearly £6m by selling 570,000 shares. He was granted 600,000 shares under a long-term incentive plan earlier this year. He still has an interest in more than 2m BSkyB shares, but the vast majority cannot be accessed until November next year.

A senior executive at one of Britain's largest institutional investors said: "Mr Ball's action raises a number of issues in terms of his motivation. Executives should be encouraged to hold and retain a meaningful shareholding so that their interests are aligned with the interests of shareholders. This is not consistent with that."

BSkyB pointed out that Mr Ball was entitled to sell his shares and that he had raised the cash because he had a young family and had made some financial commitments since returning from the US.

Mr Ball is halfway through a fixed three-year contract with BSkyB. He is paid £700,000 a year and has a bonus scheme which guarantees him an additional annual award of at least £500,000.

One fund manager said: "Even with a young family he is well remunerated. A number of investing institutions will factor these sales into their evaluation of the company".

Chief financial officer Martin Stewart also sold 237,500 shares in the company, raising £2.5m. BSkyB shares fell 2.65%, closing 29p lower at 1066p.

fields.headline: Motorola reverses tech recovery
fields.trailText: A profits warning from mobile phone maker Motorola yesterday brought this week's recovery in technology stocks to a juddering halt.
fields.body:
A profits warning from mobile phone maker Motorola yesterday brought this week's recovery in technology stocks to a juddering halt.

The US group said fourth quarter profits would be more than 40% lower than projected, a message in sharp contrast to Tuesday's upbeat message from Nokia. Motorola blamed a slowing semi-conductor market and delays in cutting wireless telephone production costs.

The news sent a shudder through the markets. Motorola shares fell 3.5%, rivals Nokia and Ericsson were down 2% and 2.4% re spectively while microchip maker STMicroelectronics lost 4.4% .

"It's the same old story ... the bad news keeps coming. We had our fun and games and now its back to the same old routine," said David Thwaites, European equity strategist at BNP Paribas.

fields.headline: Carpetbaggers renew attacks
fields.trailText: The Nationwide and the Chelsea building societies are under attack from carpetbaggers after the demutualisation of Bradford & Bingley.
fields.body:
The Nationwide and the Chelsea building societies are under attack from carpetbaggers after the demutualisation of Bradford & Bingley.

Stephen Major, the plumber who led the successful attack on Bradford & Bingley, says he has more than the 250 signatures he needs to stand for election to the board of Nationwide at next summer's annual meeting.

If he wins a seat he will try to bring windfall payments to 10m savers and borrowers by challenging in court Nationwide's two-tier system which makes newcomers sign away their rights to windfalls.

He has written to the Nationwide managment explaining his intentions. The UK's largest building society has admitted that a vote on conversion looks likely next summer.

The Nationwide has fought off previous challenges and is considered a harder nut to crack than Bradford & Bingley.

Andy Naughton-Doe, a chartered secretary from Feltham, Middlesex, is seeking backers for his proposal to demutualise the Chelsea, which has 400,000 members. He says he is undertaking the campaign because the board refuses to consider change despite more than 90% of members voting in favour.

The Chelsea dismissed the move as lacking seriousness.

webTitle: Chase takes axe to 15% of workforce

fields.headline: Chase takes axe to 15% of workforce
fields.trailText: Chase Manhattan is wielding the jobs axe in the City this week, informing dozens of bankers each day that they are casualties of its acquisition of two rivals earlier this year.
fields.body:
Chase Manhattan is wielding the jobs axe in the City this week, informing dozens of bankers each day that they are casualties of its acquisition of two rivals earlier this year.

Chase wants to dismiss up to 15% of its City workforce, which has ballooned since it bought privately owned Robert Fleming and JP Morgan, the US-based bank.

Chase, which is renaming itself JP Morgan Chase, employed 8,500 in the City before it acquired another 3,500 from JP Morgan.

Most of the pain is being felt by the 2,500 former employees of Fleming, many of whom are being told this week that they are no longer required. Up to 30% of the Fleming workforce is expected to leave after this week's exercise to reduce the workforce.

The axe is said to have fallen first in the securities operation where as many as 30 former Fleming staff are thought to have been told their jobs are on the line.

Other areas where jobs are at risk include capital markets and specialised areas, such as stock lending.

Chase Manhattan refused to admit that any one had left the bank this week but a spokeswoman admitted that letters had been sent to staff whose jobs stood to be affected by the takeover. The spokeswoman refused to confirm how many letters had been sent out but insisted that they had been distributed among former JP Morgan and Fleming staff, as well as Chase employees.

Insiders believe that Chase is staggering the job reduction to soften the impact. When Chase announced its takeover of JP Morgan in September, just months after Fleming, it tried to play down job cuts. It described the deal as one about growth rather than cost cutting.

webTitle: Notebook Tax cut is reverse of what is needed

fields.headline: Irish boom has passed soundness barrier
fields.standfirst: Notebook Tax cut is reverse of what is needed
fields.trailText: Notebook Tax cut is reverse of what is needed
fields.body:
Heard the one about the Irish budget? With the economy expected to grow by nigh-on 9% this year and inflation close to 7%, what does the finance minister, Charlie McCreevy do? Why, announce tax cuts, of course.

Actually, this is quite an old joke. Those with memories stretching back to the late 80s in Britain may remember that other star turn, Nigel Lawson, telling it in March 1988, when he slashed income tax even though the laxity of monetary policy meant the econ omy was already booming out of control.

That Ireland's monetary policy is too loose is not doubted. Interest rates were halved when the country joined the single currency, with predictable effects. Inflation has been on a rapidly upward trend and unemployment has been falling.

Monetary policy is now set by the European Central Bank, so the obvious course of action for the Irish finance ministry, faced by an economy that is blatantly overheating, would be to tighten fiscal policy, thereby dampening demand. Mr McCreevy has not taken this route. This week's budget contains a two percentage point cut in tax rates for both standard and high rate payers and a 6.6% increase in net spending - including a juicy 11.5% increase for pensioners.

You don't need to be Milton Friedman to know that this is not the textbook remedy for slowing an economy down.

Mr McCreevy's strategy - such as it is - seems to be that fiscal easing will keep the unions sweet and prevent them exploiting the tightness of the labour market with ever-higher wage demands that would give an added twist to the inflationary spiral.

Under the terms of the country's social pact with the unions, the government is committed to reducing taxes in exchange for wage restraint. If it hadn't fulfilled its part of the bargain, the workers were threatening industrial mayhem. In any case, selling fiscal austerity to voters when government coffers are bulging - the budget surplus is likely to be some I£6.1bn - is tricky.

But the idea that this package will finesse a soft landing for the Irish economy is highly improbable. The experience of Britain a decade ago is that the combination of stimulatory monetary and fiscal policies results first in an unstoppable boom but eventually in an horrendous bust, in which rising unemployment is the cost of a growing lack of competitiveness. And that's not funny.

To the Batcave

Holy Smoke. Batman has halved in size. This is proving to be a dangerous week for innocents playing in the City.

BATM Advanced Communications, which provides telecom companies with specialist kit, has long been a favourite of the bulletin board punting hordes (hence the nickname), and just a glance at a share price chart shows why.

Against the pennies at which this Israeli technology group was trading at the beginning of last year, the share price recently hit a mouth-watering 765p, valuing this nine-year-old concern at close to £3bn. Thousands of amateur investors thought they had struck gold. Yesterday, a "trading update" revealed that turnover this year will undershoot market expectations by close to 20%. It did not say anything about expected profits, so the market reacted by cutting the share price in half. BATM is now capitalised at £570m. Since the beginning of September the company's value has fallen by 80%.

Looking at yesterday's statement, this vicious re-rating looks wholly justified. Dr Zvi Marom, the chief executive, pinned the blame for the revenue shortfall on the inability of Infineon (the old Seimens), which supplies it with optical transceivers, to meet delivery deadlines.

He also said that BATM has been "cautious in accepting orders from certain customers with aggressive expansion plans," and then cited "deferred orders from leading telecommunications customers compared to expectations".

Ludicrously, later in the day Dr Marom was quoted as saying: "I may well take a beating for putting out this news, but I feel it is important that our investors know they can rely on being told everything that goes on in the company." Dr Marom has to tell us if something is going wrong. It's the rules.

The simple fact is that over-enthusiastic followers hyped this company to the moon and sales are now failing to match those heady expectations.

For whatever reason, many Israeli hi-tech companies quoted in London are proving to be the equivalent of Irish resource stocks during the 1990s and Australian mining plays during the 1980s - promising much, but delivering very little.

Investors tempted to pile into this stock on the view that it has been unduly savaged might remember an old City rule: the further the assets are from London, the higher the risk premium.

He also said that BATM has been "cautious in accepting orders from certain customers with aggressive expansion plans," and then cited "deferred orders from leading telecommunications customers compared to expectations". Ludicrously, later in the day Dr Marom was quoted as saying: "I may well take a beating for putting out this news, but I feel it is important that our investors know they can rely on being told everything that goes on in the company." Dr Marom has to tell us if something is going wrong. It's the rules. The simple fact is that over-enthusiastic followers hyped this company to the moon and sales are now failing to match those heady expectations. For whatever reason, many Israeli hi-tech companies quoted in London are proving to be the equivalent of Irish resource stocks during the 1990s and Australian mining plays during the 1980s - promising much, but delivering very little. Investors tempted to pile into this stock on the view that it has been unduly savaged might remember an old City rule: the further the assets are from London, the higher the risk premium.

fields.headline: DSS rebuked over benefits fiasco
fields.trailText: Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, is to investigate how Whitehall tried to avoid a "bad press" by covering up an attempt to get 112,000 poor people and pensioners to pay back £10.5m of benefits they had received twice by mistake.
fields.body:
Parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, is to investigate how Whitehall tried to avoid a "bad press" by covering up an attempt to get 112,000 poor people and pensioners to pay back £10.5m of benefits they had received twice by mistake.

An internal Department of Social Security audit report, leaked to the magazine Computer Weekly, revealed that Alastair Darling, social security secretary, was kept in the dark by civil servants on the quickest way to get the cash back. Instead they opted for a complicated process that has still left the ministry owed £3m and has cost £465,000.

The money had been paid twice by the benefits agency into the bank accounts of 111,954 people, 43% of them pensioners, using new automatic bank credits - which will become the standard way of paying benefits from 2003.

Civil servants were advised that the quickest ways to retrieve the extra money would be to withhold payments for one week or debit the recipients' accounts.

A more complicated way involved writing to ask them to return the money, with the threat of legal action if they failed to pay it back. This was the operation carried out, and the problem was compounded by a series of mistakes.

All the letters were sent on the same day, resulting in 2,000 people jamming the benefit agency's switchboard. Nearly 1,000 letters involved sums of less than the 19p stamp it cost to send the demand. Letters were also sent to dead people and to social services departments. Claimants who owed more than £1,000 were sent demands omitting the first digit, and corrected demands had to be sent out.

The report revealed that the ministry had to handle 20,200 telephone calls, 65,000 letters in reply and 168 bounced cheques - costing £17,479. And 77 people refused to pay.

It said Mr Darling chaired a "crisis meeting" after the double payments error was discovered. The reason he was not told about the easy way to claim back the cash was that "this may have caused further bad press or external pressure from lobby groups".

The DSS's auditors expressed concern about the risks of duplicate payments as the government prepares to pay tens of billions of pounds in welfare benefits by automated credit transfer into recipients' bank accounts. "As we move towards delivery in 2003 it is imperative that we limit our exposure," said the report.

Frank Field, a former DSS minister who has asked a series of questions about the overpayments, said: "It would appear that ministers have been kept in the dark. Effective government can only be ensured if officials are open and honest with ministers."

The national audit office is expected to comment on the debacle when it produces its annual report on the DSS accounts next year. It is at present investigating the ministry's competence in handling income support benefits for a report due next summer.

webTitle: Byers to sweet talk business over radical plan

fields.headline: Byers to sweet talk business over radical plan
fields.standfirst: Employers reluctant to accept longer maternity leave
fields.trailText: Employers reluctant to accept longer maternity leave.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the modernising trade and industry secretary who relishes his reputation as one of New Labour's most enthusiastic cheerleaders, is an unlikely radical.

Within weeks of taking up his cabinet post, Mr Byers issued the provocative declaration that wealth creation was more important than wealth redistribution - hardly the sentiments of a reformer.

However, his green paper on parental rights, published yesterday, does have a radical edge which would usher in the most significant changes since the second world war in this contentious area.

The prospect of a near doubling in statutory maternity pay and an extension of unpaid maternity leave to allow a woman to stay at home for a year would go a long way towards taking Britain closer to more generous arrangements in Europe.

At the launch of his green paper yesterday Mr Byers demonstrated his new found credentials as a radical when he declared that Britain was "way off pace" on parental rights. "The status quo is not an option," he said.

Mr Byers is not, however, about to abandon his role as a modernising Blairite.

The wide-ranging recommendations in the green paper are balanced with concessions to business in the hope of persuading organisations such as the CBI to drop their opposition to reform.

Showing their devotion to the Blairite Third Way, Mr Byers and the women's minister, Baroness Jay, spoke of their relish for the challenge of winning over business leaders. The two ministers, who launched their green paper at a small London business, Happy Computers, are embarking on a two-pronged offensive to sweet talk business.

In the first place, carrots are to be offered to persuade business leaders that they will not be over-burdened with red tape. A generous compensation package will help businesses cope with the costs of administering new schemes. Businesses are also to be offered an advance on maternity payments to ensure cash flow is not jeopardised.

The second element of the ministerial charm offensive is to persuade businesses that improving parental rights is in their interests. Improved rights will, they say, lead to more effective and more loyal employees.

Mr Byers detailed his thinking when he spoke of a new opportunity to "marry together" the goal of being a good parent with being a good employee. In the classic language of Blairism, he added: "We should not see them as being in conflict."

His soothing language appeared to fall on deaf ears when the CBI and the British Chambers of Commerce voiced strong misgivings about the reforms. The BCC complained of the "cumulative burden" imposed on them by the government.

However, one minister who has been closely involved in the review compared the negotiations to the battle over the minimum wage.

"We are at the same stage with business on parental rights that we were with the minimum wage five years ago," the minister said. "Business was very hostile to the minimum wage then, but no one is opposed now."

Some critics will argue that ministers have gone too far in appeasing business leaders. Severe restrictions have been placed on the right to part-time work. This has been renamed "reduced hours" and employers are to be given a veto if they can prove that their business would be damaged by an employee moving away from full-time work.

Despite misgivings, voiced by the equal opportunities commission, the government's reforms will ensure that Labour stands on a significantly more radical platform at the next general election. Labour was famously pilloried for its 1997 manifesto which adopted a safety first approach across a whole range of issues.

But one minister said the reforms to parental rights, which will be a key element of Labour's manifesto, will show that New Labour now has the courage to be more ambitious.

"We had to be cautious in the run up to the last election because we had to persuade people we were competent," the minister said.

"We have now achieved that, which means we can now be more ambitious and set out a real agenda for the second term. Our parental reforms give us a once-in-a-generation opportunity to do something really radical."

The green paper in full

fields.headline: Longer paid leave 'means stress relief'
fields.trailText: Case studies
fields.body:
The mother

Six months of paid maternity leave was "definitely, definitely" a great idea, said Stephanie Preston-Hargrave. Her sole complaint was that the green paper came too late to help her with Katie, three, and Emma, nine months.

"I've joked that I should get pregnant again so I could benefit from the new packages and have a stress-free time," Ms Preston-Hargrave, 34, said. "Six months would have made quite a difference. A year's unpaid leave could be good if you were in a financial situation to take advantage of it.

"I went back to work part-time when Katie was 15 weeks old and I didn't like that; I felt she was very young. With my next firm, I should have gone back to work when Emma was 12 or 13 weeks old. They clearly weren't family friendly."

Instead, she left the company and now works part-time in an office near her home in Manchester.

She was pleased that the proposals included paternity leave - the help of her husband, Chris Hargrave, had been essential after the births of their children. But she was worried that the green paper might deter old-fashioned employers from hiring women.

The employer

For Brian Lewis, the thought of losing workers for weeks at a time appals him. He heads a staff of 20 at Bri-tone Nail Lacquer in St Helens, Merseyside, struggling to keep down production costs to avoid losing customers to overseas manufacturers.

"If someone took two weeks paternity leave it would put us in a serious position," he said.

"Why should I underwrite any individual's lifestyle? When my four children were born I took holiday time. There's going to be a backlash from people with out kids who want time off. It's all going to multiply."

But he believed few of his workers would take advantage of the extra leave. "I don't believe any male would jeopardise a week's work for £60. Not one of the women who work here and has children has had 13 weeks off on maternity leave - they can't afford it."

The only effect would be to create more red tape. "We're getting closer to the nanny state. We're tied up looking at legislation when I should be out there getting work for these people. In the end it will affect employment."

The father

Richard Edmonstone found one big difference between the births of his two daughters: paternity leave. When Kirsten, now two-and-a-half, was born his employer at the time said he would have to use his holiday entitlement for time off. But when Erin, now 10 weeks old, arrived his new firm offered him a week's paid leave.

"The difference five days can make is incredible," said Mr Edmonstone, 33, of Edinburgh, a software development manager.

"With my previous company I had to take five days holiday, and I felt it put extra strain on the birth. You don't have time for a real break because you're dealing with all the hassle of the birth and recovery.

"In a way my new employer has pre-empted the government. With Erin they gave me five days of paid leave and I took a week's holiday. My wife, Clare, and I had a real break. It also means that if she's ill I can take some holiday time off to help out."

Such policies were in the interests of companies as well as employees. "When a firm treats you well at times like that it creates a certain loyalty. You're much more willing to work overtime to get jobs done." The green paper in full

webTitle: Comment: Leanda de Lisle: catholicism and the monarchy

fields.headline: A Catholic's dilemma
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Join the debate online
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The blood of Catholic martyrs flows in my veins. But, as I read the 1701 Act of Settlement on the Guardian's website yesterday, my face did not flush nor my veins throb. Despite the best efforts of my colleagues to get me worked into a fever over the act's denial of my human rights, I am unconcerned that it denies Catholics the right to wear the crown, or marry those who hold it. Rather, it is their troublemaking that makes me boil.
fields.body:
The blood of Catholic martyrs flows in my veins. But, as I read the 1701 Act of Settlement on the Guardian's website yesterday, my face did not flush nor my veins throb. Despite the best efforts of my colleagues to get me worked into a fever over the act's denial of my human rights, I am unconcerned that it denies Catholics the right to wear the crown, or marry those who hold it. Rather, it is their troublemaking that makes me boil.

The Guardian has not, thus far, been known as a friend to Catholics. Within these pages, the sins of individuals are visited on the church to a degree that even Islam has avoided. Now it makes a grand stand on our behalf? I don't think so. Its objective is not to see a Catholic on the throne, but to have no throne at all. That is not likely to find great support among as conservative a minority as Catholics - and certainly not from those of us of recusant descent, whose families invariably fought for Charles I, seeing in him some protection from the anti-Catholic excesses of the republicans.

Really, there is some irony in Cromwell's heirs using the human rights of Catholics to justify their cause. There is irony too in them holding up the Act of Settlement as representing all that is rotten in our democracy. The act did not simply establish the current royal dynasty and a Protestant succession. It established the rule of law.

For the first time, it was laid down that the monarch might not dismiss judges at will. Other limitations were imposed on the royal prerogative. The monarch could not leave England or make war without the consent of parliament.

Now the monarch was established for the benefit of the people and not the other way round. The last section of the act is very moving: "And whereas the laws of England are the birthright of the people thereof, and all the Kings and Queens, who shall ascend the throne of this Realm, ought to administer the government of the same according to the said laws, and all their officers and ministers ought to serve them respectively according to the same: the said Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, do therefore humbly pray, That all the laws and statues of this realm for securing the established religion, and the rights and liberties of the people thereof, and all other laws and statues of the same now in force, may be ratified and confirmed." What, I wonder, would the Guardian's Jonathan Freedland write its place?

Although it might not be strictly necessary to disestablish the Church of England, the opportunity to do so would be taken. Would this benefit Catholics - or Jews, Muslims, Hindus or Buddhists?

A letter quoted in the Runnymede Trust's controversial report on the future of multi-ethnic Britain notes how secular society tends to push religion to the margins of public space. Islamaphobia and anti-Semitism merge with a more widespread rejection of religion running through a significant part of the "tolerant", educated middle classes and the progressive media. Disestablishment would serve only to make all religions equally insignificant. Meanwhile the beliefs of the "educated middle classes" would run, untrammelled, through parliament, the media, cultural life and school lessons.

The monarch would be replaced by somebody akin to the gargoyles now sitting in our House of the Bourgeois Lords. "I never tried to defend the Lords in the old days," Jeremy Paxman wrote in the Spectator last week, "but I simply cannot see how the new place is any more legitimate: at least there used to be the possibility of unpredictability by accident of birth." Now he sees Tony's cronies, a few extinct political volcanoes and, with the coming people's peers, "a selection of busybodies who want a role in governing us without the inconvenience of getting elected". The Guardian's republic will be a dictatorship of the proletariat by school swots who dress in expensive casual wear and enjoy a little traditional toff bashing.

It has been said that the Act of Settlement cannot be repealed without amending or repealing at least eight other pieces of legislations. In fact, as Lord Douglas-Hamilton told the Scottish parliament, its non-religious provisions have been amended six times already. We could change them without unravelling the entire constitution. But that is not what the republican advocates of repeal want. As a Catholic I would like to see a Catholic monarch (who would improve on the horrors we produced in the 16th and 17th centuries). As a woman I have little affection for male primogeniture. But if this paper is for repealing the Act of Settlement, I am against it.

webTitle: Doctors despair over pressure on NHS

fields.headline: Doctors despair over pressure on NHS
fields.trailText: Doctors' leaders warned yesterday that the medical profession was falling into a state of "clinical depression" as it struggled to provide proper care for patients in an overstretched NHS.
fields.body:
Doctors' leaders warned yesterday that the medical profession was falling into a state of "clinical depression" as it struggled to provide proper care for patients in an overstretched NHS.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said it was no longer accurate to talk about a winter crisis in the health service, because problems of under-capacity and overwork continued all year round.

Reporting on the association's council meeting on Wednesday, he said: "The mood was one of despair and powerlessness to influence what is going on, because of not having the workforce or capacity." The condition of GP representatives could best be described as "clinically depressed".

Dr Bogle supported the government's NHS reform plan in July and was present in Downing Street on Monday when Tony Blair launched a winter planning strategy for the service. But his members have become increasingly disillusioned by the speed at which extra resources earmarked for the NHS can be translated into a better service for patients.

The BMA published results of a Mori opinion poll showing the proportion of the general public satisfied with the NHS fell from 72% in January 1998 to 58% last month.

When asked who or what was most responsible for the current state of affairs, 44% of the unprompted replies referred unspecifically to "the government", 20% to "the Conservative government", 11% to "the Labour government", 16% to NHS managers, and 2% to doctors.

Dr Bogle said: "The message from the public is clear. Despite increased spending on the NHS, politicians in this government and the last have failed to fulfil the public's expectations. People see doctors as the solution, not the problem."

Ten years ago GPs could almost have guaranteed finding a bed for their patients, but now most hospitals were permanently full. In some regions hospitals were forced to cram too many beds in smaller wards, leading to increased risks of infection.

Dr Bogle said it was commonplace for GPs to avoid sending patients to hospital when it would have been advisable to do so if a bed had been available.

GPs preferred the risk of possible censure by the General Medical Council for unsatisfactory treatment to the certainty that a trolley wait could do even more harm.

The BMA council heard of patients in Leeds being transferred to Nottingham to find intensive care beds. A patient needing orthopaedic treatment had been told the first available appointment was in September 2002.

Dr Bogle said hospitals were buying "trolley beds", a cross between a trolley and a bed, for patients waiting admission. It sounded "like a scene from Monty Python", with hospital managers claiming they had reduced trolley waits by putting people on equipment that looked like a trolley, but counted as a bed.

The Department of Health said the BMA had misinterpreted the opinion poll. It showed 58% satisfied with the NHS, compared with 28% dissatisfied. The satisfaction rating was higher than when the government came to power in 1997.

fields.headline: Thousand gather to mourn Dami
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Policing crime
fields.trailText: More than a thousand mourners yesterday paid their respects to murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor at an emotional memorial service held on what would have been his 11th birthday.
fields.body:
More than a thousand mourners yesterday paid their respects to murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor at an emotional memorial service held on what would have been his 11th birthday.

Paul Boateng, the home office minister, and Damilola's brother Tunde, 21, led the tributes to the boy who bled to death on a stairwell in Peckham, south London, 11 days ago. Damilola's father Richard, 55, wept alongside his wife Gloria, 49, and daughter Beme, 23, at the Mountain of Fire and Miracles Ministries church in Old Kent Road, Peckham.

Sobs came from the mourners as Tunde apologised to his little brother for not being there to protect him.

Tunde, who left his third year university course in Nigeria for a better life in England, said: "Apparently the only thing I did not offer him was protection from his killers on that fateful day.

"Damilola, I know you are resting peacefully. Please forgive me for not being there for you. I am deeply sorry for not being there for you."

With his father by his side for support, he said Damilola - or Dami as he was known to most of his friends - brought great joy and happiness to the Taylor family.

"He was a God-fearing, friendly, intelligent, loveable boy that any expectant mother would always like to have. He is part of my life that can never be erased."

In an emotional address Mr Boateng said Damilola had been a "bright rising star".

He urged people with information about the killing to come forward. "Speak, speak, tell the police what you saw."

Mr Boateng indicated that there should be more police officers, saying people needed "new faces on the beat".

A small group of Damilola's Sunday school friends sang a moving tribute to him entitled Thank You Lord.

The service was held at the Pentecostal church Damilola attended three times a week with his family after arriving in Britain from Nigeria four months ago. It replaced what should have been a birthday celebration. His father said his son had planned to mark it by taking treats to school and sharing them with his friends.

webTitle: RUC blames terrorists for 'tit for tat' killings

fields.headline: RUC blames terrorists for 'tit for tat' killings
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Republican terrorists were thought to have begun a 24-hour cycle of violence in Belfast that left two dead and another injured, the RUC chief constable said last night.
fields.body:
Republican terrorists were thought to have begun a 24-hour cycle of violence in Belfast that left two dead and another injured, the RUC chief constable said last night.

Sir Ronnie Flanagan had "no doubt" loyalists shot two Catholics on Wednesday, killing one and critically injuring the other, believing that republicans were responsible for the murder of a Protestant taxi driver the night before.

He said the force believed republicans were responsible for the murder of the taxi driver, Trevor Kell, provoking the subsequent gun attacks. His death at the wheel of his cab came when he answered a bogus booking in north Belfast.

Sir Ronnie said that the killing provoked loyalists to carry out what they saw as a reprisal. Catholic Gary Moore, 30, was shot dead as he worked on a building site in a mainly loyalist estate at Monkstown outside Belfast on Wednesday night. Minutes later, another Catholic, Paul Scullion, was shot and critically injured in a car outside a taxi depot in north Belfast.

Sir Ronnie said there was "distinct possibility" that it was the Ulster Defence Association to blame, although he told the BBC that it was too early to say "whether any of the formalised republican terrorist groups were involved, or if it was the work of some renegade or almost freelance" in the first killing.

A Sinn Fein assembly member said Sir Ronnie's comments were "groundless assumptions", while the dissident Real IRA said it was not to blame and suggested the possibility of "dirty tricks".

webTitle: Government to rush through hunting bill

fields.headline: Government to rush through hunting bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The government is to rush through a ban on fox hunting by holding the bill's second reading on Monday December 18, the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is to rush through a ban on fox hunting by holding the bill's second reading on Monday December 18, the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, said yesterday.

The haste suggests some ministers think there is a serious chance of forcing the bill on to the statute book before a May general election.

Alternatively, the government has calculated it is not averse to a fight with the Conservative rural lobby in the run-up to the election.

MPs will be given a free vote on three options. The key vote will be in a separate debate in the new year when MPs will take the bill as a committee of the whole house.

Once one of the options has been chosen the bill will be debated in detail by a smaller group of MPs in committee.

The procedure is the same as that used by the government to pilot deregulation of Sunday trading in the Shops Act. The three options, to be revealed in detail today when the bill is published, will be voluntary regulation, an outright ban, and licencing under a form of statutory regulation.

Downing Street indicated that the prime minister will vote for an outright ban.

Ms Beckett denied the decision to place the hunting bill so early in the timetable threatened to clog up the rest of its legislative programme, including its anti-crime measures.

Ms Beckett said: "All the Lords have to do is agree with what the Commons agrees then there is no need to clog anything up."

webTitle: Labour plans £100 a week maternity pay

fields.headline: Labour plans £100 a week maternity pay
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for a near-doubling of statutory maternity pay, in the most radical changes to parental rights since the second world war. Mothers will be offered £100 a week to stay at home with their new-born babies - a huge increase on the current £60.20 a week.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for a near-doubling of statutory maternity pay, in the most radical changes to parental rights since the second world war. Mothers will be offered £100 a week to stay at home with their new-born babies - a huge increase on the current £60.20 a week.

The move, which would cost the state an estimated £12m extra a week, is designed to slash the number of new mothers who return to work early because they are unable to survive on the current figure. More than half of new mothers return before the 18 weeks of paid leave to which they are entitled - with 80% citing money as the reason.

The plan, widely welcomed by family groups, is among proposals in the government's green paper on work and parents, published yesterday. It seeks to bring Britain's provision for working parents into line with Scandinavian and other EU states.

The consultation document suggests that working mothers should have the right to stay at home for a year after their child's birth - with paid maternity leave extended from 18 to 26 weeks. Unpaid breaks could last up to 12 months - instead of the present 22 weeks - and fathers could be given two weeks' paternity leave, paid at the same rate as mothers. Both parents could have the option of sharing unpaid maternity leave.

In a surprise move calculated to woo women voters, mothers could also have the right to work reduced hours for up to a year after their child's birth. The flexible working could continue when maternity leave ends, although small businesses could be exempt. Large businesses could also be let off if they can prove that their business would be "unduly disrupted".

The reduced hours plan, which the women's ministers, Tessa Jowell and Baroness Jay, and the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, had pressed hard for during a ministerial review process, had been widely expected to be dropped in the face of opposition from big business. But ministers believe it is the key to retaining the third of women who do not return to work after giving birth - at a cost to employers of £3,500 a worker, or £300m a year to the economy

"I think this is the most important issue," Ms Hodge said. "We need to find a way of reconciling the business interests with the interests of a lot of mothers, and what a lot of women want is more flexible working hours." Nearly half of all working women have children under five, with the figure likely to be 70% by 2010.

Launching the paper, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the review group had been surprised to learn that adoptive parents had no maternity rights. They would be able to take paid leave in line with birth parents, he said.

He described the work-life balance as "one of the key issues facing us in a modern society", and insisted that the system had to change. "The labour market has changed dramatically over the last 25 years and the status quo is not an option. We need to give support and assistance to parents, but in a way that business will recognise as important."

He said the employment services would be encouraged to train more temporary replacements for small businesses, while cash advances would be offered to cover employers' maternity pay. "There's an opportunity where we can marry both being a good parent and a good employee."

The proposals, out for consultation until March, were widely welcomed. The Maternity Alliance praised the government's determination to "move things forward"; the Equal Opportunity Commission said it showed a commitment to supporting families.

The Confederation of British Industry said flexible employment practice should be "encouraged, not regulated", and said extending maternity leave and offering paternity leave would hit small businesses.

The green paper in full

fields.headline: Florida court sits in 'final' judgment
fields.trailText: The outcome of the US presidential election yesterday lay in the hands of seven judges in the Florida supreme court, who were asked to make a final decision on whether thousands of disputed ballots should be recounted by hand.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Tallahassee and  Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
The outcome of the US presidential election yesterday lay in the hands of seven judges in the Florida supreme court, who were asked to make a final decision on whether thousands of disputed ballots should be recounted by hand.

With the controversial punchcard ballots under guard in a nearby room, and with Al Gore and George W Bush watching on television from Washington and Texas respectively, the judges wondered aloud whether they had any right to intervene in the most hotly disputed US election of the century.

The court adjourned last night to consider their ruling, which could come at any time today.

A victory for the vice-president, paving the way for a recount of up to 14,700 contested votes, would throw the US political scene into turmoil and take the constitution into uncharted waters. It could lead to the overturning of Mr Bush's 537-vote victory margin in Florida, and would almost certainly be challenged by Republican legislators in Florida and the US Congress.

A decision in favour of Mr Bush, ruling out a recount, would be a crippling blow to Mr Gore's hopes of winning the presidency.

His only chance of fighting on would be two separate private cases under way yesterday in the Tallahassee courts, where Democrats are calling for up to 25,000 votes to be invalidated because Republican party workers were allowed to fill in missing information on absentee ballot application forms before the election.

Rulings in both those lawsuits are also expected today. However, if the judge in either case makes the unexpected decision to disenfranchise thousands of voters because of what the Republicans portrayed as a "hyper-technicality", it would be immediately appealed to the Florida supreme court.

The judge in one of the cases, Nikki Clark, made plain her reluctance to follow that route yesterday, asking Democratic lawyers: "Why should I not find there was substantial compliance by the voters and accept their vote?"

If the Florida supreme court rules against Mr Gore on his call for a recount, however, many Democrats are likely to call for him not to pursue the absentee ballots cases. "This is coming to an end," said Democratic senator Dick Durbin. He said a Bush presidency "looks more and more" likely.

The judges at the state's highest court yesterday closely questioned both sides over the constitutionality and legality of a recount.

The Florida bench is made up of six Democrats and one independent. But, worryingly for Mr Gore, they showed they were keenly aware of the scrutiny of the US supreme court, which on Monday asked them to justify their intervention in the election, a tacit warning for the Florida court not to overreach its powers.

In a significant exchange, the Florida chief justice Charles Wells suggested to Mr Gore's lawyer, David Boies, that the state legislature had "plenary power" over the conduct of elections, "and that power cannot be eroded even by the state constitution".

However, another judge, Barbara Pariente, argued that a lower Florida court may have misinterpreted the law when it dismissed Mr Gore's challenge to the election result. Sanders Sauls had ruled that the vice-president had failed to prove there was a "reasonable probability" that the election result would be changed if the disputed ballots were counted.

Justice Pariente pointed out that the relevant statute only required that the ballots "cast doubt" on the outcome.

After yesterday's hearings, Mr Boies said that the Gore camp would accept the ruling of the court as the "final arbiter".

He added that if it ruled in Mr Gore's favour, the disputed ballots could be counted by Tuesday, the legal deadline for Florida to decide which way it will vote in the electoral college that will formally elect the president six days later.

webTitle: Scientists try to pin down the paranormal

fields.headline: Return to sender
fields.standfirst: Scientists try to pin down the paranormal
fields.trailText: Scientists try to pin down the paranormal
fields.body:
With halved ping pong balls covering her eyes and white noise playing down her headphones, office manager Annette Telesford let her mind drift.

"I see a triangle," she murmured. "Or a bird. A house ... flowers ... an animal, possibly a cat."

After 20 minutes of meditative rambling, the ping pong balls were removed and she was offered four images to choose from. Finally, after hesitating over a vase of flowers and the American flag, she plumped for a picture of a gorilla.

In a neighbouring building, paranormal investigator Richard Wiseman groaned; his team of "telepathic senders" had been concentrating on a rocky desert scene - which Annette placed fourth.

The experiment was repeated 10 times with different subjects yesterday as part of an investigation into ESP at the Museum of the Unknown in London.

Dr Wiseman, a psychologist at the University of Hertfordshire, aimed to find out whether using large numbers of senders would boost the success rates of telepathic messages. The experiments began with the senders - members of the public drawn from museum visitors - inside the building.

Two final trials took place outside, using images projected on to a wall, and it was hoped that up to 1,000 people would take part.

The event, sponsored by the Sci-Fi channel, was the largest ESP experiment since a series of Grateful Dead gigs in New York in 1971. Then, 2,000 people attempted to transmit an image to two sleeping volunteers who claimed to have telepathic abilities. Results were inconclusive.

Dr Wiseman said yesterday that a success rate of one in four, or less than that, would be written off as no better than pure chance. But anything higher would be exciting.

Emerging from her seclusion, Ms Telesford, 35, remained convinced of the possibility of ESP. She had felt a sense of blankness and wondered if this was because the desert image was being projected into her mind.

"I think everybody has it," she added. "People call it coincidence, but what is coincidence?"
