The event, sponsored by the Sci-Fi channel, was the largest ESP experiment since a series of Grateful Dead gigs in New York in 1971. Then, 2,000 people attempted to transmit an image to two sleeping volunteers who claimed to have telepathic abilities. Results were inconclusive. Dr Wiseman said yesterday that a success rate of one in four, or less than that, would be written off as no better than pure chance. But anything higher would be exciting. Emerging from her seclusion, Ms Telesford, 35, remained convinced of the possibility of ESP. She had felt a sense of blankness and wondered if this was because the desert image was being projected into her mind. "I think everybody has it," she added. "People call it coincidence, but what is coincidence?"

webTitle: Surgeons speak of life-death op on twins

fields.headline: Surgeons speak of life-death op on twins
fields.standfirst: More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: The surgeons who separated the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary spoke publicly for the first time last night about the dilemma of conducting an operation that would end in the weaker child's death.
fields.body:
The surgeons who separated the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary spoke publicly for the first time last night about the dilemma of conducting an operation that would end in the weaker child's death.

Alan Dickson and Adrian Bianchi gave a detailed account of the delicate and rarely performed operation that saved Jodie, and spoke of their feelings about the inevitable death of Mary.

The twins' parents, Michaelangelo and Rina Attard, who can be identified after they asked for a privacy ruling to be lifted, told ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald that Jodie was recovering well. Although they originally opposed the operation, they are reconciled to their situation and are delighted at Jodie' progress. But they attacked one of the appeal judges who heard arguments earlier this year over whether the operation should take place.

Despite their differing opinions, it was clear from last night's programme that there is mutual respect between doctors and parents. All are committed Christians and Mr Bianchi shares the parents' Maltese heritage. Mr and Mrs Attard are from the Mediterranean island of Gozo.

The surgeons were conscious that their actions would result in one child's death: the twins were joined at the pelvis, and Mary's life was maintained by her sister's heart and lungs. Mr Dickson said: "I think that was always in the forefront of our thoughts and our minds that normally when we go into the operating theatre we are there to save lives rather than to see our action result in the end of life."

He told the interviewer, Martin Bashir, that he prayed on his way to St Mary's hospital in Manchester on the morning of the operation on November 6. "I just prayed for help in a dif ficult situation, and I prayed for the parents. And I prayed that the outcome would be the best for everybody concerned."

The most sensitive part of the 20-hour operation came when neurosurgeons divided the twins' shared spinal cord, taking great care to preserve the nerves that controlled bladder and bowel functions. The slightest misjudgment would have resulted in a greatly reduced quality of life for Jodie.

After bones and internal organs were separated, the blood vessels connecting the twins had to be cut. Aware this would kill Mary, the two surgeons decided to perform the incision together. It was conducted in silence and with "great respect".

Mr Dickson said: "We've worked together a lot over the past 12 years and shared difficult moments but I think this was probably the most meaningful and intense situation we had been in. And one does not do that kind of thing without having a lot of thought and a lot of heartache."

Mr Bianchi added: "However hard you prepare for this sort of thing, when it actually comes to that act it doesn't come easy. It was a shared experience which, I have to say, I didn't relish."

Jodie has made speedy progress and is expected to have a normal life. Her ovaries are complete, and she should be able to have children.

Mr Bashir told reporters at a screening of the documentary yesterday that the parents were still bitter about the comments of Lord Justice Brooke. At the appeal hearing he held up a picture of the conjoined twins and said: "What is this creature in the eyes of the law?"

Mrs Attard told the programme she was furious the judge had made the comment without seeing Jodie and Mary. "Nobody can judge first without seeing. I think you have to see and then maybe you can judge."

webTitle: Car crime bill aims to curb theft and deaths

fields.headline: Car crime bill aims to curb theft and deaths
fields.standfirst: Policing crime
fields.trailText: More than 2,000 extra traffic speed cameras are expected to be installed as a result of legislation unveiled yesterday designed to crack down on car crime and the illicit trade in stolen vehicles.
fields.body:
More than 2,000 extra traffic speed cameras are expected to be installed as a result of legislation unveiled yesterday designed to crack down on car crime and the illicit trade in stolen vehicles.

New powers in the vehicles crime bill published yesterday will for the first time allow the fines paid by speeding motorists caught on film to be ploughed back into buying new cameras and updating them with digital technology.

The extra powers follow seven pilot schemes around the country. Preliminary indications are said to show "a positive" influence on speed levels and a reduction in accidents of more than 20%.

Lord Whitty, the transport minister, said the legislation would allow the proceeds from the existing 4,000 traffic cameras to finance their further expansion: "We expect a significant increase in safety cameras, mostly in urban areas. It is likely to be around 50%, based on indications from local authorities and police forces."

He also said that the introduction of digital cameras, already under way, would counter the belief that many cameras did not have any film in them: "The improved technology means when the flash goes off you must assume it is working and that it will be followed up."

Lord Whitty said 3,400 people were killed every year on the roads - one in three of them as a result of speeding motorists.

The new bill, which is expected to make swift progress through parliament, will also introduce powers to regulate the 3,000 firms operating in the motor salvage industry in an effort to tackle the sale of 30,000 stolen cars and vans each year by criminals who pass them off using the identities of legitimate vehicles. This process, known as ringing, often involves the use of the registration documents of cars that have been seriously damaged or written off.

Charles Clarke, the home office minister, said yesterday the bill would license dealers in the motor salvage industry and make sure they kept proper records of all their transactions. For the first time dealers who supply number plates will would also have to be licensed, and identity and entitlement checks will be introduced before a new set of plates is sold.

The legislation will give the police bulk access for the first time to the motor insurance industry's database so they can quickly and easily identify uninsured cars on the road. This will supplement the police's own stolen car index, which is also kept on a central computer database.

Lord Whitty said: "This bill is good news for motorists who should benefit from increased confidence in buying second hand cars and from road safety improvements generated by speed camera money. We plan to regulate the supply of number plates and also tighten up on vehicle registration procedures. Collectively they have the potential to make a real contribution to bringing down vehicle crime."

An Automobile Association spokesman said it supported legislation, saying lax control of the motor salvage industry had helped car thieves to prosper at the expense of law-abiding motorists. "The proposed legislation will make it very difficult for car thieves."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Minister opens wind farm
fields.body:
Minister opens wind farm

Energy minister Helen Liddell yesterday opened a £4m offshore wind farm at Blyth harbour in Nortumberland, the UK's first and the largest in the world.

It will test what the Department of Trade and Industry believes is a potential for £6bn of such farms around Britain, which in theory has enough offshore wind to supply three times its electricity needs.

Drink-drive law not unjust

The high court yesterday rejected a claim that the drink-drive laws breach the new Human Rights Act, but in view of the case's wider importance granted the right to petition the Lords.

Lawyers for driver Lee Parker, of Frome in Somerset, argued he had been wrongly convicted because the laws as framed infringed his right to be presumed innocent until found guilty.

M6 poster to be world's biggest

Ford is asking Guinness World Records to confirm that a 1 acre sheet of PVC to cover the entire side of Birmingham's old Fort Dunlop factory will be the world's biggest poster.

Measuring 143ft by 25.6ft, the ad for the new Mondeo will be visible from the M6.

Army increases its mobility

The army has unveiled the Supacat Mk3, an off-road six wheeler with a 1.9 litre engine that climbs slopes of 50 degrees and can carry six men and 3.5 tonnes at up to 40mph.

Built in Telford, Shropshire, 53 of the Supacats will equip the rapid reaction force, 16 Air Assault Brigade, and be dropped into action by parachute from Hercules planes.

fields.headline: The rise of quangocracy
fields.standfirst: They must be accountable to the public
fields.trailText: They must be accountable to the public.
fields.body:
This week the Guardian has done its best to get people discussing the way Britain governs itself - an effort vindicated perhaps by the Daily Telegraph's decision yesterday to dedicate no fewer than six pieces to our initiative on the monarchy. Our focus has been not just the arcane way in which we choose - or rather do not choose - our head of state, but our entire constitutional set-up. Along the way, we have made two key objections: first to a system which hoards enormous, unchecked power at the centre; and second, to a lack of regard for the elective principle which should lie at the heart of any democracy.

Yesterday came practical, on-the-ground proof that these are not mere abstract concerns - but deeply embedded characteristics of the British way of governance. The evidence came in a timely report from the Local Government Information Unit, which sought to measure the reach of quangos - the euphoniously named quasi-autonomous non- governmental organisations: bodies which are not elected by the public yet perform a range of public functions. Authored by, among others, that veteran watchdog of British democracy, Stuart Weir, the report took as its starting point Labour's pre-1997 promise to "sweep away the quango state". The party had promised to push aside the assorted boards and trusts which were making public decisions and spending public money - replacing them, wherever possible, with bodies that were open, accountable and democratic.

What happened? Labour did nothing of the sort. Instead, we have seen what yesterday's report called "the advance of the quango state", with a growing number of public tasks, especially in the local sphere, conferred on appointees - many of them meeting in secret, under the scrutiny of no one. The jobs the quangos are doing are public ones: in a democracy the people doing them should be accountable to the public.

webTitle: Two charged in Aeroflot swindle case

fields.headline: Two charged in Aeroflot swindle case
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A former senior official in Russia's national carrier, Aeroflot, was arrested yesterday and charged with large-scale fraud, as prosecutors intensified their investigation of high-level political corruption.
fields.body:
A former senior official in Russia's national carrier, Aeroflot, was arrested yesterday and charged with large-scale fraud, as prosecutors intensified their investigation of high-level political corruption.

Soon after Nikolai Glushkov, a former deputy director-general of the airline, new fraud charges were laid against its former commercial director Alexander Kransnenker.

The moves were seen as a clear indication that the authorities are determined to pursue the long-stalled and tangled embezzlement case, which involves key figures from former president Boris Yeltsin's entourage - most prominently the businesstycoon Boris Berezovsky.

The prosecutors accuse Aeroflot executives of skimming off £670m-worth of profits and funnelling the money to two companies - Forus and Andava - allegedly founded by Mr Berezovsky in Switzerland. Both companies have denied the charges.

Swiss officials have been working with the Russian prosecution department to gather documents relating to the airline's financial affairs and part of the evidence brought against Mr Glushkov yesterday was provided by Swiss investigators.

Mr Berezovsky has been summoned to Moscow for questioning as a witness in the case. After an earlier interrogation in October he fled Russia, saying that he was the victim of politically motivated persecution, fuelled partly, he said, by the president's dissatisfaction with the coverage on the television channel he controls.

He said he had no intention of returning home until the vendetta against him ceased. Prosecutors have warned that they are preparing to file charges against him.

President Vladimir Putin has promised to end the close ties between the government and Russia's oligarchs, who seized huge wealth and gained great influence in the Kremlin under Mr Yeltsin.

Mr Berezovsky is one of the first figures to have been squeezed from his position of power.In turn, he has embarked on an energetic campaign to identify himself as a wronged emigre, declaring that he would rather be a political exile than a political prisoner.

Mr Berezovsky has recently made searing new attacks on Mr Putin, claiming in a Russian newspaper that the president's election last year was partly financed by "profits from Swiss companies working with Aeroflot".

Repeatedly accusing the president of authoritarian tendencies, he has sought to depict himself as a protector of democracy. Last week he made a very public £2m donation to save the Andrei Sakharov human rights centre in Moscow.

Mr Glushkov's lawyer said the charges were unfounded his client was seriously ill.

fields.headline: Education in inequality
fields.trailText: Do not call Laura Spence a snob because she ended up doing biochemistry at Harvard, rather than medicine. The US education system specialises much later than in Britain and the normal course for would-be medical professionals in the US is to take a degree in a relevant subject at undergraduate level, and then apply for post-graduate medical training.
fields.body:
Do not call Laura Spence a snob because she ended up doing biochemistry at Harvard, rather than medicine (Why snobs can keep their dreaming spires, G2, December 5). The US education system specialises much later than in Britain and the normal course for would-be medical professionals in the US is to take a degree in a relevant subject at undergraduate level, and then apply for post-graduate medical training.

The point is that elite universities that can afford well-equipped laboratories, low student-pupil ratios, extra tuition from graduate teaching assistants to small groups of students are inevitably going to turn out better educated students, no matter what the original quality of their intake was. And, given any choice, students are going to want those facilities. The real problem is how much can the country afford to spend per pupil - unfortunately it is much cheaper on both sides of the Atlantic to have a few elite well-funded institutions.
Jacky Mallett
Cambridge, Massachusetts
warlock@media.mit.edu

 Having read your article on childcare for university students (Who cares? December 5), I felt compelled to put forward a different version. I am a mature student married to a businessman with two children. I decided to train as an occupational therapist. What grant did I receive? Nothing. What financial help do I get with my childcare? None. According to the "powers that be" my husband earns too much money for me to qualify for either. For 22 years I have been taxed independently on all my earnings, but as soon as I apply for a grant I "morph" into an extension of my husband.
Helen Barnes
Twickenham, Middx

webTitle: Letters: Tune into Jerusalem's fighting history

fields.headline: Tune into Jerusalem's fighting history
fields.trailText: In 1916, Hubert Parry and Walford Davies (teacher and pupil) were associated with a public meeting at the Queen's Hall in London to inaugurate the Fight for Right movement. The aims of this organisation were "to brace the spirit of the nation that the people of Great Britain, knowing that they are fighting for the best interests of humanity, may refuse any temptation, however insidious, to conclude a premature peace, and may accept with cheerfulness all the sacrifices necessary to bring the war to a satisfactory conclusion".
fields.body:
In 1916, Hubert Parry and Walford Davies (teacher and pupil) were associated with a public meeting at the Queen's Hall in London to inaugurate the Fight for Right movement. The aims of this organisation were "to brace the spirit of the nation that the people of Great Britain, knowing that they are fighting for the best interests of humanity, may refuse any temptation, however insidious, to conclude a premature peace, and may accept with cheerfulness all the sacrifices necessary to bring the war to a satisfactory conclusion".

Robert Bridges, the poet laureate, had asked Parry to set William Blake's words for a performance at that inaugural meeting and Jerusalem was sung by a choir of 300, with Walford Davies conducting (Not too happy. Not very glorious, December 6) . Afterwards, Parry gave Davies the manuscript and said: "There you are, my boy, do what you like with it." What Davies did was to take it to the publisher Curwen and before long he was teaching it throughout the country as a unison song.

Through the great baritone, Harry Plunket Greene, Jerusalem was adopted as the anthem of the amateur competitive festival movement and was sung at the close of every such event - it still is at some festivals.

Since Blake was once arrested for speaking treasonable words in public against King George III, it is ironic that when (now Sir) Walford Davies was to conduct the Royal Silver Jubilee concert at the Albert Hall in 1935, King George V, on discovering that Jerusalem was not on the programme, expressed dismay and said that he would "have to go down myself to the platform and whistle it".
Christopher Wiltshire
Former archivist, British Federation of Festivals for Music, Speech and Dance

 Parry's music is admittedly splendid, but, for an atheist, its words are as impossible to take seriously as those of God save the Queen. My answer to Blake's questions in the first two verses is a resounding No, and I certainly don't want to build anything resembling Jerusalem in this country. We need a non-religious, non-jingoistic tune for Olympic ceremonies etc. Why not run a competition?
Mary Wane
Windermere, Cumbria

fields.headline: Stub out this funding
fields.trailText: Nottingham university has not only taken British American Tobacco's blood money, but is mindlessly parroting the company's PR line about having changed its ways (Dons furious over tobacco cash, December 6).
fields.body:
Nottingham university has not only taken British American Tobacco's blood money, but is mindlessly parroting the company's PR line about having changed its ways (Dons furious over tobacco cash, December 6). BAT's cynical marketing practices have not changed one iota in developing countries, where it is strenuously going after young people, including previously non-smoking young women, to hook them on their addictive, lethal products. No doubt BAT will proudly cite this new sponsorship in meetings behind closed doors with third-world governments, to persuade them not to enact the advertising bans so urgently recommended by the World Health Organisation.

Big tobacco displays all the ethics of a dung beetle and university chiefs who take its money must be either stupid, culpably ignorant or just plain greedy, all qualities that are scary to find in those responsible for our own youth's education. Will Nottingham now approach the Pinochet Foundation, to sponsor a cen tre for the study of democracy and human rights?
Prof David Simpson
International Agency on Tobacco and Health
dmin@iath.org

 Given that Nottingham University has virtually operated as a private company over the past decade, one can hardly be surprised to find that it is willing to accept "donations" from all and sundry. I trust that reputable public funders will cut themselves adrift from the university as soon as possible so as not to impede its application for plc status.
Dr RM Page
Nottingham
rmp12@le.ac.uk

 As a Nottingham graduate, I receive regular invitations to contribute to the university and each edition of the alumni magazine lists the large number of former students who respond generously. One way in which this sizeable constituency can support the (potentially vulnerable) staff and make the Nottingham authorities aware that the recent decision is totally unacceptable is to contact the alumni office and make clear that any future donations are conditional on this deal being stubbed out immediately.
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes, Bucks

 As someone involved in trying to persuade my own university not to establish a professorship in the name of an arms company (GKN), may I express support for anyone in Nottingham campaigning against this and to urge others to do so?
Adam Conway
Churchill College, Cambridge
adc27@cam.ac.uk

 It is incorrect to describe Nottingham's proposed initiative as Europe's first international centre for corporate responsibility (University accepts tobacco 'blood money', December 5). The first centre was established a decade ago at Manchester Business School with the support of the Cooperative Bank. Since then, substantial centres have been established at London Business School, Warwick University, Insead and Kingston Business School to name just a few. An especially interesting centre - the New Academy of Business - was created between Body Shop and Bath University.

Typically, these centres are international from their inception, realising that corporate policies work best when the local, national and international responsibilities of businesses are linked. Academic study plays a vital part in shaping the agenda by underpinning the aspirations, hopes and claims of practitioners with serious research into, for example, the link between responsible behaviour and business performance.
Prof Tom Cannon
New Academy Review

fields.headline: Win for working parents
fields.standfirst: It should be families first, profits second
fields.trailText: It should be families first, profits second.
fields.body:
Campaigners for working parents are celebrating. Finally, after more than two decades, they have a green paper which honestly and sensibly confronts a debate about maternity and paternity leave. Britain has been left behind in Europe; many countries have long since outstripped us in the provisions made for new parents to care for their children. This is despite Britain having some of the highest rates of female participation in the labour market. The cost to the quality of family life and the well-being of babies is self-evident. All of this is generously acknowledged and backed up with detailed research in the Work and Parents green paper. The message, delivered by Stephen Byers yesterday, is clear: no change is not an option. That will help focus the minds of those businesses that persist in opposing any improvement.

There are plenty of other goodies in this Christmas stocking - indeed something for everyone as is the wont of New Labour. They include the outlines of a package carefully designed to keep everyone sweet. It runs along the lines of: an increase in statutory maternity pay (SMP) from £60.20 to around £100 a week, or an extension of maternity leave up to a year; men get two weeks paid paternity leave; business gets a generous exemption scheme on flexible working rights, plus plenty of help on administration costs and recruiting replacements to cover for maternity leave. They even recommend tackling anomalies such as adoptive parents not being entitled to leave and those women not eligible for maternity pay - such as student nurses. There are other interesting suggestions, including switching unpaid maternity leave between parents.

This is all a huge step change in government thinking - remember only a few years ago, government laughed the idea of paid paternity leave out of court. But having paid credit where it is due, it is not churlish to point out some disturbing weaknesses. The most depressing is that it presents increasing SMP and lengthening leave as either/or alternatives. But one without the other is useless; women need longer leave, yet they will not take it unless they can afford it. Hopefully, this is just a slip of wording. The paper took a very dim view of extending earnings related pay (which currently covers the first six weeks of maternity leave), arguing that it would benefit the better off - which sounds as if it comes straight from the Treasury. Also disappointing is the fact that the paper is noticeably hesitant on the key issue of flexible hours on return to work. This is where parents' interests and those of business most clearly clash. Business has been howling at the possibility, playing the damage to small business card for all its worth. Mr Byers is bending as far as possible. The whole document is tilted towards winning over business: its subtitle is "competitiveness and choice". One of the first chapters is devoted to the benefits to business of improving provision.

At the press conference, Baroness Margaret Jay, the minister for women, spelled it out: "This is not an old-fashioned argument about rights but about the bottom line." She is wrong. This is an argument primarily about rights - the rights of babies and those who care for them. Those rights derive from our respect for the next generation and for those who have the responsibilities of nurturing small children. Far from old-fashioned, this should be the starting point of policy; the economic benefits while useful to the debate, come second. Happily, there is enough in this green paper to indicate that the government and Mr Byers have finally got the message.

The green paper in full

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • The quark is the smallest sub-atomic particle known to science, but there is something smaller: the British financial community's social conscience. Difficulties raising capital has caused the Big Issue to sell off its headquarters in King's Cross, and move to rented accommodation in south London. With the money left over, Big Issue editor John Bird is setting up a social investment fund and bank, "to get around the fact that no one wants to invest in jobs for the homeless". Eventually, Bird hopes to offer bank accounts for the poor, backed by ethical investors who are happy to back the non-commercial aspects of the fund. A formal announcement is expected next year, but progress is proving to be slow thanks to the Financial Services Authority's demands. "You almost have to have no bodily hair or be a permanent virgin," he sighs. "There's a lot of hurdles we have to jump over."
fields.body:
 The quark is the smallest sub-atomic particle known to science, but there is something smaller: the British financial community's social conscience. Difficulties raising capital has caused the Big Issue to sell off its headquarters in King's Cross, and move to rented accommodation in south London. With the money left over, Big Issue editor John Bird is setting up a social investment fund and bank, "to get around the fact that no one wants to invest in jobs for the homeless". Eventually, Bird hopes to offer bank accounts for the poor, backed by ethical investors who are happy to back the non-commercial aspects of the fund. A formal announcement is expected next year, but progress is proving to be slow thanks to the Financial Services Authority's demands. "You almost have to have no bodily hair or be a permanent virgin," he sighs. "There's a lot of hurdles we have to jump over."

 Opera North, that beacon of culture in Leeds (and one of the venues of the Diary's triumphant summer tour of Leeds with Gerald Kaufman in an open-topped Rolls-Royce), is also in the process of making itself more businesslike. Its management decided that to be dynamic, thrusting, etc, etc, it needs a mission statement. A swathe of candidates has been discussed, although none have so far included such silly old words as "opera" or "music". One contender is said to have potential: "To make people come." But managers are puzzled by the sniggers coming from the orchestra pit.

 Fun and games at the DETR last Friday, when environmental protesters hurdled the turnstiles and invaded the offices of transport minister Gus Macdonald, barricading themselves in. A couple arrived late, and meeting a figure on the 6th floor demanded to know if he was Lord M. "No," he replied, "I'm Peter Unwin, the deputy prime minister's private secretary." They then asked to see Prescott, and Peter asked them to wait. Which was a problem when the police arrived to turf out the protesters. "We've been invited to stay by Peter Unwin," they chorused.

 Boris Johnson is still struggling to adjust himself to the demands of putting his brain into gear before engaging mouth. "I gave several speeches at the Tory party conference," the Jackal recently told Cambridge's Varsity newspaper, "tumultously received - uh, Nuremberg..." Boris suddenly realises that comparing the Tories to the Nazi party is not so clever: "Oh, hang on, scratch that! I shouldn't say that - they were packed out, you see [thumps desk]! That's the kind of metaphor you can't get away with..." Oh dear, Boris. Your transformation from rightwing buffoon to Tory parliamentary statesman is going to take some time.

 Speaking of engaged brains, William Hague's wasn't when he unveiled a reissue this week of a condensed The Road To Serfdom. "Hayek's argument is as relevant now as it was more than a half a century ago," said Hague. Oh yes. Check the cartoons in the pamphlet: one shows a figure being executed. "Your disciplining is 'planned'," reads this relevant argument. "If you're fired from your job, it's apt to be by firing squad." How like Britain today.

 The Tories will get no solace from the Economist's The World in 2001 annual. "Britain will be a great place to live," it confidently predicts on page 22. It also foresees a spring election: "A strong middle-of-the-road modern government under Tony Blair's prime ministership will continue in office for five more years." Hmmm, you might think, except the author is Dudley Fishburn, the ex-Kensington Tory MP who stood down in 1997.

 Australians take a refreshingly robust attitude to life, and indeed death. A news item this week in Melbourne's Age newspaper was headlined: "Kerry Packer in hospital, but he is not dead yet."

fields.headline: Eli Frankham
fields.standfirst: Civil rights leader and champion of the rights of Britain's Romani community
fields.trailText: Civil rights leader and champion of the rights of Britain's Romani community
fields.body:
The poet and charismatic civil rights leader Eli Frankham, who has died aged 72, was founder and president of the National Romani Rights Association (NRRA) and a political leader of Britain's 100,000-strong Romani community. A former professional boxer, and a wise countryman, musician and storyteller, he was known and respected by ordinary travellers across Britain and Europe.

Eli was born in a horse-drawn Romani vardo (or caravan) at Chanctonbury Ring in Sussex. For much of his young life, he travelled in southern England, until his family bought land in the Hampshire village of Horndean, where he was sent to school. Unlike many of his generation, he learnt to read and write, although he also experienced the racism that he was to spend a lifetime fighting.

"I was the only Gypsy in that school," he recalled years later. "They'd call out 'Gippo, Gippo'. I had a rough time, so I started to fight and play hookey." At the age of 10, having broken into an (empty) gas meter, Eli was put into care for four years - where he learnt to play the cornet.

Eli was always a fighter; as a member of the Frankham family, he had a proud tradition to maintain. He started his boxing career in fair-ground boxing booths on Southampton common. After the war, he became the Middle East Land Forces middleweight champion (his cousin, "Gypsy" John Frankham, later became the British middleweight boxing champion).

While serving as an army bugler, Eli met a group of Gypsies in Palestine with whom he could speak Romani; the experience was to kindle his lifelong interest in the wider Romani nation of which he was a part.

A gifted linguist with a fine command of Romani, Eli sent academics scurrying for their notebooks when he used the word kakkeratches (magpies) at the fourth World Romani Congress in Warsaw in 1990. But his relationship with gorjia , or non-Gypsy, academics was not always so lighthearted.

He mistrusted academics within the "Gypsy industry", who he believed worked with travellers only to further their own careers, and he was equally intolerant of corruption within Gypsy organisations. This attitude led to his involvement in a bitter libel suit with the National Gypsy Council, which he eventually won in 1997.

Eli founded the NRRA in the 1970s. He fought for legislation, such as the Caravan Sites Act 1968, which, for the first time, placed a legal duty on local authorities to provide caravan sites for Romani people. He opposed legislation like the Criminal Justice Act 1994, which removed the legal duty imposed by the 1968 act, and further criminalised traditional nomadic life with the new offence of "criminal trespass".

He recently sat on the advisory panel of the traveller law reform unit at Cardiff University law school, helping to draft the Traveller Law Reform Bill.

Eli helped hundreds of Romani families fight the local planning regulations that stopped them from settling in caravans on their own land. As a result, thousands of Romani children have gained access to education, healthcare and sanitation. Working voluntarily, he won huge respect from his people, and spent thousands of pounds pursuing his goals. He never received any official recognition.

Eli was both modern and traditional. He believed that education was crucial to Romani emancipation, but he also valued Romani tradition. He both kept and traded horses all his life, recorded old Romani stories and songs, and would not be seen in public without a diklo , or Romani scarf, around his neck. He was a powerful public speaker and singer, who never failed to entertain his many family and friends.

Many travellers referred to him as Uncle Eli; some of his younger relatives called him "Uncle Badger". I recently overheard a journalist asking another Romani activist if he had email. "No", he replied, "but I've got E-li."

Unlike other, more commercially-minded travellers, who have exploited the myth of the Gypsy King, Eli never claimed any title, but if any man could have filled that position it would have been him. He had the charisma and the intelligence; most of all, he had the love of his people.

Eli's last public action was to fight against the banning of the ancient Horsmonden horse fair in Kent last September. He led a march of Romani protesters on fair day, and came back two weeks later to remember the dead travellers, whose names are written on the war memorial on Horsmonden Green. On that day, he dusted off his old cornet and played the Last Post. Sadly, it was also his last post.

He is survived by his wife, Gert, and six children.

webTitle: Stop spilling our blood, people tell Arafat

fields.headline: Stop spilling our blood, people tell Arafat
fields.standfirst:
Intifada fire is dying as Palestinians turn against gunmen and leaders

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yasser Arafat has ordered his militia commanders to stop shooting from Palestinian cities and towns because people are complaining of an unbearable toll in civilian deaths and suffering, the Guardian has learned.

Yasser Arafat has ordered his militia commanders to stop shooting from Palestinian cities and towns because people are complaining of an unbearable toll in civilian deaths and suffering, the Guardian has learned.

Faced with a growing public clamour to rethink his intifada strategy and pull back the gunmen, the Palestinian leader told his Fatah lieutenants on Wednesday to hold fire.

In the Bethlehem suburb of Beit Jala, pummelled relentlessly by Israeli tank and machine-gun fire, Mr Arafat made an almost unheard of personal intervention, telephoning the Latin patriarch, Monsignor Michel Sabbah - the most senior representative of the Roman Catholic church in the Holy Land - to arrange a meeting with his Fatah area commander.

Among Palestinians there is a deepening despair at the price the 10-week uprising has exacted from their community: the overwhelming majority of the 300 killed and 10,000 injured are Arab, half the population is out of work, and acres of Palestinian olive groves and farmland have been bulldozed by the Israeli army.

There is also anger, and disillusionment. In the West Bank city of Nablus, a stronghold of Fatah militancy, militia leaders had already washed their hands of Mr Arafat's intifada: two weeks ago they laid down their guns in protest at corruption in his Palestinian Authority.

Wednesday's extraordinary meeting in Beit Jala, a largely Christian Arab town, produced the most determined effort to stop the shooting in any of the areas under Mr Arafat's control. Mgr Sabbah and four local mayors came together with the Fatah area commander and reached a unanimous decision.

"It is not a military decision, or a political decision. It is a decision according to the needs of the people," said Kamal Hmeid, the Fatah commander for the Bethlehem region. "Most of the Palestinian people want to continue with the intifada, but without the heavy losses and damages. They are saying in a loud voice: 'Please find a different way because we can not go on like this'."

The order has also gone out from militia commanders in the West Bank cities of Hebron and Ramallah, and in Khan Yunus in the Gaza Strip.

The effort to shield Palestinian civilians from further bloodshed is a delicate matter. The gunmen have no central command: Fatah militiamen are organised regionally, they owe their allegiance to local commanders and only indirectly to Mr Arafat, and they are swayed by local conditions.

An Israeli military operation, such as further missile strikes or the assassination of militia leaders, could sabotage Mr Arafat's effort to steer the uprising along a less lethal course. Two previous orders to stop shooting from residential areas bought a few days of relative calm to Beit Jala and other towns, but then the bloodshed resumed.

After Wednesday's meeting, Mr Hmeid mounted a vigil in Beit Jala, pleading with gangs of tanzim (militia) to follow the instructions. "I know it is not easy to stop," he said.

The decision to try to rein in Bethlehem's gunmen was forced on Mr Arafat by local people trapped between the Palestinian gunmen and the bombardment by Israeli tanks guarding the Jewish settlement of Gilo on the opposite ridge. The area's mayors and other notables besieged the Palestinian leader with faxes and public entreaties to stop the gunmen.

"There is no reason to use citizens' houses for this," said Raji Zeidan, mayor of Beit Jala, where 300 houses have been damaged by heavy Israeli fire. "But at the same time we cannot justify Israel's action."

People have intifada fatigue, ground down by the toll in human life and the economic cost of Israel's blockade of the West Bank and Gaza. Religious factors - the Muslim holy month of Ramada and the approach of Christmas for Christian Arabs - are also taking the fire out of the intifada.

Now, as the uprising enters its eleventh week, two strategies are exhausted: the popular demonstrations by teenage stone-throwers confronting Israeli soldiers and the guerrilla-style actions by the militias operating from residential areas.

"The aim of the intifada is not to put pressure on the Palestinian people, because the Palestinian people are already suffering from siege and from hunger, and we do not want them to suffer more. That is why we took the decision to ease the situation," said Hussein Sheikh, who commands the Fatah militias in Ramallah.

"There is a tangible reduction in the level of confrontation. This intifada is taking the shape of waves, and the Palestinians are now thinking more about the quality of action."

They are also thinking about the quality of their leaders. In the Balata refugee camp, on the edges of Nablus, the gunmen gave up on Mr Arafat's intifada two weeks ago, sensing that he was ready to reopen negotiations with Israel. They accuse him of being too eager to pick up the pieces of the fractured peace process.

"The intifada has already stopped," the Fatah area leader, Hussam Khader, said. "We discovered everything will end up on the table and we will become the first names on the blacklist of the Palestinian Authority's most wanted men after he makes a deal. Why should we risk our lives for people to become rich?"

In the camps there is growing outrage at reports that 50 of the authority's senior officials left, or evacuated their families, from the West Bank and Gaza when the uprising began in late September. The reports have reawakened ordinary people's anger at their leaders' corruption.

That resentment, put aside when the insurrection began, resurfaced this week in the West Bank and Gaza when authority staff got their salaries and found that they were paying an "intifada tax" of nearly 200 shekels (£35).

"They have been taking money to help the people since 1996," an employee from Nablus said. "So where is this money going, and why do they have to take something more now?"

In Hizme, a village in the shadow of a Jewish settlement on the northern edge of Jerusalem, Jalila Suleiman Salahaddin has been nursing her anger since November 3, when she buried her first-born son, Mahmoud Abdul Jawad Sayeed.

"The big guys, the leaders, they will buy cars, and they will buy villas, and will have a very happy life," she said.

"But we, we are the common people, and we will can do nothing but throw stones. Imagine these big officials leaving the country and going abroad. They are not committed to the soil. I think we are better than them."

webTitle: Clinton wants third term in office

fields.headline: Clinton wants third term in office
fields.standfirst: Constitutional ban is outdated, president says in nostalgic interview
fields.trailText: The US constitution should be changed to allow a president to serve more than two terms, Bill Clinton has told Rolling Stone magazine.
fields.body:
The US constitution should be changed to allow a president to serve more than two terms, Bill Clinton has told Rolling Stone magazine.

The country could have saved itself a lot of aggravation in the past month by simply electing him for a third term, he said. Unfortunately for Mr Clinton, the 22nd amendment to the constitution forbids a president from standing for more than two terms.

"Oh, I probably would have run again," Mr Clinton told the magazine in an interview. Asked whether he thought he would have won, he replied: "Yes I do. But it's hard to say, because it's entirely academic."

But he made it clear that he had not entirely given up the idea of a possible return to the Oval Office. As life expectancy has risen, the 22nd amendment may have become unnecessarily restrictive, he said. It could be changed to limit a president to "two consecutive terms" - a provision which would let Mr Clinton mount a comeback in 2004.

In the final weeks of his presidency he has given a series of nostalgic interviews to several magazines, including Esquire, in which he has made little effort to disguise his reluctance to leave office.

In the Rolling Stone interview he spoke at length about drugs and his sneaking admiration for Richard Nixon, and admitted that the Republican party outmanoeuvred him on the question of gays in the armed forces, a topic that dogged the early months of his first term in 1993.

Mr Clinton blamed the Republicans for the bitter political atmosphere in Washington for much of his time in the White House. They "thought they had found a foolproof formula to hold on to the White House for ever".

"Mostly, it's just because I won. I think, secondly, because I was the first baby-boomer president. And I opposed the Vietnam war. That made them doubly angry, because they thought I was a cultural alien and I made it anyway," Mr Clinton said.

The Republicans "didn't want me to have a honeymoon," he said, and therefore forced the issue of gays in the forces to the top of the agenda as soon as he took office, confident that they had the votes to defeat the measure in Congress.

That forced Mr Clinton to consult the then chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, General Colin Powell. Between them the two came up with what Mr Clinton called "this dumb-ass 'don't ask, don't tell' thing".

The policy resulted in "several years of problems", because it was not implemented consistently," he said.

It was a brilliant political move on the part of the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, ensuring that "the controversy would consume the early days of my presidency".

On the subject of marijuana, the man who famously claimed not to have inhaled said that the possession of "most small amounts of marijuana have been decriminalised and should be".

He added that he supported a re-examination of the variations in sentencing policy, especially between crack - for which long jail sentences are almost automatic - and cocaine, about which the courts have more discretion.

"The differences are unconscionable between crack and powdered cocaine," he said.

"I tried to change that. The Republican Congress was willing to narrow but not eliminate them, the theory being that people who used crack were more violent.

"What they really meant was, people that used crack were more likely to be poor and, coincidentally, black or brown. Those people that used cocaine were more likely to be rich, pay for it, and therefore be peaceful."

He said that Nixon had returned to the White House for a visit during which he had told him that "he identified with me, because he thought the press has been too hard on me".

"I had refused to die, and he liked that. He said a lot of life was just hanging on. We had a good talk about that."

Mr Clinton said he thought that Nixon could have been "a great president if he had been more trusting of the American people".

webTitle: Lords uphold protection for private tenants

fields.headline: Lords uphold protection for private tenants
fields.trailText: Government measures aimed at protecting thousands of private tenants from huge rent increases were upheld by the House of Lords yesterday after a complex court battle.
fields.body:
Government measures aimed at protecting thousands of private tenants from huge rent increases were upheld by the House of Lords yesterday after a complex court battle.

Five law lords reversed a court of appeal decision which had outlawed the 1999 Rent Acts (Maximum Fair Rent) Order, setting a cap on the rent that protected tenants can be expected to pay.

The order was made by the government after lobbying by MPs whose constituents, tenants with security of tenure under the Rent Act, faced demands for rent increases of up to 300%.

Many were elderly people on fixed incomes whose tenancies dated back before the Housing Act 1988, when most private tenancies were regulated by the Rent Act.

The introduction of assured tenancies by the 1988 act created for the first time a real "free market" in private rented property. Landlords brought a series of court cases against rent assessment panels, forcing them to give more weight to market rents. To cure the problem, the government applied a maximum limit to increases in rents which had already been registered.

In the court of appeal Manchester landlords Spath Holme Ltd won a ruling that, in making the order, the environment secretary and the secretary of state for Wales exceeded the powers available to them under the 1985 Landlord and Tenant Act.

But the law lords reversed the ruling yesterday.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Len Shackleton (Obituary, November 29) saved his best performances for Arsenal
fields.body: Peter Wallace writes: Len Shackleton (Obituary, November 29) saved his best performances for Arsenal; I remember one game when he laid on all of Sunderland's goals in their 4-1 win. He was also a pioneer in merchandising; I enjoyed many an ice cream in a wrapper adorned with the signatures of Shack and Sunderland's Len Duns.

fields.headline: Robert Escarpit
fields.standfirst: Acerbic commentator on the state of France
fields.trailText: Acerbic commentator on the state of France
fields.body:
For many French people, Professor Robert Escarpit, who has died aged 82, was most famous as a regular commentator for the Paris daily, Le Monde. Between 1949 and 1979, some 9,000 of his regular, 200-word Au Jour le Jour front-page pieces appeared in the paper - and it was generally the piece that one read first.

Sometimes, he considered a specific event. Thus, when Pierre Mendès France's government was forced to resign in the mid-1950s, Escarpit pointed out that no one was happier than the comedians of the Paris music halls. Now they would be able to resume their mockery of the foolish and incompetent governments that succeeded one another. With Mendès France in power, this had not been possible.

Sometimes, Escarpit took the French as a whole to task. In 1970, he wrote that they pitied poor children dying in Biafra, India or Africa. The French had long sight, he observed. But the news of five Africans being killed in a fire at their workplace in a Paris suburb passed almost unnoticed. It was time, he concluded, for the French to put on their spectacles.

Escarpit was a man of many accomplishments. He was both professor of English and professor of the science of information and communication at the University of Bordeaux, and, from 1975 to 1978, the university's president. He wrote some 70 books, including novels, texts on English literature and the sociology of literature, several works directed at young people, and a few widely-read essays on current affairs.

Born at Saint-Macaire, in the Gironde, Escarpit entered École Normale Supérieure in Paris in 1938. He studied English and, after the war, resolved to write a thesis on Byron. But then, in England, he took part in a discussion with Harold Nicolson and Peter Quennell, which hinged upon what Byron was doing at 5pm on a certain afternoon. He enjoyed their erudition, but turned away from this form of research.

Escarpit became more interested in the sociology of literature and came to England to meet Richard Hoggart. When Birmingham University established its Centre for Cultural Studies, led by Hoggart, he decided that this was the result of Hoggart's defence in the Lady Chatterley's Lover obscenity trial - and, afterwards, Escarpit always called the centre the "Lady Chatterley institute". But he created something similar in 1965, the Institut Littéraire des techniques artistiques de masse, and, in 1967, another institute specialising in communication.

Escarpit was always loyal to the Bordeaux region. He claimed that the Girondins had played a vital role in the revolution, as he claimed that the products of the region were by far the best. He always drank Bordeaux, and the story is told of how his son once persuaded him to try Burgundy. He drank a glass, then shook his head. "Oh, no," he sighed, "I prefer wine."

He was also interested in politics. In 1936, aged 18, he played an active part in supporting the Popular Front government. He fought with the resistance in the Médoc, south of Bordeaux. After the war, he found himself drawn to the Communist party, although he never adhered to their adulation of Stalin. He was in favour of decolonisation, and wrote some satirical pieces in Le Monde for those who believed that Algeria would always be French. In 1986, he was elected to the regional council of Aquitaine, as an independent associated with the Communist party.

At the time, his religious closeness to the Dominicans posed a problem. Typically, he resolved it by suggesting that God was a "left-wing intellectual".

Escarpit enjoyed life; he claimed that he had never been bored. It can certainly be said that, in all his writing and many activities, he was always intellectually honest and stimulating. He is survived by his wife and children.

Robert Escarpit, academic, writer and controversialist, born April 24 1918; died November 19 2000

fields.headline: Alf Salisbury
fields.standfirst: Lifelong communist who fought for the underdog
fields.trailText: Lifelong communist who fought for the underdog
fields.body:
In 1949, Alf Salisbury, trade unionist and communist, who has died aged 91, was famously to be found throwing himself in front of lorries trying to cross the picket of striking hotel workers at the Savoy, in the Strand, London.

In the 1980s, Alf, sometime sailor, international brigader and veteran of the 1936 battle of Cable Street, decided that the term "mongol", as applied to those with Down's syndrome, was an insult to them - and to the Mongolian people. He became one of those who campaigned against its use, including complaining to the Press Council. After victory, he was thanked personally by the Mongolian ambassador.

Alf was a doer - leafleting, lobbying MPs, picketing, marching, striking, and a shop steward in every one of his postwar workplaces. He remained involved with trades councils, and with the shopworkers' union Usdaw, until his death.

Born to Latvian Jewish immigrant parents in London's East End, Alf was one of 10 children. He left school at 14, joined the merchant marine - and the National Union of Seamen - and, in 1926, jumped ship in New York. A three-year trek across the United States, including involvement with the Wobblies, the Industrial Workers of the World, followed. Back at sea, in 1929 he got himself arrested as a spy in Guatemala and spent seven weeks in prison. Then he joined the Communist party, and, in 1936, the merchant navy blacklisted him. Involvement in the National Unemployed Workers' Movement (NUWM) followed.

In 1937, Alf joined the International Brigade in Spain, after a clandestine night-time crossing of the Pyrenees. He returned to Britain the following year, and became secretary of the Stepney NUWM. Rejected on medical grounds for wartime military service, in 1940 he married Lilly Nicklansky, and moved to Maryport, Cumbria, where he worked in a munitions factory, organised for the CP, and became a shop steward.

In postwar London, Alf was involved in East End housing campaigns, started a rent strike - and was evicted for his pains. In the ensuing decades, he worked in the textile, clothing, chemical and furniture industries, and on British Railways. He ended up with the London Co-Operative Society.

From the 1960s onwards, he was active in the London trades council movement. In 1970, he co-founded the Waltham Forest Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament. He remained involved with his union post-retirement, with London pensioners' organisations and the International Brigade Association. In the 1980s, Alf, sometime sailor, international brigader and veteran of the 1936 battle of Cable Street, decided that the term "mongol", as applied to those with Down's syndrome, was an insult to them - and to the Mongolian people. He became one of those who campaigned against its use, including complaining to the Press Council. After victory, he was thanked personally by the Mongolian ambassador. Alf was a doer - leafleting, lobbying MPs, picketing, marching, striking, and a shop steward in every one of his postwar workplaces. He left school at 14, joined the merchant marine - and the National Union of Seamen - and, in 1926, jumped ship in New York. A three-year trek across the United States, including involvement with the Wobblies, the Industrial Workers of the World, followed. fields.headline: Roger Bluett
fields.standfirst: Renowned promoter of Chinese ceramic art
fields.trailText: Renowned promoter of Chinese ceramic art
fields.body:
Roger Bluett, who has died aged 75, was a dealer who knew more about Chinese works of art, and particularly ceramics, than most specialist scholars. Indeed, his love and promotion of the subject was recognised and rewarded by the Chinese themselves.

In 1974, when he and I went on the first serious cultural trip to China organised during the cold war, we were alone among our group in being shown what, when it becomes public, will be recognised as one of the greatest archaeological revelations of our time. We promised not to reveal what we had been shown until the Chinese themselves were ready, so that, to this day, one of the most inspiring testimonials to human achievement remains known to only a handful of Chinese archaeologists.

More generally, however, much of what Bluett had learned he was quick to pass on, and the benefits of this generosity are still evident. Few men have combined, with such success, dealing and promoting knowledge. In particular, two of his enthusiasms still bear fruit.

He was the key figure behind the courses in the restoration of works of art at West Dean College, West Sussex, and was chairman of the British Antique Dealers Association courses there. Then, in 1993, he became chairman of the new Museum of East Asian Art, in Bath, which has done much to promote scholarship and appreciation of Chinese ceramics and works of art, particularly jade.

Roger and his partner Brian Morgan, who together turned the London firm of Bluett and Sons into the greatest of all dealers in Chinese art, were among the first in the market to publish scholarly catalogues; to this day, these volumes remain valuable. As a sideline, they also dealt in Islamic pottery and ancient pottery from the Middle East. It was indeed sad when, in 1988, Bluett and Morgan sold their business.

Roger also did as much as anyone to advance the interests of the British art market as a whole. For many years, he was an urbane key to the Grosvenor House art and antiques fair, equally adept at showing round the Queen Mother or Margaret Thatcher, or explaining some nicety to a novice.

Not surprisingly, he was the only dealer to have twice been president of the British Antique Dealers' Association. He was good at appealing to a wide audience and appeared with notable success on BBC programmes. He was, at once, genial and shrewd, and his enthusiasm was infectious.

Bluett was also widely cultured, having read English literature at St Edmund Hall, Oxford, after schooling at Epsom College. His wartime service with the Royal Navy was followed by a period at Sotheby's, where he learned much from AJB Kidell.

He then joined the family firm, which had been founded in 1884 by his grandfather, and took over control from Leonard Bluett and his brother. His clients included King Gustav VI Adolf of Sweden (who granted Bluett's his royal warrant and was a regular visitor), and the British, Victoria and Albert, and New York Metropolitan museums.

Bluett himself often travellled to see overseas collectors, particularly in Hong Kong and America. He was a big man, notable for his immaculate dressing and the confidence he inspired. Not surprisingly, he was responsible for building up some of the world's finest collections of Chinese art. His collectors trusted him, and many became close friends.

Bluett married twice. He is survived by his second wife Joan, and by a son and three daughters from his first marriage.

Roger Buckland Bluett, art collector and dealer, born August 7 1925; died October 25 2000

fields.headline: Bank backs Ukraine plants
fields.trailText: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development threw its weight yesterday behind a controversial project to complete two nuclear plants in Ukraine to replace Chernobyl.
fields.body:
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development threw its weight yesterday behind a controversial project to complete two nuclear plants in Ukraine to replace Chernobyl.

The London-based bank has agreed to lend £150m for work on the partially built plants at Khmelnitsky and Rivne, collectively known as K2R4, though with strict conditions.

Greenpeace said the decision ignored "serious safety concerns". But the bank insisted that K2R4 would operate to "western type safety regulations", and that the loan was tied to improving nuclear safety standards elsewhere in Ukraine.

fields.headline: Philippines president tried for corruption
fields.standfirst: Senate impeachment hearing told of mansions, mistresses and kickbacks
fields.trailText: Arguments over opulent mansions occupied by a string of mistresses, a copy of an alleged multimillion-pound kickback cheque, and a march past by tens of thousands of protesters marked yesterday's opening of the impeachment trial of President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines.
fields.body:
Arguments over opulent mansions occupied by a string of mistresses, a copy of an alleged multimillion-pound kickback cheque, and a march past by tens of thousands of protesters marked yesterday's opening of the impeachment trial of President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines.

As supporters and opponents of the beleaguered former movie star rallied outside the senate in Manila, congressmen acting as prosecutors opened their case by accusing him of running a "criminal syndicate from the highest office of the land".

With a flourish Joker Arroyo produced a copy of a cheque for 142m pesos (£2.1m) which he claimed was signed by the president, using a false name, to hide assets in secret accounts.

"Imagine the president of the Philippines maintaining a fictitious account? he said. "That is how low the president has gone in bastardising and prostituting our banking system."

He suggested that Mr Estrada had used the money to buy a million-pound mansion for Laarni Enriquez, one of his three starlet mistresses and the mother of three of his dozen children. The property includes a swimming pool with a wave machine, and a white sand beach. It also has a mini-theatre, a beauty salon and "an industrial kitchen fit for a hotel", he said.

A second sprawling palatial home, purportedly bought for another of Mr Estrada's five known mistresses, had a master bedroom the size of "the homes of 10 Philippine families", Mr Arroyo claimed.

The president's wealth is officially listed as being about £500,000.

Mr Estrada, who remained at the presidential palace yesterday, is being tried on four counts: bribery, corruption, violating the constitution and betraying the public trust. The charges allege that he received £7m in kickbacks from gambling syndicates and millions more from tobacco taxes and other sources, and that he appointed friends and relatives to high office.

In a judicial process based on the US system used against Bill Clinton, the votes of at least 15 of the 22 senators are required to secure a conviction and force him from office. The trial is expected to last until mid-January.

It is unclear whether the prosecution has enough support among the senators, who include an ex-basketball star, a retired general, a former coup leader and several former actors. One read a book for much of the opening statements while another chatted on his mobile phone.

In the two hours allotted for its opening remarks, the defence decried the prosecution's "lies and innuendo" and likened Mr Estrada to the Roman emperor Julius Caesar, who was stabbed in the senate by former supporters.

Even if the president survives the trial, his position may be made untenable by mounting popular opposition. At least 30,000 of his opponents, led by former president Corazon Aquino, the current vice-president Gloria Macapagal- Arroyo, and the Catholic archbishop of Manila, Cardinal Jamie Sin, marched around the senate building yesterday.

Ms Aquino, who became president after the 1986 "people's power" revolution which drove out the former dictator Ferdinand Marcos, urged Mr Estrada to resign immediately to spare the country a drawn-out impeachment trial.

"A president who cares about his people more than he cares about himself would not have put his nation through this agonising and potentially divisive crisis," she said.

Since the crisis erupted in October, the economy has nose-dived, the currency has lost more than 10% of its value, the stock market has plunged and foreign investment has dried up.

fields.headline: Ethan Hawke: I never wanted to be a movie star
fields.standfirst: Ethan Hawke was 18 when he won fame and plaudits with Dead Poets Society. Now 30, he's made a fortune, written two novels and married Uma Thurman. Where does he go from here?
fields.trailText: Ethan Hawke was 18 when he won fame and plaudits with Dead Poets Society. Now 30, he's made a fortune, written two novels and married Uma Thurman. Where does he go from here?
fields.body:
The last time I saw Ethan Hawke, he was pinned to the wall between Matt Dillon and Christian Slater, the poster boys of Jackie magazine's golden age. Dillon and Slater were rebels in leather, Hawke was the worthy one. The name Ethan made him sound wispy and mysterious and capable of understanding that, whilst we were committed to adolescence, there were certain childhood loyalties for which we would drop him and run.

Twelve years later he is sitting beside me in a Munich hotel room, sporting ugly black boots and a feathery beard. He isn't the luminous boy I remember from the posters: the toff in Dead Poets Society, the animal lover in White Fang, the sidekick to River Phoenix in Explorers.

In the late afternoon sun he looks quite drab, dwarfed by the suite's grand furnishings and fiddling compulsively with the boots. There's still a grunge thing going on, with his long hair and dark layers of clothing. He looks like a student who hasn't seen enough daylight. Then he gives a little Ethan smile, shrugs his Ethan shoulders and is suddenly recognisable as the orb of my 12th year.

"I sometimes think I'm so boring," he sighs winsomely. "I'll read an article about how Bob Dylan manipulated his image, put on these false personas, pretended he was like Woody Guthrie, and I think, what's the obligation in an interview to play into some mystique? But if you do, I think you end up dead." (Worthiness like this pays off: while Dillon and Slater dropped out of the race years ago, Hawke married Uma Thurman. They have a baby daughter, Maya Ray Thurman-Hawke.)

At 30, Hawke is the lead in a new film version of Hamlet. Set in modern-day Manhattan, it has Claudius as the CEO of a multinational company, the Denmark Corporation, Hamlet as a petulant young film-maker and Gertrude as a champagne-swilling lush. They inhabit the Elsinore Hotel, a Trump Tower-type complex the size of a small Scandinavian country. There is some clever visual trickery - security cameras, camcorders, televisions, to engineer the layered effect of Shakespeare's play within the play - and it's a fun adaptation.

The shock of seeing Hollywood do Hamlet was absorbed 10 years ago, when Franco Zeffirelli cast Mel Gibson as the prince in a production that gave us Glenn Close gnashing her teeth as Gertrude, and Helena Bonham Carter as a cadaverous Ophelia. This is a more modest film, featuring Kyle MacLachlan as Claudius, Sam Shepard as the ghost and Bill Murray as a mighty uncomfortable-looking Polonius, who delivers his lines with the regret of an actor who knows they won't get the laughs he's accustomed to.

Mercifully, after Kenneth Branagh's four-hour epic, the film's director, Michael Almereyda, cut the play to an hour and a half ("I don't know if this is sacrilege or whatever," offers Hawke, "but I believe that if Shakespeare were alive today, he would make some cuts"); and drew from his principal a performance that hovers between the understated and the sulky. At the time of shooting, Hawke was 27, and played the prince as a modish, MTV-educated sophisticate, loping down Fifth Avenue in a Peruvian hat and sunglasses and delivering the "to be or not to be" soliloquy in a Blockbuster video store.

"A lot of American actors when they do Shakespeare put on a phoney English accent and it drives me crazy," he says. "You're always fighting against the idea that only the British know how to do Shakespeare. One of the things I liked about this was that it was set in New York so I didn't have to pretend."

His and Almereyda's motivation for doing the play was the belief that the actors who have played Hamlet in the past have been too old. "I've always thought that he was a young man," says Hawke. "There was a great Holden Caulfield line, you know, from Catcher in the Rye, about how he saw Laurence Olivier play Hamlet and thought he was pretty good in the duelling scenes but played him more like a goddamn general and less like the sad, screwed-up kind of guy that I always thought he was.

"The common takes on Hamlet - that he's indecisive and self-involved - make more sense with a young man playing the part. I think he's really not indecisive at all. He just happens to be a very... ah... moral person who doesn't take the idea of killing somebody lightly. I think there is a much stronger case to be made that he should never have killed Claudius and it's the story of a person losing their morality and getting lost in the power his father holds over him."

Hawke spent the summer before filming attending three study sessions a week with a friend who had played the part on the stage. "First off, just to understand everything you're saying takes a couple of months. And then to try to articulate it - one of the things I've loved about Olivier is that whenever he speaks the verse, I always know what he means. He was, like, 40 years old when he played it, he had such a deep understanding of the language he could lead an audience through it. I just wanted to do it as simply as possible. Oftentimes I think that Shakespeare can be filled with lots of histrionics; Hamlet can encourage the best of actors to overact."

Wasn't that John Gielgud playing on a screen in the background of one scene? "Yeah, that's him, which is kinda neat, because he passed away the same week that the movie came out in the US."

For a while in the 1990s, Hawke looked on course for a different kind of career. His success in Peter Weir's Dead Poets Society and Ben Stiller's grunge tribute Reality Bites, in which he played opposite Winona Ryder, marked him out as a promising young thing soon to be whisked into superstardom like his childhood friend, River Phoenix. Hawke says he never wanted to be a movie star ("I never wanted to be Jimmy Stewart"), a common enough line among actors who haven't got there, but in Hawke's case authenticated by his unorthodox career moves. Twice during his 20s he took a two-year leave of absence, once to go to NYU and study English (he dropped out when a part came up), and then to write a novel. In each case he says he was testing himself to see if acting was just a phase, and in each case he returned to it with modified expectations.

"After Reality Bites came out, I had opportunities to be a different kind of actor, and rightly or wrongly" - he agonises for a moment - "I grew up in a household where there was such anger and resentment towards anyone who had any money, that I never really had any desire to make any money. And I had the idea that a real artist wouldn't have any money. That's been problematic."

Does he retain those romantic notions?

"I do." He beams. "But I fell in love with a very glamorous woman who battles them."

Hawke grew up in a single-parent family in New Jersey and at 14, after being spotted in a school production of Saint Joan, was cast alongside River Phoenix in the endearing children's film Explorers. "Acting was something that came very easily to me. It fell in my lap. But the people I admired the most were not really movie stars. I was full of Jack London and Jack Kerouac."

At 18, he came under the influence of Peter Weir and, he says, was blown away by Dead Poets Society. "The experience on that movie was, for lack of a better term, life-altering. Weir has a unique talent for making movies that are intelligent but also mainstream. I've never been terribly successful at doing that."

Hawke is relaxed about his shortcomings ("Some people may be more natural actors than I am, they can just perform and perform. And I can get kind of frazzled") and generous to his fellow actors. Of Jude Law, with whom he acted in the sci-fi movie Gattaca, he says: "I think Jude's the real thing. He is just electric, man. He is so beautiful. It's weird to be around someone that beautiful. I just couldn't believe he was straight." But there's a frown of concentration on his face when he delivers the spiel about being happy with his lot.

"Every now and then I suffer a little envy. I feel that if I had been more ambitious in a different way... But then I'm really fortunate that my interests take me in a bunch of different places and I really enjoy it. It's easy to let other people convince you that life is like a race. But there really is no finishing line. Nobody does win. With that in mind, I always feel that, if your north star is your own personal development, you can't go wrong."

This sounds like an attitude he's had to work at. "It is. It's so hard not to get sucked up into comparing yourself to other people. It's one of the hardest things in the world." Then: "I was friends with River Phoenix, you know, and I used to be painfully jealous of him. Until a friend pointed out that him doing well doesn't mean that you're doing badly. And if he does badly, it doesn't mean you're doing better. It's like that great Gore Vidal line, 'Whenever a friend of mine succeeds, a small part of me dies.' Being an adult is really challenging. When you're young, you can rely for so long on being promising, and then you have to stop being promising. You want to say, 'Hey, can't I be promising any more?' "

He has written a second novel, directed an art film called Chelsea Walls, which, he says proudly, "has no narrative", and is wise enough to pay for these luxuries by turning in the occasional regular film. In January he starts shooting on a Hollywood number with Denzel Washington - Training Day, a rookie cop drama. "Greasing the franchise," he smiles.

But his passions lie elsewhere, in the low-budget movies and the writing career that he pursues with the zeal of the autodidact. He goes on about his failure to combine the commercial with the experimental, but that's what he's done really, taking his mainstream face away from the centrefolds towards the things that inspire him. His enthusiasm is infectious.

"I've always thought that I'd love to see Quentin Tarantino do Julius Caesar. Wouldn't that be great? That would be so exciting. That would be awesome."

 Hamlet is released next Friday.
