He just happens to be a very... ah... moral person who doesn't take the idea of killing somebody lightly. I think there is a much stronger case to be made that he should never have killed Claudius and it's the story of a person losing their morality and getting lost in the power his father holds over him." Hawke spent the summer before filming attending three study sessions a week with a friend who had played the part on the stage. "First off, just to understand everything you're saying takes a couple of months. And then to try to articulate it - one of the things I've loved about Olivier is that whenever he speaks the verse, I always know what he means. He was, like, 40 years old when he played it, he had such a deep understanding of the language he could lead an audience through it. I just wanted to do it as simply as possible. Oftentimes I think that Shakespeare can be filled with lots of histrionics; Hamlet can encourage the best of actors to overact." Wasn't that John Gielgud playing on a screen in the background of one scene? "Yeah, that's him, which is kinda neat, because he passed away the same week that the movie came out in the US." For a while in the 1990s, Hawke looked on course for a different kind of career. His success in Peter Weir's Dead Poets Society and Ben Stiller's grunge tribute Reality Bites, in which he played opposite Winona Ryder, marked him out as a promising young thing soon to be whisked into superstardom like his childhood friend, River Phoenix. Hawke says he never wanted to be a movie star ("I never wanted to be Jimmy Stewart"), a common enough line among actors who haven't got there, but in Hawke's case authenticated by his unorthodox career moves. Twice during his 20s he took a two-year leave of absence, once to go to NYU and study English (he dropped out when a part came up), and then to write a novel. In each case he says he was testing himself to see if acting was just a phase, and in each case he returned to it with modified expectations. "After Reality Bites came out, I had opportunities to be a different kind of actor, and rightly or wrongly" - he agonises for a moment - "I grew up in a household where there was such anger and resentment towards anyone who had any money, that I never really had any desire to make any money. And I had the idea that a real artist wouldn't have any money. That's been problematic." Does he retain those romantic notions? "I do." He beams. "But I fell in love with a very glamorous woman who battles them." Hawke grew up in a single-parent family in New Jersey and at 14, after being spotted in a school production of Saint Joan, was cast alongside River Phoenix in the endearing children's film Explorers. "Acting was something that came very easily to me. It fell in my lap. But the people I admired the most were not really movie stars. I was full of Jack London and Jack Kerouac." At 18, he came under the influence of Peter Weir and, he says, was blown away by Dead Poets Society. "The experience on that movie was, for lack of a better term, life-altering. Weir has a unique talent for making movies that are intelligent but also mainstream. I've never been terribly successful at doing that." Hawke is relaxed about his shortcomings ("Some people may be more natural actors than I am, they can just perform and perform. And I can get kind of frazzled") and generous to his fellow actors. Of Jude Law, with whom he acted in the sci-fi movie Gattaca, he says: "I think Jude's the real thing. He is just electric, man. He is so beautiful. It's weird to be around someone that beautiful. I just couldn't believe he was straight." But there's a frown of concentration on his face when he delivers the spiel about being happy with his lot. "Every now and then I suffer a little envy. I feel that if I had been more ambitious in a different way... But then I'm really fortunate that my interests take me in a bunch of different places and I really enjoy it. It's easy to let other people convince you that life is like a race. But there really is no finishing line. Nobody does win. With that in mind, I always feel that, if your north star is your own personal development, you can't go wrong." This sounds like an attitude he's had to work at. "It is. It's so hard not to get sucked up into comparing yourself to other people. It's one of the hardest things in the world." Then: "I was friends with River Phoenix, you know, and I used to be painfully jealous of him. Until a friend pointed out that him doing well doesn't mean that you're doing badly. And if he does badly, it doesn't mean you're doing better. It's like that great Gore Vidal line, 'Whenever a friend of mine succeeds, a small part of me dies.' Being an adult is really challenging. When you're young, you can rely for so long on being promising, and then you have to stop being promising. You want to say, 'Hey, can't I be promising any more?' But his passions lie elsewhere, in the low-budget movies and the writing career that he pursues with the zeal of the autodidact. He goes on about his failure to combine the commercial with the experimental, but that's what he's done really, taking his mainstream face away from the centrefolds towards the things that inspire him. His enthusiasm is infectious. "I've always thought that I'd love to see Quentin Tarantino do Julius Caesar. Wouldn't that be great? That would be so exciting. That would be awesome."  Hamlet is released next Friday.

webTitle: A celtic village on a Spanish mountain - the set of Morality Play

fields.headline: The big picture
fields.standfirst: How could Paul McGuigan follow his brutal, critically acclaimed film, Gangster No 1? He asked a designer of the Dome's Body Zone to plan a medieval English town. Then he drafted in a group of prison inmates to build it, and dozens of fruitpickers to populate it. And then he burned it to the ground.  Peter Lennon  reports from the set of Morality Play
fields.trailText: How could Paul McGuigan follow his brutal, critically acclaimed film, Gangster No 1? He asked a designer of the Dome's Body Zone to plan a medieval English town. Then he drafted in a group of prison inmates to build it, and dozens of fruitpickers to populate it. And then he burned it to the ground. Peter Lennon reports from the set of Morality Play
fields.body:
The area around San Jose, Almeria, with its red earth and deep, wide basins scooped out of the slopes of interlacing mountain chains, has long been the choice of film-makers who could not afford the hard dollar. It is spaghetti western country, the backdrop for Once Upon a Time in the West and Sabato. Standing in the dusty winds you can almost see the tumbleweed tumble. It was these winds that etched the first wrinkles on young Clint Eastwood's blank phizog.

A few days before I arrive on the set of Paul McGuigan's new film, Morality Play, the winds once again cost a film company a few dollars more. The catering tent, complete with a spread for 200 people, rose from its moorings, drifted through the sky like a drunken magic carpet and flopped into the Mediterranean. The crew, driving up the shifty roads from San Jose, saw the whole thing.

The incident did not augur well for the stability of the mock-up medieval town that has been built of wood and polystyrene and plaster on the flank of a steep mountain. The point is reinforced when, making my way up the slithery hill-face to the castle of the Lord de Guise past peasant hovels, candle-makers' and bakers' shops and leering graven images, a piece of faux medieval England, seven by seven - presumably sent by his malevolent lordship - whacks me, unshriven, across the shoulders.

As it turns out, the set holds up well against the winds and stomping boots of cast and crew and scores of extras. Walking around it, you are constantly being tricked by the decor, even at close quarters. I am startled when a standing stone figure (actually made of polystyrene and plaster) quivers in the breeze; but when I give the "stone" wall of the graveyard a friendly punch it grazes my knuckles. The top layer of rocks is real, only the base was plywood. The tallow candles hanging in the peasants' shop are real, made in the ancient way. And, carrying realism to its extreme, the peasants' whetstone in the market place is in working order.

I do not realise it at the moment, but as I climb for sanctuary from the winds into the church - which tops the hill with the castle, overlooking the peasants below to symbolise arrogant dominance - I am looking at bits of a Welsh castle.

Alan Chester, the set construction manager, explains how this piece of foul, plague-ridden England has miraculously appeared on a Spanish mountainside. He has been involved in scenic construction since he started in the days of the Rank organisation 27 years ago. His last big job was the TV adaptation of Mervyn Peake's gothic fantasy Gormenghast.

With 19 experienced British film carpenters, painters and riggers, and another 50 Spaniards, they set up a huge workshop on the mountainside. It took them nine weeks. "The moulds came from Harlech Castle," says Chester. "We took 'squeezes' from the actual castle in Snowdonia. The castings can then be applied to the flatlage (panels of plywood or timber to which moulds are affixed). The moulds are originally taken in clay then impressions are made in fibreglass and then made in plaster. We call the men 'fibrous plasterers' because they are not just plasterers who would do a room, but people who can make cornices and work in hard plaster."

They made the casts in Shepperton studios, he says, and transported them and the screeds - guides to thickness of plaster - to Spain. They also took about 1,500 fibre sheets of various types of brickwork, each about seven feet square. "The castle is about 60 feet high. We gave them a coat of plaster to make them look more like stone and then painted over them." For the peasants' hovels below they used real logs, timber that had to be shipped from Granada.

During the time I spend on the set, they wait three days for the winds to calm before daring to shoot the climax, in which the castle itself is burned down. This involves setting off eight fire rockets while a 200 foot crane shoots the scene from on high.

Unsworth's story is set in a 14th-century English village, which lives in fear of the Church and is plagued by priests and heartless nobles. It was a time when the dark side of paganism still left its mark on everyday life. Gargoyles and leering salaciousness were in order. This is taken care of by Stephen Hicklin, a scenic sculptor who worked on The Draughtsman's Contract. Hicklin is also a fine arts portrait sculptor, but he says he is "often tempted by the broader palette of scenic sculpture". He recently sculpted a Treasure Island frieze for a casino in Las Vegas.

He is responsible for the plaster lady in a graveyard niche who is nursing Freudian snakes. She had a masculine counterpart - boasting impressive phallic equipment - until a week ago when someone on the set found it too tempting and nicked it. Hicklin also sculpted the crucifixes for the church.

"I worked in polystyrene," he says. "Speed really was the factor. We had to work at breakneck pace because it was during the petrol strike and we had to get all the stuff on the lorry and down to Spain as quickly as possible."

"The pagan figures," he says, "are based on Celtic designs, but the crucifixes are more Russian icon style. We needed a very eclectic flavour. These days what was once scenic carving is often done by computer technology. But the craft is not dead yet."

Russian iconography was a happy choice, since most of the extras are refugees from Russia and the Baltic states who are fruit picking in the area. Pale-faced, they are considered to look more English than Spanish. There is an even more unusual job assignment process: 25 of the carpenters and painters working on the set are convicts from Almeria jail. They are granted three days remission of sentence for every day they work on the set.

"You want to warm the heart of what you are doing," Andrew McAlpine, the film's production designer says, "by getting the local community involved."

McAlpine, production designer on The Beach, Clockers and The Piano, is also co-designer of the interior of the body in the Millennium Dome. He and his team delivered 167 pages of architectural drawings to create the world McGuigan needed for his medieval, plague-threatened town.

"We looked everywhere for a suitable site," McAlpine says. "We looked in Cumbria, Scotland, former Yugoslavia. We nearly settled for an old mine in Derbyshire, but thank God we didn't or we would be under water by now."

In the end they chose the San Jose setting, the site of an old open-cast gold mine; its huge rinsing basins serve as courtyards and village squares.

"With Paul our ambition was to make a big, old-fashioned film," McAlpine continues. "Something like A Man for All Seasons or The Hunchback of Notre Dame. The British have got stuck with kitchen sink drama or gangsters, which is OK. But we wanted a big film."

An unfamiliar touch is that the castle they build is permanently surrounded by scaffolding. "I showed to Paul the famous drawing of the Louvre being built with the scaffolding still on. The Morality Play story would have taken place at a point where there would have been social expansion. The custom that meant the lord's soldiers and their horses were all kept within the battlements - which must have been pretty uncomfortable - would have been changing. They would be moving out. The scaffolding that we've built is to indicate this expansion. But also it serves the idea of making a web around the castle, masking who is behind it."

These are the kind of symbols that audiences would need crib sheets from Cahiers du Cinéma to spot. But it demonstrates the degree of absorption in their craft film-makers can work themselves into.

McGuigan himself has done more than direct Gangster No 1, one of the technically slickest and most sickeningly vicious of modern gangster films. He has a background in documentary which is quite useful when realistically re-creating an ancient period. He does not scorn 30-foot crane shots and tracking on rails, but there is also a lot of hand-held camera work.

"In all the intimate scenes between the players," he says,"I went for the M*A*S*H effect - four or six people in shot with a lot of milling about."

The mysterious atmosphere infecting this fictitious world is only heightened by the fact that during the time I am there all activity shifts from day to night shooting. By day, the castle, church and peasant hovels stare dumbly in pale light from the mountainside, totally abandoned - as if the plague had really galloped through. There are onslaughts by snow machines that pour out wet shredded paper - dampened to help it fall rather than drift, but disagreeably sharp when it gets into your eyeballs and up your nostrils.

But by night the rutted roads to the set are full of shadowy figures in animal skins or svelte young women with cellphones on the go. A creature will suddenly appear from behind a caravan and materialise into the terrifying, shark-mouthed figure of Willem Dafoe (who plays Martin, leader of the players). In the courtyard, awaiting a hanging, powerful Slavonic figures waited in defensive clusters, like Native Americans surrendering to the US cavalry. Suddenly little Stuart Wells (who plays the troupe's female impersonator) will dance out and take a flashlit shot of someone.

During the early stages of the film's development, though, there was obviously a tussle between what Unsworth's book provided and what cinema needs to deliver. There was a general consensus that the book "lacked a third act". Through most of its length the book persuades the reader that it is primarily interested in the birth of modern theatre, here put to the service of a topical social problem - how justice can be achieved by the most lowly - and with an interesting emphasis on mime. But in the end all this is abruptly abandoned and the fish-bone of the book - a dressed-up detective story - is exposed. The killer is unmasked, but not yet brought to book; the King's Justice sends the players off, telling them he will deal with judicial and political matters. It is too lame an ending for the cinema.

Rewriting had been near continuous before the shoot. One major change was brought about by the personality and potential of Gangster No 1's Paul Bettany, cast as a renegade priest who joins the players. "We changed the ending because of what Paul was doing," McGuigan says. "I felt we were missing out and we needed something special."

The question is: which of the themes will survive and at the cost of what? Will it end up as an eloquent paean to human courage and compassion, a commitment to justice - or just a period detective yarn? Not even those most closely involved will know for certain where the weight will fall.

Among the strolling players is Simon McBurney, carrying his intensity like a torch. The founder of the Theatre de Complicite is also the deviser of the three plays-within-a-play in the film.

"What we think of as mime or mimicry," McBurney says, "can in real life often be amusing, but when it is examined close up through the lens of a camera it can appear theatrical. There will be some physical comedy in the film, but there was never any idea of doing a Marcel Marceau."

McGuigan tells me that to insure against "making a cheesy movie" he cast Willem Dafoe as Martin, leader of the troupe who pushes them to the crucial confrontation. "I wanted someone who would bring something edgy to the part," he says.

Dafoe, a useful talent to have around, sits in his caravan. Draped in a great, trailing, bug-bitten bear's skin, his great shark grimace can be intimidating, but everyone has assured me he is a nice guy; and nowhere during the encounter did he display any of a Hollywood star's airs - either arrogance or false humility. Indeed the man who illuminated so many powerful films - Born on the 4th of July, Platoon, Wild at Heart - gives the impression of not really believing he is a star. He seems quite chuffed when, my brain seared by the sirocco winds of Almeria, I completely forget his previous involvements with European directors Wim Wenders (Faraway So Close) and Anthony Minghella (The English Patient).

I ask him what he sees in Martin's character. He is cagey in his reply. "I am not good at talking about how a character is. It's not superstition, it's not so much about process. I often don't have an inkling when I am approaching, inhabiting a character. I am just trying to help Paul to tell a story. Some people are good at that, I am not."

Had he seen his director's previous film, the undeniably vicious Gangster No 1? "I happened to be in Europe at the time," he says, "and I saw Gangster in conjunction with the acting offer - it was a kind of calling card. The thing that impressed me was that it had a lot of style and it was a world realised very deeply. I knew he would be very good with creating a world. When I heard Paul came from documentary that interested me. It was a hedge against this being a costume drama. It is interesting if you apply that kind of sensibility to a fiction movie".

Is there any possibility he might also be contributing something to the direction here?

He assures me he has never had an ambition to direct. "But as I am getting older," he says, "I start working with directors who are younger and inexperienced and sometimes - I am not talking about Paul - sometimes you have to roll up your sleeves and get involved, which makes you feel you are directing."

"I don't think it is in my personality to direct," he says. "There is a pleasure in being an agent of someone else's desires. It allows you to be more creative and pretend with a wider range of impulse".

When we leave the caravan for the dark of the trailer park a great coltish figure in rags flung himself at Dafoe and gives him a strangling embrace. "Willem! Willem!" he cries. "You must autograph the script for this nice extra who wants to collect the autographs of the whole cast. You know the nice, dark one?"

"There are a lot of nice ones," Dafoe says.

The colt hopping about on stork legs is Paul Bettany. Red-nosed and sniffly, he has nothing of the terrifying psychopath he played in Gangster No 1. This was more the blond, public schoolboy Steerforth, the cad he played so well in the American TV adaptation of David Copperfield. But Bettany has a terrible cold and when obliged to lie beside an open grave for repeated takes will every now and then lift his boots knee-high in thumping jumps to restore circulation.

Rewriting Bettany's role gives the film a very different ending to the book; the focus moves from Dafoe's troupe leader Martin to Bettany's renegade priest. In the novel, Nicholas is the most despised of the players, acting as the narrator. He is more a timorous witness of bold defiance than powerful participant.

Not wishing to spoil the story, we will just say that the plot needed an articulate hero who nobly takes on the vicious Lord de Guise in a verbal duel. Paul Bettany sees this role as that of "the man in Tiananmen Square who stood in front of the tank."

The end of this magnificent set comes after three nights waiting, cowering in creaking tents, before dangerous gales. The 200-foot camera cranes swing into action; the hand-held cameras go in - " Go, Go, Go! " - and the medieval town they spent so long building goes up in flames.

 Morality Play is due to be released next year.

Draped in a great, trailing, bug-bitten bear's skin, his great shark grimace can be intimidating, but everyone has assured me he is a nice guy; and nowhere during the encounter did he display any of a Hollywood star's airs - either arrogance or false humility. Indeed the man who illuminated so many powerful films - Born on the 4th of July, Platoon, Wild at Heart - gives the impression of not really believing he is a star. He seems quite chuffed when, my brain seared by the sirocco winds of Almeria, I completely forget his previous involvements with European directors Wim Wenders (Faraway So Close) and Anthony Minghella (The English Patient). I ask him what he sees in Martin's character. He is cagey in his reply. "I am not good at talking about how a character is. It's not superstition, it's not so much about process. I often don't have an inkling when I am approaching, inhabiting a character. I am just trying to help Paul to tell a story. Some people are good at that, I am not." Had he seen his director's previous film, the undeniably vicious Gangster No 1? "I happened to be in Europe at the time," he says, "and I saw Gangster in conjunction with the acting offer - it was a kind of calling card. The thing that impressed me was that it had a lot of style and it was a world realised very deeply. I knew he would be very good with creating a world. When I heard Paul came from documentary that interested me. It was a hedge against this being a costume drama. It is interesting if you apply that kind of sensibility to a fiction movie". Is there any possibility he might also be contributing something to the direction here? He assures me he has never had an ambition to direct. "But as I am getting older," he says, "I start working with directors who are younger and inexperienced and sometimes - I am not talking about Paul - sometimes you have to roll up your sleeves and get involved, which makes you feel you are directing." "I don't think it is in my personality to direct," he says. "There is a pleasure in being an agent of someone else's desires. It allows you to be more creative and pretend with a wider range of impulse". When we leave the caravan for the dark of the trailer park a great coltish figure in rags flung himself at Dafoe and gives him a strangling embrace. "Willem! Willem!" he cries. "You must autograph the script for this nice extra who wants to collect the autographs of the whole cast. You know the nice, dark one?" "There are a lot of nice ones," Dafoe says. The colt hopping about on stork legs is Paul Bettany. Red-nosed and sniffly, he has nothing of the terrifying psychopath he played in Gangster No 1. This was more the blond, public schoolboy Steerforth, the cad he played so well in the American TV adaptation of David Copperfield. But Bettany has a terrible cold and when obliged to lie beside an open grave for repeated takes will every now and then lift his boots knee-high in thumping jumps to restore circulation. Rewriting Bettany's role gives the film a very different ending to the book; the focus moves from Dafoe's troupe leader Martin to Bettany's renegade priest. In the novel, Nicholas is the most despised of the players, acting as the narrator. He is more a timorous witness of bold defiance than powerful participant. Not wishing to spoil the story, we will just say that the plot needed an articulate hero who nobly takes on the vicious Lord de Guise in a verbal duel. Paul Bettany sees this role as that of "the man in Tiananmen Square who stood in front of the tank." The end of this magnificent set comes after three nights waiting, cowering in creaking tents, before dangerous gales. The 200-foot camera cranes swing into action; the hand-held cameras go in - " Go, Go, Go! " - and the medieval town they spent so long building goes up in flames.  Morality Play is due to be released next year.

fields.headline: The hole in Europe's cheese?
fields.standfirst: As EU leaders meet in Nice, Peter Capella reports from Geneva on changing Swiss attitudes towards the rest of the continent
fields.trailText: As EU leaders meet in Nice, Peter Capella reports from Geneva on changing Swiss attitudes towards the rest of the continent.
fields.body:
It is a sign of change that isolationist Switzerland, which is not a member or an immediate candidate, was invited to join the European Union's enlargement chat at the Nice summit yesterday.

Then again, it is the EU's second largest trading partner.

While the president, Adolf Ogi, a skiing fanatic, lobbied his EU counterparts, thousands of Genevans were preparing to start the winter sports season in the French Alps instead of a tidy Swiss resort.

Many more will hop into France this weekend on a shopping trip, a common practice in border regions throughout western Europe.

Yet, even the most pro-European Swiss are willing to pay a price to enjoy their neighbour's virtues without the strings.

Border posts collect duties from those returning with too much shopping. The Swiss juggle with cheese, meat and wine quotas with the same aplomb as cross-Channel shoppers used to play with duty free allowances.

Switzerland is likely to remain the hole in the middle of the European map, well after countries like Poland or Hungary have joined.

In Nice, Mr Ogi asked for time, even though his government, a four-party coalition that spans the political spectrum, hopes to start negotiations with Brussels between 2004 and 2007.

Previous attempts ground to a halt eight years ago when Swiss voters narrowly rejected closer trade ties with the EU in a referendum.

Last May, 67% approved a series of bilateral deals that help business with the EU, including the free movement of labour.

But it was largely due to government assurances that they were not a stepping stone for the political trappings of integration.

The biggest obstacles are Mr Ogi's own Swiss-German community - two-thirds of the population - and his party, the Swiss People's Party, which is now dominated by isolationist right-wingers, and is the largest in parliament with 23% of seats.

Progress is stifled by a complicated political system that ensures that voters can have a say at every stage of the process through referenda, even if parliament has approved it.

Support is propped up by the overwhelmingly pro-European French-speaking community in western Switzerland - one-fifth of the population - and a few major cities.

Public opinion is now split in half, and wavers with crises in Brussels and demands that the Swiss scrap banking secrecy.

Swiss-German Eurosceptics bear an uncanny resemblance to their British counterparts: they fear meddling by Brussels, the loss of national identity, and they have a latent, historic loathing of Germany.

Forty years ago, Switzerland set up the European Free Trade Association with Britain and a few Nordic countries to counter the EEC's growing power.

Some of the controversial issues, such as allowing heavier EU trucks onto Swiss roads, resemble those that delayed Britain's entry into the EEC.

And forget about strengthening the Euro with the Swiss Franc.

It is deep-rooted reluctance. Apart from the Vatican, Switzerland is the only country in the world not to have joined the United Nations, although that might change soon.

The same spirit applies within the country. One hundred and fifty years ago, the Swiss ensured that power was devolved as much as possible.

Direct democracy cannot work if the Swiss are obliged to accept legislation decided by majority voting in Brussels.

Yesterday, the president of Europe's wealthiest nation lectured his 22 European counterparts about the "Swiss model".

Modern Switzerland is a miniature EU, formed by 26 states. Each canton has its own cabinet and parliament, as well as a judiciary, a police force, health and education system, and raises most taxes.

The four linguistic communities are guaranteed a say at national level.

José Bessard, of the Swiss government's integration office, thinks the EU should adopt referenda. "Why couldn't Europe examine the possibility of a European initiative where a certain number of citizens from one or two or more countries can demand something from the EU?

"That would be a bottom up approach and not only something from the top".

It may be the price to pay for an estimated £1.6bn in Swiss taxpayer's contributions, but later in the century.

fields.headline: The Art of War
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is understatement to say that this ugly, strident, boring film leaves a nasty taste in the mouth.
fields.body:
It is understatement to say that this ugly, strident, boring film leaves a nasty taste in the mouth. Frankly, you could eat a pound and a half of condemned veal and have a better taste in your mouth.

Wesley Snipes is the star and executive producer of this dire action picture, as Neil Shaw, black ops agent for the United Nations (for heaven's sake) working undercover to undermine and subvert the bad guys before they undermine and subvert world peace. Hence the reference to Sun Tzu's Art of War: to achieve the strategic advantages of war without needing to wage war.

The bad guys are, to a man, slant-eyed chinks. This is the new Hollywood form of yellow-peril racism; having a lot of Chinese villains for way-cool martial arts stuff is a kind of fashion accessory. Donald Sutherland has a small part as the UN Secretary-General. Why? Well, casting the distinguished Canadian actor Sutherland is a sure-fire way of getting Canadian money for a movie, and this appears to have been the case with this Canadian-American co-production, in which the script briefly, but pointedly refers to him as a Canadian Secretary-General. But of course it's Uncle Sam who saves the day - after a lot of deafening gunfire and people getting thrown through plate-glass every five minutes. One to avoid.

fields.headline: Les Destinées Sentimentales
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An elegant, spacious drama, with some beautiful performances from Berling, Béart and Huppert.
fields.body:
This handsome and pleasing rendering of Jacques Chardonne's big novel of love is an intelligent excursion into period drama, bringing director Olivier Assayas away from his conventional contemporary setting and into a France emerging traumatised into the 20th century.

Jean (Charles Berling) is a Protestant minister unhappily married to Nathalie (Isabelle Huppert) and falls in love with Pauline (Emmanuelle Béart) - thus setting in train a saga played out over 30 years against a great geopolitical backdrop and the fortunes of commerce and the first world war.

The action centres on a family firm producing fine porcelain, and the fastidious connoisseurship associated with this sets a rather cold tone for the film. Moreover, it is not clear if there is quite enough energy and life on the screen to support a film of some three hours.

But it is nevertheless an elegant, spacious drama, with some beautiful performances from Berling, Béart and Huppert - the A-list of French screen acting - and an intriguing imaginative voyage into the industrious Protestant community of France.

fields.headline: Cecil B Demented
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A one-joke film in which the joke is... well, not a joke in any recognisable sense.
fields.body:
John Waters, once an underground film-maker, has long since joined the mainstream, and has now made a film about an underground film-maker. It's not so much an idea for a film as some kind of nitrogen-bubble in the blood supply to Mr Waters's brain.

Nothing in this film comes close to the putative edge and excitement of real underground movie-making, and, bafflingly, nothing in it convincingly evokes any serious reverence for underground movie-making. It is a one-joke film in which the joke is... well, not a joke in any recognisable sense.

Anyway, the eponymous Cecil B Demented (Stephen Dorff), posing as a humble cinema manager, kidnaps a big movie star, Honey Whitlock (Melanie Griffith) in Waters's beloved Baltimore, home of Edgar Allan Poe and Dr Hannibal Lecter. Then he forces her at gunpoint to appear in the underground movie he is making with a Warholian Rocky Horror crew.

Using guerrilla tactics they will storm the palaces and sancta of corporate Hollywood movie-making. Naturally, Honey comes to love and admire her captors - an hommage, I guess, to Patricia Hearst, who has joined Waters's regulars and appears here as the concerned mother of one of Cecil's technicians.

There are a few good gags here about Hollywood atrocities such as Forrest Gump and Patch Adams, and sharp digs at rent-a-rave critics whose only concern is to get on the poster. The mainstream Hollywood system produces rubbish - yes, and so what? A strange air of pointlessness pervades this film, mostly aiming pseudo-satire at non-targets.

fields.headline: 102 Dalmatians
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Gérard Depardieu's gurning turn as an evil helpmeet will require every cinema owner to hire a priest to stand in the foyer and say a requiem mass for his career.
fields.body:
This coy piece of family entertainment from Walt Disney - second helpings of the 1996 spotted-dog treat - stars Alice Evans as a young woman whose Dalmatian puppies are dognapped by the evil Cruella De Vil. (Evans has a rather steamier role in The Escort, incidentally.) She and her co-star Ioan Gruffudd are strong actors who deserve much better than this strangely tiring film, directed like a pantomime by Kevin Lima (who directed the recent Tarzan cartoon).

Like the first live-action effort, this is quite without the charm and buoyancy of the 1961 cartoon, or indeed the 1955 Disney animation The Lady and the Tramp, to whose romantic-spaghetti-dinner scene this film alludes in a smug bit of corporate in-house product-placement.

Unlike cartoons, realist live-action drama precludes cutely anthropomorphising the dogs by giving them the power of speech. But the idea of entirely non-talking Disney animals is of course unthinkable. So this film compromises by producing an adorable talking macaw, which has quasi-Babe-like powers of communication.

Like everything else, it is appallingly irritating. Glenn Close is ionospherically over the top, grimacing and leering in a world of her own. Gérard Depardieu's gurning turn as her evil helpmeet will require every cinema owner to hire a priest to stand in the foyer and say a requiem mass for his career. Anthony Powell's exuberant designs deserve praise. But, basically, this is a Christmas film that you put in your car, drive to a layby and put outside, before driving away very quickly indeed.

fields.headline: The Man Who Cried
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An engaging drama - improbable sometimes, yes, and occasionally absurd. But it has stylish and elegant performances from Cate Blanchett and John Turturro.
fields.body:
The idea of a film by Sally Potter is sometimes enough to make the heart sink: like a form of macrobiotic diet or all-over-body seaweed wrap, undertaken in the gloomy expectation of it being somehow good for you. But actually this movie is an engaging drama - improbable sometimes, yes, and occasionally absurd. But it has stylish and elegant performances from Cate Blanchett and John Turturro and is handsomely photographed by Sacha Vierney in colour tones at once rich and sepia-like.

Christina Ricci plays a young Jewish girl in late 1920s Russia who is separated from her beloved father after being burned out of their village. She ends up in Paris as a dancer with a new Anglicised name, "Suzie", just in time for the Nazi occupation.

There she meets Lola (Cate Blanchett) an angular, statuesque Russian, who becomes Suzie's pouting, giggling confidante. Blanchett suggests a Sally Bowles-like figure who yearns for a rich man - and finds one in the form of John Turturro's Dante, a petulant Italian opera singer who collaborates enthusiastically with the Nazis.

Both Blanchett and Turturro carry off the roles with entertaining brio - and Blanchett especially has a gloriously expressive face on camera. But we are clearly given to understand that their campy bohemian loquaciousness is a sign of being lesser moral entities than Ricci, with her wise and moon-faced silences.

Which brings us to the man she is in love with: Johnny Depp as Cesar, the smoulderingly dishy Gypsy musician with some sexy but carefully placed scars, who conducts her to his Gypsy encampment for the mandatory scene in which his family welcome her instinctively for a sing-song. Depp looks silly and self-conscious and just doesn't cut the mustard in any way, and this is a shame. I would like to have seen him play the opera singer, and Turturro the phlegmatic Gypsy outsider.

But like Suzie's father, Cesar can show his feelings: hence that slightly curious title, which may, I fear, put a bit of a downer on the box-office. (It's actually more about the vivid emotions of women.) But this film shows that Sally Potter has a rough-and-ready talent for storytelling, which you wouldn't quite guess from The Tango Lesson or Orlando. And it has felicitous touches: such as Alan David's lovely cameo performance as the Welsh schoolmaster who tries to teach the young Suzie to sing All Things Bright and Beautiful.

fields.headline: 'Ah eurm ern OAR!'
fields.standfirst: In his native language, Daniel Auteuil has a quicksilver eloquence. In English, he is a seal out of water, writes  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Auteuil's undoubted charisma carries it off. But, in the end, The Escort feels like a swanky artistic fantasy of what is actually involved in prostitution
fields.body:
After the calamity that was Chris Menges's The Lost Son, Daniel Auteuil has returned to Swinging London to make another film in English. He is Pierre, a slightly wizened fortysomething French intellectual who has succumbed to the male equivalent of a menopausal hot flash. In a Reggie Perrin-like revelatory moment, Pierre has seen the rat-race rut he is in, so he chucks in his job in France lecturing in literature, bids au revoir to his wife and son and gets on the first plane to London, where he is kipping down in a horrific Bayswater hotel, hoping to write a novel.

He is in a terrible state or, as the French say, a mauvaise passe - the film's original title. But director Michel Blanc and his collaborator Hanif Kureishi devise for him an unlikely salvation: beaten up by a Soho clip-joint bouncer one night, Pierre is patched up by Tom (Stuart Townsend), an unfeasibly handsome and kindly coffee bar manager, who introduces Pierre to his own lucrative sideline - being a male escort. Pierre is an instant success in this dubious trade; he sees in it heaven-sent material for his novel, and in this metropolitan excitement he sees a thrilling access to the reality denied him as a bourgeois husband and father. But his writing falters and Pierre wonders if his vocation is not the novel but simply high-class prostitution.

It sounds like the material for comedy, and sometimes that is precisely what it is, intentionally or otherwise. But with Kureishi supplying the inspiration for the daring-yet-bohemian swinging sex scenes and Daniel Auteuil in the leading role, a very cool, dangerous urban movie is clearly what it is supposed to be. The craggily charismatic Franglais gigolo or beau de jour is turning the tables on gender expectations of what prostitution is.

The problem is that, in English, Auteuil is a seal out of water. In French, he has a quicksilver eloquence when this is called upon; and when it is not, his silences are haughty, elegant, patrician. But forced into English, he barks his shins on our Anglo-Saxon syllables, and sounds absurd. Many a time he shouts his defiance or passion in English and it sounds something like: "Ah doo nuert cay-arrr weurt yoo seenk eurve me, bee-coze ah eurm ern OAR!"

This is a shame, because otherwise Daniel Auteuil is almost Bogart-like in his fierce air of seclusion, his grizzled manner of having seen the world, combined with an openness to romantic persuasion.

What is interesting about Michel Blanc's movie is that much of it works perfectly well. There is something dashing and fast in his swift cutting between scenes, from encounter to encounter, and sometimes from city to city. The resulting affectless impression of speed and detachment nicely complements the tone of irony in this urban tale, and the comic nightmare of Auteuil's character having to show his penis in advance to various clients. And the British cast Blanc assembles is really quite striking in its classy range of big and biggish names from TV and movies: Amanda Ryan, Frances Barber, Keith Allen, Barbara Flynn, Anastasia Hille. Noah Taylor has about one line as an obnoxious rich drunk at a party at which Pierre is "working": was his contribution supposed to be that subliminal? Or was most of his stuff cut?

Anyway, this cameo-pageant is crowned by the furious Peter Mullan, who plays the husband of Claire Skinner, whom Pierre cynically tells he loves to secure her long-term custom as a "regular". Mullan growls something about how Pierre's fee is equivalent to a month of his wages and lays him out with a sucker punch. It is a nice performance from Skinner, though she is a little too county-set for the pairing to be anything other than implausible. It is unfortunate that Liza Walker's role, as the tart-with-a-heart who falls for Pierre, is the most slackly and unconvincingly written.

Ultimately, the film describes what is a kind of would-be 21st-century Hogarthian progress as Pierre becomes more and more reliant on the white powder that he had been warned by the wise and almost fatherly Tom never to use except to loosen up a client. He is heading for another mauvaise passe and the movie appears to conclude by suggesting that once you're on the game, there's no way out. At least we are spared any student-ish cant about us all being prostitutes.

Auteuil's undoubted charisma carries it off - just about. But, in the end, The Escort feels like a swanky artistic fantasy of what is actually involved in prostitution; the movie strains for the secret banal horror of the hotel-room transaction, and for an ironic and sophisticated take on the "scene" surrounding it, yet opts for a moralistic assumption of a bad end for Pierre if he remains on the game - while moreover remaining unaware of what the real effects are of a long-term career in "escort" work. Is it different for boys? Or not? Nothing in the script, or Auteuil's perky, craggy face can really tell us.

In a Reggie Perrin-like revelatory moment, Pierre has seen the rat-race rut he is in, so he chucks in his job in France lecturing in literature, bids au revoir to his wife and son and gets on the first plane to London, where he is kipping down in a horrific Bayswater hotel, hoping to write a novel. fields.trailText: The doctor, the vicar, the smuggler and the aborigine venture into Tasmania's Heart of Darkness
fields.body:
"That bleb Quayle," muttered Captain Kewley of the Sincerity to his Manx crew. "If he hadn't have kept the cheese we'd have fooled that sleetch Clarke. Now, we've got to pay a £200 fine. Where will we get the jink?"

"I can prove the atheisms of geology," exclaimed the Rev Geoffrey Wilson. "Having studied the bible, I am certain the garden of Eden is to be found in Van Diemen's Land."

"I am bound there myself," replied Dr Thomas Potter, who was engaged on a biological study of the races. "From a study of specimens I believe that the Celts = Untrustworthy and Blacks = Savages . Ergo Both Destined to Die in great Conflagration. We should mount a joint expedition. I have heard there is a boat for charter."

"Cape Town is a lousy place," snurled Kewley. "What use is a free port to a smuggler? We'll be better off in Hobart."

"Look at those scuttering white pissers," thought Peevay, the half-caste Aborigine. "I should have speared them like Mother said."

"Will you be our guide?" asked Rev Wilson.

"No, I won't do that."

"I hear he's changed his mind," said Dr Potter, several days later.

"It was that red-beard shitter Potter that made off with Mother's body," Peevay said to himself, "and none of the other nums would lift a finger to help a black fellow. I will kill them."

"So near, yet so far to Eden," Rev Wilson repeated deliriously.

Wilson = quite deranged " wrote Potter in his diary. "No food left = big problem . We have lost Ben Fiddler. Hooper suggesting could = work of half caste ."

"Scuttering shitters," said Peevay, "I'd have had the nums if the ship hadn't come."

"You go somewhere remote to do a bit of running business and you bump into these fritlags again," mused Captain Kewley, as Wilson and Potter came aboard.

"The Lord has saved us," intoned Wilson.

"It looks as if we got away with it," said Kewley on his return to London, as he spotted a skeleton labelled Aboriginal at an exhibition that showed every sign of having had a red beard.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: The doctor, the vicar, the smuggler and the aborigine venture into Tasmania's Heart of Darkness

webTitle: Editor attacks 'inhuman' sackings by new owner

fields.headline: Editor attacks 'inhuman' sackings by new owner
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Daily Express editor, Rosie Boycott, laid down a thinly veiled challenge to the paper's new proprietor yesterday in an excoriating attack on his "heavy-handed" treatment of staff.
fields.body:
The Daily Express editor, Rosie Boycott, laid down a thinly veiled challenge to the paper's new proprietor yesterday in an excoriating attack on his "heavy-handed" treatment of staff.

In a memo to Richard Desmond which was copied to staff, she expressed outrage that managers had sacked a pregnant woman as well as a disabled man who had been promised a job for life. By circulating her letter, Ms Boycott appeared to be willing Mr Desmond to get rid of her.

Her strongly-worded attack came on the same day that two more senior editorial staff left the troubled paper.

The veteran columnist Peter Hitchens and award-winning home affairs editor David Taylor handed in their notice. Both are understood to be unhappy at the new proprietor, who owns a string of soft porn titles and OK! magazine. Mr Hitchens said he was leaving "for obvious reasons". He told the Guardian's media website: "I'm not happy with the new ownership."

In her memo, a copy of which has been seen by the Guardian, Ms Boycott expressed her dismay at the way that 60 staff in support departments had been made redundant.

"I understand that Sharon Harte, seven months' pregnant, was asked to distribute 'in' and 'out' letters round the floor," she said. "She took the two bundles and then discovered that her name was on the list to go."

Ms Boycott also complained about the treatment of a researcher, Simon White. "Fourteen years ago, Simon was hit by a car and was left with a speech impediment, a limp and a disabled arm.

"He is a strategic researcher in business development and, according to all his colleagues, 'excellent at his job'.

"But the real point is that following his accident, Simon was guaranteed a job for life with Express Newspapers as his disabilities mean it is virtually impossible for him to find other employment. Now he is in danger of being unemployed and faces never working again."

Ms Boycott expresses concerns that employees' contracts are not being honoured, and says she fears more walkouts.

"There are human and inhuman ways of dealing with people whose services are no longer required," she writes. "The journalists on the Express are - to a man and woman - good and honourable people, who will not stand easily by and watch colleagues' lives being trashed by heavy-handed management techniques."

Mr Hitchens, who has spent 24 years on the Express, is to join the Mail on Sunday. Mr Taylor joins the Evening Standard in London.

The letter underlines the bitterness of relations between Ms Boycott and Mr Desmond, who bought the Express titles two weeks ago as part of a £125m deal with United News & Media.

She has already been forced to write to staff about £40,000 bonuses that United's Lord Hollick sent to 25 staff, who appeared to have been selected arbitrarily. Ms Boycott and Mr Hitchens were among the 25 who benefited, but Mr Taylor and hundreds of others were not.

In an email to the paper's heads of department, she branded the payments "horribly divisive".

webTitle: The Wembley fiasco: 10 questions that should be answered today

fields.headline: The Wembley fiasco: 10 questions that should be answered today
fields.trailText: Once again, the future of Wembley stadium hangs in the balance. Almost exactly a year after the Football Association unveiled its plans for the rebuilding of Wembley, the 12 members of its management board will attend an emergency meeting this afternoon at its new Soho headquarters, charged with rescuing the project from the threat of disaster. These are some of the questions they must address as they face their last chance to get it right.
fields.body:
Once again, the future of Wembley stadium hangs in the balance. Almost exactly a year after the Football Association unveiled its plans for the rebuilding of Wembley, the 12 members of its management board will attend an emergency meeting this afternoon at its new Soho headquarters, charged with rescuing the project from the threat of disaster. These are some of the questions they must address as they face their last chance to get it right.

Why is the rebuilding going to cost so much?

The original cost of rebuilding Wembley was said to be £240m. Earlier this year the figure had soared to £660m, or more than twice that of comparable projects in Cardiff (£180m for the Millennium stadium), Paris (£260m for the Stade de France) and Sydney (£300m for Stadium Australia). No satisfactory explanation has been provided for the extra funding. What, precisely, is it for?

Why will no one explain what is going on?

The stadium is shrouded in the sort of secrecy that breeds distrust. None of the representatives of the bodies associated with the project, notably the relevant members of the government and the FA, will go on the record with a frank assessment of its current standing. Instead the debate is being conducted by means of leaks and innuendos. If this is to be a "national stadium", as its title proclaims, the nation should be entitled to a degree of honesty and transparency in its efforts to understand what is being done in its name.

Who decided that the stadium would be incomplete without a new luxury hotel?

When Wembley National Stadium Ltd came to the decision to build a hotel within the new structure, the board must have known that the Hilton hotel group already owned the sole rights to operate such a facility within the stadium precincts and that it had shown no desire to abandon the high-rise building in which it has operated the Wembley Hilton for more than 20 years.

Why should a sports stadium double as an office block?

The chairman of WNSL should reveal the evidence that persuaded him, when the basic components of the new design were being assembled, of the existence of willing takers for 100,000 square feet of office space (enough for 1,000 workers) in a part of north-west London hardly noted for top-end commercial activity.

Why will one seat in six cost £2,000 a year?

About 14,000 of the stadium's projected 90,000 seats will be given to corporate guests and fans prepared to pay £2,000 a season. While it could be argued that this proportion might be acceptable for a Premier League club, which has to make a profit in order to pay the constantly rising wages of its playing staff, it is surely excessive in the case of a stadium dedicated to the game's national showpieces.

Who sent out 2,000 invitations to cocktails?

The specification of the new stadium refers to "lavish" banqueting and conference facilities, including a restaurant seating 2,000 people - one of nine restaurants on the premises. Yet this will be adjacent to the existing Wembley Conference Centre, still operated by the stadium's previous owners. It seems unlikely that the market will suddenly expand to a degree that would provide enough clients to make both enterprises profitable.

What would happen if the hotel, the office space, and the banqueting and conference facilities were taken out of the plans, in conjunction with a reduction in the seats allocated to corporate hospitality?

The Wembley board should explain whether these facilities were incorporated in the specification in order to help pay for the cost and upkeep of the stadium, or whether their inclusion determined the cost. They should look again at the cost of running the stadium without them.

Since the FA is using the phrase "national stadium", isn't that what it should be?

The FA should re-evaluate the idea of creating a proper multisports facility by including a running track, which would enable the sta dium to form the centrepiece of a future bid for the Olympic Games. Modern techniques of design and construction could then be employed to ensure that for football matches there would be seating close to the pitch. The 1948 Olympics formed an important part of the old stadium's heritage, and if track-and-field facilities are not incorporated in the new one it seems unlikely that London will ever again be in a position to host the games, or anything like them.

Why should a single sport own the national stadium?

At the moment, the FA is the sole owner and operator of Wembley. But the current descent towards a potential debacle suggests that the public interest might be better served by some form of private-public partnership. The government, having failed to turn the Millennium Dome into a permanent monument to truth, beauty and the spirit of contemporary Britain, ought to recognise a chance to make amends by saving the football authorities from the consequences of their own hubris.

Speaking of hubris, should Ken Bates be told to step down? In its present incarnation the Wembley scheme will always look uncomfortably like Chelsea Village Mk2. Bates, after all, chairs both companies, and is seldom reluctant to impose his vision on projects with which he is associated. In recent days his contribution has been the subject of criticism both from within the FA and from merchant banks approached for funding, while architects and construction companies have also expressed reservations about the general conduct of the project. His departure might be a prerequisite to the sort of debate Wembley needs - one that would go right back to first principles and start by re-examining the definition of a national stadium.

fields.headline: Chelsea doubts over Gronkjaer transfer
fields.trailText: Chelsea may cancel their £7.8m deal to buy Jesper Gronkjaer from Ajax if the Denmark winger fails to prove his fitness by January 1.
fields.body:
Chelsea may cancel their £7.8m deal to buy Jesper Gronkjaer from Ajax if the Denmark winger fails to prove his fitness by January 1.

Gronkjaer is struggling with hip and groin injuries, as well as a shoulder problem, and Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson said: "It is correct that there is a clause in the contract which protects us in case anything goes wrong.

"Jesper visited us on Monday and we were satisfied. He is making progress. We do not believe that there is any risk the deal could be called off."

However reports from Denmark suggest the player's injuries are more serious than Chelsea thought when the deal was struck and the 23-year-old, who suffered a broken bone in his foot last season, has a reputation for being injury prone.

Shortly after agreeing the sale, the Ajax coach Co Adriaanse said: "Maybe Gronkjaer is fit enough to lift a glass of milk but not to play top-level football. He has never stayed fit during my time with the club."

The Northern Ireland international Neil Lennon is set to join Celtic by the weekend, provided he passes a medical. The Leicester midfielder, who will take a pay cut to move north, is set to complete a deal thought to be worth £5.7m. He said: "I'm here to do the medical first and if all that goes through I will start training."

The Leicester boss Peter Taylor will use the money from the transfer to strengthen his midfield and has been linked with moves for Derby's Seth Johnson and Chelsea's Jody Morris.

Manchester City have given the defender Richard Jobson a free transfer. Jobson has struggled to get into the first team this season. The City manager Joe Royle has also confirmed his interest in Bordeaux's 29-year-old French international forward Lilian Laslandes.

Arsenal have stepped up their interest for the striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic despite warnings from his club Malmo that he is not for sale. The Malmo director of football Hasse Borg said: "Arsenal invited Zlatan to train with them, but we turned them down. We have told Arsenal that Zlatan is not for sale."

One person who is joining the north London club is the former Chelsea goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwiecki, who will be their reserve-team manager for the rest of the season.

webTitle: What kind of ethical fund should you choose?

fields.headline: What kind of ethical fund should you choose?
fields.trailText: It depends on which approach you prefer and what your personal principles are.
fields.body:
It depends on which approach you prefer and what your personal principles are.

In practice, most ethical funds employ two or more of the techniques previously outlined to decide on potential investments. And there are significant crossovers between them: for example, engaging with the management board might lead to changes in corporate policy which, in turn, could make that company a "best of sector" and a candidate for investment. Which approach is more ethical and/or more effective is open to debate, so it's important to decide which approach most suits your beliefs before you invest.

Generally speaking, the dark and light green funds will be cheaper than the others. They get their information from Eiris, which means the fund managers have less to do. Funds with in-house research teams will be more expensive, but they may also be more effective and dynamic. These funds are seizing ethical investment by both hands, deciding what is or what is not ethical and rigorously selecting companies on these grounds. They will also be able to explain exactly why they have a specific company in their portfolio. So don't rule them out. In fact, there is evidence to suggest that these actively managed funds are more popular, with the engagement approach proving particularly popular with ethical investment newcomers.

At the very least, stay away from funds which claim to used best of sector and engagement approaches but which don't have their own in-house research teams. They will almost certainly be among those newcomers who are jumping on the ethical investment bandwagon without properly understanding the issues at stake. You may just be buying an expensive screened fund rather than an actively managed one, which is more worthy of the money

Ethical funds typically hold a higher percentage of shares in small to medium-sized companies and a smaller percentage in large companies than their non-ethical equivalents. Shares in small companies can often be more volatile than shares in big business, which is one of the reasons ethical funds are often seen as more risky. In the short term, this could be problematic. But this is par for the course when investing in equities - ethical or otherwise - and you should always keep your mind on the medium term, that is five years or more, to see significant returns.

But remember, virtually all ethical funds are available with an ISA wrapper. If you don't already have an ISA, they are worth considering because the profits will be tax free.

fields.headline: Credit cards
fields.trailText: Credit cards are a form of loan and provide one of the easiest ways of borrowing over a short period. You can use them in the UK or overseas to buy goods and withdraw cash that you pay for in full or in part at the end of the month.
fields.body:
Credit cards are a form of loan and provide one of the easiest ways of borrowing over a short period. You can use them in the UK or overseas to buy goods and withdraw cash that you pay for in full or in part at the end of the month.

Card issuers will stipulate a minimum monthly payment of around £5 or 5% of the outstanding balance on your card. But you can clear the whole balance if you have the resources. Most cards provide an upper spending limit. To begin with, this spending limit may be around £1000, but card issuers will increase it if you prove to be a reliable customer.

In the past, most cards charged the user an annual fee of between £10 and £15. Some still do, but with the invasion of credit card providers from the United States, card issuers are climbing over one another to offer the most attractive deal and annual fees are becoming less of a norm. The interest rate charged is also plummeting, with some card issuers offering 0% introductory rates on balance transfers for the first six months.

As such, borrowing on credit cards is becoming cheaper, but only if you have the resources and discipline to pay off the balance each month. Because they are so easy to use, it is tempting to spend, spend, spend on a credit card and not be able to meet the balance at the end of the month. The less you pay off, the more interest you are charged and, month by month, this interest will be compounded

You'll want to get the lowest interest rate you can but this is not as straightforward as it sounds. Card issuers don't just charge different rates, they calculate interest from different times and have different rates for purchases and cash withdrawals, as well as having low introductory offers. Which one is best for you will depend very much on your individual circumstances. See 'The best one for you' for more information.

Most credit cards have some form of insurance built into them. This usually covers things like damage to goods purchased with the cards or cancellation of a flight or holiday. However, this insurance usually has a myriad of conditions attached to it, so if you intend to rely on it, read the small print and make sure you understand the conditions. For example: a holiday may only be covered if the entire thing, plane tickets, hotels and so on and so forth were paid for with the card. And holiday accident cover may just pay out £100,000 in the event of death. A separate travel insurance policy would probably pay out closer to £1m in the event of death.

Affinity cards are just credit cards by another name. They operate like ordinary cards, but every time you use them the card issuer makes a donation to a particular cause, usually a charity. Organisations as diverse as football clubs and human rights organisations now have affinity cards and if you're committed to their cause, you might want to consider one. Just remember that these cards usually charge some of the highest rates in the market.

How do you get one?

By applying to a card issuer! Most high street banks and building societies offer them. But you can also get them from foreign banks and companies. Recent overseas entrants to the UK market include US banks Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and People's Bank.

Being given a card is entirely at the issuer's discretion. They will do a credit check on you and, if satisfied with your risk profile, will probably send you a card. But they might also decline. Some issuers, especially the new internet start-up banks, have very specific target markets for their products. If you don't meet their customer profile, they won't give you a card.

Most card issuers check with one of two credit reference agencies, Experian or Equifax. If you are declined and want to know why, you can check your credit history with either of the agencies for a small fee. See their websites for more information.

The best one for you

If you pay off your credit card bill in full every month - and at least half of all cardholders do - you want a card with an interest-free period. Those boasting low interest rates and annual charges often charge interest from the date of the transaction which means you will pay interest on your purchases and withdrawals even if you clear your balance in full each month. Instead, look for a card which only charges interest from the statement dates. If you're certain you'll pay the balance each month, the interest rate is irrelevant, but if you think you might need to carry some of the balance forwards every not and then, get a card with a lower rate. You might also want to look for a card with a loyalty scheme, such as air miles or cashback, or for one without an annual fee instead.

If you do not usually settle your account in full at the end of each month, opt for a card with a low interest rate on purchases. Cards with low introductory rates can save you money, but make sure it applies to balance transfers and that once the introductory period is over, it doesn't revert to an exorbitant rate. And try to get a card which starts charging interest from the your statement date or the date the bill is added to your account. Cards that charge from the day of the transaction are more expensive.

Card issuers usually charge a higher rate of interest on cash withdrawals and some charge a fee for each transaction as well. Typical charges are 1.5% of the withdrawals value, subject to a £1.50 minimum. If you use your card to get cash, look carefully at the rate of interest you're paying and think about transferring to a card with lower interest or no cash withdrawal charges.

Similarly, if you use your credit card overseas, check what kind of charges the issuer levies. Using a credit card is one of the easiest ways of getting at your money when in a foreign country, but almost all card providers charge something for overseas transactions and these will add up if you travel a lot. Typical charges are 2.5% to 2.75% of the transaction's value. They also convert overseas currency at their in-house exchange rate, which might not be the best on the market.

Compare credit cards

fields.headline: Ethical money
fields.trailText: Ethical money: it's a difficult subject to define. To the uninitiated it conjures up hackneyed images of aged hippies naively putting their money into cute, fluffy investments which will never produce good returns. But it's so much more than that.
fields.body:
Ethical money: it's a difficult subject to define. To the uninitiated it conjures up hackneyed images of aged hippies naively putting their money into cute, fluffy investments which will never produce good returns. But it's so much more than that.

For starters, ethics are relative. Something can only be ethical or unethical in the eye of the beholder. Some might say it's unethical to invest in companies developing birth control because abortion is immoral. Others would argue the reserve, that investing in birth control is morally imperative if we are to stop the bigger evils of unwanted pregnancy and sexually transmitted disease.

The arms control issue provides another case in point. Most agree it's wrong to sell arms to regimes such as Saddam Hussein's, regimes which almost certainly use them to oppress their country's people. But surely we need arms for defensive purposes? Others would argue that fighting people like Saddam Hussein is morally necessary and that we need arms to do this. In short, arms only become unethical when used by the wrong people for the wrong reasons. Ergo, companies producing weapons are only unethical if they sell them to people like Mr Hussein.

Arguably, the only thing which unites the ethical finance sector is an understanding that while money, per se, is not unethical or damaging, it can be spent and used in unethical or damaging ways. And, given that companies only exist because of us, because we buy products off them, we are in the perfect position to use our buying power wisely and not buy from companies we don't approve of.

In fact, the debate over what is or what is not ethical has become so subjective that many otherwise ethical funds now prefer the term socially responsible investment, or SRI.

It's never easy deciding what to do with your finances, and the ethical dimension can add another layer of confusion. First, you have to decide what kind of generic product to go for. For example, if you're buying a house should you go for a fixed, capped or discounted rate? Then you have to establish what your personal ethics are. And finally, you have to find a company which applies your branch of ethics to your chosen financial product.

This can be no mean feat. A huge variety of ethical financial products now exist, ranging from bank accounts to mortgages to investments. These products are all run by different companies with different definitions of what makes something ethical and, to further complicate matters, different ideas of how to convince companies to become more ethical.

Ethical money can be taken as far as you like. Some people just put part of their savings into an ethical ISA. Others will have their bank account, pension, mortgage, savings and investments in ethical products. They may also shop ethically on a day to day basis, buying goods produced under fair trade conditions or fruit and vegetables produced without chemicals and pesticides.

How far you go is up to you, just don't talk the talk if you won't walk the walk. Getting indignant about the burning of fossil fuels and global warming is easy; actually getting rid of your car, putting energy efficient systems in your home, investing in a renewable energy fund and, in short, using your personal finances as a tool for change, is altogether more difficult.

fields.headline: Why choose the ethical route?
fields.trailText: People choose the ethical route for a variety of reasons. Some may have religious convictions which bar them from supporting things like alcohol, gambling and pornography. Others will have political convictions. They may feel pornography debases women and decide they don't want to invest in the industry. Others feels strongly about international human rights and want to make sure their hard-earned cash is not being put to exploitative use in some far-flung corner of the world.
fields.body:
People choose the ethical route for a variety of reasons. Some may have religious convictions which bar them from supporting things like alcohol, gambling and pornography. Others will have political convictions. They may feel pornography debases women and decide they don't want to invest in the industry. Others feels strongly about international human rights and want to make sure their hard-earned cash is not being put to exploitative use in some far-flung corner of the world.

But whatever the reasons, all people who choose to use their money in an ethical way do so because they recognise the link between their personal spending and corporate activity. They understand that when they buy a product or invest their money they are sending tacit signals of support to the company. They know that if a product or activity does not make money for the company, it will stop the activity. As such, by not giving their money to the company they ensure that the offensive activity or product is not as profitable as it could otherwise be. They hope that enough people will feel and act in the same way and that the end result will be the company ditching the activity.

fields.headline: What is ethical money?
fields.trailText: Ethical money is money which is directed towards activities which have a positive social and/or ecological impact, and away from activities with a negative one.
fields.body:
Ethical money is money which is directed towards activities which have a positive social and/or ecological impact, and away from activities with a negative one.

The money can be directed into a huge number of financial products. Most people only think of ethical investment - buying stocks and shares in ethical companies. But banking, saving, retirement and mortgage products can also be bought ethically.

The Co-operative Bank and the Ecology Building Society are examples of companies which offer ethical banking products. The Co-op promises not to lend your savings to companies involved in a variety of activities, ranging from weapons manufacturing to child labour. And the Ecology will only give mortgages to people who want to buy energy efficient homes or build new homes with reclaimed or sustainable materials. It also looks favourably on people who want to renovate a derelict building - buildings traditional lenders will normally shy away from - because it believes it is more energy efficient to resuscitate an old house than build a new one.

webTitle: Flood risk homes to pay more for insurance

fields.headline: Flood risk homes to pay more for insurance
fields.trailText: It now looks certain that homes which have been flooded this year will see insurance premium increases or, in a worst case scenario, be unable to get insurance.
fields.body:
It now looks certain that homes which have been flooded this year will see insurance premium increases or, in a worst case scenario, be unable to get insurance.

With yet more flooding, this time hitting Devon, Cornwall and Herefordshire, insurers have admitted that if adequate flood defences are not built by the government, at-risk homes will have to pay more for their insurance or go without.

Malcolm Tarling, a spokesperson for the Association of British Insurers (ABI) today said: "Insurance is about protecting yourself from the uncertain, but it now seems certain that some homes will be flooded again."

Without insurance it will be impossible to get a mortgage, so some people are now sitting in houses which are effectively worthless because they couldn't sell them even if they wanted to. Those properties subject to premium hikes will still be able to get mortgages - provided the insurance increase does not become prohibitively expensive for the buyer - because the mortgage lender will be assured of getting the property's value back if it is flooded and becomes un-sellable.

Bernard Clarke from the Council of Mortgage Lenders said: "It is more difficult to borrow on a property whose long-term value is not secure. But for us, insurance is the lynchpin. If the buyer can get insurance, they will get a mortgage."

It is still too early to say how many homes will be denied insurance when they come to renew their premiums, or how many will see premium hikes.

The ABI says it will have to wait until all the flooding has stopped and all the claims have been paid to get an accurate figure of how much premiums will need to increase by.

At present, insurers are looking at a bill of between £400m and £500m since the end of October: but this is likely to go up as the floods don't look like they are going anywhere soon.

The government, whose responsibility it is to put up flood defences, is currently reviewing the situation. However, it is likely to be several years until adequate defences are in place.

Buildings and contents insurance are the main areas of cover affected by the flooding, although car insurance could also go up in the risky areas.

The Environment Agency says over 50% of people living in flood risk areas are still not aware that their property may be in danger. In a bid to rectify the situation it has published a new flood risk map on its website. Users key in their postcode and the map shows if and how your property is at risk from floods.

Useful links
Environment agency
Flood maps online
The met office
