fields.headline: Loans
fields.trailText: What are they?
fields.body:
What are they?

Taking out a personal loan is a way of borrowing money from a bank, building society or other financial service provider. You can usually borrow up to £15,000 for a period that can range from six months to 10 years. Generally speaking, the more you borrow, the lower the interest, but rates vary from around 8% to 20%, so you'll need to shop around. This is made more difficult by the fact that it is not easy to compare personal loan rates because different lenders calculate the total cost of the loan (known as the APR or annual percentage rate) in different ways.

Loans can be secured or unsecured. Secured loans are usually tied to your house - which means if you default, you may need to sell your house to repay the loan. Unsecured loans are not tied into anything, but if you don't make the repayments, the bank will blacklist you and you may find it difficult to take out other financial products, such as credit cards or a mortgage. Loans for specific items such as new cars are also available, often with lower interest rates. If you're taking out a loan for a car, tell your lender.

Most loans are re-paid by monthly instalments and the repayment period will be agreed before you get the money. This is usually a fixed period and you will have to pay a redemption penalty - an example being two months interest - if you want to pay it off sooner. The longer the repayment period, the more interest you will be paying, so go for the shortest one you can manage. Flexible loans, which let you borrow and pay back at will, are becoming more common, but the interest rate charged is often significantly higher.

Why take one out?

Most people take out loans because they need money for things like school fees, new cars and home renovations. Others want to consolidate existing debts and pay a lower interest rate.

Whatever the reason, people take them out because they need a cash lump sum that they can pay back over a period of months or years.

If you're looking for emergency cash to tide you over, overdrafts or credit card borrowing will probably end up cheaper because you are not tied in to the loan's repayment period.

The right one for me

First decide how much you want to borrow and for how long. Almost all lenders provide loans for up to five years, but if you want a longer repayment period you may find your choice more limited. The longest loans tend to be secured ones.

Next you should get a range of quotes. Check if the quoted is stand-alone or if it includes things like loan insurance - then pick the cheapest rate. If there's a chance you'll be able to repay the loan early and save on the interest, look for a loan without any early redemption penalties.

Lenders will push hard for you to take out the insurance, so think carefully about whether you need it or not. If you're in any doubt about being able to meet the repayments, insurance will put your mind at rest. Unfortunately it will also make the loan more expensive. A good alternative to loan insurance is accident, sickness and unemployment insurance. This will protect your overall income, including the loan, if you can't work.

And finally: before signing on the dotted line, double-check the terms and conditions. Are you clear about what the monthly repayments will be? Are you aware of any restrictions and penalties?

Repayment problems

If you find you can't meet the repayments, contact your lender straightaway. Banks and building societies are usually willing to help and might freeze the loan for a while or extend the repayment period. Obviously, their ultimate aim is to get their money back, so if the loan is secured on your house or another asset, you may have to sell up to pay back the loan. In a worst case scenario, the lender could sue to recover the debt and, if it wins, force you to sell something like your house to pay back the loan.

fields.headline: How is it done?
fields.trailText: With standard banking products - current accounts, savings accounts and mortgages - ethical investments are made simply by the bank refusing to lend money to negative activities.
fields.body:
With standard banking products - current accounts, savings accounts and mortgages - ethical investments are made simply by the bank refusing to lend money to negative activities.

It's more complicated with ethical investment products. Mainstream funds invest purely on a company's financial performance. Ethical funds are also concerned with financial performance, but they also have to consider the company's social and environmental record, which adds another layer to the process of researching and selecting companies for investment. On top of this, each investment fund may take a different approach to ethical investment. Each one may have different definitions of what is ethical and different ideas about how to convince offending companies to change their ways.

Generally speaking there are five main approaches to ethical investment:

Negative screening

A company's activities are compared against a list of negative practices. If they are involved in too many of these negative practices, they will not be considered acceptable candidates for ethical investment.

Industries that are usually subject to negative screening include the oil industry, the arms industry, the logging and mining industries, and the pornography industry. Negative practices would include poor employment conditions, and poor health and safety and pollution records.

Funds which employ negative screening usually rely on the ethical investment research service (Eiris) to provide them with a list of which companies to avoid.

The so-called "dark green" funds typically employ negative screening. As such, many people think of them as the greenest investments in the market. Certainly they are the least likely to have undesirable companies in their portfolio, but it is questionable whether this approach has much effect beyond limiting the number of companies these funds can invest in. Some argue that if you are going to avoid a company you should inform its managers of your reasons so that it has the option of changing its policies.

There is also an argument that the dark green approach misses out on periods of high growth in certain industries, because its strict investment criteria causes it to rule out entire industries.

Positive screening

A company's activities are compared against a list of positive practices. If they meet enough of them they will be considered candidates for investment by the fund.

Industries typically subject to positive screening include waste management, environmental technology, public transport, education, telecommunications and renewable energy. Positive practices would include good working conditions, energy efficient buildings and corporate recycling policies.

As with negative screening, funds which positively screen usually rely on Eiris to provide them with a list of companies with a good social and environmental record.

Positive screeners are referred to generically as light green funds because they might hold some less than perfect companies. Whether this actually makes them less effective in achieving the aims of ethical investors is debatable. Some would say they are more effective than the dark green funds because they give companies an incentive to change their ways.

Thematic investment

This involves picking companies which represent industries of the future. This will include industries such as renewable energy, health care and public transport, which will play an important role in a more environmentally sustainable future. Because of their focus on emerging industries, thematic funds tend to have a higher percentage of their portfolios in smaller companies.

Best of sector

Using the motto "invest in the best, encourage the rest", best of sector funds employ something of a carrot and stick approach. A case in point is the oil industry. Because its mainstay is burning fossil fuels it's very difficult for ethical funds to invest in the oil industry. However, while the industry as a whole is bad, certain companies within it will be better than others. They all burn fossil fuels, but some have progressive employment practices and undertake extensive research into renewable energy.

The company doing the most to improve its activities will be considered a "best of sector company", and some ethical funds will invest in it, sending a clear signal to its competitors. For example, the NPI Global Fund invests in BP Amoco (check) because within the oil industry it is making the most effort to address climate change. The idea is that other oil companies will want investment from the ethical funds and will follow BP's example. The best of sector approach also gives ethical funds the chance to invest in some of the larger, older multinationals

Engagement

This involves meeting with company management, explaining the fund's investment objectives and, therefore, why it does or does not invest in the company. Engaging with the management gives fund managers an opportunity to bring up any specific concerns which may be preventing the fund from investing in the company.

If already shareholders in the company, the fund managers, as part-owners, have more power to sway the management. They can also use their voting rights to steer the company's policies and direction, and table shareholder resolutions at annual meetings. One of the engagement approach's biggest success story's was getting BP Amoco to drop its plans to explore in the Arctic after a shareholder resolutions, tabled by , got 11% of the voted. (CHECK) The approach is popular in the US where shareholding is widespread.
